
Porschephiles #735                         Mon May 2 02:17:11 CDT 1994
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 94 21:22 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: SC RS and Cool Carbons

>Is there any problem with using Cool Carbon's with cross-drilled
>rotors.  My S came with cross drilled rotors all around....I am a
>little worried about the extra heat causing cracking.

No, there's no problem.  However, with drilled rotors there is always,
as far as I know, cracking.  You have to keep your eye on the cracks
and if/when they become severe enough, replace the rotors.  I don't
think there is any nicely quantifiable rule for "severe enough."

Needless to say, when you get into doing track events or racing with
non-original equipment, and especially in the brake department, you
really have to monitor the condition of same more carefully.  In my
own case, temperature paints showed me last year that I had temps of
over 1040F at the work face of my Cool Carbon pads, and at the
outside of my rotors.  This temperature is, I believe, on the edge
at which cast iron starts to degrade more rapidly.

If you don't have a Cool Brake kit on the car, now's the time.

In short, I recommend monitoring the cracks and periodically checking
your rotors for minimum depth.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 30 Apr 1994 21:10:57 -0500
From: schless@iastate.edu
Subject: 951 trouble


Howdy Beran

I believe I know EXACTLY what your problem is.

I had the same EXACT problem when i first got my 951
and it had hapened previously.

the reason it shuts down at about 5500 rpm is excess
boost.  The DME shuts the injectors down at 2bar or so.

The problem is in the vacuum/pressure lines to
and from the 'frequency valve' and the wastegate.

In my case the 'frequency valve' had a broken tube
which I repaired with brass tubing.  

the freq valve controls the wastegate, and is located
under the intake manifold toward back of engine,.
it has three hoses attatched, one is to the wastegate.

most likely the problem that freq valve has cracked or broken
nipple.  check carefully and repair with a brass thinwall
tube.  check all hossses for quality ect... 
Check electrical funct8ion of freq valve as well

Any question call or e-mail
 p c schlesselman
1.515.278.9627


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 30 Apr 94 21:47 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 89 951 questions (new owner)

Jeff,

>chipping:

The RaceWare fasteners from Randy Hubbard do seem to be the right
stuff.  We seem to have cured a lift-off problem in a friend's race
car with them.  However, keep one thing in mind.  As I opined recently,
the head gasket is the weak link in the system for a reason: it is
a hell of a lot cheaper and easier to replace than the other stuff
which would break were it not for a "soft" head gasket.  If the
aftermarket chips in your car are creating unreasonable pressure in
combustion, something's gotta give.  Nathan suggested yesterday that
the Autothority chips have a detonation problem at 5400 RPM; might
be worth a little investigation.

>tires:

I've seen folks run 245x16's up front.  The only car I've seen with
275's at the back was the Heimrath 968 car running in a support race
before the Montreal GP last year.  The wrench I chatted with was
rather tight-lipped and I dunno what they did to get them to fit.

Avoid 17" rims unless you are real sure that you can get sticky rubber
to fit.  Very little performance advantage, esp. given the sidewalls
on current tires like Comp T/A R1 and A008RSII.

>exhaust:

Never heard this said about the cat.  Which article was it?

>brakes:

Live with the squeal, or invest in some backing plates for the pads.
I think you can get them from Porsche, and VCI definitely sells them.

>turbo:

I think the 951's cool-down pump works fine as is.  If you'd like to
be really nice to the whole car, just let it idle for a few minutes.
I have an oil temp sender, and I let my car idle until the oil temp
drops to 210F.

>cooling:

The factory did change the radiator fan switch in production in Feb '88,
if memory serves.  Unless your car is overheating in traffic, there is
no reason to change the fan switch.  Remember that when you're moving,
the fans do zip to cool the car.  In fact, they really just get in the
way.  At the same time, you want to avoid overcooling the car, which
could happen in street driving with a fan switch which came on too
soon.  Oil temp is ideal in the 180-210F range.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 30 Apr 1994 21:24:41 -0500
From: schless@iastate.edu
Subject: 951


Howdy 

It should not be necessary to take manual control of the turbo
water pump as it thermostatically controlled, as well as running
for a few seconds at shutdown.  The thermostat sendor and wire
are just to the left of the throttle positon sensor.  
If you remove the wire to the sendor and touch it to ground the
pump should come on for about 15 sec. (good test occacsionally)

A better idea in hot climates is to install a manual switch
to turn the radiator fans on.  I did this in Phoenix
it came in very usefull on 120F days when stuck in trafic
jams, or just when the car runs rather hot.  Such as at 
autocrosses, or when car sits and idiles.

good luck

p c schlesselmann

'86 951

Date: Sun, 01 May 94 09:10:10 EDT
From: jonlowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 89 951 questions (new owner)

Jeff,

jn>  Currently we are running stock tires and rims. I would like 
jn>           to purchase another set of rims for track use, but would
jn> like 
jn>           to know if I can go to a larger tire size and what those
jn> sizes 
jn>           would be. Can I purchase 17" rims for this car? Is 245
jn> front 
jn>           and 275 rear to large for this particular make?

Stay with the 16 inch rims. They are easier to get tires for (at least at
present) for track use.  You can fit 245/45R16's all around or even 255/50s
on the rear, but your this changes your effective final gear ration, slowing
acceleration.

jn> In the recent issue of Excellence Magazine there was a article 
jn>           about exhaust systems on turbo cars and that if you track
jn> them 
jn>           its not a bad idea to replace the catalytic converter
jn> with a 
jn>           straight pipe during tracktime. The logic was that you
jn> save 
jn>           burning up the catalytic converter do to extremely high
jn> temps 
jn>           during track use. Any comments on this. Considering the
jn> cost 
jn>           of a new catalytic converter this sounds like good
jn> advice.

Gut your current catalyst.  It is cheaper and just as effective, unless you
get one of the Turbo Cup exhaust systems which are unmuffled and can't be
used on the street.  You have to cut the catalyst off to gut it, then mig
weld it back on.

jn> excessive break squeal, very annoying. Any ideas on how 
jn>           to quit these babies down.

You can try one of the spread on compounds on the back of the pads, but in my
experience, one lap at the track will cook the stuff enough so that it does
not work any longer.  Are you sure you have the factory silencing pieces on
your calipers? They go between the pistons and the pads. Look at the parts
microfiche at a dealer to see what the parts look like.

jn> One of the nice features about this car is it has a kind of turbo 
jn>           cooling system that comes on when the car is shutdown
jn> hot. I 
jn>           was wondering if there is any kits out there to gain
jn> control of 
jn>           this system to force it to run longer, maybe a override
jn> switch or 
jn>           timer.

You don't need anything else.  When the car is shut off, the coolant pum runs
for 20-25 secs., then is thermostatically controlled to cycle on and off
after that until the turbo is cooled down sufficiently.  The turbo is cooled
by  antifreeze in your cooling system.

Jon Lowe

Date: Sun, 1 May 94 12:46:44 -0400
From: ulrich@canberra.whoi.edu (Nathan Ulrich)
Subject: Re: 89 951 questions (new owner)

Jon Milledge Engineering
239 Parsonage Street
Marshfield, MA  02050
(617) 834-3932 Voice
(617) 834-3935 Fax

Builds all types of racing and high-performance street engines, with most  
work involving 944 Turbo engines, but also including 911, 944 2-valve,  
944/968 4-valve, 944 Turbo 2 and 4-valve up to 3.0 liter displacement, as  
well as Formula Ford, S2000, FF2000, Cosworth BDA, Lotus Twincam, and  
American stock-block V8s.  Also supplies chip kits for 944 Turbos, EFI  
systems, street and race camshafts for above-mentioned engines,  
turbochargers, racing clutch conversions, big brake kits, larger  
intercoolers, Quaife differentials, 375 hp and 417 hp conversion kits for  
944 Turbos.  Has engine dynanometer for custom development or test (up to  
1000 hp).  Most recent major 944 Turbo engine project produced over 500 hp  
at 1.45 bar boost from a 2.8 liter engine (real dyno numbers, not the  
exaggerated claims you see floating around).

Jon is a good friend, and does all our engine work.  He's been involved in  
racing for over 30 years, winning something like 80 races out of 130  
starts, in everything from Formula 5000 to Showroom Stock.  He's most  
known to Porsche fans as winner of the Firestone Firehawk endurance  
championship in 1985, driving a Porsche 944.  He placed sixth in the  
worldwide Porsche Cup standings that year.

Our friendship aside, he's one of the few people involved in aftermarket  
work whose claims are backed by solid analytical knowledge (his horsepower  
numbers don't contradict any laws of thermodynamics :-) and thoroughly  
tested on an engine dyno.  If he doesn't know the answer to a question,  
he's not afraid to admit it.  I could not recommend him more highly.

His chip kits for the 951 are $300, produce 265 hp with the non-S turbo  
and 290 hp with the S turbo (real numbers!), and don't blow head gaskets.

Nathan
ulrich@canberra.whoi.edu

Date: Sun, 1 May 94 15:09:17 -0500
From: pfile (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Message

May 1994

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

Well, 'tta.com' got moved OK, and will actually be more accessible in its new
home, having more-or-less direct connectivity to both the main CIX router in
San Jose and locally to Sesquinet and the NSFnet backbone... If you understand 
that, then you'll appreciate it; otherwise don't worry about it...

We had a minor flame-war that started with a mailer that hung and kept sending
messages over and over and over again to the list. So, a few points here, and
*YOU'D FLIPPIN' WELL BETTER READ THIS!!!!!*

1) I don't need individual subscribers to tell me this is happening -- believe
   me, I can tell already.

2) Neither I nor anyone else needs running commentary from other subscribers
   saying "stop already" or whatever. That only adds to the number of junk 
   messages out there.

3) Personal attacks won't be tolerated. If someone really does something out
   of line, *I'LL* sanction them. 

   These are the rules. Trespassers will be violated. Survivors will be
   prosecuted.


COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 7 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.


CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at n_weissenberger@harvard.edu.   You can ask her for info or 
get her to send you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year and cheap at twice the 
price. (Vic Skirmants' racing column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds published the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 or (908) 287-8070..

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
President,                                                    NetSmiths, Ltd.
2025 Lincoln Highway     Edison     NJ     08817
Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com       voice: (713) 661-2084 fax: (713) 661-0633
Edison:  e-mail: stan@netsmiths.com voice: (908) 287-8070 fax: (908) 287-3883
I live in Houston TX and work in Edison NJ. Don't bitch about *YOUR* commute.

'81 Euro 911SC Targa	(daily driver when I'm where it is...)
'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
'64 356 SC  		(OK, so I fell in love again...)

Date: Sun, 1 May 94 19:01:54 -0400
From: kennedy@admin.njit.edu (William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648)
Subject: 911T Zeniths

Thanks to the several 'philers who responded regarding my subject carburetors.
Symptom was lumpy idle, poor transition to higher rpms, then running ok above
2500 rpm or so.Also float level gauge just overflowed when I tried to use it,
leading me to question my understanding of how to use it -- could the car 
really be drivable with more than one stuck float valve?

Yes!  I opened the carbs up as far as the float bowls and found three of the
four floats stuck to the bottoms of their respective bowls.  So four of the
six cylinders were getting no idle metering at all, and the car was still
drivable.  Back together, float levels set (I DID know how, after all), and
although highway performance is not perceptibly different, around town it's
like a different car.  Transition from idle to cruise is positively Japanese.

And now maybe I'll get more than 14mpg.  (Engine's in a Vanago, so I don't
expect miracles.)  The change was so significant that I don't really mind that
the $80 or so I spent for new float valves was probably wasted -- I put the
new ones in, but three of the old ones haven't seen a float in at least a
few hundred miles, so they haven't been working real hard.

Be of good cheer, amateurs.  Sometimes we actually find problems and solve
them.  
B.

Date: Sun,  1 May 94 21:37:50 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 88 951 problem (help!)

Beran, welcome to the fold!  I'll be very brief in my answers, since I 
don't have much time here!

> My 951 has been recently purchased for me and mine as a daily driver
> and weekend warrior. It seems to be real fast, more than normal.
> I have never driven another 944 turbo but this porsche seems as fast as
> or faster than my 87 930?? is that possible?
> My mechanic says it's not stock and that it is faster than normal but 
has said
> he doesnt think anything on the inside was changed..ie. cam but that maybe
> the chips or other things were done.
Well, this is a very fast car, but what do you consider "normal"?  A 
chipped 951 can approach or virtually match a stock 87 930 in 
acceleration.  Can you inquire about chips from the previous owner?  If 
not, just examine the KLR & DME boxes under the passenger's feet.

> The Problem:
> Under hard acceleration (foot to floor) in third gear at about 5,500 rpm
> the motor cuts out. It feels like the fuel is being shut down or that
> it's not getting any fuel
[...]

> Theory:
> Could the fuel pump be bad?
No, very unlikely.

> Could the fuel pump not be able to handle the extra boost or what ever
> the previous owner did to make it faster than stock (unconfirmed still)
No, absolutely not the problem.

> Already tried:
> My mechanic said he disconnected (i think) the oxygen sensor and it had alot
> less power but didnt seem to have the cut out problem.
Also not the problem unless you have a bad sensor or mixture problems.

Possibly bad gas or knock sensor shutting off the boost, loose intake 
air line or vacuum-type leak, boost system problem, bad spark plug or 
wire or coil.  Also may be bad sensor on the flywheel causing premature 
rev-limit (I think this is unlikely, as it would mess up the whole fuel 
injection).  Could also be really bad fuel mixture.  Depends on exactly 
what is happening, and other related symptoms: exhaust color, on/off 
characteristics, boost level, engine temp., etc.

> Natick, MA
Who's your mechanic?  There are a few good ones around you (I'm next 
door in Ashland).

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 1 May 1994 18:47:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: ero@netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: 930 survey results

I received 4 responses, plus my own info. Thanks to all.
Yr.: 1-76, 3-78, 1-86
owned how long: average 4 yrs. (18 mo. to 8 yrs)
average mi. 78,000 mi.
mi. p/yr.: not enough info.
daily driver/pleasure: all pleasure (I've been using mine as a daily 
driver for the past 3 mo. while my truck is being painted.
repairs: most seem to be non-turbo related, oil leaks, chain tensioners,ect.
buy another: No-2, Yes-2(I'm in the yes), no comment-1
Some observations: While I was looking I found 2 basic types of turbos, 
really beat and normal wear and tear. My mechanic informed my that 
disconnecting the speedo was not uncommon, and a good mechanic should be 
able to tell the milage of the car by the motor. I also found that some 
people just drove the car and did little if any maintainence (as in 
mine)and some were meticulous. My goal was to find one in good condition, 
not perfect, because I wanted to be able to drive it anywhere and park it 
and not worry about door dings ect. My main concern was the drivetrain.If 
yours serious about buying one be willing to spend a few hundred bucks 
and have it thoroughly checked out. Also, as with any Porsche, you should 
buy the newest one you can afford. I've decided to keep mine for a few 
more years and then buy a newer one. I've owned the car for 9 mo. and 
have spend $4200, which averages out to $461 per mo. on repairs, with a 
major service. Since I still need to deal with the trans, and possible 
turbo rebuild I see my per mo. average about the same for the next year. 
I pay $1131 per yr for insurance thru A.A.A. On a side note a car dealer 
sold a 79 730 w/5,000 mi. for $30,000. He said the car was perfect. The 
owner drove it for awhile and discovered he had broken head studs. Last I 
heard he was looking at about $5000 in repairs, so ya never know.

Date: Sun, 1 May 1994 23:27:49 -0700
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: {




Subj:  Re: Drag Force & Distributors

Date:  94-05-01 03:01:29 est

From: MAESTRO132@aol.com

TO:     porschephiles@tta.





     Guys:





         Thanks to all the porschephiles who reported their

Time-to-Coast in neutral from 65 to 55, on a deserted,

straight, level, windless road. From this information (and

the weight of your car+yourself+any passengers), the Maestro

will estimate your Drag Force at 60 MPH and compare it with

Road & Track's.



         When there's enough Drag Force Data on the various

models, the Maestro will present the results.



         And he certainly understands ifin you, like others,

wish to report  YOUR Time To Coast in neutral from 65 MPH to

55 MPH via private E-Mail to avoid being unjustly flamed.



         Oh- and the Maestro recently purchased a Sun

Distributor Tester (many thanks to Larry's Liverwurst

Laboratories, whose initials may or may not mean anything),

and has spent many happy hours testing Porsche 356/912

Distributors, as well as the beloved .050, and various VW's

(like the .009, .010 and .019). Even tested a few '68/69

912's with the vacuum retard. (There's a working vacuum pump

with the Sun, so vacuum retards can be tested too!)



         Data obtained from some 100 Original & Replacement

Distributors includes the maximum mechanical advance for

each type, and  ifin #3 cylinder is retarded and if so, how

much.



         Included too are the Distributor Diseases- no

advance, too much advance, jerky/sticky advance, and the

observed frequency.



         Not to mention some 10 Distributors whose points

could not fire as they were grounded for various reasons. In

some cases, the Engine (and maybe the CAR) was sold because

it just wouldn't run after the tune-up was done. Find out

why you don't want to use cardboard with aluminized mylar

for a points "insulator".



         Since the Maestro has been criticized for long

postings, he is hesitant to post the results here. But he'll

be happy to send you the data via E-mail if you desire and

if enough people express enough Desire,  he'll post the info

here.



          Just let him know.



          And:

 

          Keep The 356/912 Faith!!!



          The Maestro



    :p

restoring involve *only* floor-pan, longitudinal, and battery_floor renewal. 
Well,...some small patching here and there is tolerable....

Hopefully the car is 100% complete,(seller say so) and all or most parts are 
restorable. If I remeber right the car also has a sunroof, I'll check in my

After the tragic death of Ronald Ratzberger (saturday), Formula 1 was 
claiming its first death victim in several years. Because of that (and the 
fact F1 isn't my main interest) I decided not to watch the Live-coverage 
from Imola. In a way I wish I had, the horrible crash which took Senna's

Senna was a great personality, true racer and sportsman, and a joy to watch! 
I will miss him, and F1 won't be the same!

with ABS and active suspension to practice in, and the Ferrari 186 to race 
with. Wastegate disconnected..............!!! No barriers, just concrete.

be banned, i think Estoril and Hungaroring should be 'the standard' to 
compare with when it come to 'track-safety'.

world.....................

Date: Mon, 02 May 1994 13:04:04 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Welding and leading a 356


>Remember when using lead, you must get ALL the rust off first. Sandblast or
>use muriatic acid (a form of hydrochloric acid). Then you must get all the
>acid off, using something like DuPont metal prep. Don't get acid into any
>seams, you'll never get it out and it will be as bad as the rust you are
>trying to get rid of.
> 
>Pete

Thanks for the advices, I'll be occupied with removal of paint and bondo the 
next week(s) and would like some feedback whether one should use paint 
remover or exenter-grinder, or/and wire brush in some areas. In some areas 
the car has up to 5mm of bondo, but no rust underneath, it seem the previous 
restorer rather put on bondo than try to hammer out and straighten panels. 
Crazy,...eh? After I get to bare metal I'll zink spray the car.
 I will wait with the seam welding etc until I've stripped the outer shell, 
it'll be nice to do something else than cutting, shaping, welding and 
grinding for a while.

cheers,
trond

My wife painted my wheel center caps for me - used Testor model paints, like

little off.  After two years they still look good, but there's some nicks in
places.

Date: Mon,  2 May 94 08:24:26 CDT
From: Steve=Putnam%Prod=Qual%Mfg=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: RE: Hand Painting Center Caps


>Date: Fri, 29 Apr 1994 10:28:17 +0500
>From: Barry Chapin 617-258-2809 <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
>Subject: Hand Painting Center Caps

Barry,

<snip>
>And I want to paint them myself.  Is this hard to do?
   I got the idea from a 951 next to me at a autox last year.  It looked
   like an acceptable challange for a scale modeller like me.   

>What type of paint and brushes should I use?  
   My suggestion is paint pens from hobby store, WalMart, etc. No cleanup
   and easy to use.

>What color is the yellow/gold background (Yellow or gold?)  
   I went with the gold since that is what the hood is and the wheel emblems
   that I have seen.   

>Has anyone done this themselves?  Do you think the standard new cap 
>would need any preparation (primer, etc).
   A good cleaning with a degreaser,
   Lay down the gold layer, then the gloss black, then red,
   letting each coat dry well.
   Spray gloss clearcote (hobbystore etc.) over it with a 
   mask/templete to only spray the emblem area.

   Will last several months depending on washing habits/skills.

>Why do I want to do this you may ask?  Well...
<snip>
>And they want $62.95 each, so I want to make my own.
   Gee, considering the number of emblems that get ripped off, I'll 
   keep painting mine.


Regards,  Steve

Internet- Steve=Putnam%Prod=Qual%Mfg=Hou@bangate.compaq.com   
Lone Star Region PCA
1986 928S  Meteor Metallic

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 08:32:33 -0500
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: dynamat of any value?

>From: "Andrew J. Toth" <TOTHAND@hsdwl.utc.com>
>Subject: Re: dynamat of any value?
>| 
>| has anyone used dynamat sound deadening? I was thinking of taking
>| some of the edge off the engine noise to add to comfort for long
>| highway trips  by installing dynamat under
>| the back deck and behind the rear seat on my early 911.  Any other
>| suggestions?
>| 
>| Jim
>| jfuerstenberg@dcmdc.dla.mil

  Jim, Andrew, and gang;
 I cant tell yet of the material's efficiency to deaden sound, but i can
tell you the stuff is of value  -like $35 a box  of six puny sheets!!
 Seriously though, each sheet is about 10"X24" , adhesive backed, maybe
a hair over a 1/16" thick and made out of the scrapings off the bottom
of the refinery's cracking tower...asphalt with maybe some rubber?

  Getting this stuff off a car's floorboard is the PITS..
  *But* it does seem to absorb some vibration and most importantly, protect
the body metal underneath, *provided* it was applied well, and a good
seal between the metal and the sheeting is made.
  For those of you with galvanized sheet constructed cars this is less of
a problem, but for Porschemobiles of pre-76 vintage...beware because gaps
and voids can trap moisture and encourage rust.  This would imply clean
surfaces, and one of those cute roller tools and heat guns the factory 
manual mentions for best application.
  
  As far as alternatives, i vote to stay with what the oem folks use and 
that is the asphaltic pads in direct contact with metal, after that you've
got little choice in the carpet pad/carpet or moisture barrier/fiber (door).
  I have first-hand results of someone using foam carpet pad...that is
a sponge waiting for rust, just add water.  Now that car's floorpan is
2/3 rust because the planet is 2/3 water!  And since they were very intent
on using something thick behind something that already fit tight..screws
werent long enough, and the car's interior looked overstuffed because it
was.  Blech!
  I'm speaking of a 76 914, but perhaps 9XX's are similar.
  Inside the car there were many places that could benefit from the 
dynamat (or Wurth's mat) application.  Most notably, the inner wheel house
at the footwell, and inside the front trunk, and inside the doors.  The
factory does apply a dusting of material in the doors, but not much.
  I believe adding some to the doors outer skin (on the inside) would
give the biggest gain (or attenuation, in this case), and be most
unobtrusive.  
  Another product that could be used for this sort of thing, and be much
more flexible in application, would be the high-build undercoatings that
come in spraycan form.  The stuff i have is rubberized and applies 
nicely..but the fumes will curl your eyebrows..beware!
  Hope this was of use.

  -kyle
  <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.ncr.com>
  73,76 914 2.0
  85 IROC Z-28   ...with new T-Top seals!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 09:39:47 -0400
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: 911 Clutch change experiences

I had fun Saturday replacing the flywheel seal and clutch on my '73 911S.  It
was leaking 1-2 quarts of oil between fillups, and leaving a trail of oil
drops down the road.  You could rev up the engine using the hand throttle and
see oil dripping from the flywheel area at the rate of 1-2 drops per second ;-).

Anyways, it was easier than applying the same procedure to a 914 in that you
didn't have to jack the car 2.5 feet in the air to get then engine out - 3 or 4
inches sufficed once the 911's license plate panel was removed.  The only hitch
to getting the engine out is the damn air conditioner compressor bracket which
interfered with the right rear engine mount - you had to jockey the engine over
to get the bracket to clear.  Almost got out the Mikita grinder to take the
corner off of the stupid thing.

Stupid mechanic tricks uncovered: 1) one of the flywheel bolts was shorter than
the other five, unbalancing the flywheel.  2) The transmission mount bolts came
out with the threads stripped, mainly because they had standard (not metric)
threads.  Had to really scrounge around town to find some replacement 12mm
bolts...

Stupid parts supplier tricks: somehow I ended up getting the wrong clutch disk.
Of course I found this out after 15 minutes of jockeying the 100 pound
transmission around trying to get it to mate with the engine.  Turns out in
70-71 they used an almost identical clutch disk, but with a different spline
to fit the 901 transmission - that's the disk I got.

Stupid engineering tricks: installing the transmission seal (not my main
mission, but since I had the chance...) required special Porsche tool #xyz for
my '73 915 transmission.  This transmission is different from the later
models in that the throwout bearing guide tube is _cast_ into the case instead
of having two mounting screws.  Replacing the seal took sort of a cylindrical
corkscrew-theory device which pulled the old seal, and a special installation
tube so you wouldn't knock the new seal back into the differential.
Fortunately my local mechanic had one of these, so all that stood between me
and a new input shaft seal was a six-pack of cheap beer.

For the uninitiated: you don't need any special spacers or such stuff to
separate the engine and transmission.  They just pull apart - although its
easier if you remove the clutch fork lever arm from the bottom of the
transmission since it hits the engine at the end of its play.  When you
put them back together, you have to guide the fork into the throwout bearing.

Now the car runs great and leaks nary a drop of oil.  Now if I can just get
that speedometer cable to screw onto the transmission...;-).

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe

------------------------------

Date: 02 May 94 09:22:12 EDT
From: Lance Flynn <71137.1777@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: ! RE: 89 951 questions (new owner)

  Jeff,
	Congrats on you new car. The 951S is one you'll be very happy with 
no matter what changes you do (or do not) make. Following is my two cents 
worth on your questions:
	Chipping - The head gasket on the 951 is definitely not its 
strongest point. Otherwise why would the factory be on its third (or is it 
more already) revision for this part? Increasing the boost, which is really 
how these aftermarket guys get more power out of these things) puts more 
load on the head gasket. There's no getting around this point. Different 
suppliers have created different mapping in the engine control module and 
some may have better parameters for minimizing the potential for blowing a 
head gasket than others. Maybe Jon Milledge has THE ANSWER. Other postings 
have listed how to contact him.
But why do you want to chip the car anyway? 162mph too slow for you? Losing 
drag races to Corvettes? Want to cheat in PCA Club Racing? Believe me, your 
car is pretty damn fast just the way it is. When you can go 10 or 11 tenths 
lap after lap on a variey of tracks, then go for more power.

	Tires - I tried unsuccessfully to find 17" wheels that would fit 
the 951S last winter, but there may be some. A good track set up is 8"x16" 
in front and 9"x16" in the back. The car understeers too much with the 7" 
rims that come with the car. If you want to avoid wheel spacers you need a 
53mm offset on the 8" fronts and somewhere between 57 and 60 mm on the 9" 
rears. 245-45s fit very nicely on these sizes. If you use your 17" idea 
with 245s in front and 275s in the rear, I think you'll get back to an 
understeering situation.  Besides even if you do chip your car up to 290hp 
I don't think you'll need more rubber on the back than the 245s give you.

Exhaust - I think taking out the converter for a little better flow through 
the whole system (put in a K&N air filter to help the flow on the inlet 
side) makes sense, although I don't think it hurts the converter to use it 
on the track. The Porsche part that replaces the converter is 
#951.111.093.05. I guarantee that the aftermarket replacements don't have 
the heavy gauge stainless steel or the perfect fit of this part. 
Unfortunately, you can probably only get it thru Andial which means $$$.

	Brakes - One of the best parts of the car. Squealing is generally a 
function of the pads you're using. My experience is no squeals from the 
street pads that Porsche supplies with the car. For track pads Cool Carbons 
don't seem to squeal for me, but Performance Friction do. Pads don't last 
long (front pads anyway) if you track the car, so you'll be able to try 
different brands and compounds till you find one you like.

	Turbo - Keep in mind that what keeps pumping through the turbo when 
you switch off the ignition is only coolant - not oil. Even the owners 
manual recommends running the the engine at "increased idle" (can anybody 
figure ouwhat that means) for a couple of minutes after "hard or extended 
driving". I'd be more concerned about doing this than extending the time 
coolant circulates through the turbo.

	Cooling - Can't comment on having the fans come on at a lower temp. 
I've never changed my sensor and I've never had any coolant temp probs. 
This sensor may just be a solution to a problem that doesn't exist.

I hope this helps you out. Good luck.

Lance Flynn '89 951

Date: 02 May 94 14:18:58 EDT
From: Hubert Lai <70363.1332@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Wire on 944 Hatch

While cleaning out the interior of my 1983 944, I noticed a broken wire which
has me completely mystified.  The wire is on the right side of the car and leads
from a point near where the hatch support strut is mounted to the car to a
sliding clip which is mounted to the shaft of the support strut.  This wire is
broken, and I will be fixing it soon.  I do not know, however, how long the wire
has been broken.  I suspect it has been a long time.  Just from looking at the
wire, I would have assumed it had something to do with the rear window defogger.
However, even with the wire broken, the defogger functions perfectly.  I can't
find anything about it in Haynes.

Any ideas?

<=- Hubert

Date: Mon, 2 May 1994 13:38:37 -0400
From: weltyc@cs.rpi.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: What does SC stand for?


This is a great excuse for me to forward out to you mail-hungry
porschephiles my editor's column for the end of `93.  As usual, you
may use this for your own newsletter if you have one.  I can also, at
no extra charge, configure my mailer to send this out 20 times, since
it's been almost a week since anyone has sent me nasty email.

What follows is a recent interview I did with Santa Claus:

CW: To begin with, whats with the name? "Santa Claus" sounds Spanish,
but I happen to know you are German.  

SC: Ho ho ho. Don't feel bad, many people are confused by my name. I
am actually Saint Nicholas, and I am from a region of western Turkey
called Lycia. I became famous during the height of the Roman Empire. I
was known for my generosity, and most particularly for saving young
girls from lives of prostitution. My fame spread quickly through the
Empire (which is most of modern day Europe) when I was canonized, and
was made the patron saint of children.

CW: But I thought you were German.

SC: Ho ho ho. Many Americans associate me with Germanic cultures
because I was brought into this country by the Dutch, in whose
language my name is pronounced, "Sint Niklaas". The dutch language has
a very rhythmic quality, and the English speaking Americans thought
they were hearing "Santa Claus." That is where my name comes from in
your country.

CW: If I understand you correctly, you're trying to tell me you're not
German.

SC: Not in the least, no ho ho. In fact, my association with Christmas
is equally accidental. Saint Nicholas Day is actually December 6th,
and the tradition on that day was for someone to dress up as me (I
used to wear a red robe lined with white fur due to my station as a
bishop of the Catholic Church) and give gifts to children. After the
protestant reformation, most Europeans decided they didn't want to
give up this holiday, so it was merged with the pagan winter festival
which had already become Christmas. 

CW: This is going to cause a bit of confusion. Why would I interview
you for a magazine dedicated to German cars if you're not German?

SC: Well I ho ho hown a Porsche, if that helps. In fact, the
designation "SC" on the 78 through 83 911 stands for "Santa Claus." I
have a white 78 SC coupe, and I'm having the elves prepare a 73 RS for
Club Racing. 

CW: That's a bit of a stretch - what about Kris Kringle? Is he German?

SC: Ho ho ho. I suppose he is, in a way. You see, Kris Kringle is
another Anglicized Dutch word. The Christmas celebration revolves
around the "little Christ Child," which in Dutch is, "Christkindle."
Americans heard this as, "Kris Kringle." By this time I was already
associated with Christmas and so that name became associated with me.

CW: Well that's just great. Isn't there anything German about you?

SC: I have a summer cottage in Heidelberg. Ho ho ho.

CW: Bingo! That's the connection we'll use. By the way, a few more
sessions on the "stairmaster" wouldn't hurt there Nick. 

=====

Christopher Welty                   Asst. Director, RPI CS Labs, Troy, NY 12180
weltyc@cs.rpi.edu                  "Porsche:  Fahren in seiner schoensten Form"

Date: Mon, 02 May 1994 11:42:14 -0700
From: "Anthony A. Waitz" <waitz2@siarc.com>
Subject: Re: 89 951 questions (new owner) 


> At the same time, you want to avoid overcooling the car, which
> could happen in street driving with a fan switch which came on too
> soon.

Kevin,

I don't think you have to worry about over cooling the engine by
running the fan too much.  If the engine gets too cold the thermostat
closes and the fan has no effect.  I have observed this in my car.
I replaced the normal 92 C thermoswitch with an 82 C switch.  Once
the engine comes up to temperature the fan runs continuously but the
temp gauge never drops below the center tick (about 79 C) since the
thermostat shuts at 83 C.

AAW

Date: 2 May 94 14:24:00 -0500
From: ANTHONY.KELLEY%MSFC2PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov
Subject: Re[2]: Performance Chip Upgrades (for 944s)

     


     
>I have an '84 944.  Its ignition timing is retarded suficiently to 
>prevent detonation with low octane fuel.  I recently switched to using 
>high octane gas exclusively.
     >It seems that a modest HP gain could be realized by 
     >advancing the spark somewhat.  Is this true and do any of 
     >the aftermarket chips provide this?
     
>The early US 944 cars (through '87) had a relatively low compression ratio 
>(~9.7:1) presumably to allow the use of low octane petrol.  So, do the 
>later models, with their 10.5:1 CR require premium fuel, or does the DME 
>compensate enough to allow regular gas?
     
Thanks,
     
    Eric
    -----------------------------------------------------------------
    
    It is true that a modest gain could be realized by advancing the spark. 
     I would be happy to advance it for you for a small fee.
    
    The 10.5:1 cr cars do require higher octane fuel; 
    
    The DME's can be adjusted manually via the FQS (fuel quality switch) to 
    one of eight positions that will retard the spark 3 degrees and/or 
    increase the fuel injection pulse width in order to allow operation 
    with lower octane fuels.  BTW, this switch can be re-programmed to 
    *advance* the spark and to allow custom fuel injection settings.  As 
    delivered, the DME's do not automatically compensate for low octane 
    fuel.  This applies to normally aspirated Bosch Motronic systems.
    --ken house-----keeno racing team electronics repairs Motronics.

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 12:18:09 
From: kev@aixwiz.austin.ibm.com (Kevin Bishop)
Subject: possible stupid 944 question


The other day I was walking to my car in the parking garage at work
and I passed a Porsche owned by one of the guys I work with. While
walking by I read the model designators on the back of the car. On
the left side it said "Turbo". On the right side it said "944S2".
It is a 1989 model year car.

I admit that I don't know a lot about the 944 line-up, but I thought
that the 1989 turbo 944's were just "944S". Since I know the guy that
bought the car brand new, I know that there hasn't been any funny stuff
done to the car. But he doesn't know (or care) what the differences
were between the S2 and the S.

So, my question is: What's the difference? 

Also, I guess I'd like to know how unusual this car is. I can't remember
seeing another 944S2 turbo before.

Many thanks to anyone willing to answer this.

Kevin Bishop

Date: Mon, 2 May 1994 12:45:15 +0800
From: tilden@kea.Data-IO.COM (John Tilden)
Subject: Re: 911 Head Temp Sender

Lou Nicotra Writes:

> I'm getting ready to replace the temperature head sensor (NTC II) that  
> provides data to the Motronic CPU to resolve some cold starting problems 
> on my '84 Carrera.
> Where is the sensor and how do I access it?

	Funny you should ask, as I just accomplished that fix on my '87
	Carrera.

	The sensor is on the front side of No. 3 cylinder head, behind an
	oval rubber grommet. Under the car, you look above the left axle, and
	to the inside of the left shock. It's low, just above the bottom
	of the sheet metal shroud.

	If you have already purchased the sensor, you have examples of what the
	grommets look like , as the sensor comes with new grommets.

	The plug end of the sensor is atop the engine on the left side with
	two other sensor plugs on a bracket, just forward of the distributor,
	and above the fuel rail. It is the top most plug, the white one.
	to remove the plug, there is a metal retainer which is fastened with
	a single screw, in the same plane as the bracket, remove the screw,
	and slide the retainer out, and the plug will come out of the bracket.

	Wire goes thru a clip bolted to the manifold.

	You may need to reomove a clip which retains the flywheel sensor
	leads to the shroud, just below the cover/grommet for the Temp. Sensor.

	Tools: the sensor has an attached lead, so you need a slotted deep
	socket to install the new sensor, 14 mm hex. The old sensor has a 
	13mm hex head, bummer! I cut the lead off close and used a 13mm deep 
	socket as I don't have a slotted 13 mm.
	Your longest screw driver isn't long enough to push the grommets
	back in place, I used a 24 inch long wood 1x2 to aid in this.

	It is a tight place, so struggle a while, but it'll all go back
	together in time. 

	Hint: tie a piece of string to the old sensor plug before you pull
	it through the bulkhead, as you wont be able to reach back there with
	the engine in the car!  

	New sensor has two leads instead of a single lead and a ground return
	path. Mating plug has two lead connections. 

Good Luck
John Tilden
tilden@data-io.com

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 13:03:30 PDT
From: Brian_VanBuskirk <bvb@hpcvnh.cv.hp.com>
Subject: 356 clutch problem

Greetings porschephiles,

I spent Saturday replacing the clutch on my '60 B coupe, and ran
into an unexpected surprise.  After getting everything buttoned
up, I started the car and tried to put the car in reverse.  No luck.
It seemed the clutch wouldn't fully disengage, limiting me to 2nd-
4th gears only.  Adjustment of the clutch pedal didn't improve 
matters any, even after all play was removed.  

I spoke with a local VW/Porsche guy who suggested that the fly- 
wheel nut may be interfering as a result of re-surfacing the 
fly-wheel.  He recommended machining the old nut or replacing
it with a thinner VW nut.

Any ideas?  I'm using a modified 912 T/O bearing, and the pressure
plate I put in didn't match the one I took out (but Automotion
assured me that I had the right part).

Thanks,
Brian Van Buskirk
bvb@hpcvnh.cv.hp.com
(503)967-4337

Date: 2 May 1994 13:25:46 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Zone 7 AutoX School

Zone 7 AutoX School
    Hi, fellow P-Philers!
    I attended the Zone 7 Autocross school this past weekend in the parking lot
at Candlestick Park.  I find myself wishing I know more ways of saying "Wow!" 
It was incredible -- what a kick!
    The first day was full of different excercises.  Everyone started with a
skid-pad excercise, trying to learn about throttle steering.  My group (the
beginning and intermediate air-cooled four-banger group) ran a slalom next,
then went on to a chicane course--close to a tiny autocross course!  Next was
the double-box, where we tried to link left-right turns and also link turns in
the same direction.  There was an Oval, where we tried to cope with a sweeper
at one end and a hairpin turn in the other (I spun about four times!), a
Braking course with three straights and three sharp turns, and finally a
Figure-8 which was two decreasing-radius turns strung together.
    The second day, we ran through and worked two different autocross courses,
a "fast" course, and a "technical" course.  I really loved the fast course. 
The technical one hated me.  Actually, I only spun once or twice on it.
    I was also able to ride with Bill Newton in his 912 around the fast course.
 That car really handles, and he really knows how to get a lot out of it!  My
other ride was with Sandy Provasi, in my 914, around the technical course. 
*That* was humbling.  We needed third gear on the long straightaway by the
timer, but Sandy said she didn't want to go for it because she didn't really
know how what kind of shape the gearbox was in.  Even with that, she bettered
my best time by four seconds.
    As with so many people, my biggest problem is that I won't slow down
enough.  It wasn't much of a problem on the fast course, but the technical
course had a very slow section that I just couldn't seem to slow down enough
for.  I also need to work on making my apexes even later.  Gee, you mean I
*have* to go out and drive more to get better?  Awwww....   ;-)
    So c'mon, everyone!  All you PorschePhilers in the Bay Area, sign up for
the second class!  There are supposedly still spaces open.  I think it's in
August sometime.  98 bucks is pretty cheap for two days of driving fun,
together with some of the best drivers in the area--who are eager to share with
you the knowledge and techniques that will make you a better driver.
    Besides, you didn't *really* need those tires anyway, did you?

- --Dave Darling (DD)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 14:53:38 -0500
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: To FI or not to FI  RE: Yes! FI..

>From: Steve Tynor <tynor@atlanta.twr.com>
>Subject: To FI or not to FI
>
>My dad is trying to decide whether to revert his '74 914 2L to stock
>fuel injection or not. His car currently has a single Holly and is,
>shall we say, rather anemic. My car (also a '74 2L) has what appears to
>be stock fuel injection and it feels like it has more power (it's
>
>Anyway, if you ask George Hussey at Automobile Atlanta, he'll tell you
>to revert to FI. It seems to be the conventional wisdom for street
>914's.  I test drove a lot of 2L's before I bought mine (most of them
>carburetted) and all felt anemic, so I'm inclined to advocate FI.
>
>My dad still has much of the original FI (throttle body, computer,
>etc.), so he'll probably not have to spend too much for parts (he
>figures a few hundred $$, max). This is not a `money is no object'
>project :-). Another option would be to change to duel webers and a cam,
>or a different single carb, I suppose. 
>
>Does anyone care to comment on how he can best evaluate his options?

  <some deleted>

  Steve, and the gang,
  This topic comes up ever' now and then..
  Let me say this about that...

  I have been running a pair of Weber 40IDF's on my '73 powerplant for
nearly ten years.  I want to return to Fuel Injection.
  Why?
  Well carb's SUCK of course..  can you say LINKAGE?

  The set was originally installed to replace a fuel injection system that
baffled me and was in need of expenditures to fix...what was expensive
back then is not so much now (in comparison).  My carb setup is from PMO
and is of very good quality.  At the time, carbs were very competive
price-wise to fuel injection parts..so the Weber's got in.  And the 
difference is wonderful, throttle response..engine sound..powerband all
improve slightly---or does it?  I think some of this is false...how many
times has your bravado increased by *LOUD* exhaust??  Without a dyno..
i cant tell precisely.
  If you are using/tuning a pair of Weber 40 IDF's..you are really tuning
FOUR independent carburetors that share a pair of float bowls.
  I have found this to be VERY difficult and time consuming...and i am
having some trouble getting it right!  I do have the manual, and 
flowmeters..but a rubber hose to listen to the jet squeek to balance out
the flow..*beat* me with the rubber hose! give me a Colortune and a 
Gastester, but now we are talking money for test equipment of equal
value to a working FI system!  no gain?

  On the other hand, since there is now TWO carburetors..they must be
synchronised perfectly or the discord will drive you nuts.  Ah! you say
adjustments are no problem..wait till you go to clean these out after
30k miles, and now the screw settings are off and you cant remember 
exactly what/how to get it right!
The problem is the finesse it takes to make the combo run over the long-haul.
Fuel injection requires less tinkering over the same period of use than
does carbs, and the carbs will need cleaning if the fume managment is in
place, or if long term storage occurs.
Weather can affect the things, you may not have a choke for cold-start..
so you pump raw fuel into your engine in efforts to keep it lit.
Since this is racing hardware, such amenities as *engine fume management*
are not used, so now your pretty is spewing oil fog all over itself and
fuming up your nose because the airflow thru the motor is also what keeps
your bod warm when you open up the heat valves.
  And the car just is not the same driving on a long cruise...cruising
implies precise control of all four carbs...VERY tough to maintain.

There are other carb combo's available..I've tried them too.
  -they suck also.
I still have my 32/36 DGV setup, and I've added a set of 34 PICT's also.
These have their own peculiarities in use, such as after-run dieseling,
or lack of choke..not a nice thing to have in extreme hot/cold climates
like Kansas.  And then you have the problem of icing, backfire, and flooding
so life is not so blissfully ignorant as a proper functioning fuel
injection system.

  Hope this was of use.
- -- 
  -Kyle-not-so-blissfully-ignorant-Ehler
  <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.ncr.com>    ^-----rhymes with 'sailor'
  73,76 914 2.0                             'cuz i cuss like one.
  85 IROC Z-28

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 14:34:27 PDT
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: auto-x school

Any comments from those p-philes who went the the Zone 7 auto-x
school last weekend?  I'll give you mine!  (suprise....)

I was very impressed with the whole experience.  These guys were
very professional and organized.  This was my first class, and I've
never auto-x'd so I was the real beginner.  The instructors were
very helpful and encouraging, as were all the other students I
met.  We got plenty of time out on the course either on an exercise
or on the course.  If you haven't ever done this, do it!

I also got to put some faces with the names I see on this net and
that was fun, hi to everyone I met!

I see lots of folks asking for recommendations on how to get more
power, better brakes, tires, suspension, etc.  For my part, I think
that if these folks ever intend to track their cars they need to 
go to a school or auto-x first, and then find out what they really
need.  For me, it's easy.  I need to learn to drive better!  My car
is a stock '70 911T, M&S all weather tires (good for learning about
oversteer), stock 2.2L still running the Zeniths, and I think the
car is great for this type of event, for me, for now.  All types of
cars, 356's, 912's, old and new 911's, 924's, 944's, and a 928.  Run 
what ya brung!

I was a little nervous about taking the 20+ year old car out there and
finding the redline more in a day than I had in almost 2 years, asking
the most from the brakes and suspension, and then driving the car home.
Now I know why Porsches cost so much.  Even this oldie (and every other
car I saw out there) did all it was asked and then drove home.  And
beleive it or not, I averaged 17 mpg for Saturday........ something to
be said for these mild small motors...

I know I'm the rookie preaching to many experienced drivers, but I also
know that there are lots of people out there who have never been to an
auto-x or a school.  Until you have, you don't begin to learn what your
car can do, just the way it is right now.

I was a little suprised (not to sound sexist, really) on the amount of
women instructors.  I had two during the weekend and they were both
great.  Yelling at me the whole time on how to improve, when to brake,
when to gas, and how to drive the exercise or course.  I met a few of
the women on this net out there, I hope the experience encourages you
(and some of your friends) to come out next time.  I trying to talk
my wife into it.  I think we all learned something that can help us if
we continue to do some type of track event or to drive to and from
work.

Quizz time-

how many people drove the car to work today that they took to class over 
the weekend?

how many people left the numbers on the car......

Mark

Date: Mon, 02 May 1994 18:29:08 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com  ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re:  Tiptronic Questions

Tom Birchard writes:
>...As part of my Artificial Intelligence in Manufacturing class...I have
decided to design a 'smart' automatic transmission...Porsche has already
done this...Questions follow<

1)  How does it REALLY drive, is it as good as it sounds?  Almost!

2)  Has anyone heard any substantial complaints?  Yes!

3)  How successful was Porsche in selling Tiptronic equipped cars? Not very.

4)  Are there any other sources of information that I should read? Yes!

Having said that about that, Barney now removes his shoe and absent
mindedly begins inserting it into his mouth.

Besides power loss through the torque converter, all automatic
transmissions (smart or otherwise) share two common problems; up-shifting
and down-shifting.  The Tiptronic is no different!  It's been two years
since I last drove a "Tip" but here is what I remember.

As I recall, there is an automatic up-shift from 1st gear to 2nd whether
you want it or not.  For some reason, Porsche engineers have determined
that it is okay to blow up the engine, or at least bump the rev limiter in
their manual transmission cars but not in the Tiptronic.  This is extremely
disconcerting on an autocross course and down right dangerous on a less
open playing field. While I understand that this has been remedied in the
968, I believe it is still built into the 911 (993) map.

The big problem is downshifting.  Unless you're lucky enough to drive for
Frank Williams or those Italian guys, you are NOT going to be able to match
engine revs on the downshift.  The transmission will wait until the
downward gear change will rev the engine to something less than redline. (I
mean we are talking 500 to 750 RPM less than red line.)  This can be a real
surprise when the downshift called for two seconds ago suddenly takes place
right at the apex of the corner.

Lately a new complaint has popped up.  The new 911 manual gear box has six
forward speeds.  Introduction of the 6th gear has improved the overall
closeness of the ratios.  The Tiptronic, with only four speeds, now seems
remarkably sluggish in comparison.

The local P* dealer is reluctant to talk about sales in general, let alone
Tiptronics.  The inference was, however, that the Tip may be the least
requested option.

Additional information may be gained from reading "Can You Believe An
Inside Tip" By Jerry Sloniger, EXCELLENCE MAGAZINE, August 1993.

Maybe you will want to look at the possibility of converting last years
Formula One technology with its up-down, any time, anywhere ability into
passenger car use.

I'm going to post this on the "net" too, so stand by for more useful commentary

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     autoxer/racer   SLC


------------------------------


Porschephiles #737                         Wed May 4 02:13:29 CDT 1994
Date: Mon, 2 May 94 17:54:55 EDT
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: Re: 89 951 questions (new owner)

Lance Flynn <71137.1777@CompuServe.COM> writes:

| But why do you want to chip the car anyway? 162mph too slow for you? Losing 
| drag races to Corvettes? Want to cheat in PCA Club Racing? Believe me, your 
| car is pretty damn fast just the way it is. When you can go 10 or 11 tenths 
| lap after lap on a variey of tracks, then go for more power.

I couldn't agree more. I put in an Autothority chip in my '87 951 last
Fall and it's wonderful - but I'm glad I waited.  I've got about 3 years
of hard-core track experience now. Even before I chipped the car, I was
able to keep up with (and often pass) chipped 951's. The chip won't make
you any faster through the turns, and that's where all the fun is!

Save the money on upgrading the car and invest it in some drivers
schools. You'll be glad you did,

Date: Mon, 2 May 94 17:15:33 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Wire on 944 Hatch

I know this one.  Found out about it while at the '91 Parade in Boston,
in the middle of the night.  The wire is for triggering the light in 
the hatch area when the hatch is opened.  If it's disconnected, no light.

However, as I found out, if the wire grounds itself, the light comes on
(and in my case, triggered the alarm!).


Pat
'86 944
'72 914

Date: Mon, 2 May 1994 16:34:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Keith M Roberts <kroberts@crl.com>
Subject: Accuracy of boost gauge ?


Hi, I have an 84 930 and was wondering how accurate the factory
boost gauge is. The owners manual states normal boost as ~.8 bar.
most of the time my gauge confirms this, but it occasionally will
reach 1.0 bar.Is this normal for a stock waste gate ?
Also have any other 930 owners used the aftermarket 1.0 bar springs
available at many sources ? Should I be concerned about reliabilty
with a 1.0 bar spring in an otherwise stock engine in good condition ?

Thanks, Keith Roberts

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 00:30:29 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject:  HAPPY DAY

  o   o   Today is the HAPPY DAY.  I stopped by Taylorville, Ill. to pick
    |     up my 62/356B which had been there most of a year in as the
  \___/   only Porsche in a shop that specializes in Jaguars and anything
          else English.  It was a 'body only' job because there is nothing
wrong with the original engine.  So far as I know, it has never needed to
be removed from the car.  It started right up and without more than a
'once around the block' trial did 300+ miles today violating the speed
limit as much as I dared the whole way.

There are still some minor things .. like the horn isn't connected and
the new windshield has a scratch in front of the driver.  (my next door
neighbor is in the glass business and will get paid to put the new one
in .. when I get home .. another 800 miles from here)  Also, the radio
needs to get some of its dried out components replaced .. but it still
works and the clock needs to be fixed.  Not too bad for 32 years.

I won't take on the Maestro challenge, because my engine is a stock
normal engine.  It might be fun to see how fast it can go, but 110 is
not there without some mods.

Rick Dill .... from Clarksville, Tenn.

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 08:18:18 +0200
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: wheel centers


Steve Jagernauth wrote:

>I am interested in any info you may receive concerning painting your wheel 
>crests since I need to do same.  Similar questions:
>
>        - Porsche color names/codes (Guards Red/Yellow?)
>        - kind of paint (enamel? lacquer? brands?)
>        - clearcoat needed?
>        - stripping/cleaning old paint (paint stripper and sanding OK?)

I refinished my Fuchs two years ago. They have a center cap with the brass
Porsche badge and they looked awful when I bought the car. The centers and
the badge had to be stripped from the old paint and I used paint stripper
which worked after 2 - 3 treatments. Then I had to polish the brass badge
which wasn't that difficult. Ordinary brass polish. 


The tricky part was the painting. The centers were painted at the same time
as the wheels but the badges were more fun. I got enamel hobby paint, red and
black (I think it was Bostic). The horse and was the most difficult
because I don't have that steady hands (OK, I got help from my girlfriend).

After that a clearcoat which also came from the hobby shop. The brass has
not oxided significantly on these two years.
 
The paint I used gave acceptable but not excellent results. The brass surface
is not smooth and even with enamel paint you could see the structure of the
surface in the paint. If I had used more paint this may have been better??

The results were acceptable for the wheels but it wouldn't do for the hood 
badge.

I hope this helps.

Magnus
'82 911 SC (Santa Claus?)
Sweden

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 09:21:02 EST  
From: "Bruce Wm. Pigozzi"  <22107bwp@ibm.msu.edu>
Subject: Senna Questions

The spectacular crash and death of A Senna came as a shock to many
(especially after the only days before in virtually the same spot).  My
local paper printed an AP story read, in part, " 'He was the victim of the
new regulations that banned active suspensions, traction control and
electronic accelerators,' Formula One reporter Castilho de Andrade said..."

I am a mechanical novice (is there a lower category?) so pitch any answers
to my level - -
What actually IS an "active suspension"?
I think I know what traction control is (sort-a-like ABS for pulling not
just braking?) but what is an "electronic accelerator"? Sounds like Formula
One is closer to virtual reality and Senna should be alive with his video
helmet on!

Subject: 951 Perf Mods - chips

I recently asked the list about perf mods for my 951 which Charlie, Kevin and 
Nathan, among others, replied to.  Thanks for the info/opinions! 

On chips, I spoke to Jon Milledge yesterday and his kit includes DME/KLR chips 
and wastegate shims which produce 265HP for the 951 with no known head gasket 
failures (at a good price $300) among 600+ customers.  However, Jon was unable 
to provide curves showing torque and HP curves due to his recent move from CA. 
So, does any of his customers have any?  Nathan?   

Since his kits require shimming the wastegate, what exactly does this mean and 
the results?  Is this to spool up boost faster?  Is lag reduced?  How 
difficult for DIY - tools?  Also, this implies that the mod is permanent which 
means you can't simply plug in the stock chips if you want to return to stock. 
 Are the stock overboost controls retained?  Can the clutch handle the 
additional power?  

I'm seeking as much info as possible before I commit to doing this.  

TIA,

Date: Tue,  3 May 94 11:03:07 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Comparison of C2 vs. C4 911?

> From:  <netmail!kresh@cvi.hahnemann.edu>
> Subject: Comparison of C2 vs. C4 911?
> Date: Tuesday, May 3, 1994 9:28AM
>
> Would very much appreciate opinions from C2 owners and few C4 drivers as
> to the general impression and satisfaction index with these cars. Was the
> 89 C4 "bug free" (first year of the model)?

Early C4's were criticized for understeer.  This can be removed via the 
usual suspension tuning & mods, and I _understand_ (not very factually) 
that Porsche improved this in later C4's.

Early C4's also had fuel sender problems and cracking tail light 
assemblies.  Haven't heard anything beyond that; maybe others have.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Tue,  3 May 94 11:23:58 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: possible stupid 944 question

> From: Kevin Bishop  <netmail!kev@aixwiz.austin.ibm.com>
> The other day I was walking to my car in the parking garage at work
> and I passed a Porsche owned by one of the guys I work with. While
> walking by I read the model designators on the back of the car. On
> the left side it said "Turbo". On the right side it said "944S2".
> It is a 1989 model year car.
Oh, these cars are easy to make.

Just get a 944S2 (3 litre DOHC normally aspirated), and buy a "turbo" 
sticker from the dealer.  Affix this to the rear flank and step on the gas! ;-)

No S2 turbo's were made, 'cept maybe as an experiment at the factory.

		JBS
