Date: Tue, 3 May 1994 07:44:08 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ

+---------------------------------------------------------------------+
|             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              |
|                   (last revised March 2, 1994)                      |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------+

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It will be posted 
regularly, once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are 
undoubtedly additions changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited 
in improving the FAQ.  Send any comments to the name at the end of 
the FAQ.

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  What can you tell me about the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  How is the list maintained?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  What about Unix-based mail problems with the list?
  What are the copyrights or ownership of material sent to the list?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives in /pub/porschephiles?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What models of streetable Porsches have been made over the years?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other well-known Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative 
issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting
all of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with
slow mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want
to convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What can you tell me about the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          President, NetSmiths, Ltd.
          2025 Lincoln Highway
          Edison, NJ 08817

     He lives in Houston TX and works in Edison NJ (Don't bitch about 
*YOUR* commute): 
          Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
                   voice:  (713) 661-2084 
                   FAX:    (713) 661-0633
          Edison:  e-mail: stan@netsmiths.com 
                   voice:  (908) 287-8070 
                   FAX:    (908) 287-3883

     His cars currently include:  
          '81 Euro 911SC Targa (daily driver when he's where it is)
          '74 914 2.0 (SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
          '64 356 SC (OK, so he fell in love again).

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

How is the list maintained?
     
     The list is maintained fairly regularly.  Stan tries to handle
changes at least once every other day.  There will probably be times
when he's on the road and less able to deal with problems, so be
patient.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

How do I submit administrative requests?

    Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  You can also 
reach Stan by phone at (713) 661-2084 or (908) 287-8070 when he's not
traveling.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What about Unix-based mail problems with the list?

     If you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay attention to 
your replies.  The default will send the reply to the "porschephiles-
request" address, as it is the UUCP "From" address (first actual line 
of the mail header).  PLEASE BE AWARE THAT STAN ROUTINELY TRASHES SUCH 
MIS-ROUTED MAIL!  If your mailer starts screwing up, you will be dropped
from the list.  Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any 
more, send Stan mail and he will do his best to figure out what's
happening.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What are the copyrights or ownership of material sent to the list?

     The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence
by and between members of a closed community.  As such, the copyright
for EVERYTHING that ANYONE posts lies with them.  PERIOD.  This is 
*NOT* a bulletin board system, where consent for further redistribution
is implied by nature of the the system; it's PRIVATE.  If you wish to
use something written by someone on the list, you must first seek their
permission unless they specifically grant the right in that specific
posting to reprint it at will.  And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD idea
to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing
up down the line.  Remember, when you read something on this list: what
you are reading belongs to whoever wrote it.  They may have plans to
publish it further themselves.  They may want to keep it "private"
(i.e. just for list member use).  They may not care what gets done with
it.  It's still theirs, and before re-use, permission must be
obtained.  Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a
big deal about it.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available via FTP at tta.com in /pub/porschephiles/
Archives in five subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94) each of which has 
the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  Period!!!  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM
CST, or Stan may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to
mail you archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to
use BINARY mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX
"uncompress" program, or equivalent, to restore to textual format.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What else is available in the tta.com archives in /pub/porschephiles?

     FAQs: This FAQ; also specific FAQs about specific Porsche models
are being added (so far there's only one, for the 914--feel free to
contribute one on YOUR favorite Porsche).
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state of residence, their car's year and model, and their net
address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the information,
and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out on a monthly
basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't send your Alfa
Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send submissions or changes 
to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1-703-922-9300

Does take non-US membership.  You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to
join.  Hours are 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.  Have 
your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number(s) handy, if you own a car, 
or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your 
check.  National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is 
reachable via e-mail at n_weissenberger@harvard.edu.  You can ask her 
for info or get her to send you an application as well.

          Porsche Club of Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1-313-558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (Vic Skirmants' racing column is worth that, as are the
classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1-619-325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1-215-652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     Porsche Cars North America, for a fee of $20, will research the 
original bill of sale for your car and give you a Certificate of 
Authenticity stating the facts and figures for the car as it was 
delivered to the dealer.  If you're interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What models of streetable Porsches have been made over the years?

     356  - The original Porsche sports car, built from 1948 until 
            1965; various engine and drivetrain components and various 
            styling variations existed.
     550  - Really more of a racer in the fifties, but driven on the
            street as well; this is the car James Dean died in.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the coming
            993.  Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Through its long life, many many variations, from the
            original 2.0 litre car to the new 3.8 litre RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1967 through
            1970.
     912E - The 911 with a four-cylinder engine from the 914, 1976.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between 
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6 
            was a variant with a two litre 911 engine inserted in place 
            of the four-cylinder engine.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine, updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain.
            Has the best aerodynamic shape of any Porsche.
     928  - The high end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5 litres 
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5 litre displacement, except for a 2.7 litre
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3.0 litre 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative.  2.85 litre, four valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive.
     964  - Another name for the 911 Carrera 4 and Carrera 2 as introduced
            in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992.  Most noteworthy feature
            is variable valve timing.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, due in showrooms in 4/94.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     FAQ  - Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
     FWIW - For what it's worth
     IMHO - In my humble opinion
     IMO  - In my opinion
     PCA  - Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     POC  - Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     PCGB - Porsche Club of Great Britain
     PCNA - Porsche Cars of North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PANO - Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
     PAG  - Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     YMMV - Your mileage may vary
     :-)  - Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to "read"
            it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       telephone: 415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

       Argus Publishers Corp.

     911 and Porsche World -
       British independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Coverage
       of UK club racing, tech Q&A, owner's reports, and so forth.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in the US.


      Automobile Atlanta
      505A South Marietta Highway
      Marietta, GA 30060
      telephone: 404-427-2844
 
The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
prices.
 
 
     Automotion

sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?

There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for you
depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the technical
articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of their
Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's executive
office.

What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  
If you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note:
Information about water-cooled cars is lacking; those with favorites
should submit them to one of the names at the end of this FAQ.)

     Bruce Anderson
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Duane Spencer
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       (ISBN not known)

     Dr. Brett Johnson
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       (ISBN not known)
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Charles O. Probst
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Fred Puhn
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Harry Pellow 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
 

There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While the
Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other well-known Porsche people) here?
 
     Bruce was invited to join and did so back in '91. The load then
was too much for him.  All of what, 2k a day or so.  Now, at 15x to 20x
that load, he probably doesn't want back on.  He's not stupid -- he 
knows where we are.

     No specifics are available regarding other renowned Porsche people.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Who maintains this FAQ?

     Currently, the FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode, who can be reached
as thode@nprdc.navy.mil.  Anyone who wants to contribute can do so.  
Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are welcomed.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 May 1994 13:11:00 EST
From: reid_zeigler@merck.com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: original paint


Michael asks:

>What value is THE origional color vs. A origional color?

The reason THE original color is so important on Porsches
is because of the way they are painted at the factory.
The body shell is painted inside and out - in every nook
and cranny with the body color. In order to do a *correct*
job of changing the color, the body must be stripped to the 
same extent that it was when it was originally painted. Not
too many people are willing to do that. I've seen a few 
total restorations where the color was changed and there was
absolutely no way to tell. I doubt that the value suffered 
much. On a very valuable collectible Porsche, I'd still stick
with the original color, just to protect my investment.

 - Reid

Date: Tue, 3 May 1994 09:40:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@herbie.sad.hp.com>
Subject: re: 94/924 hatch wire

From: Hubert Lai <70363.1332@CompuServe.COM>
> Subject: Wire on 944 Hatch
> 
> While cleaning out the interior of my 1983 944, I noticed a broken
> wire which has me completely mystified.  The wire is on the right side

> suspect it has been a long time.  Just from looking at the wire, I
> would have assumed it had something to do with the rear window
> defogger.  However, even with the wire broken, the defogger functions
> perfectly.  I can't find anything about it in Haynes.
> 
> Any ideas?

My 931 has a similar wire.  The rear defogger gets it's juice through
the rear hatch shocks.  On one side, the switched +12V from the
console goes through an insulated shock to the heater wires on the
window, and on the other side the return current goes through an
UNinsulated shock, to the car chassis.  There is a wire connecting the
shock to the chassis on this side, but if I disconnect the wire, I still
can get defog current through the shock mount itself.

I suspect that the shock swivel mount is not a reliable connection for
the ~15A or so thet the defoger uses, and so Porsche added a wire to
handle that current.  You may find that the defogger works a little
better or more reliably with that wire reattached.

 -mike   '80 $931 Fire Engine Red!
___________________________________________________________________
mikew@sr.hp.com                       mailstop 1UR-M             
                                      MMS Manufacturing Engineering         
Mike Weihman                          Microwave Instruments Division
Hewlett-Packard Company               1212 Valley House Drive    
(707) 794-4454                        Rohnert Park, CA 94928  USA

Date: 3 May 1994 10:31:46 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 914 Rear Sway-Bar?

914 Rear Sway-Bar?
    Attention all 914 autocrossers:
This past weekend at the School, I heard quite a bit of talk about
the rear "sway-bar" (anti-roll bar) in the factory Sport Group on
a 914.  The consensus was that I should dis-connect the rear bar,
unless I was running a rather large (bigger than factory) bar up
front.
    What do you-all think?  I'm going to be running in Stock, so
I'm not up-grading the front bar.  Should I yank out the drop-links
and tie the rest of the bar out of the way?  Would the Factory have
done something that decreases cornering ability in the Sport Group?
    All replies welcome.

- --DD  ( == Dave Darling )



------------------------------

Date: 3 May 1994 10:08:33 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: AutoX School

AutoX School
    Sorry for my ramblings yesterday, but I was still pretty wiped out
and my mind (such as it is) was very scattered.  I'm still excited about
the School, however.
    I'd like to thank Mark B. for his more coherent thoughts on the
school, and to re-emphasize one point that he made.
    Lots of people ask about go-fast parts for their Porsches.  The 
absolute *best* go-fast goodie that you can *possibly* get for your car
is learning how to drive your car to its maximum potential.  Period.
Go out and get some "seat time"!  It will make a *lot* more difference
than simply putting more HP under the hood.
    The school is a good place to get seat time, and you have a *lot* 
of world-class instructors.  If you don't want to use an entire weekend, 
find an autocross that you can get to.  You won't learn as fast, but 
you'll still learn, and there will be instructors there as well.  
They're glad to help people learn about maximum performance driving.

- --DD  ( == Dave Darling )

Date: Tue, 3 May 1994 11:52:55 -0400
From: Alex Noordergraaf <noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com>
Subject: Re: 914 clutch problems


I would like to thank everyone that responded to my clutch problems.
The wisdom on the net to rescue once more.  Really, everyone, the
response was VERY helpful - thanks to everyone.

I plan to take the least invase approach first.  It was suggested that
the strands inside the cable could be tearing one at a time and that
the cable may have been damaged by contacting the heat exchanges.

Yesterday I ordered a new clutch cable, and while I am at it I also
ordered a new throttle cable and the bronze bushing for the pedal
cluster.  My pedal cluster has no bushings in it, and the throttle
sticks sometimes.  I can hopefully fix all this stuff in one shot!

Once I replace all these cables I will be able to tell if the
clutch cable is pulling out of the tube.  If it is I will fix it then.
I really hope that it is only the cable that is broken and not
the mount :-). [optimism is all]

If anyone is interested in the procedures that I go through while 
replacing the cables and the bushings please let me know and I will
post a summary.

Alex (noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com)

Date: Tue, 03 May 94 11:05:00 PDT
From: "Dayton, Mike" <DAYTONM@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: Bushings

Guten tag!

On my way to work yesterday, something was definitely amiss.
I quickly put my finger on it - my passenger's side spring plate
bushings (replaced months ago as a part of my torsion bar fiasco)
had mysteriously stopped squeaking.  The driver's side never
squeaked, but the passenger's side made this annoying little noise
with every slight movement of the spring plate.

If I ever figure out why it stopped squeaking, I'm going to bottle it
and make millions - with a 100% discount for porschefiles of course.

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 11:08:48 PDT
From: dorr@hyperion.llnl.gov (Milo Dorr)
Subject: Zone 7 school

Ditto Dave and Mark.  Last weekend's school was a blast.  I have not
yet stopped having flashbacks!  One of my favorites is a right hand
sweeping turn at full throttle with the instructor screaming GAS, GAS,
GAS, GAS in my ear.  The start/finish line was near the exit of the
turn, and I remember thinking that I would probably kill the flagger
(who should have been positioned on the other side of the course,
IMHO) if this pedal-to-the-metal idea didn't work.  But, I followed
instructions and, of course, the car went around the turn on rails
just fine.

At times I wished that I weren't driving a turbo car to begin my climb
of the learning curve, although these thoughts were temporarily
suppressed on the longer, straighter sections of the course :-).  Even
though I was expecting it, the sudden arrival of power nevertheless
sent me spinning a couple of times.  The ultimate in frustration,
however, was exiting a turn with my eye on the approaching apex and
the accelerator mashed to the floor, waiting for what seemed an
ETERNITY for the cavalry to arrive with the extra horsepower.  I
understand that there are techniques for mitigating the lag problem
(better anticipation, left-foot braking, etc.), but these were a bit
too advanced for a beginner such as I.  Nevertheless, I am determined
to learn to autocross a 951 well, which I am convinced is possible
after having had the opportunity to ride with Jon Milledge (who was
mentioned in a few recent postings) at a no-points practice event at
the Pleasanton fairgrounds a couple of years ago.  What an experience!

Candlestick Park lived up to its reputation as the inhospitable place
that nearly sent the Giants to Florida.  Especially in the late
afternoon, the wind occassionally pitched the timing and scoring
trailer around a bit, picking up debris and hurling it at the
assembled cars and participants.  This had a few people worrying about
paint jobs, but I don't think there was any real danger.  The parking
lot surface seemed pretty good (much better than the coarse runway
surface at the previous Crow's Landing venue, I was told), although
there were a couple of pieces of asphalt missing in the line I was
hoping to use in the double-box exercise.  The lot had some elevation
changes that created an off-camber turn on one of the courses (no
high-speed banking, unfortunately ;-)), but this added to the overall
learning experience, while subtracting from several people's scores
(all driving 911's as I recall) who downed multiple pylons there.

As for Mark's quiz, I did drive my autocross car to work yesterday
(thump-thump-thump, I will probably have to get the front tires shaved
to make them round again :-( ), but I washed the number off the
windshield beforehand.  I decided that people on the street would be
more likely to think that I had just come from a used car lot than
would think that I was any kind of racer!

 -Milo



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 03 May 1994 15:00:10 -0400 (EDT)
From: anselmo@thermsa.eng.sunysb.edu (Andrew P. Anselmo)
Subject: ('77 924) Turn signal on while engine is off,

Hi folks-

I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
the turn lights still remain on.  This might be in the turn signal 
flasher relay (which seems to work fine), or someplace else.  I noticed
this one night when I left my car; unfortunately, last night I forgot
to check... and had to get jumped this morning.

Any ideas?  I figure proper debugging procedure would be to take out
the relay, and continue from there and the Haynes electrical diagram...

A.

Date: 3 May 1994 10:44:00 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Used-Porsche Interest Group

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:06 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Used-Porsche Interest Group           Date:  5/3/94
Many people have expressed interest in some of the used cars for
sale I have posted from ads in local bay area papers, only to find
the cars were sold after a couple of days.  The really good deals
obviously go quickly.

My messages get posted and turned around (to me, anyway) between
6 -24 hours.  That delay is too long for the really good deals
(89 951 $12.9k, 78 SC $9.9k, 91 C2 $32k, etc.).  I can send direct
messages to most of you in a fraction of that time.

I am willing to maintain a special list for direct mail to those
seriously looking, and at the same time post it to porschefiles for
the curious.  Members of the direct mail list will obviously see the
message twice.

The following porschephiles are already included in the Used-
Porsche Interest Group (U-PIG):

Lee Chen
Mike Dayton
Bill C. Hutton
Ted Matsura
Risto Tolonen
Trond Vidar Olsen
Denny Zorn

Please let me know if you wish to be added to or deleted from U-PIG.
Send me your name and email address.  I can't take the time to tailor
messages to your individual interests so U-PIG readers will all get
the same mail.  I will try to post the best deals across the Porsche
model line.

Again, if you do not need "express mail" and are happy with the
current delivery you do *not* need to be in U-PIG.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 15:37:22 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: air filter

> Ok, so this might sound like a stupid question, but what's the hype about
> the K&N air filter?  I saw one add in Pano/Excellence that claims that
> this filter will improve the air flow by 59%! What's so different about
> this filter?  Is it really expensive (you know, when the add says "call
> for best price", it's something that they wouldn't brag about).  If this
> is a faq please e-mail me to save bandwith. 

They may seem expensive at first, but since they 'last a lifetime' with
proper cleaning and oiling, they actually end up cheaper after a few
years.  Airflow is supposed to be improved somewhat, giving a small hp
boost, though I'm sure somebody on the list has dyno figures or something
to back this up.

Blaine

Date: Tue, 03 May 94 11:01:55 pst
From: GFORCE@cccpp.com (GFORCE)
Subject: Re: Senna Questions

The spectacular crash and death of A Senna came as a shock to many 
(especially after the only days before in virtually the same spot).  My 
local paper printed an AP story read, in part, " 'He was the victim of the 
new regulations that banned active suspensions, traction control and 
electronic accelerators,' Formula One reporter Castilho de Andrade said..."

I am a mechanical novice (is there a lower category?) so pitch any answers 
to my level - -
What actually IS an "active suspension"?
I think I know what traction control is (sort-a-like ABS for pulling not 
just braking?) but what is an "electronic accelerator"? Sounds like Formula 
One is closer to virtual reality and Senna should be alive with his video 
helmet on!

Active suspension is a concept invented by Lotus ? (I think..), all it means is 
that the suspension system is 'smart' in that it stiffens the side the load is 
on though the turn...ie, on a left hand turn, the right side suspension stiffens
up.


G


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 16:55:35 -0400
From: kennedy@admin.njit.edu (William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648)
Subject: K&N air filter

Soren Grama inquires about whether K&N air filter is worth it.  I'd be glad
to have my understanding confirmed or refuted, which is:  K&N filter does
provide a measureable, perhaps not a driver-perceptible, gain, and the 
factory didn't use it because of noise level and (on carbureted 911s) no
way to hook in warm-up pipe.  Any happy users have a comment?
B.

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 16:21:20 -0400
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: 915 transmission driveshaft flange query

I've got a driveshaft flange that has been helicoiled (actually 3 helicoils
and 1 timesert).  I recently removed and reinstalled the driveshaft, and
now 1 of the inserts is stripped, and I can't torque the other 3 bolts up
to spec (60 ft-lbs) without them starting to pull out.  I don't really feel
like being stranded somewhere with a disconnected driveshaft and I don't want
to have to check the bolts every week to see if they are working themselves
out - I want to fix it right.

For you welders out there, could I take the flange out, remove the inserts,
mostly fill in the holes, and retap the threads?  Would my weld even stick to
the thing (which is certainly steel, but of unknown metal treatment)?  Or
should I just get a new flange altogether ($$$?)

It appears to be held on to the transmission by a single bolt in its center,
torqued to 20-30 ft-lbs.  Does it just have a spline on the other end or
what?  Will it's removal cause all my $ynthetic gearbox fluid to $pill out?

Thanks,
Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
'73 911S Coupe

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 13:19:07 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: air filter

Soren,

     The K&N  filter will allow your engine to breathe better
*ONLY* if the old filter was limiting the flow (rather than the
muffler, cat, etc.)  I use one because I didn't like dropping $20
ea on paper filters.  The K&Ns for a CIS 911 are about $40.  Then
you buy a spray can of oil, and clean and re-oil them yourself.
I felt no performance difference, but like being able to clean
and re-use it.

- --   Bob
^Z

Date: 03 May 94 18:45:16 EDT
From: Triet Le <73370.50@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: '86 951 Stereo Squeals

If there are any car audiophiles out there, here's some questions for you. 
I have decided to get the stereo on my recently purchased '86 Pearl White 
951 in shape for the summer. It is a relatively new Panasonic tuner/CD 
front end with a detachable face hooked up to a Rockford-Fosgate amp(4x20?) 
into stock speakers. The driver's door speaker is blown. I don't want to 
cut anything. I assume the the existing front end/amp with good front 
speakers and a Bazooka for bass should be an improvement over the existing 
situation.

1) What is a good replacement door speaker? According to Crutchfield, the 
speaker needs to be 4x6metric and less than 1.625" deep. They sell nothing 
that works. I would like to use a high-end plate speaker; ie. MB Quart or 
ADS.

2) Crutchfield also says that the rear speakers are hard to change. This is 
not a big deal since I don't want to change them anyway.

3) I would like to hook up a Bazooka tube(s) for additional bass. My 
options are

a) Unpowered 6" Bazooka tubes hooked up to the rear speaker leads in the 
hatch. I would trace the wires, cut them off close to the speakers without 
removing the speakers, and hook them up to the Bazookas. This means that I 
use existing puny wires.

b) Same thing except put the Bazooka(s) in the footwells of the rear seats. 
This would allow me to run Monster cable direct to the amp (in the front 
passenger footwell.) If the amp is a triamp (haven't checked yet) then I 
could have more power for a single Bazooka only.

c) Place 1 powered Bazooka and 1 unpowered Bazooka (wired in series) in the 
footwells of the rear seats. Add Y-connector to existing amp power feed to 
power the Bazooka. Add patch cable to feed music to Bazooka. Retain 
existing rear speakers.

Questions:

What is the best option?

How would a crossover/filters fit into this?

The existing stereo sometimes makes a high pitched squealing noise which 
goes away when I turn the stereo off/on or turn it up enough to drown it 
out. I have experienced this in other 944's and would like to get rid of 
it.

The stereo now is often used at top volume. This is sometimes insufficient. 
I expect that it will be sufficient if I replace the blown speaker. What 
else can be done?

Did I say that I have never installed anything in a car even remotely 
electrical.

And speaking of next month's paycheck.

I am considering KONI Sport gas shocks for the car. I would like to do 
springs at the same time. The only springs that I have found that are rated 
at 250+ lbs (Troutman, Weltmeister) lower the car. This is unacceptable for 
me (live in NYC.) Eibach apparently sells 220lb springs with stock ride 
height. Would this be a big difference over stock? Any suggestions? The car 
is stock now except for an Autothority chip and cat pipe.. The rear shocks 
are soft, which is prompting this exercise. The tires are 205/55 and 225/50 
RE71R's.

Date: Tue, 3 May 94 19:49:22 -0500
From: damon@thunder.cadcam.iupui.edu (Damon Beals)
Subject: Re: pressure gauge suitable for FI (D-jet)?


> 
> For all of you with high pressure fuel systems, where would I get a
> fuel pressure gauge I can use to calibrate my 914 with D-jet (approx
> 35psi needed, max).  Of course all chain stores only have low pressure
> stuff for carbs, and refer me to NAPA, which only has one thing for
> $50 which goes to 100psi; and somehow I doubt that will be useful if
> I'm trying to read 29.5psi accurately.  Anybody have a source? Thanks
> a lot.

   I when to the local hardware store and bought a pressure guage used for
water tanks or chemical sprayers..  It goes to 50 pounds and is in 2 pound
increments but it will tell you close enought what your pressure I think the
book says 29-35 pounds or it that a little high.. I set mine to 32 and it
runs just fine.

  Damon Beals
   74 914 with a 72 1.7 engine..

Date: Wed, 04 May 1994 10:35:51 +1000
From: "Mark Kosten - Computer Centre, La Trobe Uni." <M.Kosten@latrobe.edu.au>
Subject: Re; Senna Questions

From:	IN%"22107bwp@ibm.cl.msu.edu"  "Bruce Wm. Pigozzi"  4-MAY-1994 02:14:24.64

>The spectacular crash and death of A Senna came as a shock to many
>(especially after the only days before in virtually the same spot).  My
>local paper printed an AP story read, in part, " 'He was the victim of the
>new regulations that banned active suspensions, traction control and
>electronic accelerators,' Formula One reporter Castilho de Andrade said..."

Our local commentators (including Grand Prix winner Alan Jones) analysed
the accident and identified a probable suspension failure at the
entrance to the corner. The car in fact veers right into the Armco
instead of even attempting to turn left.

If this is so then the lack of high-tech solutions seemed to play little
role in the accident. The same goes for Alboretto's wheel
failure, causing severe injury to pit crew. Can't say about Ratzenberger.

I saw the accident on TV live and it seemed survivable, but I guess
luck ran out for Senna. It certainly is disturbing when this happens,
and reinforces the dangerous nature of racing cars.

Mark Kosten

Date: Tue, 03 May 1994 21:34:03 -0400 (EDT)
From: ALW1@delphi.com
Subject: stan on superchargers

I read the reply to Stan about the supercharger option to improve performance.
I have an '87 911 Cab that German Auto in Knoxville supercharged - I could not
be happier. The car now has the power I had always wanted it to have - no 
turbo lag, just fast from th start. I had them put in the paxton supercharger.
They dynoed the car at 350 horsepower. So far I have put over 5,500 miles on 
the car and have not had any problems. The people at German Auto were great to
work with, and they were very concerned that I be happy with their work - I was!

I understand Bruce Anderson has been to visit them and was impressed with their
work. I believe he went with them to Road Atlanta with a C2 and C4, both with 
wipple superchargers. They set track records while they were there. 

If anyone is interested in supercharging their Porsche, I encourage them to 
contact German Auto (615) 691-1911. If I had to decide whether or not to 
supercharge my 911 again, I would do it in a heartbeat.

Al Wagener

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 03 May 94 16:30:11 EDT
From: loukrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Wire on 944 Hatch

Hubert,

The wire is the grounding wire for the rear hatch area courtesy light. There
is a small metal contact which touches the gas strut piston rod when the
hatch is open, grounding the circuit, and viola! Light! 

If you look you'll see a short length of black plastic tube around the piston
rod where it comes out of the cylinder. When the hatch is closed, the plastic
separates the piston rod from the metal contact, and the light goes out.

HTH,

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic

Date: Tue, 3 May 1994 16:22:17 +0100
From: <kfosburg@dhm.com>
Subject: Re: Senna Questions



On Tue, 3 May 1994, Bruce Wm. Pigozzi wrote:

> The spectacular crash and death of A Senna came as a shock to many
> (especially after the only days before in virtually the same spot).  My
> local paper printed an AP story read, in part, " 'He was the victim of the
> new regulations that banned active suspensions, traction control and
> electronic accelerators,' Formula One reporter Castilho de Andrade said..."
> 
> I am a mechanical novice (is there a lower category?) so pitch any answers
> to my level - -
> What actually IS an "active suspension"?


Lots of Senna discussions which, IMO, is appropriate even here at 
PPhiles, and the other lists dealing with autos that I'm on. It was 
definatly the most black weekend in racing I personally have ever felt. I 
personally watched Senna win at Detroit and Phoenix, and out qualify 
others at the other F1 venues I've been to. 

He was a master to watch drive, especially in qualifing. Watching his
hands only move fractions of an inch while others steered back and forth
was amazing. Never a hesitation, only sheer concentration and 
determination when going for that "fast" lap. I, and F1 fans everwhere, 
will miss him and his prominance he brought to autoracing.

What is active suspension? Basically, take out your springs and shocks and
replace them with actuators (pneumatic or hydraulic). Tell the actuators
to push or pull based on feedback signals from every imaginably sensor
(pitch rate/acceleration , roll rate/accel, lateral accel, driver input,
force exerted on suspension struts, speed, etc...). The control laws are
very complex and the speed of computation/actuation must be very fast as
well as redundant for safety. 

Watching an actively suspended car around the same circuit as this year's 
passive (springs/shocks) cars is like night and day. They are bumping and 
bouncing much more and have MUCH more instability. I think we will see a 
lot more crashes this year, due to the lack of active suspension alone :-(

The instability caused by pitch changes will cause many high speed 
handling problems. The lack of traction control mostly effects low speed 
handling and is not as much of a safety problem. Besides, the cars 
sounded awful with traction control on (sounds like engine missing and 
sputtering, yuck).

FYI,

Karl
1971 911E


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 08:00:37 -0400
From: Steven John Timmins <timmins@strauss.udel.edu>
Subject: Re: 951 Perf Mods - chips


Kits which require the shimming of the wastegate are a REAL pain the
the butt.

Getting the wastegate bolts off w/o breaking them is no simple chore,
and if you break something on the wastegate (which is cast iron) you
are SOL.

Personally I recommend the kits which use the modified banjo bolt (like
autothority).  You can change the boost in about 20 seconds (wiuth a
spare bolt and a 17mm wrench) and the bolt is more accessable than the
dipstick (guess that's not saying much). 

You have heard it before but I'll say it again - my opinions may be
tainted as I am an Autothority dealer.

S

------------------------------

Date:  Wed, 4 May 1994 09:08:22 -0400

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 13:18:29 CET		Message-Id: <AA19450>
From: tidbits@aviano.af.mil
Subject: Re:  ('77 924) Turn signal on while engine is off, key out of ignition ('777 924)

Yes, that's a feature, not a bug. Long time ago (1980) many German
municipalities turned off their street lights at night to save energy.
(In my town it was 11PM.) German cars were required to have this 
feature to allow you to park on the side of the road, or half-on-
the-sidewalk style, with a marker light on, and not get hit by
a bicyclist (not a car, which would see your reflector light, but 
a bicyclist.....). The idea was not to leave it on all night; if you
need to park all night you get off the road entirely.

But many times I inadvertently left the light on all night and the 
battery didn't need a jump next day. Could be the US-spec cars 
don't just turn on the front and back marker lights, they turn on
lots more (for more info write: Rolling_Tupperware-request.....).

Bottom line: most Euro cars do it. Just neutralize your turn signal
when you stop and you're all set.

Pete Jones
Pordenone, Italy

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 08:17:37 EDT
From: len1@sos.att.com (L.E.Nicotra-WH-77122H(WH5672)W214)
Subject: Trun signal germlims

Anselmo writes:
=====================
I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
the turn lights still remain on.  This might be in the turn signal 
flasher relay (which seems to work fine), or someplace else.  I noticed
this one night when I left my car; unfortunately, last night I forgot
to check... and had to get jumped this morning.

Any ideas?  I figure proper debugging procedure would be to take out
the relay, and continue from there and the Haynes electrical diagram...

=======================

Here's the deal, I don't know where I read this, but years ago, I read that a
German motoring law says that when you park on the street, at night you must
leave a light turned in. I think it has something to do with the width of the
street. 

It is definitely a FEATURE of your car! Read your owner's manual. Not once but
a number of times. You'll be amazed at what you'll pick up.

THis feature, only works when the key is removed from the ignition. Up on the
lever, right side ligths and viceversa. My Mercedes has the same feature, but it
located right on the headlight switch. Two extra positions CCW.

Hope this helps! Just be carefule when getting out of the car...

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len1@sos.wh.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 08:52:49 EST
From: reid_zeigler@merck.com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: turn signal stays on



Anselmo writes:

>"... when I leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off 
>the car, the turn lights still remain on.

This is normal European car behavior. In Germany and some 
other countries you are required to display "marker lights" 
on the side nearest the road if you are parked beside the road at 
night. 

It's a good safety idea, but a pain in the neck if you 
pull into a parking space in daytime and don't notice that the
signal lights are on. I've done a few push-the-car-and-jump-in 
rolling LeMans starts over the years. (assuming flat parking 
lot... - key on, push hard, jump in, 3rd gear, clutch out, pray,
doodle the gas, drive away) If you're pessimistic or not the 
physical type you might want to pray first.

 - Reid


 - Reid



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 08:26:54 EDT
From: len1@sos.att.com (L.E.Nicotra-WH-77122H(WH5672)W214)
Subject: Shifter play

Hello out there Porsche Pushers!

Here is one for you. I think 911/914 owners could help me...

Checking the shifter linkgage last night, I discovered that the shift coupler
(behind the front seats, under an inspection plate on a 911) had some play.

It can be traced to a plastic bushing. The bushing has elongated in the forward/
backward direction (not up/down). It is about 1mm per direction. THis actually
translates to about 1/2" of free play at the shift lever.

I know there are replacement bushings available. Is the play normal? I would
think that you would want NO PLAY in this critical part. Am I right?

Also, has anyone replaced the bushings? The shift coupler is held by a square
head screw to the trans, and by a C clamp to the shifter... Once I remove it,
Is the shaft on the coupler a press fit? Can it be hammered out with a drift?

As usual, thanks in advance for your wisdom!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len1@sos.wh.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 09:06:56 CDT
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: ('77 924) Turn signal on while engine is off

Andrew P. Anselmo writes:
>
> I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
> leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
> the turn lights still remain on.  <...>

It's a feature.  When I was in Germany in March, I noticed it
on our rental car also (it was an Opel).  The Germans use it
when parking at night in a precarious position.  They would
leave the turn signal on for the side of the car that was on
the street (the other side was usually on the sidewalk...).

mjt


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 9:49:17 EDT
From: Paul Moruzzi <pmoruzzi@hpwarhw.wal.hp.com>
Subject: Turn signals staying on...

This also happens on my 951 and I believe it is a feature across all the
models.  It is intended to be a feature.  The idea being instead of
leaving your parking lights on (lots of bulbs) when parked on the street
you can leave the turn signal on and only have two bulbs on.  I've used
this feature a few times, and I've seen a fair number of cars parked
with only turn signals on in Germany.

Paul Moruzzi

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 09:57:02 -0400
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re: Re: 914 clutch problems

Alex wrote:
> I plan to take the least invase approach first.  It was suggested that
> the strands inside the cable could be tearing one at a time and that
> the cable may have been damaged by contacting the heat exchanges.
Probably the #1 cause of the cable tearing strands one at a time and then
snapping is failure to keep the end of the cable from rotating when adjusting
the nut (or pair of nuts) at the end of the cable.  I suggest you use a set
of vice-grips or equivalent.  What happens is that when you tighten the nuts,
the cable end wants to turn with them and it just happens to be the direction
that unravels the twisted strands, usually breaking several in the process.
This weakens the cable right at the joint between the threaded end and the
cable...eventually the two will part ways.

Another thing you might check is it see if the ground strap on top of the
transmission is still connected.  I have heard stories where the strap was
not connected and the clutch cable becomes the best ground strap available.
It becomes hard and brittle from the heat and eventually snaps.

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe

Date: 04 May 94 11:11:46 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: turn signal

Andrew Anselmo writes:
 
>I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I
>leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
>the turn lights still remain on.  This might be in the turn signal
>flasher relay (which seems to work fine), or someplace else.  I noticed
>this one night when I left my car; unfortunately, last night I forgot
>to check... and had to get jumped this morning.
 
Chances are it's supposed to do that. I'm not sure if U.S. spec cars
have this feature, but German-spec cars do. If you leave the turn
signal activated and pull the ignition key, the turn signals on the
appropriate side will stay on (but not flash). It's intended as a
marker light for when you're parked on a dark road or some
such. Not sure if the main light switch needs to be on or in the
parking light position to have the turn signals act as markets.
 
Is your car a gray market car? I can't remember now if US cars
do this too.  Bottom line: Don't worry about it, just don't leave
the lights on.
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 10:44:27 -0500
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: air filter

>Subject: Re: air filter
  [some deleted]
>>you buy a spray can of oil, and clean and re-oil them yourself.
>>I felt no performance difference, but like being able to clean
>>and re-use it.
>>
>>--   Bob
>
>Bob, I was told lastweek that you could use ATF (Dexron 2) for oiling 
>the filter (yep, ATF sure looks/feels like the K&N oil).  Both are light 
>oils, but I haven't tried it yet (my filter's not due for a wash yet).
>
>Anyone else have the inside scoop?
>
>Lawrence

  Bob, Lawrence, and those who use recyclable filters:

  I beleive the proper oil for use in air filtration applications is 
actually water-soluble.  This is so cleaning of the filter can be done
using soap and water rather than solvent.  "filter coat" as it is known
in the HVAC business, is used on many filters to boost performance.

  The ingredients on my can are as follows;
   Soluble hydrocarbon oil............. 48.0%
   Sodium ortho-phenylphenate..........  0.5%
   Polyethylene thickener..............  1.5%
   Propellant: Methylene Chloride...... 20.0%
               Dichlorodiflouromethane. 30.0%  <--why we dont use it anymore.
   Vendor:  Research Products  Item # 418
            Madison, Wi  53701
- -- 
  -kyle
  <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.ncr.com>
  73,76 914 2.0
  85 IROC Z-28

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 11:33:54 +0000
From: kwb1@cornell.edu (Klaus W. Beyenbach)
Subject: Active suspension

On active suspension:

In the research/developent facilities of some German automobiles
manufacturers the future of the active suspension is forged.  As Karl
writes:

What is active suspension? Basically, take out your springs and shocks and
replace them with actuators (pneumatic or hydraulic). Tell the actuators
to push or pull based on feedback signals from every imaginably sensor
(pitch rate/acceleration , roll rate/accel, lateral accel, driver input,
force exerted on suspension struts, speed, etc...)

Add to this a front-mounted camera that examines the contours of the
upcoming road surfaces, feed this input to the active suspension, and you
have a wheel that holds its position while going over a pothole!  Neat?! 
Anyway, this is coming.

Looking forward,

Klaus W. Beyenbach
1981 911 SC
Ithaca, NY   


------------------------------

Date:     Wed,  4 May 94 09:29:12 PDT
From: "Michael P. Lammers"  <Michael.P.Lammers@Forsythe.Stanford.EDU>
Subject:  Backfire -- 1973 914 1.7

Dear Fellow Porsche Owners,

I need help! My 1973 914 1.7  backfires upon deceleration.
The backfiring usually occurs between 3k and 2k. I have tightened
all of the header bolts and my exhaust system appears to be solid
and tight all the way through.  I have cleaned the contacts in my
throttle body switch (although were really clean when I opened it).
I have checked the vacuum on my pressure sensor and I have swapped
sensors (I have two that appear to be in good shape). All of my
hoses appear to be tight. I have adjusted the valves and set the
timing. I have new points, plugs, etc.  The engine has about 12k on
a rebuild and the backfiring started within the last several weeks.
I recently replaced fuel injector #1 -- it was leaking. The car
accelerates and cruises very well. There is no popping on the way up
the rpm scale. Other than a leak in the exhaust system, I would
like to know what, if anything, can cause a car to backfire. Could
it be timing, fuel-air mixture?? If you have any insight or
suggestions, I would like to hear from you. I appreciate your help.
Thank you!

Michael Lammers

Full E-Mail Address: mu.mpl@forsythe.stanford.edu

PHONE 415-725-5265
FAX   415-723-7796

To:  PORSCHEPHILES@TTA.COM

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 11:20:29 +0000
From: kwb1@cornell.edu (Klaus W. Beyenbach)
Subject: Turn signal is parking light

>Hi folks-
>
>I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
>leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
>the turn lights still remain on.  This might be in the turn signal 
>flasher relay (which seems to work fine), or someplace else.  I noticed
>this one night when I left my car; unfortunately, last night I forgot
>to check... and had to get jumped this morning.
>
>Any ideas?  I figure proper debugging procedure would be to take out
>the relay, and continue from there and the Haynes electrical diagram...
>
>A.
 Dear Andrew,

The behaviour you describe is normal and intentional for European Porsches
and perhaps also for Porsches made for the US market.  I have a Eurospec
911.  The purpose for the turn light (either right or left) to remain on
even after the ignition is off is to provide the vehicle with a parking
light.  

If you go to Europe you will see much of this use of the parking light, not
on Porsches alone.  I belief it is a TUF requirement in Germany.  That your
car required a jump suggests a weak battery and/or alternator.

Klaus W. Beyenbach
1981 911 SC
Ithaca, NY

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 12:29:04 EDT
From: edd@suneast.East.Sun.COM (Ed DeBarros - Chelmsford Site Human Resources)
Subject: Re: Senna Questions




Karl writes:

>>I think we will see a >>lot more crashes this year, due to the lack
of active suspension alone :-(

>>The instability caused by pitch changes will cause many high speed
>>handling problems. The lack of traction control mostly effects low
speed handling and is not as much of a safety problem.

>>Lots of Senna discussions which, IMO, is appropriate even here at 
PPhiles, and the other lists dealing with autos that I'm on.


Much of the observations over the last few seasons regarding F1
advances in technology have focused on the areas of traction control,
semi-automatic gearboxes and active suspensions.  Engines have gone
from turbocharged to normally aspirated with, so it seems, no apparent
loss in speed.  So, engines have gotten better at making these cars to
go faster and advances in handling allowed them to take advantage of
the increased power. The loss of traction control and active
suspensions seem to have upset the balance between the car's ability to
make power and keep it on the track, almost like the problems Indy cars
had a few years ago where the performance of the cars exceeded the
capabilities of the track at Indy.
 

What do Pphiles think ?

Is it a balance of technology problem ? Is it a driver problem, i.e., do 
driver's have to re-learn driving skills they lost as a result of using 
active suspension, traction control, etc. or does FISA need limit 
engine power and speed among other things, ( tire width, crashworthiness, 
etc.),to make things safe ?

What is the problem, if there is a problem ?

What is the best way fix it ?


Ed

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 08:23:00 EDT
From: frankc@teleng.eng.telxon.com (Frank Ciotti)
Subject: Re: ('77 924) Turn signal on while engine is off,

> I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
> leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
> the turn lights still remain on. 

This is indeed a feature.  It is intended to allow you to park the car on
a street at night (who would do this, I don't know) and turn on the lights
on the street side of the car so that hopefully someone will see it (and
not hit it).

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 10:56:54 -0500
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: 915 transmission driveshaft flange query RE;

>Subject: 915 transmission driveshaft flange query
>
>I've got a driveshaft flange that has been helicoiled (actually 3 helicoils
>and 1 timesert).  I recently removed and reinstalled the driveshaft, and
>now 1 of the inserts is stripped, and I can't torque the other 3 bolts up
>to spec (60 ft-lbs) without them starting to pull out.  I don't really feel
>like being stranded somewhere with a disconnected driveshaft and I don't want
>to have to check the bolts every week to see if they are working themselves
>out - I want to fix it right.
>
>For you welders out there, could I take the flange out, remove the inserts,
>mostly fill in the holes, and retap the threads?  Would my weld even stick to
>the thing (which is certainly steel, but of unknown metal treatment)?  Or
>should I just get a new flange altogether ($$$?)
>
>It appears to be held on to the transmission by a single bolt in its center,
>torqued to 20-30 ft-lbs.  Does it just have a spline on the other end or
>what?  Will it's removal cause all my $ynthetic gearbox fluid to $pill out?
>
>Thanks,
>Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
>'73 911S Coupe

  Jeff and gang,
  I 'spose the flange is forged steel and not cast iron...
  And since it is junk..you cant make it worse than it is so it might be
worth a go.  How much is a new/recycled flange?  How much to pay for a weld
and precision tap on the flange?  That would seem to determine which path.
  Regardless of which route, you will give the tranny a chance to leak your
lube, so drain it before you start.
  On the welding;
  Eesh, yeah the strip-outs could be weld-filled, but getting the tap to
make a nice hole in the exact same spot might be dicey.  If it were mine,
i might try it just so i could file it away for later..
  But i think i would trust a made right and known good part that had
not been 'diddled' with...the doggone thing just has too much riding 
on it to be trivial.  (cheap insurance)?
  -kyle
  <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.ncr.com>
  73,76 914 2.0

Date: 4 May 1994 09:59:17 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Zone 7 School II Entry Form

Zone 7 School II Entry Form
Well, you've heard at least three of us raving about it.  A number of people
have expressed interest, so here's the enrollment form for the
second session of the 1994 Zone 7 Autocross School.

Info  (copied as directly as possible from the paper form)  :
for Beginning and Intermediate Autocross Drivers
August 6&7, Candlestick Park, San Francisco

Two full days of friendly and expert instruction
Individual attention -- intructors ride in your car
Two people may attend in one car & will still get full track time

$98 per person, includes a copy of _Secrets_of_Solo_Racing, a 192-
page autocrossing hadbood and TWO days of driving.

_Pre_-registration _REQUIRED_  ALL Porsche drivers welcome  You do
_not_ have to be a PCA member  You must be 18 years old to attend

For further information call Henry Watts, 408-245-4040

There was also some suggestion that due to the regulation changes some
of the teams were using a little less wing etc.  One of things that
happened right around the point where Senna should have entered his turn
was the dip in the pavement in which his car seemed to bottom.  Could
coming out of this in combination with less down force have been part
the problem? From the angles that I saw it was hard to tell whether or
not the car veered but component failure must be a big possibility.  I
assume that they may figure that out from looking at the car? 


I too am interested in the exact role of the active suspension... does
it also eat irregularities in the pavement surface or is it more coarse
than that? - more like just a left-right (front-back?) bias change?

Date: Wed, 04 May 94 11:09:36 -0600
From: Jan Bjernfalk <bjernfal@dsd.es.com>
Subject: Re: 951 S 

>Were there any other 88' 951 S's sold in the U.S. through PCNA besides the 
>limited edition model that was silver rose metallic? In 1989 was the standard 
>turbo (951) dropped from the line to be replaced by the 951 S, and just 
>designated 89 944 Turbo?  I realize that model types and release times were 
>different for other parts other the world, so I am just interested in U.S.A 
>PCNA models.
>
>Thanks All,
>
>PS.  After many hours of research and help from fellow members I am finally   
>   starting the 86' 951 clutch job. Wish me luck!!!!!
>
>Mike Kehr


From my readings in old issues of Porsche magazine (d.b.a. Excellence)
there was only the silver rose limited S model in 1988.  1000 units, I think.

In 1989, all 951's had the same specs & mechanicals as the 1988 S-version,
so the older "standard" turbo model was no longer available, and what was the
"S" became the standard package.  It's actually redundant, though 
perhaps helpful, to refer to one of these as an '89 951-S.

Jan Bjernfalk

'89 951 White

Date: 4 May 1994 09:44:40 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  ('77 924) Turn signal o

RE> ('77 924) Turn signal on while engine is off
>I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
>leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
>the turn lights still remain on.

    Actually, I think that this is a designed-in "feature".  (As
in: "That ain't a bug, it's a feature!")  I'm not sure how it's
used in Deutchland, but (at least) early-mid 70's Porsches seem 
to do this.  Both of my 74 914s do.
    If you want to solve this problem, you may need to find a
different signal relay, or maybe a different switch in the steering
column.
    Let us know how it turns out!

- --DD

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 13:07:38 -0400
From: Alex Noordergraaf <noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com>
Subject:  TechTips collection

I have wanted to do this for quite some time, and have finally gotten
around to it [even got Stan's approval].

The combined wisdom present on PorschePhiles is pretty tremendous, and there
are many tidbits of knowledge which are really helpful when debugging
problems.  For instance, when my 1.8L 914 wouldn't idle I was totally stuck
until someone suggested: check the oil filler cap gaskets, which solved my
idle problem entirely!

I would like to collect these tidbits.  I am mostly interested in
914s, but out of respect for the other Porsche models I will also
collect techtips on them as well.

Once I have organized all submitted techtips they will be available for
anonymous ftp from tta.com and be distributed once a month like the FAQ's.
Updates will be made as more submissions are received.  As time permits I
will go through my archives for helpful tips, but I only have 914 stuff.  If
someone would like to do that for the other models, please do!

Submitting a techtip.  Send an e-mail message to 
'techtips@tac3.vv.hac.com'.  Do NOT send the message to my personal
mailbox.  Use your own judgement as to whether you want to post it
to the list.  The subject line on your message should include the
Porsche model that the tip applies to as well as a brief description
of what the techtip addresses.  The body of your message will have 
the techtip.  Please try to keep these short: the one or two liners
that can be SO helpful.  If more people seem to be interested in
longer techtips that can be changed - let me know what you are
interested in.

Please send any comments or suggestions to me at noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com.

Alex

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  4 May 94 08:21:09 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: active suspension and Senna's death



    > What is "active suspension" ?

       Active suspension is to conventional suspension what Electronic
   fuel injection is to a carburetor; imagine that you take what is
   really a very crude mechanical system (a spring and damper shock) and
   replace it with a computer running at 40million calculations+/second
   tied to a hydraulic controller. Yes, active suspsension can be used to 
   invert body lean (Road and track did an article featuring Lotus testbeds
   years ago, showing settings that actually leaned into corners) but the
   significant advantage is in dampening out the normal spring effects
   conventional suspension have.  I saw a demo video GM produced about 8 years
   ago, showing 2 Corvettes (one with, one without A.S.) running across
   obstacles like speed bumps, high-speed dips, railroad-type risers, etc,
   and the difference was almost laughable; the car with conventional 
   suspension would bounce and settle where the A.S. car absolutely glided  
   across bumps as if they weren't even there. The net is a car that
   rides like a Lincoln but within milliseconds cad adapt to handle as stiff 
   as if it had 1" sway bars, hi-rate springs and poly-bushings. 
       If you ever watched recent F1 video, you'd see the difference from
   the car-cams in how much smoother the Williams-Renault car was than 
   the lower technology cars. But claiming that removing these killed Senna
   is simplistic; Senna advocated these because his Williams-Renault team
   was King at making a car with automatic trannys, throttle control, ABS,
   and active suspension and beating everyobody's butt for years; his 
   remarks probably had to do less with his life than his livelihood.  My
   understanding is that the powers-to-be were trying to a)level the playing
   field for the guys who couldn't engineer that well, and b) try to reduce
   the cost out of F1 by restricting the amount of technology needed to 
   compete (Closed-loop traction control was banned from drag racing for 
   the same reasons).  Some cars (Ferrari) were probably more dangerous with
   their unrefined A.S. than without. F1's efforts at removing technology and 
   Turbos makes a lot more sense than, for instance, talk of removing ground
   effects in Indy cars to "slow the drivers down for safety reasons"
   (spreading oil on the track would have the same effect).  Plenty of other 
   teams have managed to keep drivers alive without this technology for
   years, having it was part of the reason Senna won so much and made so 
   much. 
     The most remarkable reminder of Senna's crash is that so many crash at
   ridiculously high speeds and walk away. If any technology was missing for
   Senna, could it have been a barrier of $50 barrels ??
    
                                                                    
 






Automatic trannys, active suspension, ABS,
   throttle control was 






  
       


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 20:55:39 +0200
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@janus.hut.fi>
Subject: tire pressures

Hello netters,

At inspecting the tirewear of my 944 the other day a simple question  
occured me that I couldn't figure out. Given the car's 50/50 weight  
distribution on the axis how come the recommended (manual) tire  
pressures are uneven at 2/2.5 bar (29/36 psi)? Seems to me that the  
usual load of a driver and at most one  passenger cannot much off-set  
the weight distribution as they are sitting quite close to center of  
gravity. So if no serious luggage is carried what is the point of the  
tire difference in pressure? Is it just to make sure that there is no  
wheel damage in bottoming out in with unusually heavy load in the  
back? If I know that I do not have it am I better of with even  
pressures? (I have identical tires&wheels all around but the manual  
seems to indicate that the right pressures are independent of some  
changes like 215 versus 205 etc.).

Mehr Licht, bitte.

Kari Eloranta
