Date: 4 May 1994 15:15:09 -0500
From: "Sarah Sprafka" <sallys@kccgw.com.msu.edu>
Subject: Play in shifter

                       Subject:                               Time:3:11 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          Play in shifter                        Date:5/4/94
  L.E. writes "Checking the shifter linkgage last night, I discovered that the
shift coupler
(behind the front seats, under an inspection plate on a 911) had some play.

It can be traced to a plastic bushing. The bushing has elongated in the
forward/
backward direction (not up/down). It is about 1mm per direction. THis actually
translates to about 1/2" of free play at the shift lever.

I know there are replacement bushings available. Is the play normal? I would
think that you would want NO PLAY in this critical part. Am I right?

Also, has anyone replaced the bushings? The shift coupler is held by a square
head screw to the trans, and by a C clamp to the shifter... Once I remove it,
Is the shaft on the coupler a press fit? Can it be hammered out with a drift?"

No the play is not normal.  I experienced that in a 914 1.7L.  There was a lot
of play in the shifter when the car was in gear, which was not good.  I did not
personally replace the bushing, however the person who did indicated it was a
reasonably straightforward job.  Not much wisdom here, but a little experience
with the phenomenon.  Good luck.

Having gone to only a few Autocross/Driver School/Track Events I've
noticed a range of tool/equipment commitments:
(1) the full team with trailer, compressor, full equipment to do almost
    everything ever imaginable to the car.
(2) the SO drives another vehicle with jack, jack stands, a couple of tool
    boxes, lunch and items found to be critical in previous disasters and
    near disasters.
(3) the one-car set-up, where everything you might need has to fit in the
    car you're going to drive.  Seems this usually means some milk crates
    to hold everything and a (blue?) tarp to cover it up.
My request focusses upon the one-car bundle of tools & stuff. Are there any
experienced trackies who'll share their INVENTIVE additions to the one-car
setup! (Example: The other day at our local track event, heavy twisties
(like for garbage bags) were used to hold up parts of a Cool Brake Kit.)

Date:  Wed, 4 May 1994 17:00:41 -0400
From: STEVE.STOMSKI@gsa2.sprint.com
Subject:  Shift Bushings

    Lou-

    I think you may be a confussing the bushings in your shift
    linkage.  The bushings that are readily replaceable are the ones
    at the bottom of the shifter (one is a collar the other a cap that
    the ball sits in).  The coupler that you are talking about (the
    one under the inspection plate behind the front seats in the
    tunnel), at least to my knowledge, does not have a replaceable
    bushing-  the whole unit must be replaced.  I would not, however,
    jump out and spend the $60 or so to replace it just because of the
    play you mention:  as I recall, there is a significant amount of
    free play even in the new units.  I agree as to not wanting any
    play, but it is there.  AS for the coupler itself, it comes off
    by loosening the C clamp blot and by taking the lock/set bolt
    (square head screw) out of the coupler and shaking it off.

    I hope this helps.

    Steven Stomski

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 16:18:44 EST
From: reid_zeigler@merck.com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: shift play



Lou Writes:

>It can be traced to a plastic bushing. The bushing has elongated
>in the forward/backward direction (not up/down). It is about 
>1mm per direction. THis actually translates to about 1/2" of
>free play at the shift lever.


The bushing is actually made that way in order to reduce
vibration back to the shift stalk. Even if you replace the
shift knuckle, the new part would be about the same. The bushing
isn't sold as a separate part, to my knowledge, but you can make
one out of Delrin or Nylatron and insert it as you said.

The biggest cause of sloppiness is the two bushings up front.
They're cheap and fairly easy to replace.

 - Reid (zeigler@merck.com)
        '73 911E

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  4 May 94 13:19:30 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Re; Senna Questions

> Our local commentators (including Grand Prix winner Alan Jones) analysed
> the accident and identified a probable suspension failure at the
> entrance to the corner. The car in fact veers right into the Armco
> instead of even attempting to turn left.
I would be very skeptical of a media commentator "analyzing" a crash 
[U.S. spelling!], unless s/he saw Senna's car's right side at the 
fateful corner and clearly saw a suspension problem.  The video from 
ESPN (USA) which came via Italian sources, showed a blurred image of 
the car plowing off the corner, completely intact as viewed from the 
left side.  The image was blurry due to tube-type cameras with 
attendant phosphorus lag, rather than solid state pickups.

> I saw the accident on TV live and it seemed survivable, but I guess
> luck ran out for Senna.
Going into a nearly immovable wall at 186mph at an angle around 60 
degrees is *far* from survivable, due to the rate of deceleration.  In 
Senna's case, extreme skull & brain damage resulted, _possibly_ from 
the deceleration, possibly also from his head hitting the wall or 
cockpit surrounds, or from striking a wheel (etc.) at the moment of impact.

High speed accidents become survivable when speed is reduced rapidly 
but at a rate below human limits (thought to be around 40-45 g's), via 
sand traps, deformable barriers, destructable vehicles, stretchable 
seatbelts, and helmets that distribute impact force around the head.  
Hitting at shallow angles (approaching parallel to the wall) also 
aren't as bad, since the deadly component is *not* the car's forward 
speed, but its speed in the direction of the wall, which will be 
substantially less.

>> Someone who did a thorough inspection of the replays suggested that the
>> front wing came loose and impacted Senna's head.  This, if true, would
>> explain the extent of the head injuries.
The wing looked attached OK prior to the collision, though the video 
was blurry as mentioned above.  It might have been loose enough to 
provide no downforce, but it was definitely at the front of the car and 
pointed correctly.

After the collision, pieces were everywhere.  Who can tell what hit his 
head?  IMHO, it's not fair for any amateur / announcer looking at 
crummy video to decide, and publish, statements which could easily be 
construed as facts.  I'm hoping that factual investigation and detailed 
analysis will give us an answer.  The phrase "probable suspension 
failure" sounds more authoritative than "possible suspension failure" 
or "I'm guessing it was suspension failure", etc.  Besides, hitting a 
wall at 186mph is enough right there to kill; an accelerated 10 lb (?) 
wing hitting a helmet is "in the noise" at that point!

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 1994 13:10:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Matsumura <tedm@rahul.net>
Subject: Re: air filter

I was wondering if anyone uses their K&N in a CIS airbox with pop off 
valve?  My situation is that my pop off valve goes off every few days due 
to the cold start not hooked up.  On occasion it can also knock open the 
airbox.  I have dents in my paper filter from the pop off valve, and 
would want to make sure that the K&N "gives" rather than possibly 
damaging the pop off valve.

Also, more air doesn't equal more power.  You can drive a 911 without an 
air filter and without the air box attached, and you're not necessarily 
going to get more power.

I would be interested in prices and souces of aluminum air boxes.  The 
plastic one seems chintzy, especially the way the two straps attach the 
cover.

Ted

> >ea on paper filters.  The K&Ns for a CIS 911 are about $40.  Then

> >and re-use it.

Date:         Wed, 04 May 94 17:39:26 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 944 Fan Switch Problem

On Wed, 4 May 1994 10:50:08 -0400 Joseph said:
>It always works in position 4 (the super high speed).  It is tempermental and
>works once in a while in the lower speeds (1, 2, or 3).  It doesn't seem to
>make any difference if the A/C is on or off.  It does seem to make a difference
>in the outside ambient temperature.  It worked properly, to the best of my
>recollection during the past winter.  Now that it has started to warm up
>a bit, it is unstable.  It was also unstable last summer as I recall but I
>didn't worry about it.

Same problem here in my '87 944S.  Pos 4 works all the time but sometimes
it stops in pos 1,2, and 3.  If I have the A/C on in pos 4 (to cool the
car) and then turn to 3, fan stops.  Back to pos 4, fan is on full. I've done
two things to get it working. One is, turn A/C off, turn fan off, then
turn fan on to pos 1,2, or 3, then turn A/C on.  It will continue to
run ok in that fan pos.  I've also had some luck, rotating the fan speed
switch rapidly back and forth. I've also noted the voltmeter drop ever
so slightly when I rotate the switch, so there's voltage going somewhere.
I haven't been able to consistently reproduce the problem to debug it.

Darren

good tire pressure gauge.  Any recommendations?

Date: Wed,  4 May 94 16:44:46 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: adjusting Motronic timing

I tried sending this directly to ANTHONY.KELLEY%MSFC2PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov,
but the mailer couldn't deliver it, so I am posting to the list...
- ----------
| From:  <netmail!ANTHONY.KELLEY%MSFC2PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov>
|
| >I have an '84 944.  Its ignition timing is retarded suficiently to
| >prevent detonation with low octane fuel.  I recently switched to using
| >high octane gas exclusively.
| >It seems that a modest HP gain could be realized by
| >advancing the spark somewhat.  Is this true and do any of
| >the aftermarket chips provide this?
|     -----------------------------------------------------------------
|     It is true that a modest gain could be realized by advancing the spark.
|      I would be happy to advance it for you for a small fee.
|
|     The DME's can be adjusted manually via the FQS (fuel quality switch) to
|     one of eight positions that will retard the spark 3 degrees and/or
|     increase the fuel injection pulse width in order to allow operation
|     with lower octane fuels.  BTW, this switch can be re-programmed to
|     *advance* the spark and to allow custom fuel injection settings.  As
|     delivered, the DME's do not automatically compensate for low octane
|     fuel.  This applies to normally aspirated Bosch Motronic systems.
|     --ken house-----keeno racing team electronics repairs Motronics.

Your mentioning the FQS rings a bell.  I will have to look through the service
manual and the Bosch Motronic technical handbook to see if I can figure
out how to do this myself.  Any details that you could provide would
certainly be appreciated.

Does reprogramming the FQS require a new DME chip?

On a related note, I have been wondering how much of an asset
my PC programming experience would be in understanding the
DME.  I imagine some specialized equipement would be needed
to do any modifications (i.e. a logic analyzer, an EPROM burner, etc).

Thanks,

    Eric

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 19:39:28 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Turn signal lights

I don't have a true "fix" for the turn signal lights-on problem,
but described below is an enhancement that made it a non-issue for me.

My solution for the turn signal remaining on problem was to get a 
"Light Reminder" from K-MART and add a few sense diodes to make it detect
the different lights-remaining-on problems.  It cost ~$5.00 US.

The K-MART device has a beeper and a red LED.

I don't know if they still stock them.  Probably J.C. Whitney does.

The explanation below assumes not everyone has an electronics background,
read with this in mind.

The "Light Reminder" is a two lead device that is connected between the
headlight supply voltage and the ignition on supply voltage. 

When the car ignition is on and the lights are on, both "Light Reminder" leads 
are at 12 volts, since there is no potential difference the device doesn't beep
or the LED flash.   

If you turn the ignition off and leave the lights on, one light reminder
terminal is at +12 volts since it is connected to the lights and the other
terminal is connected to ground through the ignition coil/CDI/oil 
pressure light.

So the light reminder senses "Lights on" AND "ignition off".

It will beep (for ~10 seconds) and flash the LED (continuously).

If the lights are off and the ignition is on, the "Light Reminder"
sees 12 volts but inverted from the previous sense, and it doesn't beep/flash.

You could use several "Light Reminders" to monitor each condition but
I wanted one "Light Reminder" to sense if I left the 911 turn signal in left
or right mode, the parking lights on or the headlights on.

The "Light Reminder" can sense the different lighting circuits with 
some diode logic.   Any 100V, 0.5A diode is adequate, the popular 1N4004 at 
400V and 1A is fine. 

The diodes isolate each lighting circuit from the others, so one circuit
will not feed the others unintentionally. 

                                         __________  diodes 
                                        /
                                       V 
                                        
       parking light fuse ------------>|-----|
                                             |
       left turn signal fuse---------->|-----|
                                             |
       right turn signal fuse--------->|-----|
                                             |
       headlamp supply fuse----------->|-----|
                                             |
                                             |
                                     -------------------
                                     |                  |
                                     |  Light Reminder  |
                                     |                  |
                                     |                  |
                                     --------------------
                                              |
        to ignition on ------------------------


The 911 fuse box has convenient screw terminals, one wire was run from
the passenger compartment to the 4 diodes which terminated at the screw
terminal box.

The Light Reminder was mounted under the dash and was connected to
the "ignition-on" wire.

I installed this on my 1972 911T, 1969T and even my 71 VW bus, ~3 years ago.
I haven't accidentally left the lights on since.

It preserves the "leave the lights on one side" mode but warns you
it is happening. 

A 12V buzzer could be used in place of the light minder if a continuous
beep was O.K.   If the buzzer is not polarity sensitive, and 
the multiple diode logic assembly is not used, at least one diode must be 
in series, otherwise the buzzer will buzz with both lights on-ignition off 
and also in the "lights off-ignition on" normal daylight driving case.


John Wright

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 20:39:02 PDT
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: C2 vs. C4


I have the 1990 C4 that was used in the auto-x school.  I heard that in the 
hands of a race driver, the C4 is at a disadvantage in handling to the C2.  I 
also heard the same thing about the ABS system.  I assume the driver can't 
get the car to do certain things that a race driver would want out of a race 
car.  The C4 also weighs more than the C2.

After using my car in the auto-x school, I no longer think the C4 was at that 
much of a disadvantage.  I liked how it handled there and I really think that 
it is a lot harder to spin out in a C4 vs. the C2.  I don't have any 
experience on the C2 but my instructor has a Carrera and he drove a C4 at the 
school where he said that he couldn't get the "tail" of the C4 to "push" out 
like he normally does with his own 911.  Also at the slalom portion of the 
course where he would normally "feather" the gas and control the car from 
spinning out, he suggested that with my C4 I should just gas it on through.  
I don't know if these comments are complimentary or critical, but you do have 
to drive the C4 differently than a C2 to get the most performance.
             
I do know that the 89 & 90 C2/4 had a problem with the factory alarm system.  
If you took your radio out (which is connected to the car alarm) the alarm 
will not sound nor will the lights flash.  It just seems normal, but in 
reality your alarm is going off without the visual and audio warnings.  The 
next day, your battery will be dead!  I understand the factory corrected this 
problem for latter years.

Quincy Dong (born-again C4 lover!) 
QLD1@pge.com




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 May 94 20:10:01 PDT
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: Zone 7 auto-x school

> Ditto Dave and Mark.  Last weekend's school was a blast.  I have not
> yet stopped having flashbacks!  One of my favorites is a right hand 
> sweeping turn at full throttle with the instructor screaming GAS, GAS,
> GAS, GAS in my ear.  The start/finsih line was near the exit of the
> turn, and I remember thinking that I would probably kill the flagger
> (who should have been positioned on the other side of the course,
> IMHO) if this pedal-to-the-metal idea didn't work.  But, I followed
> instructions and, of course, the car went around the turn on rails
> just fine.

Milo, I remember that turn.  I think the flagger was safe from you.  I was in 
my instructor's car at that turn in front of the trailer where we did a 360 
on his pratice run--just before crossing the timer.  What was funny, he 
didn't hit any cones on that 360 and proceeded to his timed run.  All I could 
remember was holding on, smelling the rubber from the screaching tires and 
dirt being throwned into the car during the spin.  I still learned something 
from that run--I could still go faster in my own car on that turn, since I 
couldn't approach his speed at that point anyway.  I didn't have the same 
concern you had, all I could do was keep my eyes on the track and look for 
the apex.  I barely noticed the flag whenever I passed the flagger.

I've never had so much runs pushing my car to the limit before.  The $98 
bucks was cheap, concerning the amount of track time we had.  Nothing like 
knowing the limits of your car before you really need it on the streets.

There is another Zone 7 auto-x school in August at Candlestick again if 
anybody is interested.  Maybe the wind won't be as bad during the summer 
there.  
                                                         
I was impressed by how well organized the event was.  It was so organized, 
that we were able to get more runs than I thought possible.  The school is 
where you get two full days of driving vs. about 5 minutes at an actual 
autocross, but then again you don't get a trophy at the school.

Quincy Dong
Metallic Dark Red C4

Date: Thu, 5 May 1994 00:02:14 -0500
From: schless@iastate.edu
Subject: 951 audio systems


Howdy Triet


Just a coincedance I guess but I was working on my
car audio just last weekend (in my 951)

I decided to change the speaker setup in the rear.
(under the hatch).  There was a set of 6x9 Pyle woofers
back there wich were just soso.  They where mounted into
plywood custom fited into the rear under the carpet ect..

I removed those 6x9 and the plywood and found some
new 1/5 in. plywood for the new SUBS.
I carefully crafted the new plywood so it fits
all the way across the back under the carpet
(it is split in 2 pieces because of wedge shape of compartment.

I installed the 2x100W Toshiba Amp in the spare tire well
(no heat buildup probs yet) 
I Installed the two eight 8 in. subs in the side pockets
and wired it up!  (line level and power lines installed
on previous hellish occasion)

Fired it up and tuned in the Techno Station WOW
How did I live without SUBS!  What a Whimpy system 
I had without Them!!

I think The Tubes would be a good alternative to
if you dont have a jigsaw or bandsaw, but I love
making things! (

Maby I could make some of the plywood boards for sell
if there is an interest.

Note: the carpet over pockets had holes cut in them for
    6x9 so I had to buy some 'close match' US style
    carpet.  It is a very close color match to 
	the beige color so its OK.

- ---
Your have a squeel in your system?  the only thing
that comes to mind is positive feedback or some
sort of improper signal grond problem with amps ect..
(most amp outputs can NOT touch ground..they are
floating (i think thta the word))

In my 86 the smallish rectangular speakers where replaced
They are fairly common size and there in ample room behind
them.  Just remove the 4 phillips screws any pull off
wire conectors.  Go buy a set of Polk or Infinity or ?
that match old screw holes (watch outside diminsions).
- --oops i'mm talking about door and back seat spks--

Send a note if more questions

p c schlesselmann

Date: Thu, 5 May 94 07:06:20 +0200
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: active suspension

 Just a minor comment on active suspension:

I visited University of Cranfield (GB) during the water on runway trials for
our Saab 2000 aircraft. It turned out that they had been involved in the 
development of the active suspension for the Lotus F1. They told me that
it was very difficult to optimize this system, especially if you would
have it in a street car. The initial testing was made with a Lotus Esprit
(Turbo?) and it was indeed interesting to see the same car with "normal"
suspension in that same turn. The car with the normal suspension "rolled"
significantly while the active suspension car didn't roll at all. 

If the active suspension quit to work the car was almost undrivable and could
be dangerous why it was difficult to add this feature to a production street
car.

Does anyone know if any car is sold with active suspension today?

Magnus Ottenstrvm
Sweden

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 May 94 05:26:00 UTC
From: w.oconnell4@genie.geis.com
Subject: Buy a repainted 911? Help

Stefan Reitshamer asked:
  I'm going to look at an 85 911 today that was repainted
  several years ago. The current (2nd) owner says the first owner
  "scratched the right side of it" and had the entire car repainted
  (by the dealer, he thinks).
  He wants $18.5k, which is a rather cheap; I'm guessing he didn't
  pay that much for it.
  Should I stay away from this car? Otherwise, it sounds like it
  could be in very good shape.
 
A nine year old 911 that was repainted is not all that strange.  A good
friend has a body shop that does alot of Porsche restoration work and it
usually has at least one in for a repaint to get rid of assorted stone
chips, dings, etc.  I am always amazed at how many will get a full repaint
rather than just the panel but they want to be sure that everything matches.
Assuming the re-paint was done right, treat it as a plus.  Any good shop
should be able to check the car out to insure it is as advertised.
 
Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA
 81 SC Pacific Blue - Die Luft-Keule fur Manner

was the Glockler Porsche, introduced by German race car designer/ driver
Walter Glockler (pronounced Gluckler)). Built in both rear- and mid-engi-

the track, but also in influencing Porsche's ... 550 series..." said

the Mrozer Spyder.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 May 1994 01:48:54 -0700
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: L0u

{{{{







Subj:  Re: Shifter play

Date:  94-05-05 02:54:44 EDT

From: MAESTRO132@aol.com

To:     Porschephiles@tta.com



Len writes:



>Checking the shifter linkgage last night, I discovered that the 

>shift coupler (behind the front seats, under an inspection plate 

>on a 911) had some play. It can be traced to a plastic bushing. 

>The bushing has elongated in the forward/backward direction 

>(not up/down). It is about 1mm per direction. 

>THis actually translates to about 1/2" of free play at the shift lever.



>...Is the play normal? I would think that you would want NO PLAY 

>in this critical part. Am I right?



>Also, has anyone replaced the bushings? 



Dear Len:





           You, sir, have a 356/912 Style Linkage-U Joint- congratulations!
They last a loooong time, until their plastic bushings fail, then the
shifter play becomes a sight to behold (brings a new dimension to the word
"loose"), with the possible loss of a set of gears (like third and fourth),
as happened just this weekend to a guy who had just bought an Original
California 1964 356C and was about to drive it back to Taxachusetts when he
suddenly found himself without third and fourth gear. Realizing that it
would be a Drag to drive 'cross country in a 356 in First and Second, he
called me at (408) 727-1864, and through the miracle of telephonic
problem-solving I was able to diagnose his problem and provide him with
another U-joint (exchange).

    Now, first of all- there SHOULD be some play- oh, 1/8" gap or so but
only in the fore-aft direction- that is for taking up positioning errors and
is Perfectly Normal.

     Second, the "repair" of the U-joint is best left to a machine shop that
knows how. The steel "T" must be pressed apart without damaging the aluminum
yoke.  Then the plastic bushings must be installed in the eyes of the yoke
(and just try this without a few Special Tools),  and then the steel "T"
piece must be pressed back together without damaging anything (again, just
try this without Special Tools and see what happens! That's why there are so
many broken yokes stuffed with pieces of rubber tire.)  

   I save up the bushingless U-Joints, and then we spend an afternoon
rebuilding a bunch at a time. Much more efficient that way- and Time is such
that ifin your 911 is more than 20 years old and its U-joint hasn't failed
yet- just wait a few months (or years),  and they will!

      So,  ifin you someday suddenly notice TREMENDOUS "slop" in the
gearshifter, peel back that rubber protector in front of the trans, and
watch the pieces of plastic bushing fall out of the rubber protector! The
pieces were the plastic bushings. 

    One-half inch slop in the gearshifter isn't Tremendous slop. You'll know
Tremendous slop when it happens- guaranteed!  More likely, you  might have a
failed bushing under the gearshifter in the little "cup". They're almost
always bad, but they never seem to improve the shifter action much after
replacement. The results of replacing a bad U-joint bushing, however WILL
surprise you! Happily so!

    Should you have to replace the U-joint, no drift is needed, just remove
the safety wire around the square bolt with the conical end and remove the
square, conical bolt. (it DOES have safety wire through it doesn't it? You
WILL replace the safety wire afterwards, won't you? If not, the conical
bolts comes loose and you lose gears, and ultimately, you lose the square
conical bolt- which mean that you LOSE! As it's the ONLY SQUARE CONICAL BOLT
in the whole car! And damn hard to find when you need one. Don't ask me how
I know.

     Then, loosen the pinch bolt at the U-joint/long-linkage-rod-interface
and the U-joint can usually be coaxed out. Don't let a drift or a hammer
near the damn thing.

   Oh, and One More Thing in this single-spaced comment- make sure you
scribe a MARK on the U-joint where the linkage rod fits over it, at the
pinch bolt and through one of the "flutes" of the linkage rod, and remember
which flute you used!  That way, you, like the guy this weekend, might just
get all the gears back, First Try, upon reconnection, without spending many
happy hours using Trial & Error techniques attempting to get Reverse or 4th
to make its appearance from the ether!

     And should you ever find yourself trying to find just such a "missing"
gear, don't forget that the linkage rod moves in the OPPOSITE direction to
the gearshift lever because it's on the other side of the fulcrum, so if the
gearshifter needs to go more "forward", you gotta get the shifter at the
U-joint to go more "rearward"! Don't ask me how I know all this.



      Don't mess with the U-joint unless you have too!  And:



      KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!



      The Maestro :p

Date: Thu, 5 May 1994 07:49:30 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: RE:  fan switch problem


I just fixed a similar problem in a Honda.  It turned out that the
commutator had become dirty.  The lower voltage applied at lower
fan speed numbers was not sufficient to overcome the high resistance
between the brushes and the commutators.  The solution was to take the
motor apart and clean and polish the commutators.  After that, the
motor worked like a champ.  It sure beat the $250+ for a replacement.

John Smaardyk

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 May 94 09:19:55 EDT
From: len1@sos.att.com (L.E.Nicotra-WH-77122H(WH5672)W214)
Subject: 911/914 Shit Linkage Play Summary

Porsche Friends:
	The following is a summary of responses to my question on 911/914
shift linkage play question.

Subject: '84 Carrera, 28K Miles (for comparison reasons...)
Diagnostic: About 1/2" play on stickshift when in gear forward/backward
Question: Is this normal?
Mechanical check: Shift coupler connecting gear lever to trans has a plastic
	bushing. Noticed play of about 2mm total. 

Summary of responses:

A play of about 1/2" is both normal and needed. Keeps the car in gear while
engine moves around in mounts, and reduces shifter rattles.

Failure mode presents itself as TREMENDOUS "slop" in the gearshifter with
the innability to get car into 3/4 gears.

Most likely culprits for linkage play are shift lever bushings under gearshift
lever. They are cheap and fairly easy to replace. Four screws hold the shifter
assembly to the floor.

For those that need to replace the bushing in the shift coupler, they are 
available as replacement parts from mail order suppliers (Automotion, 
AJR Racing, Stoddard, etc.) The coupler shaft can be driven out with a 
drift to get to the bushings.

Warning: Adjusting the shift linkage after removal of the shift
coupler might be tricky. Might pay to mark alignment befor removal...

So there you have it folks! I hope that this is both useful and informative.

Thanks to all that responded to my original posting including the Maestro and
Bruce Anderson (yes Bruce!)...

Happy motoring!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len1@sos.wh.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo

Date: 5 May 94 12:17:50 GMT
From: mvmas@mvusa.att.com
Subject: porschephiles@tta.com

Another way the clutch cable can go on a 914 is at the back end, where you
have that 2" roller on which the cable does a U-turn.  There is a rubber boot
right before that to minimize the amount of the cable exposed, but if it is
in bad shape or falls off, the grease usually on the cable and roller will
capture dirt and pebbles.  These will eventually grind through it.

Mark A. Skala              "The honda civic del-sol: NOT a new idea!"
mvmas@mvusa.att.com

Date: 5 May 94 14:43:28 GMT
From: mvmas@mvusa.att.com
Subject: re: 914 problem

[This is a re-send.  I haven't seen my message, and it's been a week or so.]

>Porschephiles:  I have a problem with my 1973 914 2.0 L. When I start it
>up, and either creep along or accelerate slowly, the engine speed
>oscillates, so that it lunges forward and then slows down with a period of
>about 1 second. The engine doesn't cut out completely, just slows down.
>This lunging stops after the engine warms up. My first thought is to ignore
>it, since I can avoid it by keeping engine rpm up. My second thought is
>that the throttle position sensor (?) has a dirty place at semi-closed
>position. Maybe the mixture at startup is far too rich? What do people
>think? Where should I look first? Thanks, Michael

well, assuming I understand your definition of the problem, I have had about
the same thing.  I didn't really try to fix it, it happened by accident while
messing around with the system.  The pressure sensor on some 914's has epoxy
over the end plug, and some don't.  My current car didn't, so I took the
plug out, and there's an adjustment screw in there.  Turning it too far one
way seemed to have the effect of having to push the throttle a good distance
before the engine would accelerate the car.  Turning it too far the other
way would make the car buck as you describe.  It's most drivable set just
barely away from where it's bucking.

Of course this is all assuming that you have a working throttle position
sensor, are you aware that you can take the black cover off the switch
without removing it from the car?  

YMMV, I'm not sure whether what I did covered up some other minor problem,
or if it compensated for the engine's high mileage.

Mark Skala             Porsche: the best defense is a good offense.
mvmas@mvusa.att.com

Subject: 951S Production Numbers

Mike Kehr asked:
>Were there any other 88' 951 S's sold in the U.S. through PCNA besides the 
>limited edition model that was silver rose metallic? In 1989 was the standard 
>turbo (951) dropped from the line to be replaced by the 951 S, and just 
>designated 89 944 Turbo?  I realize that model types and release times were 
>different for other parts other the world, so I am just interested in U.S.A 
>PCNA models.

Jan Bjernfalk <bjernfal@dsd.es.com> replied:

>>From my readings in old issues of Porsche magazine (d.b.a. Excellence)
>>there was only the silver rose limited S model in 1988. 1000 units, I think.
							  ^^^^^^^^^^^
Actually, only 470 and 700 951S were made in 1988 and 1989 respectively.  This 
is according to "The Illustrated Buyer's Guide" by Dean Batchelor.  As someone 
already stated, the 'S' designation was dropped in 1989 since that was the 
only 951 available.

Date: Thu,  5 May 94 10:09:23 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Fan Switch Problem

> From: Darren Evans-Young  <netmail!DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
> To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
> Subject: Re: 944 Fan Switch Problem
> >It always works in position 4 (the super high speed).  It is 
tempermental and
> >works once in a while in the lower speeds (1, 2, or 3).

> Same problem here in my '87 944S.  Pos 4 works all the time but sometimes
> it stops in pos 1,2, and 3.

I forgot to mention something in my posting 5 minutes ago.  Fan speed 4 
bypasses the dropping resistor bank entirely, which is why it works 
even when speeds 0-3 might not.

Also, the switch itself, or related wiring, could be getting 
dirty/defective.  Personally, my first area to attack would be the 
resistor bank.  Mine had this identical problem when it was new.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 05 May 1994 11:41:27 -0400 (EDT)
From: ALW1@delphi.com
Subject: supercharging


I have gotten a number of inquiries about supercharging since I left
a note stating my experience with having my '87 911 supercharged.
I thought it more appropriate to answer them all at one time, just in
case someone else has the same questions and doesn't feel 
comfortable asking.
 
First, I must correct the comment about a record at Road Atlanta. 
I apparently misunderstood Tommy Vann, at German Auto, talking
about his supercharged 911's having really fast times at Road Atlanta. 
I thought he was talking about record times - the mistake was mine, 
not his.
 
Second, the cost to supercharge your 911 depends on which model 
you have. 
 
If you have an SC or a Carrera, the cost for the kit is $4,495. Tommy
 says that it takes him 25 hours to install the supercharger, and he
 charges $45 per hour. That means you would have to spend another
 $1,125 to have them install it, for a grand total of expense of $5,620. 
You do have the option of doing it yourself or getting someone else to
 install it for you.  
 
If you have a C2 or a C4 the cost goes up to $13,000. ( I don't know if 
that is the kit alone or the kit plus installation - you would need to call
about that.)  According to Tommy, they use the wipple supercharger
on those cars,  versus the paxton on the SC and Carrera, and much
much more work has to be done.
 
Third, for the SC and Carrera there are no internal engine
modifications needed. Some things in the engine compartment have
to be moved around, a new chip is put in the Carreras and a new
ignition system is put in the SCs, but that is aboutit.
 
Fourth, when I talked to Tommy today to get my facts straight, 
he said if anyone is interested in more details, he can be reached at
(615) 691-1541. This is a direct line to his office; the number I left in the
last message was to German Auto, which then must direct the call to
him. He would rather you just call him directly.
 
Fifth, Tommy is just getting on American Online and I hope to soon
have himJjoin the Porschephiles group so he can answer your
questions directly. 
 
Finally, I am not connected with German Auto; I am just a very
satisfied customer. I just love the 911 and am thrilled with the extra
power I now have.  If it has given me so much satisfaction, I assume
that other people may be interested too. If I can answer anymore
questions, please drop me a note, or ifany of you get to Western North
Carolina and want to see my car, let me know.
 
Al Wagener

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 May 94 09:51:49 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Fan Switch Problem

> From: Joseph I. Wiesenfeld  <netmail!joew@joew.us.dg.com>
> Subject: 944 Fan Switch Problem
> Date: Wednesday, May 4, 1994 10:50AM
>
> I hope that one of the net wizards can help me with a problem with the fan
> switch on my '89 944S2.
> It always works in position 4 (the super high speed).  It is tempermental and
> works once in a while in the lower speeds (1, 2, or 3).  It doesn't seem to
> make any difference if the A/C is on or off.
There's a dropping resistor bank with thermal circuit breakers under 
the wiper area cover.  Most likely you've got an "open" on one of the contacts.

Pull the plastic cover, find the bank, and clean the contacts.  Check 
for connection integrity.  This should fix the problem.

		JBS

Date: Thu, 05 May 1994 07:47:07 -0700
From: kweber@fmiapd.com
Subject:  '72 911S - Converting MFI to EFI

Oh yes, this should excite the purists.

I'm considering converting a worn-out stock MFI system on a '72 911S
to a full-featured Electronic ignition and injection management
system, probably using a system available from Motec.  Briefly, this
would involve adding sensors to the engine (crank timing,
temperatures, air mass and temp, etc) adding electronic injectors and
removing the distributor to replace it with a direct-fire ignition.
The electronics part is not a problem for me, but I am concerned
about (1) placement of the injectors, and (2) suitability of the
stock cam for such a set-up.  I *hope* that the electronic injectors
would be well-located in the old MFI positions, and that the MFI cam
is just a suitable for EFI.

So, does anyone have any experience on such a project, or even some
constructive comments?  Many of you have far more 2.4L MFI experience
than I do.  Thanks in advance.

Ken Weber        kweber@fmiapd.com

Date: Thu, 5 May 1994 07:53:03 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Another tire pressure question

Seeing a question about tire pressures reminded me of one I had.  At
several gas stations the employees have asserted that the recommended
tire pressures in a car's driver's manual should not be believed, and
that you should always fill up to the maximum pressure rating provided
by the tire manufacturer.  (I know, consider the source, right?)  The
story is that the car builder has different concerns than the tire
builder, like "softer ride" or "less noise," and the tire maker knows
at which pressure the tire performs best.  I'm just curious whether
anyone else has heard this story, and whether there's anything to it.

- --Walt Thode

Date:  Thu, 5 May 1994 10:58:38 -0400
From: STEVE.STOMSKI@gsa2.sprint.com
Subject:  Ed's request for comments

    Ed-

    Several years ago, when Porsche was doing so well on most of the
    racing circuits of the world, the sanctioning bodies decided to
    change the rules (presumably to foster competition).  After
    contending with mid-stream rule changes so many times, Porsche
    finally decided that its racing budget could no longer handle
    having to re-tool each time it got competitive.  Eventually
    Porsche was out of racing because of the
    sanctioning bodies' god playing.

    Like Porsche, Senna too is out of racing because of an
    organization that is a victim  of lobbyists
    (why the teams don't just spend the
    money on engineering instead of lobbying is probably because a
    rule change is cheaper to buy than a team of top-notch designers).

    Some of you may take exception to my comments that Senna's death
    was caused by the rule changes (or even that Porsche's absence
    from the racing world in the form of a works team was due to
    the rule changes).  Fine, I will admit
    that it is in part speculation.  But, give me a break, F1 and Indy
    car racing is not historic racing: it is the cutting edge of the
    technology, and as such it is intended to evolve.  If a company is
    not competive in either manufacturing or designing a race car for
    Indy or F1, then take your car to another series.  Lets reserve at
    least some series for the best drivers, cars, crews, and
    technology-  after all, how are we going to make progress in
    the industry without such a venue?

    With each F1 team worth several (or is that many?) millions of
    dollars a year, a limit on technology is not going to make a
    significant reduction in the cost of competing (Gee, now that
    active suspension is outlawed in F1, I think I'll take a second
    out on my house, put a team together, and join the circuit!!!-  IN
    MY DREAMS).  But seriously, even with a reduction in technology
    necessary to compete, the teams with the most money are still
    going to win- it has proven itself over and over again.  So, the
    ones that end up with the short end of the stick are the Sennas
    the Porsches, and of course the industry (and ultimately the
    consumer, who won't see the technology on the market -- ABS
    anyone?).

    In closing, I too would like to express my grief over the loss of
    a great man and a great competitor.  Senna touched the lives of
    many fans (me included) with a tenacious dedication and
    brilliant expertise -- characteristics we all can use
    in our everyday lives.  And throughout he remained a decent,
    caring man.  He will be missed.


    Steven Stomski

------------------------------

The NordStern region of the Porsche Club of America has a very active racing 
and autox schedule at BIR, BlackHawk, and assorted other places as well as 
concours, rallys, and vintage racing.  Neighboring regions have similar events 
that welcome PCA members to places such as Elkhart Lake which IMHO is the best 
track in North America.  You need to be a Porsche owner to join PCA.  I can 
connect you with the NordStern membership telephone number if you are 
interested in joining.

Date: Thu, 5 May 1994 10:45:57 -0400 (EDT)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Brazilian story on Senna's Accident

Reprinted without permission.

Brazilians Furious Over GP Safety

SAO PAULO--Ayrton Senna's brother hit out at safety levels in Formula One
n Wednesday and angrily accused the sport of being obsessed with money.
Leonardo Senna accused the sport's officials of skimping on safety after
his brother was killed during Sunday's San Marino Grand Prix when he crashed
into a concrete wall at high speed.

"If there had been some kind of protection, maybe tires or something, Ayrton
would be alive and intact today," he told reporters, his voice trembling with
emotion.  "Unfortunately, in Formula One, all people think about is money."
Brazilian grief over the accident has been accompanied throughout by a
sentiment of anger. The press has been bitterly critical of Formula One
directors over what it sees as a lack of safety in the sport. On Wednesday,
as Senna's coffin arrived in Sao Paulo, banners with messages such as
"Goodbye Senna," "Senna will be in our hearts forever," and "Senna has
stepped up onto the highest podium of all," were mixed with ones of protest.

One group of fans outside the building where Senna's body was lying in state,
chanted: "We want justice, we want justice. They killed Senna." Senna's coffin
arrived in Sao Paulo at dawn on Wednesday on a flight from Paris. Draped in a
Brazilian flag, it was taken on top of a fire engine to the Sao Paulo
legislative assembly where it was lying in state until Thursday morning's
funeral. Thousands of people filed past the coffin to pay their last respects.
The first in the queue had been waiting since early on Tuesday. Around 70
people were reported to have been treated by ambulance staff after having been
overcome with emotion. The motorcade which accompanied the fire engine on the
mile journey from the airport brought Sao Paulo's traffic to a near standstill.
Crowds lined the streets, packed the bridges over the route and threw ticker tape
at the coffin. Government offices and schools in Sao Paulo shut. Senna's death
has stunned Brazil, where his triumphs on the racetrack were deeply cherished
by people who, in nation suffering  rampant inflation, urban violence and
corruption scandals, often have little to smile about.


FORZA!

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963 



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 05 May 1994 12:55:51 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com  ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re:  tire pressures

Kari asks:
>...'how come the recommended (manual) tire pressures are uneven at 2/2.5
bar (29/36 psi)?'...<

Barney sez:
The lower front tire pressure is designed to produce understeer or the
tendency of the car to continue in a straight line even though the front
wheels are turned.  Most drivers, when entering a corner at speed, will
tend to lift off of the throttle.  In cars with a 50/50 or greater weight
bias toward the rear, this lifting will cause the rear end of the car to
swing out in the direction opposite the turn, or to oversteer.  The tire
pressure induced understeer helps cancel out the driver induced oversteer
and is mandated into all cars by D.O.T. safety regulations.

At an autocross event or at the track, most P* car drivers will inflate the
front and rear tires to the same, or very nearly the same, pressures.  They
do this because: a) They have learned not to lift in a corner, and, b) They
want to be in charge of the cars behavior and not have it influenced by
some outside factor.

In daily life, things are not so simple.  Driving around on short sidewall
front tires that are inflated to 36 pounds is hard on your car.  On my
daily driver (Carrera) I worked out a compromise.  I increased the front
pressure 2 pounds and lowered the rear pressure by 2 pounds.  This had the
dual effect of giving me a fairly netural handeling car and has decreased
the center of the tire wear on the rear.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     autoxer/racer   SLC


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 May 94 12:53:39 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: air filter

> I was wondering if anyone uses their K&N in a CIS airbox with pop off 
> valve?  My situation is that my pop off valve goes off every few days due 
> to the cold start not hooked up.  On occasion it can also knock open the 
> airbox.  I have dents in my paper filter from the pop off valve, and 
> would want to make sure that the K&N "gives" rather than possibly 
> damaging the pop off valve.

I have a K&N in mine, but also have one of the aluminum (newer style than
original stainless steel box) airboxes with a built in metal popoff valve,
so I doubt that the filter could damage it.  I do seem to remember some
mild 'dents' in the air filter, but I'm not sure if that's from the valve
itself or the blowback.

> Also, more air doesn't equal more power.  You can drive a 911 without an 
> air filter and without the air box attached, and you're not necessarily 
> going to get more power.

Without an air box attached, you wouldn't get much at all in a
fuel-injected car.  In cars that might be running a little richer than
stock (!!!), the extra air would be useful.  Improved airflow is generally
a plus, though not always.  Wish somebody had those stats on K&N
improvements...

> I would be interested in prices and souces of aluminum air boxes.  The 
> plastic one seems chintzy, especially the way the two straps attach the 
> cover.

I heard a nasty rumor that the guy who designed and manufactured those
airboxes died, and his sons decided to discontinue the business or
somesuch.  I have seen one of the original stainless airboxes at a swap
meet, and boy was it an ugly, kludgey looking thing.  Also, the guy wanted
something like twice the original price for it.  The OEM boxes are chintzy,
but the popoff valve seems to do a pretty good job of protecting them.  I
like my version of the aluminum one.  It looks stock, even in the black
color, and the popoff valve inside looks to be of industrial quality.  I
also heard the original stainless boxes had fit and finish problems and
were not entirely airtight (? anybody know for sure ?).  I think the
dimensions were not stock, and thus they will not work in 914 -> 914/6
conversions.  This from somebody who was looking to do that (not me).

Blaine

Date: 5 May 1994 11:10:54 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  Interior Turn Signal In

RE> Interior Turn Signal Indicator
>My right turn signal seems to dim and stay on according to the dash when
>putting it on while driving, but it is actually blinking outside the car. 
>I've never been able to figure it out in almost 7 years now.
>
>Karl 71 911E

    I had a similar problem in my 2.0L 914.  The problem turned out to 
be in the intermittent relay that controls all the flashing lights in
the car.  There are several on/off gizmos inside the one plastic box,
and so what happens to one part doesn't necessarily reflect what's going
on in another part.
    In the 914, the relay was up above the fuse box above the driver's
knees.  Two screws, and yank the relay; new (used) relay; and all's fine!

- --DD  ( == Dave Darling )

>>It can be traced to a plastic bushing. The bushing has elongated
>>in the forward/backward direction (not up/down). It is about
>>1mm per direction. THis actually translates to about 1/2" of
>>free play at the shift lever.


>The bushing is actually made that way in order to reduce
>vibration back to the shift stalk. Even if you replace the
>shift knuckle, the new part would be about the same. The bushing
>isn't sold as a separate part, to my knowledge, but you can make
>one out of Delrin or Nylatron and insert it as you said.

Bushings are available thru Automotion (at least). Old catalog pg. 168.
 Theory of not transmitting
vibration suits me.  I would surmise that the wear along the horizontal
surfaces would be the area of
concern more so that the fore/aft (it's an ellipse (sort of) shape when new,
anyway).  The more significant
bushing is the nylon cup at the base of the shift lever that *does*
frequently wear-out...

	My car has had an irregular idle and surging on accelleration at
	about 3500 rpm ever since I've had it. So I've been looking for the 
	miracle cure. I thought the Temp Sensor may provide some improvement
	as it was mentioned in an article in Excellence mag.
	At this time it seems that my idle has stabilized somewhat, but that
	may be wishfull thinking.
	I'm in the process of running a full diagnostic per the manual on
	the car, no conclusions yet. Surging is still there, actually it is 
	more like poor throttle transition, low power below 3500 and then a 
	step funtion increase in power, as if someone turned on the switch to 
	"GO-FAST-NOW". No relation to wet weather, however as you know it is
	always wet weather in Seattle! My car doesn't seem to miss under load
	especially above 3500 RPM, Goes like a scalded ape!

	for Bosch parts direct, so perhaps saving some markup from Porsche!

------------------------------

Date: 05 May 1994 18:09:46 GMT
From: David_K._Ferguson@onenet-bbs.org (David K. Ferguson)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles in Autoweek

Sarah Sprafka writes about being dissappointed  with the AutoWeek article on
PCA Club Racing.

As a PCA Club Racer who has attended 4 races including the "First Ever" race
in Denver, let me tell you about PCA Club Racing.  The program is designed to
let you enjoy the competition of "real" wheel-to-wheel racing without the
fear of undue risk to yourself or your car.  The key is an attitude
adjustment by the participants.  As a driver, you need to be willing to
"share" the track with the other racers, to give them the corner if they make
a move to inside in a turn.  Most participants get their reward from just
being in the race, not from any trophy or finishing position.  

Since the event sizes are small (40-100 drivers), there are typically several
classes running in a single race.  For most drivers, this means your race is
with the car in front of you, and the one behind you.  So what class you car
is in, really doesn't matter once the green flag drops.

But, the Club Racing Rule Book does divide the cars into 8 "stocks" classes
(E1-K), and 4 "super" classes for modified or race cars.  

The stock classes allow any springs, sway bars, 1" wider than stock wheels. 
DME Chips, brakes and ignition must be stock, transmission ratios unchanged,
and tires must be within 3% of the rolling diameter of the stock tires.  If
the car has a different DME  chip, non-stock brakes, or different gear
ratios, then it runs one class higher.  All stock class cars must run on DOT
tires with a minimum of 2/32" tread.

The super classes are divided by displacement, and have sub-classes for race
tires (and/or chassis reinforcement) or street tires.  (Class A has 4
subclasses for Turbo w/race tires/chassis stiffening, Non-turbo w/race
tires/chassis stiffening, and turbo/non-turbo on street tires).  Cars in
these classes must use Porsche built chassis, engines & gearboxes. 
Everything else is free.

I would estimate that 30-40% of the cars are non-street legal race cars
running in the super classes.  More than half of the cars are normal street
cars with roll cages, fire extinguishers, windows nets, racing seats, 5 point
harnesses and cut-off switches (these being the bulk of the safety
requirements).

Some of the fast-guys are really fast (Martin Snow's 911 Turbo for example),
Ron Mistak's 914-6, and we've seen a few 3.8 RSR's.  Next are the SCCA
prepared GT-1/2/3, 914-6 and 911's.
Keeping up with these cars are the big-engined light cars (3.2L 73 911's with
RS flares, etc), well prepared RS Americas (see Monte's Smith's RS and Mike
Doolin's RS shown in the AW article).

Here is the top-10 finishing order (with fast lap times) from the fast group
at the Las Vegas race:
Martin Show     911 Turbo   (A1) 00:57.095 (100.844 mph)
Ron Mistak      914-6 2.8   (B1) 01:00.161 (95.743 mph)
Richard Raimist 911 3.8 RSR (A2) 01:01.030 (94.380 mph)
Monte Smith     911 RSA     (A4) 01:02.457 (92.223 mph)
Rick Ollila     911 3.6     (A2) 01:02.515 (92.138 mph)
Chick Misura    914-6 2.8   (B1) 01:02.015 (92.881 mph)
Marvin Epps     914-6       (B1) 01:02.737 (91.812 mph)
Mark Mehilic    911 RSA     (A2) 01:03.659 (90.482 mph)
Chris Fisher    930         (A1) 01:05.040 (88.561 mph)
Henry Schmidt   914-6       (B1) 01:03.658 (90.484 mph)
(Don't ask, I was ahead of Chick Misura/Mark Mehilic when I DNF'ed....)
   
Ellen and I will be going to the Club Race at Hallett, OK in 3 weeks, and
returning to Second Creek in Denver, CO in June.  Any other club racers at
these events be sure to look us up.  It was good to talk to Barney and Drew
Spencer in Las Vegas.

David Ferguson
Boulder, Colorado
914-6 race car, Class B1

Date: Tue, 03 May 94 01:37:00 PDT
From: "Hartje, Will" <whartje@smtpgw2.az05.bull.com>
Subject: Re: Senna Questions


Active Ride Suspension is a computer controlled, springless system. The 
system constantly adjusts the suspension arms to maintain the ride height of 
the vehicle and compensate for the weight transfer as it brakes, accelerates 
and corners. Therefore the car does not dip as it brakes or leans as it 
corners. the intent is to maintain maximum adhesion on all four wheels at 
all times.

An electronic throttle is what it says, it does not rely on mechanical 
linkage to operate it.


 ----------
From: porschephiles-request
To: porschephiles
Subject: Re: Senna Questions
Date: Tuesday, May 03, 1994 11:01AM

The spectacular crash and death of A Senna came as a shock to many
(especially after the only days before in virtually the same spot).  My
local paper printed an AP story read, in part, " 'He was the victim of the
new regulations that banned active suspensions, traction control and
electronic accelerators,' Formula One reporter Castilho de Andrade said..."

I am a mechanical novice (is there a lower category?) so pitch any answers
to my level - -
What actually IS an "active suspension"?
I think I know what traction control is (sort-a-like ABS for pulling not
just braking?) but what is an "electronic accelerator"? Sounds like Formula
One is closer to virtual reality and Senna should be alive with his video
helmet on!

Active suspension is a concept invented by Lotus ? (I think..), all it means
is
that the suspension system is 'smart' in that it stiffens the side the load
is
on though the turn...ie, on a left hand turn, the right side suspension
stiffens
up.

From:  <netmail!russ930@aol.com>

From:  PaulSturm

========================================================================
I have a question about Comas.  If this has been answered already,
I am sorry for asking again, however, I haven't seen this addressed.

While the medical team was working on Senna, a car proceeded down the
track, well after the race was stopped.  First, Was this Comas, as
the commentators suggested.  Second, does anyone know why he was
on the track after the race was stopped?

As for this weekend's tragedies I can only say I wish we were all given
a better oppportunity to get to know Roland Ratzenberger as a Formula 1
driver.  As for the death of Aryton Senna, I may not have known him
personally, but I feel as though I have lost a friend; a friend whose
company I enjoyed on many spring and summer weekends.  Aryton, thank you
for sharing your skills and talent with all of us who will never forget
our appreciation and our admiration.
========================

This was an extremely strange footnote to the incident.  On the
BBC coverage, an interview in the pits was happening.  I noticed
an engine start up in the background and thought....hmmmmm, what
the heck is that?  All of a sudden, you can hear the driver tearing
out of the pits, and accelerating hard through the course.  On
replay, you can clearly hear him max out his revs as he starts
down the straight.  And then suddenly, he appears braking hard
right into the corner of the accident.  What the hell was going
on?  Why on earth was he on the track, and who let him out?
=========================
Maybe he and others wanted to check out Ayrton's condition and talked to
the marshalls. After all, he could talk back to the pits while on the
scene.
==========================
Comas' fastest lap of the race was the first, and I believe he dropped
out very early with handling problems.  I think he was in the pits at
the time of Senna's accident, and the team just were oblivious to what
had been happening, so when they made whatever change they wanted to
make, Comas sped onto the race track.

But surely the team would know what was happening, because they have
another car (umm, who is it?)...  Maybe they figured he could leave
the pits to make the lap and line up for the restart, not realizing
that the track was blocked.
========================================================================
French tv TF1 showed an enlarged view in slo-mo, where you
could barely make out something (debris?) that the car goes
over. Prost remarked that the corner had been resurfaced and
was bumpy and that if it was debris then Senna could have
just lost control completely.

Prost was also very vehement in his attack on F1 politics, saying
in a not-too-concealed way that a major problem was incompetent
people making rule changes without thinking about the possibly
affects on safety. Only money counts. He has called for an independent
committee to be set up to regulate safety in F1, the committee to
be made up of drivers (ex. and current) and engineers.

Prost went on to say how devasted he was by the events (he found it
very difficult to talk about Senna) and that although himself and
Senna were never friends, they always respected each other, and that
the "bad-blood" between them was exagerated by the press. In particular,
he added, Senna and himself had more recently begun to understand
each other. Before the race Senna sent a message via TF1 to Prost
saying "we miss you" and the morning of the race Prost met Senna to
wish him luck.

Prost concluded by saying that without Senna he himself would never
have become what he is.

Date: Thu, 5 May 94 18:01:30 EDT
From: Mike Kohlbrenner <kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Another tire pressure question

> ...
> At several gas stations the employees have asserted that the recommended
> tire pressures in a car's driver's manual should not be believed, and
> that you should always fill up to the maximum pressure rating provided
> by the tire manufacturer.  (I know, consider the source, right?)
> ...
> --Walt Thode
> 

The max pressure on the sidewall of a tire is used to establish the max
load a tire can carry.  Even my itty-bitty 185-60-14 Honda Civic tires
can carry about 1050 lb. each -- my car weighs about 2300 lb.
If I ran them at max pressure, I would likely end up wearing out the
centers of the tread more than the shoulders.  Go with the 
manufacturers recommendation -- AT FIRST.  After you start to wear your
tires somewhat, check them out.  If the shoulders are wearing more
than the center, increase the pressure a couple of psi.  If the centers
of the treads are wearing more quickly than the shoulders, decrease
the pressure.  A lot depends on your specific tires and the way you drive.

Now, this says nothing about inside shoulder vs. outside shoulder wear
difference.  That has more to do with your alignment and the way you
drive.

Mike Kohlbrenner
<kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>

'67 VW Beetle      (Every once in a while it gets closer to running...)
'90 Honda Civic Si (Daily driver/Track Car -- YaHoo!) 
??? Porsche ???    (Someday it will be mine...)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 May 1994 16:45:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: LAFORCE@XENON.ARC.NASA.GOV
Subject: re: tire pressures

Walt writes:


>Seeing a question about tire pressures reminded me of one I had.  At
>several gas stations the employees have asserted that the recommended
>tire pressures in a car's driver's manual should not be believed, and
>that you should always fill up to the maximum pressure rating provided
>by the tire manufacturer.  (I know, consider the source, right?)  The
>story is that the car builder has different concerns than the tire
>builder, like "softer ride" or "less noise," and the tire maker knows
>at which pressure the tire performs best.  I'm just curious whether
>anyone else has heard this story, and whether there's anything to it.

No.

The max pressure is just that: maximum cold pressure.  

As in "do not exceed."

Here's the static force ballance:

The flat area on the inside of the tire is going to equal the load on 
the tire divided by the tire pressure.  Increasing tire pressure will
thus reduce the contact patch on the ground.  However this is a gross
simplification.  Contrary to what one is taught in freshman physics, 
(see my book "The Coefficent of Friction and Other Lies") the area 
of the contact patch will affect the amount of lateral G the tire will
support (yes folks, it's official: size does matter :-O)

Generally speaking, the tire is going to perform best when the contact
patch is maximized.  The problem is how and when/where to maximize the 
contact patch.

Also generally speaking, if you run a tire at max press, you will 
notice that all the center tread is gone before the side tread (this
also happens with a wide tire that is underinflated).

To speak generally a bit more, I'm told that most cars will perform
better about 2psi higher than spec - better milage, traction, and 
tire life.  The ride will also be harder.  The spec is a compromise 
between comfort and performance.  Porsche may be an exception to 
this generality.

Now, if you were running 78 serries tires, they might perform best at 
the max pressure because the sidewall compliance is reduced, keeping 
the contact patch maximized in a hard turn.

With a normal aspect ratio tire (e.g. 50 serries ;-), you will get the 
best handling below max pressure.  At least this has been my experience.

For example, I tend to run the BFG comp TA-R1 at lower pressures than the
Yoko A008RS.  The BFG has a stiffer sidewall (and slightly better turn-
in) than does the Yoko and I think this is responsible for the lower 
pressure.  I think both are rated at 44psi.  I would run the bfg's in the
low 30's and the yoko's in the high 30's.

I generally set the (auto-x) pressure by marking the edge of the tread
and part of the sidewall before a run and checking how much the tire 
has rolled over during the run.


- --Soren

p.s. my favorite bit of tire trivia is this:

      At 125 mph a 24" dia. tire has a centripital acceleration of 
      1000 G's at the tread!

------------------------------


Porschephiles #740                         Sat May 7 02:21:15 CDT 1994
Date: Thu, 5 May 94 18:31:27 EDT
From: Mike Kohlbrenner <kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>
Subject: re:F1 technology/Senna

>
> Much of the observations over the last few seasons regarding F1
> advances in technology have focused on the areas of traction control,
> semi-automatic gearboxes and active suspensions.  Engines have gone
> from turbocharged to normally aspirated with, so it seems, no apparent
> loss in speed.  So, engines have gotten better at making these cars to
> go faster and advances in handling allowed them to take advantage of
> the increased power.

F1 engines during the turbo era produced well over 1000 HP, especially
in qualifying trim.  Current normally aspirated engines are somewhere
around 800 HP.  The speed advances have come from the other technologies,
i.e. aerodemonics, chassis design, etc.

> The loss of traction control and active
> suspensions seem to have upset the balance between the car's ability to
> make power and keep it on the track, almost like the problems Indy cars
> had a few years ago where the performance of the cars exceeded the
> capabilities of the track at Indy.
 
Perhaps true, but consider that fast lap and qualifying records set last
year with active cars are being broken already with passive cars.  The
new Benetton is mighty quick.  And just wait until the Williams is
sorted out...

> Is it a balance of technology problem ? Is it a driver problem, i.e., do 
> driver's have to re-learn driving skills they lost as a result of using 
> active suspension, traction control, etc. or does FISA need limit 
> engine power and speed among other things, ( tire width, crashworthiness, 
> etc.),to make things safe ?
>
> What is the problem, if there is a problem ?
>
> What is the best way fix it ?
> 
> Ed

I think that Trond really hit on the point.  The problem is track safety.
The safest car can always be driven off the track at speed.  It is the
design of the sand traps and walls that determine if someone dies...

Watkins Glen, '92 (?) Tommy Kendall busts up his feet and Mc-somebody-or-
other dies in the Nascar race in the same summer.  They ended up building
a chicane at the end of a famous straight to make people go slower through
the turn.  Some think that it was a copout.  I think it was so they could
create another "Action point" and build another grand stand...

It's the same as the dangerous intersection in your town.  They only put
the traffic lights up after somebody dies.

F1 cars will continue to break track records, regardless of the limitations
put on them.  It may take a while, but they will.  F1 cars will figure
out how to live without "driver aids" -- Benetton already seems to be
pretty well hooked up.  And F1 cars will always crash.  Hopefully, the
safety features will be able to keep up with the progress.

As far as Senna, I really didn't like him, but I am really going to miss
watching him race, especially in the rain!

Race In Peace in that great 'Ring in the sky!

Mike Kohlbrenner
<kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>

'67 VW Beetle      (Every once in a while it gets closer to running...)
'90 Honda Civic Si (Daily driver/Track Car -- YaHoo!) 
??? Porsche ???    (Someday it will be mine...)

Date: Thu,  5 May 94 17:26:25 PDT
From: Mike Conte <mikecon@microsoft.com>
Subject: Wheel fans for 911...do they work?

I've always had trouble keeping my brakes cool. Currently, I run Motul 
fluid, Pagid pads, Carrera brakes, and the Cool Brake ducts on my 74 
911. I've seen the ads for the GTP wheel fan add-ons for Fuchs allows 
in Pano. Has anyone tried them (or any other wheel fans)? Do they work?

I've read that wheel fans are most useful for removing large amounts of 
hot air that is ducted to the brakes (like in a 935 or 962), but may 
not make much difference on a stock car (and mine has the rubber lip 
spoiler, which does reduce airflow under the car).

Any info on this (or other brake cooling secrets) appreciated.

Mike (mikecon@microsoft.com)

Date: 05 May 94 20:43:48 EDT
From: Hubert Lai <70363.1332@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Expensive Rattling Noise?

You may recall my posting a couple of weeks ago about a noise 
my 1983 944 (with automatic transmission) was producing.  Well, 
the noise has become a regular occurrence and is no longer 
intermittent.  I brought it to Wiessach Performance, the place  
where I get most of my work done.  A total of three mechanics
went at the problem and I spent the entire day at the garage 
myself. At first, they thought it was a loose heat shield.  
There was also some speculation that it might be a burned out 
element in the catalytic converter or a loose oxygen sensor.

The symptoms -- the metallic rattling noise occurrs when the 
engine is in the range of 2800 to 3100 rpm under load.  The 
noise does not occur when there is no load on the engine (i.e. 
when the car is in neutral).  The pitch of the noise is fixed, 
regardless of engine speed or wheel speed.  The noise is most 
prnounced when accelerating hard from a standing start.  When 
the car is stationary the noise can be produced by putting it 
into gear, standing hard on the brakes, and applying power.  
However, the engine will not rev beyond about 2300 rpm under 
those circumstances and the noise that is produced does not 
have quite the same sound.  The noise does not occur when the 
car is cool, but it takes less than 30 minutes to warm the car 
up sufficiently to produce the noise.

Two of the mechanics took the car for a test drive.  One drove 
while the other hung out of the passenger side with the door 
open and his head near the ground, trying to isolate the 
noise.  Ater this, they concluded that the noise was coming from 
the mid-section of the car, behind the engine but ahead of the 
midpoint between the front and rear wheels.

We swapped my oxygen sensor out for a plug, but the rattling 
noise didn't go away.  So much for that.  The mechanics used a 
rubber mallet to whack away at the exhaust system, but they 
couldn't find anything loose.

After all that, they have come to the conclusion that the noise 
has to be coming from the transmission, specifically the bell 
housing area.  This diagnosis was reached because the noise 
only occurs under load.

Cost -- I am told that the worst case scenario is that 
the flex plate in the automatic transmission (the equivalent of 
a flywheel?) needs to be replaced, in which case I'll be 
looking at Can$2,100 plus tax.  At best, it could just be a 
loose bolt which won't cost me anything apart from labour for 
taking the transmission apart and putting it back together.  
That will still be Can$680 plus tax.

Questions -- This car is 11 years old.  It has been maintained 
well and only has about 50,000 miles on it.  What is the 
likelihood that there is a serious problem with the 
transmission?  ($2,100 to me is serious.  Shit, I'm not even 
happy about $680.)  Can I just live with the noise, and keep on 
driving the car?  In other words, is the noise the only thing 
I'll have to live with, or is the noise an strong indicator 
that if I keep driving something really bad will happen to me?  
If I drive the car until it really breaks, how long have I got 
and will it cost any more to fix at that point than if I pay 
the mechanics to go into the car now?

One last question -- can I get into this part of the car 
myself?  It seems that labour is a huge portion of the cost, 
and if I could work on it myself, I could save a lot.  I am far 
from an expert on these things.  I've got my Haynes, but that's 
about it.  I can do routine things but I've never done anything 
major in a car.  However, I am pretty good at reading instructions and 
then translating that into actually doing it.

Any and all comments are very welcome.  The car will be going 
into the garage on Monday if I don't hear to the contrary, so 
if you have any input, I would be grateful if you would send it 
to me direct before then.  (I'm on the digest.)  Thanks to 
everyone in advance...

<=- Hubert

Date: Wed, 04 May 94 17:30:00 PDT

Subject: RE: Brazilian story on Senna's Accident


Formula 1safety is not perfect but it ispretty good. the statisticcs of no 
race deaths for twelve years(prior to Senna's) speak for themselves. 
Tamburello is a turn, not a corner, like those at Indianopolis or Phoenix or 
Michigan hich also have concrete walls on the outside, Tamdurello at least 
has some grass run off. I agree that a tire wall would help but it still may 
not of saved Senna's life. As for the money, Senna accepted the risk and was 
at one time the world's highest paid sportsman because of it. His brother 
did not complain then!

From: porschephiles-request
To: Porschephiles List; Exotic Cars List; Italian Cars List; BMW List
Subject: Brazilian story on Senna's Accident
Date: Thursday, May 05, 1994 10:45AM

Reprinted without permission.

Brazilians Furious Over GP Safety

SAO PAULO--Ayrton Senna's brother hit out at safety levels in Formula One
n Wednesday and angrily accused the sport of being obsessed with money.
Leonardo Senna accused the sport's officials of skimping on safety after
his brother was killed during Sunday's San Marino Grand Prix when he crashed
into a concrete wall at high speed.

"If there had been some kind of protection, maybe tires or something, Ayrton
would be alive and intact today," he told reporters, his voice trembling 
with
emotion.  "Unfortunately, in Formula One, all people think about is money."
Brazilian grief over the accident has been accompanied throughout by a
sentiment of anger. The press has been bitterly critical of Formula One
directors over what it sees as a lack of safety in the sport. On Wednesday,
as Senna's coffin arrived in Sao Paulo, banners with messages such as
"Goodbye Senna," "Senna will be in our hearts forever," and "Senna has
stepped up onto the highest podium of all," were mixed with ones of protest.

One group of fans outside the building where Senna's body was lying in 
state,
chanted: "We want justice, we want justice. They killed Senna." Senna's 
coffin
arrived in Sao Paulo at dawn on Wednesday on a flight from Paris. Draped in 
a
Brazilian flag, it was taken on top of a fire engine to the Sao Paulo
legislative assembly where it was lying in state until Thursday morning's
funeral. Thousands of people filed past the coffin to pay their last 
respects.
The first in the queue had been waiting since early on Tuesday. Around 70
people were reported to have been treated by ambulance staff after having 
been
overcome with emotion. The motorcade which accompanied the fire engine on 
the
mile journey from the airport brought Sao Paulo's traffic to a near
standstill.
Crowds lined the streets, packed the bridges over the route and threw ticker
tape
at the coffin. Government offices and schools in Sao Paulo shut. Senna's 
death
has stunned Brazil, where his triumphs on the racetrack were deeply 
cherished
by people who, in nation suffering  rampant inflation, urban violence and
corruption scandals, often have little to smile about.


FORZA!

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Date: 06 May 94 12:35:27 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Glockler Porsches

Pal Negyesi was looking for some info on the Gloeckler (note English
spelling for Glo"ckler, two dots over O) Porsche.
 
Two books come to mind. First of all, Karl Ludvigsen's "Excellence was
Expected," the best single-marque car history book ever written. There's a
whole chapter in there on the Gloecklers.
 
Also, try Gordon Maltby, "Porsche 356 and RS Spyders."
 
Jerry Sloniger's "Porsche: the 4-cylinder, 4-cam sports & racing cars" has
a small mention of Gloeckler.
 
These are currently available from Motorbooks in Wisconsin and from
most stores that specialize in automotive books and Porsche stuff.
 
Pete

Date: 6 May 1994 09:35:53 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Tire wear and inflation pre

        Reply to:   Tire wear and inflation pressure

> ...If I ran them at max pressure, I would likely end up wearing out the
> centers of the tread more than the shoulders.  Go with the
> manufacturers recommendation -- AT FIRST.  After you start to wear your
> tires somewhat, check them out.  If the shoulders are wearing more
> than the center, increase the pressure a couple of psi.  If the centers
> of the treads are wearing more quickly than the shoulders, decrease
> the pressure.

> Mike Kohlbrenner
> <kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>

The above has always been the conventional wisdom, and sounds quite
logical: overinflated tires wear more quickly in the center.  I have been
informed by my very well respected mechanic that this is no longer the
case.  In fact, it is quite the opposite.  I do not recall the reasons,
whether they were related to modern tire design or 911's in specific
(the former, I think), but he was quite adamant about this.  Has anyone
got further info?

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Fri, 6 May 94 12:54:20 EDT

20 rows deep -- and then there would be the risk of those same tires doing
the killing.  Tire walls are great only for lower speed contact.

As far as risk, it is true that Senna realized them and was well paid.  But
does that mean that we should just pay people to take risks or should we
devote more resources to advance track safety technology?
