Date: Fri, 6 May 94 13:08:09 EDT
From: dougie@physics.att.com (Douglas Dykaar)
Subject: Wheel fans for 911...do they work?


I have them on my 951, along with thermocouples on the brake pad backing plate.
I measured a small but finite difference (at the glen), ~10 degrees F. I think p
art of the problem is that the front of the fan is exposed to the air flow. To b
e effective I think a low pressure area has to be created with a flap at the fro
nt of the wheel
well. I see them on the fronts of many race cars...

Doug Dykaar
AT&T Bell Labs
dougie@physics.att.com  908/582-4133

Date: Fri, 6 May 1994 10:51:34 +0600
From: Eisuke.Muroga@att.com
Subject: Re: 944 electrical problems


I think a number of the electrical contacts (switches, etc) are
prone to oxidation and other "dirtiness" causing them to flake out.
I had problems (as a number of other posters have noted) with the
944 sunroof microswitch. Spraying Radio Shack switch-contact cleaner/lubricant
cured the flakyness of the sunroof. Perhaps the fan switch could also be
prone to dirtiness/oxidation as well.


Eisuke Muroga


------------------------------

Date: 6 May 1994 10:33:55 U
From: "Donn Mukensnable" <donn_mukensnable@qmail.hq.interlink.com>
Subject: Re: Tranny gear teeth!?!?

        Reply to:   RE>Tranny gear teeth!?!?
> Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com> writes in
> Message-Id: <9405051834.AA01408@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
> Subject: Tranny gear teeth!?!?

>  . . . .   After cleaning them, they appear to be teeth, yet quite
> small.  They are approx. .1 wide by .15 high with a chamfer on both
> opposing faces.
>        What could these be?  

 This is *bad*!  Yes, from the description they are synchro teeth, probably
from either 1st or 2nd gear.  In P-car trannies there is a ring that slides
to connect the shaft and cluster gears with a friction collar to match the
speeds of the two (that's the synchro part).  If the speeds don't match, you
can lose teeth from the cluster gear (these are really engagement teeth, not
the ones that provide the ratio.  There are only about 50 or so of these per
gear and when some leave, there is much more strain on the remaining ones. 
This leads to a progressive 'decay' that can result in eventually losing a
whole gear.

 One thing to check once the car gets rolling (unless you do a teardown of
the box first) is whether the shifter "wobbles" when you have engaged a
particular gear.  This is a sign that more than a few teeth are missing.

- --Donn--





------------------------------

Date: 6 May 1994 09:36:55 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re- Wheel Studs ) Bolts to 

Re: Wheel Studs ) Bolts to Studs ? 
>>This is my personal peeve  - not being allowed to convert them -
>>because it's such a #%#@^!!! pain to change tires on my 914.  I
>>would change mine in an instant (since PCA already allows this)
>>if I could.  
>>
>I can't see any racing advantage that occurs by changing to studs.  I just 
>simply makes it easier on the pit crew.  (You know, us, the drivers at 
>auto-x events.)   I also would change them if I only ran PCA, but I also run 
>in SCCA regional and divisional events.  A protest isn't worth it.  

    If you *do* this sort of change, make sure it's done *right*!!!!  The
standard Bug kits out there are *NOT* good enough!  Trust me, I'm looking
at some serious bucks because of one.
    Item one:  The studs are *NOT* long enough in the rear for (at least)
the Fuchs alloys and their look-alikes.  Insufficient engagement = very
very very unsafe.
    Item two:  The studs do *NOT* have sufficient engagement in the hub.
I was re-torquing the nuts on my 1.8L, when OOPS!  Stripped one, and
noticed (for the first time) that the engagement is only about 75% of a
full stud diameter.  THIS IS NOT SAFE!  Now I'm looking at having one
of my huds either Time-Serted or replaced (!!!!) and I need to go out
and buy the *real* lug bolts.  Sigh.  Anyone wanna buy this car?
    Forgive me for being so emphatic, but it's something that just bit
me in the ass, real hard!  If you *do* go this route, make sure that 
the lugs have an adequate strength and hardness, and that *everything*
has *at least* 1 full diameter's worth of engagement!

- --Dave Darling (DD)



------------------------------

Date: 6 May 1994 09:09:48 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- 914 problem

re: 914 problem
>Porschephiles:  I have a problem with my 1973 914 2.0 L. When I start it
>up, and either creep along or accelerate slowly, the engine speed
>oscillates, so that it lunges forward and then slows down with a period of
>about 1 second. The engine doesn't cut out completely, just slows down.
>This lunging stops after the engine warms up.

    The TPS basically has three positions--Wide Open Throttle, Fully Closed
Throttle, or Somewhere In Between.  It's actually just two switches.  Since
this is happening at part throttle, I'd think that the TPS doesn't have
anything to do with it.
    Since it goes away after the car warms up, I'd suspect the warm-up
regulator (= aux air regulator).  I forget where it is on the 2.0L, but
check the resistance, and make sure that it's fully open when cold and
fully closed when warm.  Other possible culprits:  Manifold pressure
sensor, various vaccuum leaks.
    That's my guess.

- --DD



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 6 May 1994 11:03:20 +0600
From: Eisuke.Muroga@att.com
Subject: Re: 944 speaker replacement



>>1) What is a good replacement door speaker? According to Crutchfield, the
>>speaker needs to be 4x6metric and less than 1.625" deep. They sell nothing
>>that works. I would like to use a high-end plate speaker; ie. MB Quart or
>>ADS.

I've thought about this myself. I wonder if something like a Boston Acoustics
separates system would work, putting the tweeters in the area by the
window switches (ala 968) and cutting holes to put a round woofer where the
normal 4x6 speaker is. I have put in the Kenwood 4x6's that Crutchfield
recommended, but the improvment was marginal.

I put Boston Acoustics 6 1/2" coaxes in my Honda and really like these
speakers. They have a smooth natural sound without the buzziness of most
car speakers. I've also listened to MB Quart and they sounded pretty good,
but I think they would require heftier amplifaction.

Eisuke Muroga

Date:     Fri, 6 May 94 16:17:51 EDT
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  85 911: Leaking transaxle shaft seals

I took advantage of a "free" Porsche service clinic and they did indeed
find a few things wrong with my '85 911...nothing too bad, really.

The big surprize was that the left & right transaxle seals are leaking.
Cost estimate is $225...not bad, but its ~$200 labor to replace a lousy
$16 gasket.  I *hate* such high LABOR:PARTS ratios!  


My questions are:

(a) How "compelling" is such a [slow] leak to fix...will it really attack
the CV boots as alleged?  What other "bad things"[tm] are inferred?

(b) What other jobs can/should be done down below that I could combine
the job with?  ...preventative work; early service on bottom, etc...


Rather be spending my money on parts than labor...

Thanks,

 -Hugh

Date: 6 May 1994 17:35:59 U
From: "James Wong" <james_wong@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Re: Tire wear and inflation 

        Reply to:   RE>Tire wear and inflation pressure
I like to second Lance's statement. (Nothing to do with the fact that he is my
boss.)
When I attended a tech session hosted by Danny Kohler (sp?) or Kohler Auto in
Danville, Calif. last year. He did said that lower pressure makes the side wall
of the tire softer. So when the tire spins,  it actually elongates and thus
makes the center sticks out more and wears faster. Think of a donut shaped
ballon with water inside. If the side wall is softer,  as it spins the water
(air) inside would push out the center due to centrifugal force.

 -james

- --------------------------------------------------------------
The above has always been the conventional wisdom, and sounds quit logical:
overinflated tires wear more quickly in the center.  I have been
informed by my very well respected mechanic that this is no longer the
case.  In fact, it is quite the opposite.  I do not recall the reasons,
whether they were related to modern tire design or 911's in specific
(the former, I think), but he was quite adamant about this.  Has anyone
got further info?

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i
- --------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 06 May 94 18:18:04 EDT

Subject: Which wheels for 83 944?


Date: Thu, 5 May 94 09:10:42 EDT
From: frankc@teleng.eng.telxon.com (Frank Ciotti)
Subject: Which wheels for 83 944?

Hi,
Well this past weekend I bought an 83 944 to complement my '77 911.  Since
the 944 will be used as a daily driver, I wanted to start looking for an
extra set of wheels so I can have one set for Winter.  Currently  the car
has the std. 7x15 cookie cutters.  I believe the offset on the wheels
was changed in '87 (correct me if I'm wrong), but what is the proper offset
for the earlier 944's.  Did porsche ever make 16" Phone Dials to fit these 
cars ('86 951?)?  I want to go to 16" and keep the cookie cutters for
Winter. And what is recommended - 16x7 & 16x8's, or 16x7 all around?  
Will the 16" Fuchs from an early 911 fit?  I would prefer phone dials
because of cost.

Robert Wood will have an ad in the next Panorama closing out 7x16 Fuchs 
wheels for pre '87 944's (pre ABS) for $100. The wheels are new, have no 
center caps, have a 951xxx part number, and are genuine, new, forged, 
Porsche, alloy, list price $1000+, etc. wheels. They do not take credit 
cards, and expect to sellout in 1 day. You will probably never again see 
these wheels at this price. They are normally available used for about 
$200. They will fit in the rear, but not look as nice (wide?) and will not 
handle 245/45/16 tires like the 8x16 would. They however are lighter, 
stronger, and in all respects  (except looks?) better than cookie cutters 
or phone dials. Buying new wheels from a reputable company is of course far 
less interesting than looking at comparably priced scratched, curbed, bent, 
faded used wheels. If you want 8x16's for the back, you will find that 1 
used wheel costs more than a set of 4 7x16's. I think (no flames please) 
that the correct offset is 23.3. The address is below. They are waiting for 
Pano to be delivered before releasing the wheels. Good luck.

Robert W. Wood, Inc.
     1537 Pontius Ave.
     Los Angeles, CA  90025
     telephone: 310-473-6649

Porschephiles #741                         Sun May 8 02:24:31 CDT 1994
Date: Sat, 07 May 94 00:32:01 EDT
From: bpenteco@aol.com
Subject: Turn indicator w/ key off

(I've been out of town for a couple of days and this has probably been
answered, but I'll put in my $.02 anyway.)

Andrew wrote:

> I was wondering if anyone had come across this gremlin; when I 
> leave my turn signal on (L or R), and shut off the car,
> the turn lights still remain on.

I think you are seeing normal functionality. My car does it ('83 944) and
I've seen another (~'85 911) do it. I dont know how widespread it is across
the model line.

My guess at the use for this feature comes from the way I saw people park on
the streets in Germany. When there isn't much room, cars may hang out on the
street a bit. At night, using the turn indicator keeps the parking lights on
one side lit, making the car visible to passing traffic and using half the
power of using the headlight/parking light switch.

In other words, maybe you can track it down and "fix" it, but I don't think
it's broken.

Bob Pentecost
Silver Sage Region, PCA

>
>You went all the way to Texas and ran an event in an ex-Minnesotan's
>car and didn't even  post a story?  You have a lot to answer for, Bucko. 
>Now, I want you get this story written and get it on the list.  And I want
>to use it in THE RIGHT LINE.  A fine way for the President of the Minnesota
>Autosports Club to act!
>
>Phil Ethier, THE RIGHT LINE, 672 Orleans St, Saint Paul, MN  55107-2676  USA
>h (612) 224-3105  w (612) 266-6244    phile@stpaul.gov
>"OH.  Was that out loud?"  - Cliff Claven

Tad responses:

Yea Mark,  what gives?  Please forward a copy of the article to me so I can 
have it posted on porschephilles@tta.com and our regional PCA newsletter. 

For those of you that might be interested:  Mark hasn't told the whole 
story.  Yes, he came down from MN to run my humble little 74 914 1.8L toy.   
Since he was the person that got me into racing in the first place (Thanks 
again Mark!) the least I could do was give him a ride!! 

Well,  let it be said that he not only drove my car, he RACED my car and 
almost beat me!!!  Right out of the box. We were running at this years 
Little LeMans run in Austin TX (not MN).  It was a wonderful high speed 
event hosted by the Hill Country Region PCA.  
The course was modelled after the French course.  IMHO, the course clearly 
favored high horsepower cars.  Amazingly, the little 914 held its own.   
There were 50 drivers all in European cars.  85% Porsches, then Alfa's and 
even a Sunbeam.  Mostly stock 911's and 944's.  Although there were two full 
road racing prepped 911 beasts.  Killer machines.

My 914 is a testy,  little tail-out happy (oversteering) beast with a funky 
(aren't they all) shifter. (No sway bars, either.)  It has taken me six 
months to get use to it. He did it by the second run.  (I ran a 90 Civic Si 
for two years.)  It truly was great competition.   With six runs each at we 
both had a chance to try some different things.  Unfortunately,  a little 
rain spoiled the last three runs.  (Of course Mark got his fastest time in 
the rain.)  My margin of victory was VERY small: 100.162 to 100.927.   It is 
a very positive feeling to see another driver do well in your car.  That way 
you know _you_, not just the car,  have room for improvement.

 
Tad Haas
tad@wst.com
Welcom Software Technology
Houston,  TX  



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 7 May 1994 02:55:11 -40962758 (CDT)
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: re- 914 problem

>     The TPS basically has three positions--Wide Open Throttle, Fully Closed
> Throttle, or Somewhere In Between.  It's actually just two switches.  Since
> this is happening at part throttle, I'd think that the TPS doesn't have
> anything to do with it.

While I too suspect the air leak that Dave Darling alludes to on the
problem 914 in question, it's worth pointing out that the the TPS
really, really does have three settings -- WOT, FCT, and in between.
There are limit switches for fully open and *transition* to fully closed from
somewhat open. There is a bogus squiggly line resistive element for the
"in between" parts. This wears out, and necessitates replacing the part
every 10 years or so. Just take it apart sometime and look....


Stan

Date: 07 May 94 17:54:53 EDT
From: Triet Le <73370.50@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: What's a fuel damper?

My mechanic informed me that he had replaced a leaky fuel damper in my '86 
951 and that he did it without asking (tried to call but voice mail was 
broken), because it was leaking fuel on a hot manifold. The part price was 
$55 and it took one hour of labor (he did some other stuff that he 
didn't/shouldn't have charged me for so I am not sure that the 1 hour of 
labor is accurate.) The car was in for a timing belt retension. It runs a 
lot better now on a cold start. It used to require feathering the gas pedal 
while driving until the oil temp was up. Until then it felt like there was 
a banana in the exhaust. Now it drives normally from a cold start.

Question: What is a fuel damper, and would replacing a bad one with a good 
one have the effects that I noted?

PS. How much should it cost to paint the panel in between the front 
headlights? My car is Pearl White (like an Audi) and I was quoted $400. 
This panel is less than 2 square feet. I have 5 stone chips. They say that 
it costs so much because it is a special color, they have to remove the 
lights, the car has to be masked, and because it is a Porsche. The panel is 
straight and requires no bodywork. I think that I will invest the $400 in 
WANG stock. If they win their suit against Microsoft, I will cash out and 
paint the whole car.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 07 May 94 20:27:10 EDT
From: william911@aol.com
Subject: Re: active suspension-production cars

My daily driver is an Infiniti Q45a (91) with "active suspension" option.
Prior to this, I had an almost identical '90 Q45 with the normal suspension.
What a difference!!!
Keeping in mind that this is a 4000lb sedan, I can comment to everyone that
the handling characteristics are very impressive. Net effect is like a 1000lb
lighter car.
I drive my 69 Targa on weekends, and the cornering power of the two is quite
comparable, with a *much* firmer overall ride in the 911 as the price for the
good handling.
By far the best aspect of this suspension is it's ability to provide a
smooth, compliant ride the 95 percent of the time that you are just driving
from a to b, while always remaining prepared to keep the car in a flat (they
actually programmed a few degrees of lean into the computer, after
discovering that the total absense of body roll in a turn is disconcerting to
most drivers.)
When a dip or rise is encountered, the car moves thru one damped cycle of
reaction to the change in the road surface, and then returns blissfully to
it's ride-height sensored normal post. 
This version of AS is semi- rather than fully active; the actuators push down
only  @ 0 to 2500 psi per corner, revised every 8ms, I think. The Lotus type
is push-pull (like a low-rider) and can reportedly be programmed to do really
eerie stuff.
Hope this has been interesting to all of you Porsche types.
Bill Conway
'69 911 targa, '70 911S coupe, 91 Q45a, 93 G20, & a truck!  

------------------------------

>I've done a few push-the-car-and-jump-in
>rolling LeMans starts over the years. (assuming flat parking
>lot... - key on, push hard, jump in, 3rd gear, clutch out, pray,
>doodle the gas, drive away)

I'd add hit the starter...If there is any juice left in the battery,
this'll help get the engine turning while "popping" the clutch.  Worked for
me numerous times in other cars.  The porsche hasn't had that problem.

Larry Rebarchik

Date: Sun, 8 May 94 15:51:18 +0200
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@janus.hut.fi>
Subject: Re: tire pressures

Thanks for everyone responding to my inquiry about the tire pressures  
for a 944. Among others Jim Pasha and Barney Bettilyon pointed out  
that they can be set at 2.5 bar all around to reduce the  
understeering tendency. Seems to me that one probably wants to do  
this only on dry track conditions though. The increased front  
pressure decreases front brake efficiency and makes it easier to lock  
them up. I certainly like to keep this in mind as it is pretty easy  
to lock them up on a wet road even with lower pressure i.e. larger  
contact patch. Moreover the underseering via lower front pressures is  
enforced by regulations at least in some countries (for safety  
reasons).

Kari Eloranta  

------------------------------

Date: 08 May 94 12:38:17 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Active suspension

 
Bill Conway writes

>This version of AS is semi- rather than fully active; the actuators push down
>only  @ 0 to 2500 psi per corner, revised every 8ms, I think. The Lotus type
>is push-pull (like a low-rider) and can reportedly be programmed to do really
>eerie stuff.

Way back in 1987, I had the opportunity to go around Lotus' test track at the
old WW2 bomber airfield, next to the plant. They had put active suspension
in some old Lotus Elites. I drove, while Roger Becker, Lotus' chief engineer 
(or was he just chief engineer of suspensions? don't remember) worked the 
black box. On one lap, the car responded normally -- leaned out for turns, 
etc. On the next lap around, Roger had reprogrammed it to stay absolutely
flat in the turns. "Now watch this," he said. On the third lap, the car leaned
INTO the turns, like an airplane banking.

You point out that the Infiniti system is not completely active, at least not
by Lotus' definition of the word (no springs, hydraulic actuators must
to all wheel positioning and movement). I don't think anybody has a true
active suspension on the market yet.

I understand one problem with the Infiniti system is that if the controls for
the electronic suspension fail, the car becomes undrivable and must be
towed.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 8 May 94 10:06:27 PDT
From: dorr@hyperion.llnl.gov (Milo Dorr)
Subject: What's a fuel damper?

Triet Le writes: 
>Question: What is a fuel damper, and would replacing a bad one with a
>good one have the effects that I noted?

The function of the damper in Motronic systems is to smooth out the
high frequency oscillations in the fuel pressure caused by the rapid
opening and closing of the injectors.  Although I've never had one go
bad, it is pretty easy to believe that you would have had some
drivability problems if there was a bad part in the injection system.
I'm glad the leak didn't cause you any REALLY bad problems.

>I think that I will invest the $400 in WANG stock. If they win their
>suit against Microsoft, I will cash out and paint the whole car.

What ever happened to making money the old-fashioned way?  Only in America...

 -Milo

Scott Winders wrote:

>I am looking for a pair of 9x16 Fuch wheels (these came in only
>one offset) and a pair of 8x16 Fuch wheels in the 951 offset.

I just went thru the same search.  From what I found there at least two
offsets for the 9x16s (having 911 or 930 series part nos.).  I ended up
buying the deeper backset ones (note change from offset term) that were
about 5.5" of backset.  The other rims (which are still available) are in a
set, and would you believe it, the fronts are 951 series 8x16s]  Both the 8s
and 9s in the set are 5.25" backset....

Now for the bad news:  These wheels were bought new from the factory and
custom painted w/ painted centers (Fly Yellow), then used for about 1K
miles.  Perfect does not come close to describing their condition -- but the
price for what they are is fair: I believe he wants $1400 - $1500 (w/o
tires).  I don't think he's very negotiable on price and he *will not*
separate them.

E-mail me or call if you are interested and I'll relay the phone number on.

 -Scott Jessen

<kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 10:30:33 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: re- 914 problem

>>     The TPS basically has three positions--Wide Open Throttle, Fully Closed
>> Throttle, or Somewhere In Between.  It's actually just two switches.  Since
>> this is happening at part throttle, I'd think that the TPS doesn't have
>> anything to do with it.
>
>While I too suspect the air leak that Dave Darling alludes to on the
>problem 914 in question, it's worth pointing out that the the TPS
>really, really does have three settings -- WOT, FCT, and in between.
>There are limit switches for fully open and *transition* to fully closed from
>somewhat open. There is a bogus squiggly line resistive element for the
>"in between" parts. This wears out, and necessitates replacing the part
>every 10 years or so. Just take it apart sometime and look....

Just for completeness, the "squiggly line" isn't a resistive element,
is is a sequence of switches. Each time the wiper passes from one part
of the line to the next, an extra "injector squirt" is provided. This
therefore acts like an accelerator pump, providing extra gas as a
function of the rate of change of throttle position. Therefore, if you
have symptoms like those of a bad accelerator pump in a carburated car
(hesitation on sudden throttle opening), check these "squiggly lines",
and/or the connections to them.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 09:35:32 PDT
From: lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 11:09:01 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: re: 914 problem (pressure sensor)

>well, assuming I understand your definition of the problem, I have had about
>the same thing.  I didn't really try to fix it, it happened by accident while
>messing around with the system.  The pressure sensor on some 914's has epoxy
>over the end plug, and some don't.  My current car didn't, so I took the
>plug out, and there's an adjustment screw in there.  Turning it too far one
>way seemed to have the effect of having to push the throttle a good distance
>before the engine would accelerate the car.  Turning it too far the other
>way would make the car buck as you describe.  It's most drivable set just
>barely away from where it's bucking.
>
On the 914 pressure sensor, you can make mixture adjustments externally,
with some care. First, the plug itself is part of the adjustment
system. At the factory, it is adjusted to a particular position, and
then sealed with epoxy. The only ones I have seen without epoxy are
sensors which have already been "adjusted", for better or worse. You
can get the epoxy out of a virgin sensor, but it takes some tricks.
You can't just dig out the epoxy from the back, and then unscrew it.
The epoxy will cause the aluminum to gall. I had success with separating
the halves of the sensor (old units had screws, for new units, drill out
the rivets and replace with screws and nuts). Screw the plug into the
housing, away from the epoxy in the threads. Note the angular 
orientation of the plug and its approx. depth before you do this.
Once the plug comes out and goes back in easily, and you know where
you started, you can start adjusting. There are three adjustments,
in terms of mixture change as a function of engine vacuum. The center
screw is the overall mixture. A collar around the center screw, which
has an internal hex, adjusts a break point where the slope of richness
versus vacuum gets steeper. The plug determines the mixture at minimum
vacuum. One of the issues is that turning the center screw (for more
richness over the whole range) may or may not also turn the collar
with the internal hex. You can make a tool like a hollow allen wrench
to hold one and turn the other. The second, and perhaps biggest,
problem is figuring what you really want to do. I have seen lots of
cars with "adjusted" sensors which don't run as well as stock cars.
I would be very cautious of making random adjustments and seeing if
you like it. At the least, get a second sensor (perhaps at a swap
meet), and play with it, keeping the stock unit as a reference to
see if the car is really better when you get done adjusting. Also,
be careful that you are not adjusting around some other problem.
This has a lot in common with random changes to carburator jetting.

While on the subject of sensors, they seem to have a common failure
mechanism where the internal diaphram cracks, causing a vacuum leak
as well as incorrect mixture adjustment. To test, suck on the vacuum
port of the sensor (through a piece of tubing, if you are squeemish).
There should be no air flow. If there is any flow, the sensor has
failed or is failing. This is an easy test at a swap meet, to make
sure you are not buying junk.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: 09 May 94 08:24:22 PDT
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Wheel fans for 911...do they work?


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Wheel fans for 911...do they work?
Date: 1994-05-09 10:16
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Mike Conte wrote:

>I've always had trouble keeping my brakes cool. Currently, I run Motul
>fluid, Pagid pads, Carrera brakes, and the Cool Brake ducts on my 74
>911. I've seen the ads for the GTP wheel fan add-ons for Fuchs allows
>in Pano. Has anyone tried them (or any other wheel fans)? Do they work?

Mike,  I can't help you on the wheel fans.  But in addition to what you are
already doing, I'd try a set of Cool Carbons in the front.  Also, I don't
know what your experience level is, but braking efficiently makes a huge
difference in how much heat you generate (shorter harder braking versus
longer lighter braking).  At your next event you might try talking to folks
that are turning faster lap times than you in similar cars about their
braking points and duration.  If you can get a ride with one of the top
drivers you can learn an immense amount (about more than braking efficiently
too]).  I found that most of my brake heat problems went away as I gained
experience and was more efficient with them (my lap times came down
dramatically, too).

If you are time trialing and have a co-driver you need to adopt some cool
down regimen as well.  On your last lap (cool down lap) be especially carful
to stay off the brakes as much as possible.  If you have room in the pits
you might try running the car at moderate speed without braking to help get
the heat out.  You want to get as much of the heat out *before* you park the
car as you'll have a lot of heat soak occur once the air flow is stopped.
 Good luck...


------------------------------

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 13:10:43 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Accuracy of boost gauge ?

A friend with a tell-tale 930 boost gauge which I've watched during 
on-track antics has over-boost too.  By carefully studying the gauge 
while he drove, I noticed that the "over boost" was actually a 
backwards pressure pulse caused by sudden throttle closure during full 
boost (i.e., during upshift @ full throttle).  The gauge pulsed upwards 
on the back-wave from the throttle plate.

The above assumes a pressure pick-off point before the throttle; a 
manifold pressure monitor _shouldn't_ do the same, though you never 
know with these things...

		JBS

- ----------
> From: Keith M Roberts  <netmail!kroberts@crl.com>

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 10:23:36 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Re- Wheel Studs ) Bolts to

Dave,
(and anyone else that wants studs on a 914)

I've added studs to the rear of my 914 track car.  Quite simple.  
Have the holes drilled out to accept a 911 stud and use 911 studs.
As for the length, you will want longer studs for the rear (has to
go through more).  To do my car, I got a 'cup-o-studs' from one of
the local Porsche body shops that has to remove a lot of studs to
put on longer ones for wheels with spacers, etc., had the holes 
drilled out (rear only so far, I had that apart for the trailing
arm bushings) and press the studs in from the back.  Because my 
914 is a track car, I picked up a bunch of steel lug nuts [4~
(nice Porsche units) and am using them. 

Pat Norris

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 13:14:44 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Tire wear and inflation pre

> > ...If I ran them at max pressure, I would likely end up wearing out the
> > centers of the tread more than the shoulders.
[...]
> > Mike Kohlbrenner
>
> The above has always been the conventional wisdom, and sounds quite
> logical: overinflated tires wear more quickly in the center.  I have been
> informed by my very well respected mechanic that this is no longer the
> case.  In fact, it is quite the opposite.  I do not recall the reasons,
> whether they were related to modern tire design or 911's in specific
> (the former, I think), but he was quite adamant about this.  Has anyone
> got further info?

I've heard this too.  Old bias-ply tires do ballon-out with high 
pressure, but radials have the opposite effect.  I believe (not factual 
science) the reason is that low pressure lets the tire deform at high 
speed, where centrifigal force (sort of - don't bash this from a 
physics point of view!) causes the [now] softer center to bulge out.  
This is exactly the problem that dragsters have in a *big* way on the 
rear tires.

		JBS


		JBS

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 13:05:52 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>

> 1) regions that do time trials require roll cages and other safety equipment
> for good reason: people doing time trials trash their cars!
I agree completely: do NOT let people time trial with rollover 
protection!  Rollovers happen on the track, and at low & high speed 
autocrosses.  Don't wait for a serious injury or death to use common sense.

> 2) time trials are competitive events, driver education events are not.  the
> existence of competition voids warranties and insurance, both of which are
> absolutely in force during driver education events.
re insurance, yes, this is true in Massachusetts USA also.

We've found over the years that some people like time trials, but most 
don't.  I agree that it wastes an inordinate amount of time for very 
little payback.  Lots of our entrants leave, since getting 2 cold 
sprint laps for $65 (our amount back then) is a real waste.  Trading 40 
minutes of track time for 2-3 is dumb for us!

PCA racing, along with other venues, fulfills this need in a more 
structured way that works great for the purpose.  Go racing!

------------------------------

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 13:35:11 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Brazilian story on Senna's Accident

> [...]
> >Tamdurello at least
> > has some grass run off. I agree that a tire wall would help but it 
still may
> > not of saved Senna's life.
> At the speed that Senna hit, tires would do no good, unless they were around
> 20 rows deep -- and then there would be the risk of those same tires doing
> the killing.  Tire walls are great only for lower speed contact.
I disagree.  Senna's forward speed was 186mph, but he didn't hit the 
wall straight-in (90 degrees); he had some angle between 45-60 degrees 
(my estimate), leaving an impact speed of 130mph - 160 mph.  Now, with 
4-6 rows of bolted-together tires, and a wide side pit preceding them, 
the impact force _might_ have been brough below the fatal level.  
Remember, the tires and sand don't have to _prevent_ the impact, they 
just have to lengthen the time of deceleration to reduce the peak force.

> As far as risk, it is true that Senna realized them and was well paid.  But
> does that mean that we should just pay people to take risks or should we
> devote more resources to advance track safety technology?
There's no reason to avoid improving safety.  That corner (and others 
similar to it) should've been fixed after Berger's crash in 1989, if 
not before.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 13:28:11 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: What's a fuel damper?

> From: Triet Le  <netmail!73370.50@CompuServe.COM>
> Subject: What's a fuel damper?
> Date: Saturday, May 7, 1994 5:54PM
[...]
> Question: What is a fuel damper, and would replacing a bad one with a good
> one have the effects that I noted?
Someone else already answered the "what is a damper" question.  If you 
have a bad damper, you'll have all sorts of drivability problems like 
hard starting, incorrect mixture (surging, poor high-rev performance, 
detonation, inability to pass emissions inspection, etc. etc.).  The 
part price you gave sounds OK, but the labor might be a little high if 
the hour was _just_ for replacing the valve.

Splitting hairs over 15-30 minutes labor isn't really good for you or 
the mechanic.  It's when they start kicking the bill up by 25% - 100%, 
or also several thousand dollars, that you need to start asking 
questions.  In *any* event, an attempt to call you for work 
authorization must occur in my opinion.

> PS. How much should it cost to paint the panel in between the front
> headlights? My car is Pearl White (like an Audi) and I was quoted $400.
> This panel is less than 2 square feet. I have 5 stone chips. They say that
> it costs so much because it is a special color, they have to remove the
> lights, the car has to be masked, and because it is a Porsche. The panel is
> straight and requires no bodywork. I think that I will invest the $400 in
> WANG stock. If they win their suit against Microsoft, I will cash out and
> paint the whole car.
Well now!  You may note by my return address that I have an opinion on 
that suit!  Wang needs to make money with good products and services, 
not by winning suits.  But I digress.  :-)

$400 sounds high for a respray of just one panel, especially if you 
bring them the panel (on newer cars with detachable center panel).  
It's a 1 day job, really, and not that hard.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: 9 May 1994 10:40:13 -0800
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 914 Rear Say-bar Results

914 Rear Say-bar Results
Summary of results from 914 rear sway-bar question:

    Most people (about six or seven) advise getting rid of the rear 
bar entirely, or just disconnecting it and tying it out of the way.
(Does not necessarily apply if the car in question has a monster 
bar up front, though....)
    Stan seems to be of this camp, and mentions that his old 1.8L 
racer has *no* sway bars, and that Tad Haas is beating thoroughly-
prepared 2.0L's with it.  (Driver obviously has *something* to do
with it!  ;-)  Bruce A. is also of this camp.  (So were all the
instructors that I talked to at the Zone 7 AX School.)
    Two people suggested keeping the bar, and adjusting the driving
and/or tire pressure until I get handling that I like.
    Two people suggested that it was all personal preference, and
I should think of trying it both ways.

Against most people's better judgement, I'm going to keep the stock
setup.  At least, for a while.  I figure that I can get a much
bigger advantage by simply getting more seat time, and I don't
really want to mess with the suspension at this time.

- --DD

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 13:48:53 -0400
From: kennedy@admin.njit.edu (William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648)
Subject: what Senna died for

Kyle Ehler asks whether racing is "... testing human interface, or automotive
technology, or medical technology?"

None of the above.  Motor racing is entertainment, and will probably be less
successful (as entertainment), not more, as Kyle's three technologies reach
higher levels of refinement.  If that means changing the Formula One rules to
require M&S tires, or figure-eight racing, or no onboard electronics, that's
what we'll get.  Racing without the entertainment revenue is just a brutally
expensive test track, with your technological competitors taking notes on
everything you do.  

B.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 09 May 1994 11:19:34 PDT
From: Greg DesBrisay <gd@cellnet.com>
Subject: Re: mail filter 


Mitch,

I use mh as my mail handler and have found the pick and sortm command
to be pretty handy.  I've set up some aliases to sort all of my
discussion list mail into separate folders, then I sort the folders
according to subject.  That makes it fairly easy to go down the list
of new mail and delete entire batches of mail in which I have no
interest and then devote more of my time to reading the mail in which
I do have an interest.

Here's my alias that picks out the porschephiles mail, files into a
folder called porschephiles.new, and then sorts the folder according
to subject:

alias porschepick	'refile `pick +inbox -from tta.com -or -to tta.com -or -cc tta.com` +porschephiles.new >& /dev/null; sortm -textfield subject +porschephiles.new >& /dev/null'

This alias is included with my other "<list>pick" aliases in another
alias that runs whenever I want to look at and filter my incoming
mail.


I read my mail from within emacs using rmail.  The emacs interface
makes it really easy to review the subject lines of the new mail,
delete anything I don't want to spend time on, and then read the stuff
I want to.  One of these days I'll figure out how to do all this from
within emacs, it has the capability to do so, and I won't have to
suspend emacs everytime I want to incorporate and filter my new mail!

Greg DesBrisay
'67 912






------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 1994 14:13:04 EST
From: reid_zeigler@merck.com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: time trials

re: posting from ? Northwest REgion

NNJR-PCA (Northern New Jersey Region) has done time trials
and I don't think there are insurance problems or additional
equipment requirements as long as cars run solo on the track.

I find them totally boring as a spectator, however they do
allow the driver to push the envelope a bit without endangering
other drivers' sheet metal. I've seen a lot of cars off track,
but no serious accidents, whereas in drivers ed events, there 
have been a few upside-down cars and seriously bent fenders.

You might want to talk to our region president, Ken Geiger
10 Arlena Terrace, Ramsey NJ 07446 - 908-241-7750 (work)
to see how our region handles rules, insurance etc.

 - Reid

Ok, I think too much bandwidth has been allocated for the RX vs Porshit 944T.

But that post really hit a nerve...

If I had to choose between a 944 Turbo and an RX7 Turbo II, I would take the 
later. Both are fast. The RX turbo II has one the smooth power, the 944T has 
the loudest , buzziest 4 cylinder in the market. Who came up with the idea of
a 3 liter four cylinder ? Its not my idea of a smooth revving engine.

And if you compare 944 turbo with third gen RX7s, there is no comparison.
The 93+s also beat all the 968s out there. And put $3k on a 93 and you can 
suck the doors of a 911 turbo (great car nonetheless).

Nobody mentioned the reliability of all Porsches. My cousin has a 944 non 
turbo and spends $3000 every year on tune ups , maintenance etc. She 
drives the car like a granny and only on weekends.  

I think Porsche had an edge in the 1960s and 70s. Now rice rules !

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 16:13:16 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: time trials

>From: bart@research.att.com
>
>>We're going to start running time trials for the first time here in the 
>>Northwest. We plan to use the same car classes as the PCA Club Racing 
>>rules describe (tho we won't require roll cage, etc). Partly because 
>
>this is a seriously bad idea, and i hope words don't fail me.
>
>ahem, <flame on>..
>
>1) regions that do time trials require roll cages and other safety equipment
>for good reason: people doing time trials trash their cars!
>
>2) time trials are competitive events, driver education events are not.  the
>existence of competition voids warranties and insurance, both of which are
>absolutely in force during driver education events.
>
>3) time trials waste time.  if you rent a track for a weekend, why waste the
>last 1/3 of available track time with only 1 or 2 cars on the track at a time?
>
>if you want to race, go racing.
>
><flame off>

Just to offer a second opinion, several regions in Zones 1 and 2 have for
a number of years occasionally run time trials as the last portion of
drivers education events. It was actually more popular perhaps 10 years
ago than today, but I think the data should still be relevant. Several
regions were still running such events up until a few years ago. I don't
know if they have continued to do so now that PCA racing is available.

The safety requirements are the same as those for drivers education (roll
bar in open cars, etc.) rather than the more stringent requirements
of full race cars (cages, full drivers suits, racing belts, etc).
The number of incidents during the time trial phase tended to be as
low or lower than the incidents during the drivers ed. phase. As you
mention, the time trial aspect changes the insurance issue, although
not all insurance companies will swallow a drivers ed. accident
anyway (but some will). On the issue of wasting time, this was always
a strong bone of contention. There were always a set of drivers ed.
attendees who wanted more track time, and would avoid the time trials,
and another set who were very enthusiastic about time trials. There
were enough of the latter to keep running them.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 14:10:41 PDT
From: Mike Conte <mikecon@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Wheel fans for 911...do they work?

Thanks for the response, Scott. I've got Cool Carbons in my car now, 
because I couldn't get Pagids in time for the last track day. I've 
driven both and while the Cool Carbons are quite good, the Pagids are 
even better. Too bad, as the Cool carbons are cheaper! Our local track 
here in Seattle has lots of elevation change and is hard on brakes, so 
I'm often in the middle of a mini parade around the track access road 
with others cooling their brakes too.

I'm interested in any info on braking technique which would reduce 
boiling. My guess is that longer, lighter braking would reduce peak 
temperatures. There isn't anyone going faster in a similar car, tho I 
know I tend to brake later and harder than most. Perhaps my problem is 
my motor is too small - I'm trying to make up too much in braking!

BTW, Douglas Dykaar  <netmail!dougie@physics.att.com> has reported to 
me that wheel fans make about a 10 def F difference on the front of his 
951 at Watkins Glen. So not a lot.

Mike

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 10:42:22 PDT
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Re: 911 valve adjustment

After adjusting the valves for the first time on my 71 911E, I have
a few comments that hopefully will make the job easier for any other
neophytes.

It's just like adjusting VW valves, right? Why pay your mechanic an 
exorbidant fee? 

After psyching myself up (it's been years since I did anything more
complicated than change the plugs), I started to pop off the valve
covers - wait - there are _4_ of them, and a few dozen nuts holding them
on.  OK, no problem.  oops, I didn't expect 2 quarts of oil to flow all
over me and the driveway when I took off the lower covers :-).  

Funny that my Haynes manual didn't mention to drain the oil first.

My local Porsche parts house provided me with a valve cover gasket
set, which comes with a full set of nylock nuts and washers. They
also sold me a special feeler gauge that has a curved handle and
replaceable blade.

After making it through about 4 valves, I broke the blade off my
special new Porsche feeler gauge. I tried my regular feeler gauge
and broke the blade off of that too. Being Sunday afternoon, and
with everyone closed, I had to wait until the following weekend
to continue the job. I left the valve covers off and the hoses and
wires disconnected so I could easily take up where I left off.

A few days later, I got a note in the mail from the apartment mananger:
"We will be resurfacing the parking lots soon, please be prepared to
move your car at moment's notice. Recall that your rental contract
states that non-running vehicles are prohibited." :-)

When I stopped by the Porsche shop the following week, I asked the owner
if it was common to break feeler-gauge blades during valve adjustment.
He said with a straight face, "It all depends on the skill of the user,
I've had mine for years.  I have some mechanics who are in here every
week for a new one."  Biting my tongue, resisting the urge to describe
what I felt would be an appropriate torture for the engineer who ignored
the mechanic when he designed the cylinder heads, I forked over the 95
cents apiece for several replacement blades for the feeler gauge.
One of the mechanics there mentioned that he has ground away parts of
the handle to  get better clearance.

Continuing the job, I tried to psych myself info the brain-surgeon
delicate-touch mode (while rolling around in oily kitty litter
in my carport) and took care to preserve the feeler gauge.

It is worth noting that the crank pulley has three notches, at
0, 120, and 240 degrees, that can be used to aid in valve adjustment
(there are also two marks near 30 degrees BTDC which should be
ignored). Pull your spark plugs and put the tranny in neutral and you
should be able to turn the crankshaft with a wrench on the fan pulley
nut. You will probably have to press the fan belt in with your free
hand to keep it from slipping. Read the decals on the bottom edge of
the engine bay to get the firing order and cylinder positions.
Once you find one cylinder at TDC (it's easiest to start by lining
up the crank pulley at 0, at that point cylinder 1 will either be
on its compression or exhaust stroke. Grab the cam followers and try to
wiggle them - if there is any play, then cylinder 1 is on its compression
stroke and you can adjust its valves. Otherwise, it is on its exhaust
stroke and you need to rotate the crank one turn in order to get to
the compression stroke (if you are not confident, you can always peek
at the distributor rotor, it will point toward the the plug wire that is
firing, i.e. the cylinder that is at TDC on its compression stroke).  
Both valves are closed and can be adjusted when the piston is at TDC on
the compression stroke.  Once you are in sync, you can proceed to the
next cylinder in the firing sequence by rotating the crank 120 degrees
(to the next pulley notch) clockwise.  In this manner you can adjust the
valves with a minimum of crankshaft turning.

The green machine is now back on the road, I drove it to work today
and it seems to be running fine, no leaks, no new noises.

 -Mitch Craig

------------------------------

Date: Mon,  9 May 94 13:37:15 PDT
From: Mike Conte <mikecon@microsoft.com>
Subject: FW: cool brakes

Thought I'd forward to the list....
- ----------
From: Mike Conte
To: Magnus Ottenstrom  <netmail!magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: RE: cool brakes
Date: Friday, May 06, 1994 10:37AM

Thanks for the reply.

More air is the key, no doubt. One guy I know who tried wheel fans only 
saw 10 deg C difference with them on, tho I heard this third hand and 
I'd like to know more.

One way for you to do ducting is to replace your air dam with a Carrera 
air dam. It has the cut outs for fog lights and you can run ducts from 
there. You would need to replace your wiper washer tank, and the 
Carrera one is shaped differently to fit behind the air dam. It looks 
more stock than an RSR front spoiler, tho you could use one of those too.

I have heard that most racers have moved away from squirting water on 
the brakes to introducing water vaper into the brake cooling ducts. 
This gives good evaporative cooling, but doen't have the bad effects of 
warping rotors or reducing friction. You might, in fact, use less water.

As you point out, most of these systems are pretty primitive, in that 
it is up to you to decide when to squirt the water. You could leave it 
on all the time, but water is heavy so you'd better have short 
sessions! A better system would be one that has its own feedback loop. 
Temperature Thermocouples are pretty cheap (US$30) tho you'd need to 
build something to read them and respond. Your idea about the brake 
light is a good one - easy and perhaps good enough. You could even add 
in a little delay, like pump for 5 seconds after the brake light goes 
off too, so you could tap your brakes to start the system at will.

Another system I have seen from Tilton (I think), is a brake fluid 
recirculating system. You run brake lines back from the bleed valves in 
each caliper to the recirculator which has it's own bleed valve. The 
action of the brakes recirculates fluid, the idea being that only a few 
ounces of fluid in the caliper get hot anyway. This doesn't cool your 
brakes, but does help prevent you from boiling the fluid. NASCAR guys 
use them so they can run smaller air ducts, meaning higher top speed. I 
think the Tilton peice runs about $300, tho installing it isn't 
trivial. I haven't tried one.

Cool carbons will make a big difference for you. The thicker the pad, 
the better heat isolation from the caliper, so don't run them down too 
far.  Pagids are even better, but more expensive. The Motul will 
definitely help too, and changing it often will help. If you don't have 
Cool Brake ducts, those will also help. Removing the rear brake backing 
plates will also improve cooling, tho it isn't often that the rear 
brakes will overheat.

Hey, I like the new Saab!

Mike
- ----------
From: Magnus Ottenstrom  <netmail!magot@weald.air.saab.se>
To: Mike Conte
Subject: cool brakes
Date: Friday, May 06, 1994 10:00AM


Mike

I don't have any experience with cooling fans for brakes
but an increase in air velocity will improve the cooling.

I have a similar problem and I don't want to cut out scoops
in the front spoiler. So I have considered making some kind
of water cooling of the brakes. What do you think about that?

A bottle could be placed in the trunk (replace the spare wheel
when running on the track). One could use a windshield washer
tank and pump and have the hoses directed to the discs/calipers.

You would then have to press a button on the straights when you
notice that the brakes get hot.

Complicated? Not really. Drawbacks? Cracking or changes of the
metal characteristics?

This metod is used in truck racing although they have a constant
flow of water. One could also consider to take the brake light
signal to control a relay which makes the pump to start when
you press the brake pedal...

Just an idea...

Good luck

Magnus
'82 911 SC
Sweden

P.S. People are telling me that it's my braking technique
that makes the brakes to get too hot and they are probably
right. This season I have new Cool Carbons and Motul brake
oil so it will be fun to see how it works when I go to the
tracks next time.

Date: Mon, 09 May 1994 17:11:29 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com  ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re:time trials vs. driver ed.

In reply to Mike's posting about the PNW Region starting a Time Trial
Series, Bart makes some interesting observations some of which I agree with
and some of which I don't.  The "I don't" follows:

Bart says:
...'time trials waste time.  if you rent a track for a weekend, why waste
the last 1/3 of available track time with only 1 or 2 cars on the track at
a time?...if you want to race, go racing.'...<

Barney responds:
Come on, Bart, you get what you pay for.  I would rather spend 2/3rds of a
weekend driving 10/10ths and then sit in line for an hour waiting for my
timed run, than I would spending ALL of a weekend driving 7/10ths.  But
it's just a personal preference.

The way I see all this Autocross, Driver Ed., Time Trial, Club Racing
stuff, (in that order) is that they are all just stepping stones on the
way to learning how to drive your car.  If you don't want to time trial
then don't, but at the same time, don't try to discourage someone else
from giving it a try.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     autoXer/racer   SLC

Date: Mon, 9 May 1994 15:27:35 +0800
From: Pete.Rado@Corp.Sun.COM (Pete Rado)
Subject: Time Trials

I first joined the Porsche Club on the east coast, where time trials are not done
and later moved to the GGR region of California where time trials are done.  Saftey
equipment on cars is a function of level of modification.  There are 3 classes or levels
of modification that do not require roll bars....they are basically stock and stock with
minor, reversable mods.

I've seen easterners bounce of tire walls in "driver eductation"
and I've seen GGR drivers do the same.  I can't say I've seen any difference in frequency
or the severity of the accidents.  I've never seen anyone injured.
My observation is that the accidents that involve
bent metal are more often piloted by experienced drivers (yes instructurs) than not.

The plus side of time trials is you can see that you are improving.  At the Russel school,
for example, timed laps are a major portion of the program cause you can't always tell that
your technique is improving by the seat of your pants....its measured in time.  Saftey is
still the number one emphasis and improvement in time is encouraged thru a better smoother
line, not by taking unnecessary risks.  Those felt to be taking too much risk are asked
to leave.

The negative side is the loss of Sunday afternoon to 3 unimpeeded timed laps vs. a possible 
2 @20 minute run groups....But you do drive all day Saturday.

Another negative is that if you caught up in the competition of it all....well, hold
on to your wallets!  There is a lot of serious money, 50K and up, easilly invested
in changes to Porshces to try to be the fastest in the class or on the track.  Most of
the cars here are trailered to the track (not street legal) and those who have a totally 
stock porsche can
be counted on 2 hands.  On the east coast, it was the other way around.

Anyway, if you want to know the specifics of how the time trials are run, the different
classes and level of saftey equipment, contact Henry Watts (his number is in a recent
mail on autox school) and ask him to send you a copy of the GGR time trial rules.
Henry led a group to rewrite the rules for 1994 and they did a good job.  No need to
start from scratch.  I'm sure he will share them with other PCA regions.

Pete



	From porschephiles-request@tta.com Mon May  9 15:09 PDT 1994
	From: bart@research.att.com
	Date: Mon, 9 May 94 07:34:49 PDT
	To: porschephiles@tta.com

	this is a seriously bad idea, and i hope words don't fail me.
	
	ahem, <flame on>..
	
	1) regions that do time trials require roll cages and other safety equipment
	for good reason: people doing time trials trash their cars!
	
	2) time trials are competitive events, driver education events are not.  the
	existence of competition voids warranties and insurance, both of which are
	absolutely in force during driver education events.
	
	3) time trials waste time.  if you rent a track for a weekend, why waste the
	last 1/3 of available track time with only 1 or 2 cars on the track at a time?
	
	if you want to race, go racing.
	
	<flame off>

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 17:50:50 -0600
From: Drew A. Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: Time Trials, a waste?



Begin forwarded message:

> >We're going to start running time trials for the first time here in the 

> >Northwest. We plan to use the same car classes as the PCA Club Racing 

> >rules describe (tho we won't require roll cage, etc). Partly because 

> 

> this is a seriously bad idea, and i hope words don't fail me.
> 

> ahem, <flame on>..

Hmmm, where's that bottle of dry chemical....
........Oh, there it is.....
SSSSWWWIIIISSSSHHHH>.......Hack, cough wheese....

Fire's out.  Now, where were we?....

> 

> 1) regions that do time trials require roll cages and other safety equipment
> for good reason: people doing time trials trash their cars!

I guess this depends upon what you define as "trash"...
People will occasionally do something bad to their cars at a time trial, but
trashing seems to be somewhat infrequent (depending upon whether their driving
at 8/10ths or 10/10ths). People who trash cars at the track probably do the 

same on the street except it just takes a little longer and the safety issues
are much greater (i.e. no corner workers, other drivers, etc.)

The POC does not mandate a roll bar/cage for cars
running in "bone-stock" class, but they remain highly advised.  

I wouldn't run a high speed event without one.

> 

> 2) time trials are competitive events, driver education events are not.  the
> existence of competition voids warranties and insurance, both of which are
> absolutely in force during driver education events.

Clubs like POC/PCA have driver education events during time-trial/club-race
weekends.  This usually manifests itself as a distinct run group for 

students/instructors where speed is monitored by the instructure and
emphasis is place on car control and learning the line.  Prior to a 

student going "solo" they must be allowed to by their instructor. 

Shit happens, however, so when entering this type of event, one must
be realistic about the possibilities of something happening.  It seems
to me to be the same philosophy most of us may have about driving to 

and from our place of employ every day...    


> 

> 3) time trials waste time.  if you rent a track for a weekend, why waste the
> last 1/3 of available track time with only 1 or 2 cars on the track at a  
time?

I guess it depends upon how the event is run.  The events I've attended at 

Phoenix and Las Vegas were full weekends where everybody had 8 20-minute
practice sessions with the last session of the day on Sunday being the timed
runs.  During the practice sessions, there were as many as 15-20 cars on the
track at once with strict passing rules.

As far as time trials being a "waste", the seat time provided through the
events (at least the way they're run out here) is invaluable at learning how
to handle the car at speed and to learn the proper line.

For most new drivers on the track, they usually have their hands full just
trying to coordinate the necessary actions to keep the car on the surface
at the correct location and speed without the worry of cars attempting
passes on either side.  


Before I'd go wheel to wheel with anyone, I'd want to feel that I had some
degree of trust in the other drivers' familiarity with the track and ability 

to control their vehicles.

> 

> if you want to race, go racing.
> 

> <flame off>
>

Granted.  However, it's probably a good idea to learn how to drive 

before attempting to race.  That is, of course, unless you don't 

care about trashing your car...

Drew

------------------------------

Date: 9 May 1994 17:57:44 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Re: Which 911 is the better

        Reply to:   RE>>Which 911 is the better
>> Steve,
>> 
>> You couldn't have picked two cars on more opposite ends if you tried.  The
>> 69-73 911S's, light, agile, fast, original body style, etc. are highly
>> desirable and will be (or are) collector items.  These cars are 
>> appreciating fast.  The 74-77 911S's, with their overstressed 2.7
>> magnesium cases and their thermal smog equipment (and associated
>> overheating, oil leaking, short engine-life nature) did terrible things to
>> Porsche and their owners.  These cars have a very low resale value. 
>> Simple choice, really.
>
> I thought the 69-73 S was or will be a collector also.  A local consignment
> dealer assured me that they are not and that the carbureted S's are the ones
> in demand right now.  He said he gets one call a week from Europeans asking
> if he has one.  Please assure me that he is incorrect.  I want to buy a
> 911 that has real appreciation potential as well as POWER.

I am quite certain he is wrong.  In fact I know that in 69 the wheelbase was
increased by 2.5", moving the engine forward a bit, which resulted in more
than a litte improvement in handling.  The rear fender was also slightly flared
for larger tires, and there were some other weight shifts made for better
balance.  These were important changes for handling.  The performance was
better too with its 170-190 hp lightweight cast magnesium case.  About the
only criticism was the Bosch mechanical injection which is hard to tune.  But
many porschephiles have said they work great(!) if you don't neglect them.

68 was considered a bad year due to the poor air injection emission control,
problems with improper plugs and timing that resulted in pitted/burned pistons;
there was no USA "S" due to emission trouble.  66 had weird front end shake
problems, tire balance problems, and strange iron weights in the bumpers to
deal with the weight bias, front to rear.  The Solex carbs were a disaster.
67 was a better year with its Webers and the "S" was nice.

I think you'll find POWER a tradeoff here.  Earlier cars were lighter so they
were more tossable and very fun to drive (I had a '66 25 years ago).  But later
cars had more hp.  However, the 73S was faster than all other 911's built until
the SC came out in 78 (which matched its 0-60 time of 7.0 sec).  Excluding the
930, of course.

You might look up the 911S Registry, a club for pre-74 911S owners.  I've seen
their ads in R&T or Excellence or Panorama?  I'll bet a porschephile would know
an address & number.  These guys could probably clear up any confusion here.

BTW, some of our European friends on the net have pointed out that they get a
tremendous import break on "antique" cars.  Trond Vidar Olsen in Norway, for
instance, is looking for a 66 or older 911 to save $thousands.  (It needs to be
*manufactured* 30 years ago and he wants to buy it next year.)  I wonder if
this dealer you're talking to isn't confused because of this?  It might explain
the demand.

>> $12k for a 76 is just an average price.  $9.5k for a 73 is a very good one.
> 
> I found out that new valves, pistons, and cylinders were put in 9K miles ago.
> There is one small dent above the right rear tail light from a shopping cart.
> The owner's mechanic says the bumper was misaligned from the impact as well.
> There is a hole in the muffler from condensation.  The owner did a lot of 
> short distance (<2miles) driving and water didn't have a chance to burn off
> according to the mechanic.  No Carrera tensioners.  It has the Turbo
tensioners
> with guards.
>
> Also there is wear on the drivers side carpet, and I guess the interior is in
> good shape not excellent.  There is a crack in the dash.
>
> Do you still think its a very good deal?  What is the price range for a '73S
> in your area?

These old cars can cost a mint to get right, especially if they've been neglected.
If this is in "average shape", as it sounds it is, I would guess that $9.5k is
still
pretty good.  A very good example of a 73S would cost over $20k.  You do the
math.
If the rebuild was good and the rust is contained I'd go for it.  You might
want to
do some legwork on the maintenance history.  Especially the rebuild.  And watch
that rust.  Quarter panels, taillight boxes (actually unscrew them and pull
them
out!), torsion bars, u-joints, floorboard, gas tank, upper rear of fenders,
lower
rear windshield corners.  I would worry about rust most of all.  The dash work
and the rest of the interior is a pain but it can wait.  The engine and body
can't.

Good luck.  Sorry for the long posting.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 21:48 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: bad A/C compressor on 944

Mark,

Kind of an unusual problem, but what the hey.  Usually, nay almost
invariably, you get a hose leak at one of its ends.  Porsche also had
a bunch of bad o-rings and released a tech bulletin on the matter a
few years ago.

I'd think about a remanufactured part, available from Porsche or in the
aftermarket, rather than a new one.  No idea on pricing.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 21:52 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Which wheels for 83 944?

Frank,

"Phone dials" are definitely available in early offset and in 7x16 and
8x16 sizes.  Which set-up you choose, in terms of wheel diameter and
width, is really a trade-off among performance, comfort, and budget.
And aesthetics too, I reckon.

The Robt Woods deal mentioned by someone else is a good one.  He has
only the 7x16 Fuchs at that price, and the 8x16 are still fairly dear.
If I were looking for phone dials, I'd try 944 Ecology first, then
Robert Woods.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 21:48 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Tranny gear teeth!?!?

They're not "synchro teeth;" they are teeth off the dog gears.  The good
news, such as it is, is that in 911 gear boxes a dog gear presses onto its
gear and may be separately replaced, much less expense.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 21:48 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Help! Info about Glockler Porsches

In addition to Peter's list, Gloeckler's are also covered in Boschen and
Barth's "Porsche Specials," which is a really neat book.

Kevin

Date: Mon, 9 May 94 21:48 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: air filter

>  I beleive the proper oil for use in air filtration applications is 
>actually water-soluble.  This is so cleaning of the filter can be done
>using soap and water rather than solvent.

Well, this is probably nice to have.  But I just use ATF, and I clean
the filter by wetting it with water and Simple Green, then rinsing,
press most of the water out by wrapping in a towel, dry overnight, and
re-oil.

Works for me.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 1994 03:07:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: Bill <sesquive@mailbox.syr.edu>
Subject: Re: Porsche Supercup on ESPN! (fwd)


For those interested in the SuperCup on ESPN, Bruce Anderson supplied 
mme with the following interesting bits.

Hi Bill,

Originally Brumos had a twin turbo 993 ordered to run in the GT 1 class of
IMSA. Porsche canceled the order when they decided that they were going to
run the Dauer 962s at Le Mans. Porsche felt that they would be too busy
developing those cars to do the 993 turbo as well. Because there wasn't going
to be anything 993 running here in the US PCNA decided that they wanted to
have the SuperCup races televised. Nick Ham is running a few of the races,
but originally they planned to have both Nick Ham and Price cop running in
the whole series. They had US sponsors and buyers for the cars, but they
never came up with enough sponsorship to make it happen. Ham made a deal with
Franz Konrad to run the car for him for a few races, I think 4. Ham placed
ninth at San Marino. The Porsche Club of America has decals on the car. It is
too bad that they didn't get their deal together it would have been great to
see both Nick and Price Cobb running their cars in Europe. 

Bruce Anderson



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 16:54:46 SGP
From: Lawrence Leong <lawrence@hpsgsh.sgp.hp.com>
Subject: Re: air filter

Kyle Ehler answering my question on oil for recyclable filters:

>  Bob, Lawrence, and those who use recyclable filters:
>
>  I beleive the proper oil for use in air filtration applications is 
>actually water-soluble.  This is so cleaning of the filter can be done
>using soap and water rather than solvent.  "filter coat" as it is known
>in the HVAC business, is used on many filters to boost performance.
>
>  The ingredients on my can are as follows;
>   Soluble hydrocarbon oil............. 48.0%
>   Sodium ortho-phenylphenate..........  0.5%
>   Polyethylene thickener..............  1.5%
>   Propellant: Methylene Chloride...... 20.0%
>               Dichlorodiflouromethane. 30.0%  <--why we dont use it anymore.
>   Vendor:  Research Products  Item # 418
>            Madison, Wi  53701

Kyle, K&N sells an alkaline-solution for cleaning the filters.  It feels
like some petrol-based cleaner in an alkaline carrier.  It's quite an
effective degreaser too (better than say, AutoGlym "Machine Clean").  The
can of K&N oil I have doesn't list the contents though, but I still think
it's oil-based.

Anyway, Methylene Chloride, if my memory serves right, is a suspected
carcinogen and known tumorigen (sp?).  It should not be used around
pregnant and/or lactating women -- it could be passed to the baby.  It was
a good solvent initially, but after reading the MSDS.....

Thanks for the info tho.  I'll check out with the facilities guys if they
can get any of this "Filter Coat."  BTW, what is the colour of "Filter Coat"?
Is the K&N oil red just becoz of colouring matter (curious minds want to
know)?  Again, anyone know for sure?

Lawrence

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 11:46:00 UTC

Subject: Time Trials

  >We're going to start running time trials for the first time here in the
  >Northwest. We plan to use the same car classes as the PCA Club Racing
  >rules describe (tho we won't require roll cage, etc).
  We used to run them here in the Northeast but they dropped off due mostly
to taking to much time away from track events.  They were very popular in
the begining and since you have not had them out there, they probably will
be for you as well.  If you want some help setting them up, two very active
Riesentoter members just moved up there and you could probably get them
involved.  The names are Dr. Debbie Cooper and her hubby, Bill.
  BTW, we didn't require roll bars unless you had a cab of course.  Course,
times have changed and cars are, on average, much more powerfull.  One thing
we discussed here was determining the roll bar requirement based on the car.
It was the modified ones we were thinking of, i.e., if someone is willing to
spend mega bucks to get a 500hp car, perhaps a roll bar is not out of line.
It never went anywhere as the time trial series dropped off.

actuator went out. In all cases the car was very driveable, and was repaired

small coil-overs on each actuator that apparently handle this chore, among

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 07:10:41 PDT
From: bart@research.att.com

>911. I've seen the ads for the GTP wheel fan add-ons for Fuchs allows
>in Pano. Has anyone tried them (or any other wheel fans)? Do they work?

i haven't, but i know people in nnjr and cvr who have and swear by them
("they *really* work" is the generic response).  gtp doesn't make adapters
for all wheels - my 951S' stars, for example - and i'm not sure if/how
paint sticks to these grey babies.

btw my cvr friends *melted* their wheel fans on a hot day at new hampshire
intl speedway..

>I'm interested in any info on braking technique which would reduce 
>boiling. My guess is that longer, lighter braking would reduce peak 

guess again!  staying off your brakes AMAP - for reasons i don't completely
understand - works better.  some possible explanations: 1) "taking it easy",
eg going slower in turns, actually means *more* work for your brakes, 2)
less time at higher temp actually results in more heat transfer - hopefully
to the air, 3) less time for pad/rotor ccontact reduces the amount of heat
transfer to the rest of the brake system, 4) can it be that ablation -
making your pads disappear faster - dissipates significant energy mechanically?

point 2&3 can be argued either way - i'd like to see a numerical simulation..

 -bart

Howdy all,

I ran into a MAJOR problem this weekend while fixing the broken
rear trunk bolts (standard 914 failure).  Instead of the mount
ripping off the engine compartment wall, the bolts actually
broke off inside the mount.  I removed the trunk, and the hinges, but
I can't get out the remains of those bolts.  I used WD-40, and my
snap-on extractor (aka eaxy-out) to no avail.  Those bolt ends
are REALLY frozen.

The only solution I see at this point is to grind off the old mounts
and weld on new ones.  This isn't a really pleasant option :-(. Does
anyone have an alternative that I could try?

ANY comments and suggestions appreciated.

Alex (noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 11:05:36 -0700
From: keith_watson@rainbow.mentorg.com (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: Wheel fans for 911...do they work?

Mike,

> ... Our local track
> here in Seattle has lots of elevation change and is hard on brakes ...

> I'm interested in any info on braking technique which would reduce
> boiling. My guess is that longer, lighter braking would reduce peak
> temperatures. There isn't anyone going faster in a similar car, tho I
> know I tend to brake later and harder than most. Perhaps my problem is
> my motor is too small - I'm trying to make up too much in braking!

I have over 1,000 miles at Portland in a stock 911SC.  I also race a
VW Golf at both Portland and Seattle.  Both cars are very hard on front
brakes.  I started track driving in the 911 and was always dynamiting
the brakes.  It would stop quick on the track when the brakes were hot
but not on the way home when the brakes were cold.  I learned that
longer lighter pressure on the brakes keep the brake fluid from
boiling as bad.

My Golf needs a lot of air getting to the front brakes since it is
heavy (2200 lbs :-) and has disks in the front and drums in the rear.
It has an air dam with brake ducting.  The brake ducting is aluminum
dryer ducting (like aluminum foil) with NO wire in it.  If you go off
course you don't want wire getting caught up in the rotating
components.  A single 2" diameter duct on each side isn't big
enough on my car.  I need either two 2" ducts or one 3" duct.

I would highly recommend what someone else said and get a front spoiler
which has brake ducting holes in it.  Then move the pickup point on
you Cool Brake Ducts to the openings in the spoiler.  The RS style
spoiler looks nice too. :-)

Keith Watson
Oregon Region
81 911SC Targa


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 12:33:57 CDT
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Which 911 is the better


The previous posts have said it all. The 76 should be avoided. The 73 S
is either being sold by an uninformed person or has some other major
problem. This car should sell for at least $15K ($20K would be more
like it) if it were a really straight 73S. A proper mechanical
restoration could cost $8K to $12K depending. The body and interior
could go to $6K easily (repaint). I am suspicious of the shopping cart
story (what was in that cart  to bend the bumper...lead or uranium?). I
would have a leakdown test performed and a Porsche-experienced body
shop look at the car.  It may have been hit a long time ago. How much
money are you willing to spend to get the S right?


One could argue forever about if the 911 is collectible. I would say
yes for the 911S because they will fetch $20K-$30K for a proprly
restored car. When the price gets to that level more people are
motivated to collect/restore the cars. The 911Es are $8-10K lower on
average and have not reached collector status. But 911E prices have
been going up slowly (wishful thinking here??) as the Ss disappear into
the hands of collectors. 911s are not priced as high as some cars they
competed with in the 70s (XKE for instance)... and are close to some
others (Corvette, Camaro, Mustang). At least the old 911s have a
limited supply (as opposed to SCs which are in some ways a more sound
way to spend your$$) in that they have either been hacked up to the
point of no return by well meaning owners in the late70s/early 80s or
have rusted into oblivion.



Bill Hutton 

'71 911E coupe (whose mechanical
restoration will be complete on Friday!!)
