Date: Tue, 10 May 94 14:17:02 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: brake harder for cooler brakes...

Bart writes:
> guess again!  staying off your brakes AMAP - for reasons i don't completely
> understand - works better.  some possible explanations: 

> 1) "taking it easy", eg going slower in turns,
>     actually means *more* work for your brakes, 

While that's true, it's not what he said - he was saying taking it easy on
the brakes - not applying them hard, presumably to get down to the same
cornering speed. And that doesn't work because the disks have this pad pressing
against them for a longer time. They cool better when there's air flowing over 
them instead.

> 2) less time at higher temp actually results in more heat transfer 
>    - hopefully to the air,

This effect does work - there is an analogue in the coffee drinking world:
if you put your cream in the coffee right away, the coffee is hotter after
ten minutes than if you put the cream in at 9 minutes and 56 seconds. This
is because objects at a higher temperature radiate and convect heat away
more rapidly.

> 3) less time for pad/rotor ccontact reduces the amount of heat
>    transfer to the rest of the brake system,

Probably not - the amount of energy involved getting from speed V down to
speed v is the same either way, and it all turns to heat...

> 4) can it be that ablation -
> making your pads disappear faster - dissipates significant energy mechanically

For carbon/carbon brake systems like they use in F1, this IS the best way to
prevent brake system overheat, but for us regular semi-metalic or Cool Carbon
on steel disk types, the ablation isn't much of an effect.

The flat-out best way to reduce brake system heat is: go faster in the turns.
Really, this isn't as dumb as it sounds. Lots of folks try a track event, they
don't have brake trouble, then they start going faster on the straights and
cook their brakes going through the turns slow, then when they pass a certain
plateau, and start cornering faster, the brake trouble goes away...

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 13:44:55 EDT
From: dougie@physics.att.com (Douglas Dykaar)
Subject: braking-longer and harder


in my 86 951, one second of braking raises the temp ~ 10 degrees (F), one second of no brakes cools them ~1 degree.
temperatures measured at the brake pad backing plate.
I don't have data for hard vs soft pedal, I'm usually too busy driving to watch the gauge...

doug

Date: Tue, 10 May 1994 10:30:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Matsumura <tedm@rahul.net>
Subject: Re: Which 911 is the better

Keep in mind that from '76 on, the paint process was improved to prevent 
rust.  Also, although the 74-76 2.7's have major reliability problems, a 
used sports car from the '60s is likely to also have a rebuild or two or 
replacement by now as well as the 70s car.

I'd recommend to new 911 owners to get a '78 SC if they can come up with 
15K or so.  Reason is the 3.0 engine, and body capable of wide 
wheels/tires, plus the improved paint.  None of the previous 911's have 
any of these much desired features, except '76+ have the improved paint.

I think the early 911's probably make excellent project and antique cars, 
but not daily drivers (unless you're a mechanic, and then you probably 
have a "fleet" of british cars too... <g>)

Ted

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 15:41:48 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 914 trunk lid problem

> The only solution I see at this point is to grind off the old mounts
> and weld on new ones.  This isn't a really pleasant option :-(. Does
> anyone have an alternative that I could try?
> ANY comments and suggestions appreciated.
> Alex (noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com)

Hi Alex,

   I just heard from a friend that MG (the welding rod company) has a
broken-off-bolt-extractor rod that works really well. You stick in the
bolt hole and apply lots of current, and it welds onto the broken off end
of the bolt or stud. Meanwhile, the rosin-like coating lubricates and
protects the threads of the hole. Once the bolt has been built up enough,
you grab it with a stud extractor (the big beefy kind) and twist it out.
The price is high, but you can do 10 to 15 bolts per rod. You need to have
an arc welder for this...


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 1994 15:46:52 -0500
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Performance upgrades, tire pressures, rolling starts


On non-factory performance upgrades:
- ------------------------------------

I exclude from the following performance upgrades obtained by
disconnecting equipment with the only purpose to reduce emissions.
IMHO, factory engineers have analyzed the mechanical, thermal and other
stresses on the engines and have decided that for a "reasonable"  engine
life under "usual" driver demands (whatever these are), they will go with
the certain fuel-injection and ignition settings the stock car comes in.
For example, here are some concerns on bumping up the rev limiter.
Cylinder and piston wear are a function of mean piston speed and maximum
piston speed,  which increase proportionately with engine rpm. Lube flow
between piston and cylinder, and occasional  piston scrapes and impacts
against the cylinder, are both functions of: lubricant viscosity; 
pressure difference from top to bottom of the piston; piston speed; and
several others. Of course all of these change at different engine
operating conditions (power and speed), and there are statistical
variations from cycle to cycle on the same engine and from engine to
engine.

To compensate, engines expected to give different performance (defined as
combinations of power and torque at different speeds) are designed 
slightly different. For example, I would think and I seem to recall
reading somewhere that the 930 cylinder head and some other components are
slightly different from the 911 similar components (can someone confirm?). 

Since Porsche is rather conservative, indeed there is some room to improve
engine/car performance by tweeking factory settings, new chips,
supercharging etc etc etc. But this performance-upgrade room is claimed at
a reduction from the "reasonable" life. Considering these, it becomes a
personal choice of how much upgrade to go for (from no upgrade at all to
all-out) and how much "life" reduction to accept in our personal vehicles.
Now, let's consider buying a Porsche with some performance upgrades driven
some miles by  an enthusiastic Porsche driver, like we all are....


On "correct" tire pressures:
- ----------------------------

I use the 911 only on sunny weekends, and for the occasional driving event,
using the same set of tires for all kinds of events until it is time to
replace them. I have had CompTAs, PZEROes and RE71s at different times. 
A few years ago I took the family for a spirited country run in the 911.
   ----------------    |||| ----------------
      -------------    |||| |   }}}}8-)    |    
            -------    |||| |   ====|^(    |
               ----    |||| ----------------
My better half occasionally and very reluctantly agrees to join me in 
some of these excursions  8-)  if I promise to help her choose bedding or
something as important at her next shopping spree  :-( 
The weekend before I had been at an autocross. 

A few miles (3 to 5) into the country roads I noticed bad handling
(understeer in some corners, wiggly Carrera tail in others). 
After a few minutes of this I was forced to stop and investigate, because
I felt it was getting plain unsafe. I checked tire pressures and they were
WAAAAY HIGH (I don't remember exact numbers). I had forgotten to take
the autocross-type tire  pressures down from the week before, and had not
noticed the bad handling on the relatively straight highways on the way
back home from the autocross (oooops!). The tires were hot, had pressure
gage, but had no thermometer and therefore could not use P.V=R.T,  to
calculate how much to lower tire pressures for safe handling. So I did it
the old fashioned way: for the next few miles I gradually reduced
pressures until I was satisfied with the handling. Next morning, when 
I checked cold-tire pressures out of curiosity, they were within 1 psi 
of manufacturer's specs in the owner's manual.

In driver's education events my car handles best at or very close to
manufacturer's spec cold pressures. Granted, this means I have learned to
use the understeer/oversteer characteristics induced by these particular
tire pressures. I think the reason we increase tire pressures at
autocrosses is because the approximately 60 seconds or so of each drive
are not enough time to heat up the tires to reach the "correct" hot-tire
pressures. I believe that cold-tire pressures in the owner's manual
correspond to pressures suitable to driver's education events and spirited
driving, and therefore safe for "cruising".  Wear patterns on shoe polish
at the edge of tires  at driver's education events indicates just-right
rollover.   For my type of driving, these tire pressures also happen to
produce about  even wear from inside to outside of both front and rear
tires, at about the same rates, ie I needed to replace all four CompTAs
with PZEROes (1991) and the latter with four RE71s (1993). The right rear
tire gets A LITTLE more wear than the other three, just noticeable when   
I am about to replace tires, and my mechanics tell me its because of the
way torque is transmitted from the engine to the rear tires to road.

Higher pressures on extended drives would tend to bulge the tires along
their outer perimeter, reduce the contact patch with the road, and thus
also friction. This improves miles per gallon (mpg), but the reduced
friction means less traction for cornering, acceleration and deceleration.
A family friend keeps telling me he pumps up the tires "real good" to
increase his mpg on his frequent long-distance trips, and I have not
convinced him yet of how dangerous it is. I sure hope he does not have to
brake in an emergency.


On rolling starts:
- -----------------

In the past I also had done my fair share of starting cars with dead
batteries by rolling them, jump in, clutch in, 2nd gear, turn key, clutch
out, pump accelerator, hope. Three or four years ago I was told this is
ill advised for fuel injected cars with catalytic converters, because it
dumps raw fuel in the converter, destroying it after only a few such
starts. Does anyone know if this is true?

At the time I had only done it a couple of times on a 924, and
never did it again (I started carrying booster cables instead). The 924
passed emissions tests several times long after I had stopped these
rolling starts, so obviously I had not done sufficient damage.



- ----------------------------------------------------------------------
Most automobile owners measure miles per gallon; what distinguishes 
Porsche owners from the others is that they measure smiles per gallon.
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------

T. Korakianitis
ourios@zeus.wustl.edu

Date: 10 May 1994 16:56:23 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Andrew J. Toth" <TOTHAND@hsdwl.utc.com>
Subject: Re: 914 Trunk Lid Problem

| 
| 
| Howdy all,
| 
| I ran into a MAJOR problem this weekend while fixing the broken
| rear trunk bolts (standard 914 failure).  Instead of the mount
| ripping off the engine compartment wall, the bolts actually
| broke off inside the mount.  I removed the trunk, and the hinges, but
| I can't get out the remains of those bolts.  I used WD-40, and my
| snap-on extractor (aka eaxy-out) to no avail.  Those bolt ends
| are REALLY frozen.
| 
| The only solution I see at this point is to grind off the old mounts
| and weld on new ones.  This isn't a really pleasant option :-(. Does
| anyone have an alternative that I could try?
| 
| ANY comments and suggestions appreciated.
| 
| Alex (noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com)
| 

Alex,

You can try heating the mount with a torch, then spraying just the bolt
(well...what's left of it) with a cooling agent.  After that, use the
extractor to turn out the bolt.  I've used freon as a coolant; 
I'm not sure what's available now.  Most electronics supply shops should
have something along these lines for use in troubleshooting.  Good luck!


						    ajt

- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Andrew J. Toth                             Katana Pilot
    tothand@hsdwl.utc.com                                  ===o&o>

    Speed costs money...how fast do you want to go?
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: Electrical problem 


I've got a problem with  the windshield wipers on an 84 930 .
Sometimes when I turn on the airconditioning the wipers will come 
on by themselves. Occasionally this will also happen when the turn
signals are activated. The car has delay wipers and 
you can hear the relay click on and off when this happens. The relay 
makes no sound when you turn on the wipers with the column switch and the 
wipers work normally at all other times.

Does anyone know *exactly* where the delay wiper relay is located ?
It sounds like it is up in the trunk behind the heater blower box.
I would like to access it to check the various connections etc.
but I don't want to waste a couple of hours just looking for it.
Any help or suggestions would be greatly appreciated !

Date: Tue, 10 May 1994 16:34:37 +0700
From: trevor@internet.wst.com (Trevor Wagenfuehr)
Subject: Re: 914 trunk lid problem


>The only solution I see at this point is to grind off the old mounts
>and weld on new ones.  This isn't a really pleasant option :-(. Does
>anyone have an alternative that I could try?
>
>ANY comments and suggestions appreciated.
>
>Alex (noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com)
>

Unless you broke the easy-out off in the bolt, you could go ahead and drill 
the bolt out completely to the diameter of the thread root, the re-tap the 
treads to the correct size. If you broke the easy-out off though, I think 
you will be screwed.  ;)

Actually, I would be interested in anyone elses comments about what to do 
when you break an easy-out off inside a bolt that has broken.


Trevor Wagenfuehr
trevor@wst.com

74' 914 2.0
Soon to be SCCA CS Miata Eater
Trevor Wagenfuehr

in the message. I kept the Turbo II for less than one year and traded it for

and just ordered a 993. They will eventually see the light, too :-).

just don't understand why someone has to waste the time bashing a sports car.

one, some like the other and if you are a car freak, you should be happy
there are so many good cars to chose from.

him that RX7 sales are going down and 911 sales are going up (the new 993 is
very successful). In fact, I believe all the Japanese brands are having a
more difficult time in the sports car market.

Date: Wed, 11 May 1994 09:58:51 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: 356 suspension.....

Hi p..people,

Not much new from my 356 restoration.

Since last I've installed front cell panels,(the ones 'behind' the full 
closing panels) these were very easy to manufacture and with the help of my 
new flange/punch tool it was easy to put them in place too. I've also 
completed the front section of the car, inner wings, struts, diagonal, etc 
and used lotsa zink spray and sealer and 'carosol' rust shield to keep the 
car from rusting again.

I've started the dirty task of cleaning suspension arms, brake parts etc, so 
that the front suspension can be finished. I've rebuillt my ZF steering box, 
which involved removing almost 0.5mm of the bottom of the peg, heat treating 
it, polishing the worm, installing 'new' bearings (anno 1961), oil seals, 
making new gaskets and painting it in a low-gloss black enamel. It's 
(almost) as new. 

To a little surprise I found the suspension arms to be stamped with the VW 
brand. Is this normal, or could these be from a beetle? Could I as well look 
around for better beetle suspension arms to use on my car? Mine is showing 
signs of wear both in the inner and the outer surface. The spindles too are 
VW stamped, but it is the large diameter axle, is this too normal? Didn't 
Porsche bother ordering these without the VW stamp?

Well,....I hope someone out there have some clues,......by the way ; it is 
the Bilstein VW-Bus steering dampener that should be used with the 356?
Another question while I'm at it; will Beetle inner and outer tie-rod ends 
be OK for the 356. (.........has TRW parts for Beetle!)

cheers,
trond

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 11:17:40 +0200

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 08:38:01 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Air Filters

Is there any filtration test data on the re-useable oil soaked filters?
This technology was the traditional filter used for internal combustion
engines, but it was supplanted for good reason.  The paper filter
technology, properly done, is vastly superior at getting fine abrasive
dust out of the intake stream.  This is basically the same technology
used in untra-clean manufacturing facilities.  I've built some of those.

Life of modern engines has been significantly extended by two major
factors.  First is better filters for air and oil.  The second is
better oils.  I, for one, will stick with the paper filters.

Rick Dill
8-)   My 356 is home and running on sunny days.

From: STEVE.STOMSKI@gsa2.sprint.com
Subject:  $11,000 '83 SC

    Jon-

    First of all, I think $11,000 for a 1983 911 with 93,000 actual
    miles would be a very decent price.  But, the deal sounds suspect
    to me, especially if the fool won't even let you start the car.
    What does the guy expect you to do, slap the $11,000 down, with no
    questions asked, then have him deliver the car to your house on a
    flat bed?  This does not strike me as a deal of a lifetime, after
    all, you can find pretty decent '83s for around $12-13,000 that,
    believe it or not, you can actualy DRIVE before you buy- what a
    concept.  Moreover, for $15,000 you should be able to buy a very
    clean, well maintained, DOCUMENTED 1982-83 SC.

    Good Luck.

    Steven Stomski

------------------------------

Date:  Wed, 11 May 1994 09:16:33 -0400
From: STEVE.STOMSKI@gsa2.sprint.com
Subject:  911 Oil Filters

    Thom-

    I have gone through similar investigations and have concluded that
    the only filter for my 1971 911 is Mahle (or one from the Porsche
    dealer that has the Porsche name on it that is specifically made
    for my car).  This is not elitist or label buying, but based on my
    understanding that the other filters do not have the relief valve
    that the Mahle does that lets the oil continue to flow
    even if the filter is clogged.  While Purulator and even Mann
    filters will fit, I am pretty sure they don't have the relief
    valve.  As for price, if you find the right source at the right
    time you can get Mahle filters for around $7.50 each.


    I hope this helps.

    Steven Stomski

------------------------------

Date: 11 May 94 09:23:46 EDT
From: Doug Thompson <74270.3516@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Which 911 is better

Ted Matsumura writes:

>Keep in mind that from '76 on, the paint process was improved to prevent 
>rust.  Also, although the 74-76 2.7's have major reliability problems, a 
>used sports car from the '60s is likely to also have a rebuild or two or 
>replacement by now as well as the 70s car.

>I'd recommend to new 911 owners to get a '78 SC if they can come up with 
>15K or so.  Reason is the 3.0 engine, and body capable of wide 
>wheels/tires, plus the improved paint.  None of the previous 911's have 
>any of these much desired features, except '76+ have the improved paint.

>I think the early 911's probably make excellent project and antique cars, 
>but not daily drivers (unless you're a mechanic, and then you probably 
>have a "fleet" of british cars too... <g>)

I agree with Ted about checking the '73S out thoroughly.  The price sounds too
good to be true, which means it probably is.  Check for hidden rust, damage from
a crash, etc.  Pull up the carpets in both the interior and trunk, check for
rust around the dual batteries in the trunk, etc.  Leak down test on the engine
is a must.  The 2.4 engines are generally reliable, but lead oil because of the
expansion of the magnesium case.  If things check out, buy it before the owner
discovers what it is really worth.

I have to disagree with Ted, howerver, that early 911s aren't good daily
drivers.  I use my '72 911T Targa daily (summer and winter) in the D.C. area and
it is fun, reliable daily transporation.  In the last 18 months, it has made two
trips to Illinois, two to Florida, one to the Parade in Cincinatti and countless
swap meets up and down the East Coast.  Maintenance?  Oil change every 3,000
miles (of course), a major tune every 10,000 miles and periodic checks of the
mechanical injection pump.  If you have a mechanic who knows how to deal with
early 911s, particularly mechanical injection models, the car can be a
dependable daily driver.  The 911 has to be dependable.  I also own a British
car (TR-6) and need all my time for it <g>.  Actually, the TR is my significant
other's daily driver with over 100,000 on the clock.  Are we tempting fate here?

- --Doug Thompson

1972 911T Targa (daily driver)
1974 TR-6 (daily driver--the gods must be smiling)
1971 914-6 (Still on jackstands after all these years)
1974 Mustang (When we absolutely, positively, must have A/C). 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 08:38:48 -0500
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: 914 Trunk Lid Problem

>Subject: Re: 914 Trunk Lid Problem

>| ripping off the engine compartment wall, the bolts actually
>| broke off inside the mount.  I removed the trunk, and the hinges, but
>| I can't get out the remains of those bolts.  I used WD-40, and my
>| snap-on extractor (aka eaxy-out) to no avail.  Those bolt ends
>| are REALLY frozen.
>| 
>| The only solution I see at this point is to grind off the old mounts
>| and weld on new ones.  This isn't a really pleasant option :-(. Does
>| anyone have an alternative that I could try?
>| 
>| ANY comments and suggestions appreciated.
>| 
>| Alex (noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com)
>| 
>
>Alex,
>
>You can try heating the mount with a torch, then spraying just the bolt
>(well...what's left of it) with a cooling agent.  After that, use the
>extractor to turn out the bolt.  I've used freon as a coolant; 
>I'm not sure what's available now.  Most electronics supply shops should
>have something along these lines for use in troubleshooting.  Good luck!
>
>                                                   ajt
>
>    Andrew J. Toth                             Katana Pilot
>    tothand@hsdwl.utc.com                                  ===o&o>

  Alex, Andrew, and friends..
  Have you tried to drill out the remains with a 'reverse twist' drill?
  -one option  Eastwood has these.
  Andrew is right about the torch stuff..if it works.  Maybe dry ice as
coolant.  You might have better luck using one of those microtorch tools
radio shack sells, with it you can use a tight, controllable, intense
heat.  Get as little heat on the stud as possible.
  When you reassemble, use some anti-seize compound on the threads.
  There is also a mod for the bolt that adds a groove to the bearing face,
and a grease zerk to the bolt head...a shot of grease and the thing is ok.

  What condition is the hinge mount under the body, usually if the bolts
are rusting in place (moisture is present), the mount rots out and needs
replacing.  I would prefer to do that than futz with getting out and maybe
destroying the stud/threads.  Look for cracks around the spot welds too.

  Replacing the hinge mounts is pretty easy and about the same amount of
work (well, for me anyway)... ask me for more detail on how to's if you
wish.  I'm horribly busy now do'in enviro strife testing on our disk array
product.    gotta go...my [mail] box runneth over.
- -- 
  -kyle
  <kehler@daisy.wichitaks.ncr.com>
  73,76 914 2.0
  85 IROC Z-28

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 09:37:12 CDT
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Outside mirrors for 911T in '72?


The mirrors are an old-fashioned chrome design. I dusted off the books
and road test compilations and found up to and incluiding 2.2 l cars
the mirrors were round. Some photos of 2.4 l cars have a chrome square
mirror, some have the round design( very early examples?). In the US
there was only a left side mirror.  I do not think two mirrors were a
US option. English cars had a single mirror as well (but on the other
side of course!)

Two mirrors are better than one, but the rear quarter vision in the 70s
911 is excellent so a quick turn of the head after a check in the dash
mirror works well. I was suprised how little I've missed the right side
mirror.

------------------------------

   a catalytic converter off of a '88 911

  in the road. The heat still works)

Date: 11 May 94 14:45:17 GMT
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Noisy Distributor Cap/Tuneup

My 951 would occasionally idle erratically or take several tries starting.  I 
started going through the std tuneup of plugs, rotor, cap, fuel filter etc 
since I didn't get service records when I bought the car last year.  I changed 
the Champion plugs to Bosch Platinums.  

Upon inspection, I found that old distributor cap's terminals were worn down 
to the ceramic material so I changed it last night and heard a distinct 
knocking which I confirmed came from the cap by using a piece of wood as a 
stethoscope. 

The replacement cap is apparently not made by Bosch since I got it from 
Carlsen's EuroSelect parts bin.  It started right up this morning and I got to 
work without any idle problems.  My idle speed is fixed now at 1000rpm instead 
of bouncing around.  BTW, I didn't replace the rotor since it looked OK. 
 Is this knock OK?  Should I return the cap and only use genuine Bosch parts? 

Any gotchas for fuel filter, changing brake pads and bleeding?  I didn't see 
special tools mentioned in Haynes.  It looks straightforward. 

P.S. Is anyone from NNJR attending this Sunday's autox at the Meadowlands?  
Pocono Raceway Memorial Day weekend?  If so, drop me a line or stop by and 
introduce yourself.  My PA plate is AJY8878.

TIA,
___________________________________________________________________________ 
Steve Jagernauth	     '87 951 Black (Sunny days, Track, AutoX) 
AT&T Global Network Design   '87 Audi 5000CST 
Bridgewater, NJ

I have decided to convert my 1965C Cab from a 6 volt to a 12 volt
system.  Technically, I know all the steps that need to be taken.
I'd appreciate any warnings or problems I may encounter along
the way.
 
Thanks,
Joyce_Thomas@cpqm.saic.com
1965 356C Cab
1986 944 



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 16:52:56 +0100
From: paer_cederholm@public.se (Paer Cederholm)
Subject: Outside mirrors for 911

Mirrors

For -72 - 73 Porsche had different mirrors for different markets. In Germany and
some other countries it was sufficient to deliver a car with just one left hand
mirror. In Sweden for example cars had to be delivered with both left and right
outside mirror to be street legal. For the -72 model Porsche designed a new
small rectangular shaped mirror for the markets that did not need a right hand
side mirror. The other markets had to stick with the old round ones. For the -74
model year they enlarged the rectangular mirror and, I think also made a right
hand version available. These mirror were later replaced by the big electric
UUpaddlesUU.

Regards,
Paer.

PS. I have the small rectangular on my -73 S Coupe, the right hand side of the
car looks clean and better without mirror. 

- --
SINDBAD Information - Public dial up mail & news service, Sweden

in warm (65 degree) storage since October, and has been on the chopping block

has not been turned over since the Fall I bieleve (I think the shop pushed 
the car out of storage to the chopping block).  I do not want to harm 
anything mechanical when starting/driving it for the first time.  Should
I remove the airbox cover (with air filter) when starting it the first time
to prevent a possible backfire?  I do not have a pop-off valve.  What about
getting the parts lubricated before starting the car?  Is there anything
special I need to do to the gas or oil that has sat all year?  

Furthermore, what would a decent tune-up consist of, since the car has been
sitting for such a ling time.  Any thing that might need fixing or
adjusting?  It ran ok when it went into the shop last October.

Also, the car has a brand new paint job (Metallic Black).  How long do I
have to wait for the paint to "cure" or "harden" before I wash the car?
What about waxing it?   I was told I may have to wait sometime before
waxing it (30 days?).    Do I have to keep it super clean for a while so
that any dirt or pollen does not get stuck or rubbed into the new paint
job?  What about sunlight?   I do know that I have to keep away from 
thoose guardrails this time.

 -Barry Chapin   chapin@draper.com

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 11:08:20 PDT
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: Outside mirrors for 911T in '72?

My '70T sits outside, so many mornings the windows are fogged 
over.  Even if I clean them off they fog right away for the
first 10 minutes or so of driving (and my rear defrost doesn't
work-does anybodies?), so I really like having the right side
mirror.

Up to '72ish? the round mirrors seem to be "correct".  The good thing
about them is I think they'll go on either side by just rotating the
mirror around the base.  Automotion has them for $65ish, a fellow '70Ter
just bought one for the right side of his car.  The only thing I don't
like about them is that they are pretty small.  The later rectangular
mirrors offer better visability, but as we seem to agree, not available
for the right side and are much more expensive.

How about later mirrors?  I'm also interested in a good set of mirrors
for my car.  Previous owner installed incredably ugly "sport" mirrors
that I'm certain he thought made the car racey (went well with his gold
chains) that K-mart would be embarrased to sell.

Mark

Date: Wed May 11 10:02:43 EDT 1994
From: tpollock@mutt.d.umn.edu
Subject: 951 Bashing by RX7 Club members

Re: Recent post bashing the 951 versus the RX7 Turbo II

I have owned two RX7's, a 1980 and a 1987 Turbo II model, both purchased new. 
 The "80" was a delightful car, light, simple and pretty much bulletproof.  I 
put 60,000 mile on that car and had no trouble at all.  The biggest mistake I 
made was trading it for the "87" Turbo II. In the thirteen months that I owned 
that car it was in the shop eleven times.  There was a substantial driveline 
vibration that defied solution.  I became good friends with the Mazda zone rep 
and he finally brought in an expert from Washington who diagnosed the problem 
as a "bent" driveshaft.  It took three attempts with new driveshafts before 
they found one that was straight.  The Mazda people admitted that they had a 
supplier problem and there were a substantial number of Turbo II's delivered 
with this defect.  The Turbo II was a little easier to drive around town than 
the 951 and I could usually out accelerate the local 951's at stop lights but 
found that the Porsche pulled away above 60 mph.  The Turbo II was 
uncomfortable on long trips, the seats are awful, the plasticky red/orange 
dash clashed with the rest of the interior, and it was simply not as much fun 
to drive as the "80" RX7. I was happy to see it go.   

I now drive an "87" 951, it feels much more substantial than the Turbo II, it 
can cruise comfortably at speeds the RX7 can't reach and more importantly, the 
951 feels safer and more controllable at 130 mph than the Mazda does at 90.  
It came with dual airbags and brakes that are incredible.  In comparisons test 
by the major car magazines during the mid "80's", they universally chose the 
Porsche over the Turbo II.  My 951 has 34,000 miles on it and has needed only 
routine maintenance.  All the 951 owners that I know have found the car to be 
relatively trouble free - particularly from "87" on.  With low mileage "86" 
951's selling in the $12,000 dollar range, the price/performance ratio makes 
them a great buy for drivers that appreciate fine machinery.  You need to 
drive both cars back to back to really see the difference between them.

By the way, my troublesome Turbo II didn't spoil me on all Mazda's, I bought a 
Miata for my wife and that car is a lot of fun to drive around town, sweetest 
gearbox I've experienced.
  
Tom Pollock
Center for Professional Development
University of Minnesota
tpollock@mutt.d.umn.edu
1987 Porsche 951 - Alpine White - Summer daily driver
1990 Mazda Miata - White - wifes toy
1993 Eagle Vision TSI - Black - Winter daily driver
1988 GMC Surburban - rust - urban assault vehicle and tow car

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 May 94 10:58:51 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re:leaky A.C. compressor in 944

  Mark wrote;
>Anyone have any experience with bad (leaking) A/C compressors on 944's. My
>father's '87 944S has an internal leak in the compressor (according to a
>reputable dealer) and must be replaced for ~$1600. Are there any other
>alternatives here?

   I've converted 2 928s to use Sankyo-type compressors, converting 2 
different
 brackets (78/79 brackets need to be "re-radiused," early 80's bracket
 is a close fit and only took change to all-thread rod to "hang" it with).
 I started off spending a lot of time at the parts store looking thru the
 billion and 3 different rotary compressors to see which one was closest. 
Then I
 ruined the eventual core value of the new compressor I got by hacksawing off
 the extra mounting "ears" that interfere in the tight space (and will limit
 your adjustment range) and drilling out the threads in the remaining ear the
 all-thread went thru (bracket holes and the compressor holes were different
 size). The clutch/belt alignment worked fine in both instances, though,
 apparently this is one area thats pretty standardized.

   Both cool great and work fine, however even though I've done it twice I
 don't know if I'd do it again; if you spend $350, you will probably be able
 to get a local shop to rebuild yours. This sounded high to me at first,
 but when you consider that any compressor/clutch is $200 plus, then the
 bother of new fittings, its probably the best alternative. You can buy a
 used Alfa for $1600....                                   

         Lee A, '79 928 (and other perpetual projects...)

   (p.s., 928 international sells rebuilds for $500, I'd suggest checking
    thru your yellow pages or even thru your local parts store for places
    that could rebuild yours cheaper. I even had a condensor custom-built
    for a car once, there is someone out there who can fix your compressor).

ever had, period, and I've had quite a few.

Date: Wed, 11 May 94 17:07:58 EDT 
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: FW: Senna / UPI

FYI, folks

		JBS

- ----------
From:  <netmail!Russ930@aol.com>
To: Jim Selders
Subject: Senna / UPI
Date: Wednesday, May 11, 1994 5:00PM

Senna killed by wheel says Mosley LONDON, May 11 (May 11) UPI - Ayrton Senna
may have been killed by a blow from his car's front wheel, claimed
International Automobile Federation (FIA) president Max Mosley on Wednesday
in a letter to the English newspaper The Times.

Motor racing's international boss wrote: "There is a strong suspicion that
Ayrton Senna was killed by a blow to the head from the front wheel and
suspension and that, but for this, he would have survived without serious
injury.

"We will all know more when the results of the Italian inquiry are
available."

Senna, world champion in 1988, 1990 and 1991, died after a violent high speed
smash while leading last weekend's ill-fated San Marino Formula One Grand
Prix. The Brazilian smacked his Williams Renault into a concrete wall at more
than 300 kph, destroying the car on impact and ripping both right hand wheels
off the vehicle. He died four hours later in hospital.

Italian authorities have impounded the car while investigations continue into
Senna's crash as well as the fatal smash in practice of Austrian driver
Roland Ratzenberger.

There has been widespread criticism of the Imola circuit where the deaths
occured but Mosley wrote in his letter that the FIA had consulted drivers
beforehand and had allowed concrete walls because history suggested the
corners where the accidents happened were generally safe.

"The leading drivers and the FIA were happy with the Imola walls because
experience of many accidents had shown the angle to be shallow. Injuries did
not occur.

"At the momemt it seems unlikely that doubt will be cast on a principle which
has worked well for years and on which all American oval racing depends."

The FIA held an emergency meeting at its headquarters in Paris last week and
has installed a number of safety measures in time for this week's round at
Monte Carlo - the sport's showpiece race which Senna had won a record six
times.

Both Senna's and Ratzenberger's teams will enter just one car each for
Sunday's 78-lap race and the front two spots on the grid will be left vacant
as a mark of respect to the two killed drivers.

Gerhard Berger, the veteran Austrian Ferrari pilot who has been deeply
disturbed by the deaths of his two friends, remains undecided about his
future in Formula One.

Australian authorities, meanwhile, have re-named part of the Adelaide circuit
 - where Senna scored the last of his 41 Grands Prix victories last year -
after the Brazilian.

------------------------------

Porschephiles #746                         Fri May 13 02:13:25 CDT 1994
Date: 12 May 94 12:17:23 GMT
From: mvmas@mvusa.att.com
Subject: Summary: 914 pressure gauge

I had posted a question last week about where to get a gauge to measure ~30
psi for 914 fuel pressure.  I won't include the responses, since they were
all CC: to the list anyway.  What I found was a local heating/AC supply
store, which sold me a 0-60psi gauge for $22.  They said that best accuracy
and readability is at about half scale, so 60 is the best for this
application.  It has a 4.5in diameter for easy readability.

I adapted the 0.5in NPC fitting to the 7mm tap by using a very short 12mm
heater hose with tight clamps, and an old fuel filter (old but unused)
which just luckily had a 0.5in stem on one side and 5/16in on the other.
I poked a good size hole in the paper element to not have a pressure drop.

When I hooked it up, pressure read 27psi.  I adjusted until it was 29psi,
in the spec for 1.7L.  I didn't notice any difference in driving.  The
funny thing is that when I was going to remove it, I took out the pump
relay and started the car, and could keep it running using the accelerator.
It took forever to drop the pressure even down to 10psi.

I'll probably check it every year or so, since spring type regulators are
bound to weaken over time.  And I ran a lot of water into the gauge, since
who knows what gasoline could do to it.

Mark Skala
mvmas@mvusa.att.com

Date: Thu, 12 May 94 10:59:24 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: air box pop-off valve

It should open out, so backfires within the intake system blow the 
valve open.  These backfires occur when excessive fuel vapor ignites - 
often during cold starts/restarts.

		JBS

- ----------
> From: Steve Bochinski  <netmail!steveb@WellsFargo.COM>
> To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>

Date: 12 May 94 11:19:15 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: $11,000 '83 SC

Hi, Steve, and Jon.
 
One good scenario for the dealer not letting you start the '83 911 is
because he has noticed there is a puff of blue smoke when it first fires up
in the morning. Porsche people know that this is more or less normal, but
the dealer might not know that. He might also not be clever enough to have
the thing warmed up a bit so it doesn't do that.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 12 May 94 11:19:30 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Gloeckler Porsche

Hi, Mike.
 
It's the same Gloeckler Porsche. I don't know if the family still owns the
dealership, but I think they do.
 
If you look at the results of races in the early 50s, two Gloecklers appear.
Walter Gloeckler (and his employee, Hermann Ramelow) built the cars,
initially based on VW parts (but then so was the Porsche). Gloecker was a VW
dealer, too. Walter's cousin Helm also drove Gloeckler specials.
 
Gordon Maltby's book has all this on p. 119.
 
Pete

Date: Thu May 12 08:36:50 EDT 1994
From: tpollock@mutt.d.umn.edu
Subject: Re: 951 Bashing by RX7 Club members

You ask where can you cruise at 120 mph plus - the Interstates and secondary 
roads in North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, Wyoming, Idaho, Alberta, 
Saskatchewan, Manitoba, and western Ontario.  A good radar detector is 
suggested and of course weather conditions may dictate otherwise, but you can 
"cruise" in comfort, albeit with some boredom, as the roads tend to be 
straight and wide.  Enforcement by highway patrol is pretty much nonexistent, 
there is a recognition that those are open spaces and traffic is very light.  
Speeding tickets in Montana for instance are given as "excess consumption" 
fines of $5.00 and no "points" are awarded.  I recommend a good set of Z rated 
tires and a Porsche.  This is how a Porsche is meant to be driven.

Tom Pollock
tpollock@mutt.d.umn.edu
"87" 951 Alpine White

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 May 1994 10:38:35 -40962758 (CDT)
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: '83 911 seat cover replacement - how much?

You need to find the area's best restoration-grade interior shop. *DO*
*NOT* try to save money on this -- the resulting seats will either be
very uncomfortable or look hideous. Or both, if you're *VERY* lucky....

Anyway:

> 1. Is this possible?

Yes.

> 2. How much will it cost?

It depends. Probably, to do it right, over $500 a seat.

> 3. Can they match the color?

Yes. No problem if you go to the right kind of place. (I can recommend
a place in Houston, but that probably won't help you)

> 4. How much would 2 entire seats cost? (Sport seats would be nice)

Porsche seats would be over $1200 used, and about double that new.
Recaros vary, but are in the same ball park -- and then you'd have to
have them done in leather to match...

> Also, I'd like to replace the door panels for the same reason, although
> maybe I can clean them. What do they cost?

Look, think about this: what about the headliner? The carpet? The
insulation and sound deadening? Smoke is nasty stuff... 

So, try the following: have the car detailed. *SUPER* detailed. Should
cost you like $200 or so, tops. The detailers have tricks and solvents
that can make even a ratmobile smell like a new car by just getting it clean
for a change.

Failing that, the shop *CAN* do the leather. And the headliner. And the
carpet. Or you can get a new car. Or you can learn to get used to it.
(BTW, how did you wind up buying a car with a smell you objected to? I
routinely rule cars out for that reason....)

> Has anyone done this before?

All the time...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 12 May 1994 09:01:49 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Why a turbo body?

        Reply to:   Why a turbo body?
> Why would one do a 930 body ?

For the looks, if it was just a cosmetic flare to the wheel wells.
For handling, if it involved wider rear tires.  For high speed
stability, if front air dam and rear tail were done.  For braking,
if those incredible 917 four caliper piston drilled and vented
brakes were installed, and for overall agility, if sway bars,
torsion bars, and associated suspension upgrades were done.

The factory turbo look option was almost $14k, according to
the sticker on my 88.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 May 94 09:54:00 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: RE: air box pop-off valve

     I think terminology is confused here.  The original poster
was refering to the cavity containing the air filter as the air
box.  Anyway, the pop-off valve relieves pressure from below the
surface on which it is mounted (which is really the interior of
the air box), into the area containing the air filter.  The valve
should hinge upward.

- --   Bob

^Z



------------------------------

Date: 12 May 94 11:19:47 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: 356 suspension

Hi, Trond.
 
That's correct, Porsche bought the front arms and rear trailing arms from
VW. (Plus a bunch of other parts). The VW parts used in the 356 (for
representative purposes, only the 1960 356 B is listed) are given in a table
on p. 261 (German and English editions) of Dirk-Michael Conradt's book
"Porsche 356: Driving in its purest Form" (Porsche 356: Fahren in seiner
schoensten Form). The table is taken from a factory internal document, so
some parts are not readily apparent (so "rubber sleeve, 1 per car, 0.06 DM
each" doesn't help much) but most things can be puzzled out. There are some
minor modifications to the spindles, I think, like a sleeve fitted over the
arm where it rides in the bearing of the Porsche (plastic bushing pressed
into tubes of VW, little roller bearings in Porsche) and the mount for the
front anti-roll bar. But yes, you can make VW arms work.
 
There were two spindle sizes, the switch occurred in mid-1958, beginning
with coupe #104852, cabrio #150981. Early spindles had a 25 mm inner wheel
bearing, 20 mm outer; late spindles had 30 mm inner, 20 mm outer. If you
need bearings, some are available as VW parts, some as standard DIN-norm
bearings. Disc brake cars were different again in terms of bearings, but I
think the spindles remained the "late" type. (Source: Stoddard catalog).
 
I have heard that the VW Bus steering damper fits the 356, but haven't had
to fool with it myself. Stoddard catalog lists Boge and Koni.
 
I have VW tie rod ends in my daily driver, they work fine. Technically these
are not entirely correct (there is a bend in one rod end for Porsche, while
the VW ends are straight) but they work. If you want the correct ends,
Brad Ripley at NLA Ltd. in Reno has them.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 May 94 12:22:19 EDT
From: Mike Kohlbrenner <kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>
Subject: RE: Brazilian story on Senna's Accident

Here's what I said originally:
>
> > At the speed that Senna hit, tires would do no good, unless they were around
> > 20 rows deep -- and then there would be the risk of those same tires doing
> > the killing.  Tire walls are great only for lower speed contact.
>

Here is Jim's response:
>
> I disagree.  Senna's forward speed was 186mph, but he didn't hit the 
> wall straight-in (90 degrees); he had some angle between 45-60 degrees 
> (my estimate), leaving an impact speed of 130mph - 160 mph.  Now, with 
> 4-6 rows of bolted-together tires, and a wide side pit preceding them, 
> the impact force _might_ have been brough below the fatal level.  
> Remember, the tires and sand don't have to _prevent_ the impact, they 
> just have to lengthen the time of deceleration to reduce the peak force.
> 

Last night I dug up my old "OnTrack" mags and found the source of my
information.   Lincoln Cobb had written a series of three articles on 
safety in the aftermath of the Watkins Glen turn 5 crashes in 1991.
He is involved in highway safety engineering.  He presents a very 
rational analysis of tire walls in the second of the three articles.

In short, he states:  "...these figures tell us that in the absence of
any added ballast or fill placed within the voids in the tire bundles,
a double tire wall located in front of a more rigid object will do little
to mitigate the consequences of a high-speed impact."  The "figures" show
that a 2200 lb. GTP car hitting at 100mph will lose less than .25mph by
the time the tires are used up.  A 3500 lb. NASCAR car will lose about
.15 mph.  Extrapolate the other way for a 1200 lb F1 car.  And then
consider that the number of tires "used" by an F1 car will probably be
less due to smaller frontal area.

He goes on to say "That is not to say, however that tire walls are now
and forever useless...a tire wall literall takes off more speed for slower
impacts than for high speed impacts...for an impact speed of 10.69 mph
that tire wall will bring the car to a complete halt...It seems that
the lowly tire wall has a place after all -- but that place is not
where high impact speeds are expected..."

If anyone wants any more details, request them.  Obviously, there are
copyrights involved here, but if there is interest, I will try to
work something out off-line.

Mike Kohlbrenner
<kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>

'67 VW Beetle      (Every once in a while it gets closer to running...)
'90 Honda Civic Si (Daily driver/Track Car -- YaHoo!) 
??? Porsche ???    (Someday it will be mine...)

From:  netmail!porschephiles-request@tta.com
Sent:  Thursday, May 12, 1994 2:23PM
To:  porschephiles
Subject:  Why a turbo body?

        Reply to:   Why a turbo body?
> Why would one do a 930 body ?

For the looks, if it was just a cosmetic flare to the wheel wells.
For handling, if it involved wider rear tires.  For high speed
stability, if front air dam and rear tail were done.  For braking,
if those incredible 917 four caliper piston drilled and vented
brakes were installed, and for overall agility, if sway bars,
torsion bars, and associated suspension upgrades were done.

The factory turbo look option was almost $14k, according to
the sticker on my 88.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Thu, 12 May 1994 09:12:22 -0700
From: Scott Winders <winders@porsche.support.apple.com>
Subject: Re:  Why a turbo body?


The only reason I can see to do a turbo body conversion is because
you like the looks. The narrow body (SC Style) is much more
aero-dynamic (sp) and can have the same brakes installed. The only
real advantage the turbo body has is can take much larger tires.

I looked at doing this conversion to my '78 911SC. It cost too damn
much and would not provide me any benefit except looks. My '78 has
more rubber on it than a standard '84 turbo (225/45 in the front,
245/45 on the rear).

Scott
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 May 94 17:30:17 PDT
From: pete@morhila.wa.com (Pete Gregory)
Subject: Zen & the Art of Solex Carburetors

Thanks to Peter Albrecht's advice last month, I began to look elsewhere for
problems I was blaming on my Solex P40-II's.  I found some ignition-related
problems (timing, dwell) that were responsible for most of my performance
problems.

I've one nagging performance problem that I _do_ believe is carb-related:
at 3000-4000rpm and medium throttle, opening the throttle further (not
necessarily to full, but say opening throttle from 1/3 to 1/2) results
in momentary hesitation or 'skipping'.  Must I adjust my accelerator pumps
for more delivery, or look elsewhere?

My mixture is about right (passed smog, behaves expectedly when twiddling
mixture screws at idle, 20mpg city driving), and plugs look perfect.  I'm
not sure where to look for a solution.

I'd really like to buy 'Zen and the Art of Solexes' were it in print.  Can
someone recommend a good book on Solexes?  It's easy to find material on
Webers, but...

Thanks,

Pete

Date: Thu, 12 May 94 23:31:25 -0500
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: 356 Tach Failure

A word of warning to those of us out there with the mechanical tachs on 
our 'tubs: I had my newly-redone tach fail after about 20 minutes of use.
Took it back to International Instrument here in Houston (713) 863-0020
who does really really good work and has a pile of NOS parts for old
Porsche, Mercedes, etc laying about. Was told nope, can't be -- each 
instrument is run in for 2 hours to make sure it's working OK. So, we
took it apart, and voila! we have the culprit.

Seems the tach drive seal on the front cover failed. And proceeded to leak
oil into the cable. Which then got spiraled up the cable, into the tach
itself. Where it gummed up the works.

Stoddard does have the necessary replacement seals, which I'll have in a few
days. In the meantime, my tach is apart soaking in an ultrasonic cleaner full
of trichol or something, and it'll be another $80 to get it back and working
right...

So: if you think you have a leak from the drive, *FIX IT*. I wish I had...

Stan

Date: Fri, 13 May 1994 10:52:36 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: 356 suspension

Pete et.al.

>into tubes of VW, little roller bearings in Porsche) and the mount for the
>front anti-roll bar. But yes, you can make VW arms work.
I will inspect my arms and see whether the sleeve on the arms can be 
replaced or remanufactured. They are a bit worn in this area, but I'll try 
to improve them. 

>There were two spindle sizes, the switch occurred in mid-1958, beginning
>with coupe #104852, cabrio #150981. Early spindles had a 25 mm inner wheel
>bearing, 20 mm outer; late spindles had 30 mm inner, 20 mm outer.
Luckily for me my #105905 has the larger spindles, I'm pretty sure I can get 
SKF bearings for my car.(Swedish quality.)

>I have heard that the VW Bus steering damper fits the 356, but haven't had
>to fool with it myself. Stoddard catalog lists Boge and Koni.
Examining some of the parts that came in a box with my car, I found a red 
koni dampener, I believe (hope) this is the steering dampener. I checked it, 
and it seem to be okay. I'll use it if it is the right 
one.($59+freight+tax_saved :)

>I have VW tie rod ends in my daily driver, they work fine. Technically these
>are not entirely correct (there is a bend in one rod end for Porsche, while
>the VW ends are straight) but they work. If you want the correct ends,
>Brad Ripley at NLA Ltd. in Reno has them.
For now I will stick to VW tie rods, I just disconnected the old ones (with 
the grease nipples on 'em). I will then be able to see whether their 
function is good enough. I can always use them somewhere else,....

cheers,
trond


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 May 94 07:15:00 PDT
From: "Dayton, Mike" <DAYTONM@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: Pop valves

>A simple question for the group:  Shoud the valve open into the airbox, or
>downwards out of the airbox?

The pop valve should open upwards into the area just below the air filter.  
The portion of the airbox that is susceptible to explosion is the triangular
portion just below the finned part that is visible when you take the air 
filter off.  To the best of my knowledge this is where the cold start 
injector does its injecting, thereby providing the fuel for the explosion.  I 
think some of the later CIS systems moved the cold start injector out of this 
area of the airbox, but I don't  think it totally solved the blown airbox 
problem.

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911 - with a pop valve

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 May 1994 13:25:08 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: King Link and the wheel cylinder.

Hi people,

Suspension rebuilld;
I have just ordered TRW's king pin set (K-472), it is for the VW. I'm not 
sure whether this is both K&L pins. At least the king pin has brass bushings. 

Brakes;
I was cleaning and painting brake parts yesterday. Straightforward but dirty 
work. My car seem to have more than enough lining left, but I will have to 
rebuilld the wheel cylinders. At $115 a piece I'm pretty sure I'll try the 
rebuilld them first. 

The bleeder valve was broken in one of the cylinders. I tried the (cheap) 
extractor, and of course did it break. I had to MAG weld the bleeder/broken 
extractor, just pulsing enough to build up a weld big enough for my smallest 
self locking plier. The heat itself is often enough to loosen the old broken 
piece. It came out nicely. 

1 phone call later:
The 'soft-ware' for rebuilding the wheel cylinders is about $ 6 for each 
cylinder, Original ATE stock. Needless to say, I ordered some extra sets 
(long term planning). 

Some questions that arises; can VW wheel cylinders be used in the rear brakes??
Does anyone know whether the VW beetle fuel cock can be used with the 356 
cars? (There seem to be 2 types of Beetle Fuel-cocks. From Germany one can 
get Beetle fuel cocks for $30 or $60.)

 I'm really thankful for all the information I get, I might put it together 
and make a 356 restoration guide-article. Things like what alternative part 
to use, which other cars can supply this item, where to look for specific 
parts, how to restore old and sometimes broken parts, etc.Often I feel these 
kind of questions are unanswered in restoration guides/booklets. You can 
really save a lot of money if you know where to get exactly the same 
part(s), without the Porsche designation. 

cheers,
trond

Date: Fri, 13 May 1994 09:10:14 +0500
From: len1@sos.wh.att.com
Subject: Front suspension noise

Hello out there Porsche Friends!

I figured I passed this on for what is worth...

Checking my car the other day, I became aware of some front end noise. Here's 
how I discovered. Using my knee, I moved the car up/down by leaning on the front
bumper. I like to shake the car every so often to listen for rattles and loose
parts.

Much to my surprise, I heard a noise comming from the top of the strut on the
driver's side. Check the other side and it made no noise. Popped the trunk and
placed my hand on top of the strut tower. Kneeling on the car I could feel/hear
play on the upper strut bearing. This is the part that isolates road vibration
from the strut. It also serves as bearing when the wheels turn. 

It had about 1/4" of play. I think the rubber mounting is shot. Pass. side
does not make any noise at all. Ordered the part, and found out it has been
superseded. My car is an '84 Carrera with only 28K miles. I actually ordered
both bearings. I'll rather do a wheel alignment once! Yes, after changing them,
the FE alignment will have to be done since they control camber and caster. 
Bummer!

Any way, I figured I pass this info to the net, just in case you folks are
chasing misterious FE noises (thumps!) specially when going over small bumps
like where driveways meet the road. BTW, parts are $60/ea. 

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len1@sos.wh.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo

Date:     Fri, 13 May 1994 08:29 MST
From: JBUTLER@PARK.ADMIN.UTAH.EDU
Subject:  Re: Zen & the Art of Solex Carburetors

I have found that at a given float level, adjusting the accelerator pumps
smooths out that nagging flat spot that seems to attack while cruising on the
freeway.  Also, I like to check all four nozzles for not only volumn but
where they are aimed as well from time to time. I think the factory manuel
says the stream should hit the butterfly and NOTHING else.  Also, sometimes a
piece of dirt will clog/pratially clog one nozzle and produce a flat spot.

The factory manual says that the neato feature allowing one to adjust the
float level from the outside of the carb allows one to adjust for different
grades/types of gas.  This indicates that their may be more than one optimum
float level depending on gas and/or...altitude maybe?  Has anyone fiddled
with this concept?  I'm resolved to learn by trial and error over the summer
and any of your experiences would probably allow me more trial than error.

John, U of Utah

Date: 13 May 94 11:26:10 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Solex carburetors

Hi, Pete.
 
Pete Gregory writes:
>I've one nagging performance problem that I _do_ believe is carb-related:
>at 3000-4000rpm and medium throttle, opening the throttle further (not
>necessarily to full, but say opening throttle from 1/3 to 1/2) results
>in momentary hesitation or 'skipping'.  Must I adjust my accelerator pumps
>for more delivery, or look elsewhere?
 
>My mixture is about right (passed smog, behaves expectedly when twiddling
>mixture screws at idle, 20mpg city driving), and plugs look perfect.  I'm
>not sure where to look for a solution.
 
Did you clean the carbs of accumulated sand and whatnot? Could one of the
jets be plugged? It's not that bad a job, it's helpful to have a factory manual
to tell you which of the brass hex heads lead to jets and which are just there
to plug various holes, it's a good idea to work logically, in a clean
environment such as a good well-lit bench or on the kitchen table, placing
the jets etc. on a white sheet of paper in some exploded-view fashion
as they come out. And do only one carb at a time, so that if you scramble
the parts, you can look at the other to see where they should go. Get some
carb cleaner spray and go to work (don't spray in the kitchen!) Use proper
metric box-end wrenches, not adjustables or pliers or vise-grips! If necessary
go to the local K-Mart or similar Trashmart and buy a cheap set of third
world small metric wrenches. They won't need to take much torque.
 
Then the next step, if that doesn't cure it, is to measure and if necessary
adjust the accelerator pump volume. With ignition off and engine cold (we
don't want to somehow have a backfire at just this time) peek into the
throttle bores and work the throttle linkage. Are you getting a stream of
fuel from each accelerator pump nozzle when you blip the throttle by hand
this way? Then at least they're working somewhat. If the engine is stock,
you shouldn't have to adjust for any more than the factory required. I've
never had to mess with it, and I don't even have matched accelerator nozzles
yet it seems to run fine. I think one side is stamped 35 or 135, and the other
40 or 140, don't remember.
 
I recently had a carb problem. I could run at any speed I liked, but had a
hard time getting there -- no accelerator pump action at all on one of the
cylinders. The cause was not a plugged jet, but rather a loose brass plug
which closed one accelerator pump passage. When asking for more throttle,
three (or maybe just two) squirters squirted into the engine, the one with
the loose plug leaked onto the side of the engine compartment. This
particular plug shook itself loose on a race track, and I'll have to remember
to keep those tight in the future or even safety wire them. Cleaning
everything out fixed the problem, merely because I had to go through
everything and retighten.
 
See, aren't you glad you didn't automatically trash the Solexes? Imagine
how much fiddling you'd be doing now to get aftermarket Webers to
run even remotely as well as the Solexes you have now. And if you'd
done the carbs without first finding the simple ignition fixes, you would
have dropped all that money and still not have cured the cause.
 
>I'd really like to buy 'Zen and the Art of Solexes' were it in print.  Can
>someone recommend a good book on Solexes?  It's easy to find material on
>Webers, but...
 
Motorbooks sells a book called "Solex 1 and 2 Barrel Downdraft
Carburetors," billed as a complete guide to tuning, maintenance
and repair, includes detailed teardown and rebuild. Pub. 1987,
softbound, 5x7 in., 91 pgs. 76 diagrams, $8.95. I've looked at it
but didn't buy it. No opinion on whether it's worthwhile.
 
Tell me again what car you have, and I'll try to look up the correct jet
sizes. (912, wasn't it? I can look up the last 356 SC jets, which should be
pretty close if not identical).
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 13 May 94 16:35:59 EST
From: Chris Horvath <chrish@smtplink.chey.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Transmission Query

John,
     Those ears at the front of your transmission are "safety devices" used to 
prevent the engine from entering the passenger compartment in the case of a 
heavy front end accident.
     There are a matching pair of ears welded to the body that will interfere 
with the ears in question as the drivetrain gets pushed back from the force of 
an accident.
     I found out about the purpose of these ears after my mechanic changed the 
clutch on my `87 944S and noticed that a previous mechanic had cut them off to 
allow for easy removal of the trans and torque tube. Needless to say I wasn't 
pleased about this, and this was definately one of the factors behind getting 
out of that car and into the one I really wanted: 89 951.

Chris Horvath
Manager of Systems Engineering 
Cheyenne Software

ChrisH@Chey.Com                     `89 951  Linen Grey Metallic on Linen Grey

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: 951S Production Numbers
Author:  sjagernauth@attmail.com at SMTPLINK-Chey
Date:    5/5/94 1:39 PM



Actually, only 470 and 700 951S were made in 1988 and 1989 respectively.  This 
is according to "The Illustrated Buyer's Guide" by Dean Batchelor.  As someone 
already stated, the 'S' designation was dropped in 1989 since that was the 
only 951 available.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 May 1994 20:10:39 -0400 (EDT)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Re: et tu Wendlinger

> I don't know, folks.  Maybe the technology was really  *better* than the
> driver. Instead of allowing the driver to go faster, what it actually did
> was keep him from killing himself.  Now, without it, two dead, two injured.

There is absolutely no evidence that the change in the rules "caused" the
accidents of Ratzenberger, Senna, or Wendlinger.

Motor racing has always been a dangerous sport. It is inherent. There was
a public outcry about the "carnage" of the first Paris-Madrid race.

The facts are that humans will always make mistakes. Drivers are
human, and we will always see even the greatest drivers make mistakes.
For the last 12 years, we have been relatively lucky. (Ask people
like Clay Regazoni or Nelson Piquet if they feel "lucky?')

At Brazil this year, we saw Senna make a mistake, go off course, and dnf.
Sadly, at Imola, Ratzenberger and Senna were killed in accidents.

Did the drivers accept the risk? No doubt. At the same time, I
suspect each belives that "it can't happen to me."

Sadly, racing automobiles will always involve the risk of an
accident; sometimes that accident will be grave. It is impossible
to protect the driver against EVERY possible risk. The drivers 
accept this; so too, must the fans.

Porschephiles #748                         Sun May 15 02:19:13 CDT 1994
Date: Sat, 14 May 94 00:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 944S: Tie rod ends

Dunno about "inner."  The tie rod had a ball joint at the end.  It will
loosen up, and past a certain point needs to be replaced.  The way you
check it (and the ball joint at the end of the control arm) is by
pushing up on its base.  I use a huge pair of "channel lock" pliers,
putting one jaw on the base of the ball joint, the other on some
component to which the top of the joint is bolted, and squeezing.

It can also be "bad" because its rubber boot is not intact.  The rubber
boot keeps a heavy grease in and dirt out.  The boot is available as
an Audi or VW part; I don't think you can get it from Porsche.

The tie rod end should be pretty cheap to replace in toto.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 14 May 94 05:07:00 UTC
From: w.oconnell4@genie.geis.com
Subject: Bike/ski rack on a 944?

  Has anyone put a bike rack on their 944?  I'm getting tired of putting our
  two bikes in the hatchback of my (87) 944 and was looking at racks, there
  are a few possibilities at my local bike store:
  $50 Rhode Gear Rhode Rack (mounts on read of car)
  $90 Rhode Gear deluxe bike rack (mounts on rear of car)
  $150-$180 Yakima combination of towers, crossbars, etc. (mounts on roof,
  good for skis too)
  What experience have you had or what recommendations might you be able to
  make?
  Thanks, Chris Milner
 
Chris,
  I have both of the Rhode Gear racks.  The 'regular' one I got years ago
and used it to carry our bikes on the 944 with no problems.  I have not
tired either on the 911, not sure the turbo tail is up to it :->  Just make
sure you mount it properly.
  The rear mount has some advantages because not all cars today have gutters
to hook the roof type up to and most of the 'gutterless' versions I looked
at seemed like they might screw up the paint.
   I also have a La Prealpina (SP?) that I got years ago.  A roof system
that we used for the bikes and canoe.  944 roof was to short thus the Rhode
gear rack.  I got so used to the Rhode Gear rack I have never used this one
on the Volvo or Quattro.  Right, wrong or whatever, the rear mount seems
more secure.
  Both the roof rack and the regular Rhode Gear are headed to a sale this
weekend - live in the Phila area :->

at, the person mentioned that the dealer would not let him/her start the car.

Then someone mentioned that the 911 will puff blue smoke when started, but
not if properly warmed up.

I had the same experience once at a Porsche dealership, and I have some
questions.
When I was looking at a '87 911 Carrera, the car puffed blue smoke out of
the exhaust when it was started. The salesman said that this was normal
for a 911, something about oil dripping into the combustion chamber after
the car sits for a while. Is this true, and why does this happen?
Otherwise, the car was beautiful, Guards Red coupe, black leather
interior, 70K miles, but $29K. Ouch! Too rich for my
financially-impoverished college blood.

Another question: Do the newer 911s, the 964 and the 993 still have pedals
which come out of the floor instead of hanging down from under the dash
like other, less sublime cars? Why does Porsche do this? Is there any benefit?

Finally: Are there any plans for a 993-based RS for the US market? I'd
_love_ to drive one, hopefully own one in the distant? near? future. :)

------------------------------

Date: 14 May 94 11:16:39 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Engine running backwards

I found the following in the latest issue of Porsche Panorama, which I
submit to the list without comment (yet), for your amusement:
 
On p. 5 of the article on the Cooper-Porsche, we read:
 
"In September 1992, Muller's race team installed the new engine at Watkins
Glen, but after one lap he headed for the pits. 'It wouldn't go past 2500
rpm,' he said. 'I was afraid to go past first gear.' A glancing inspection
by James Cox, the actual engine builder, revealed the fan belt running in
the wrong direction.
 
"Muller explained, 'It was intaking through the exhaust pipe and exhausting
out the carburetors. The car was running backwards!' In haste to make the
race, a starter was installed (not by Cox) which turned in the wrong
direction. The mechanics quickly replaced it with one rotating in the
opposite direction, and Muller was on his way."
 
Comments, gang? I am eagerly awaiting your findings, meanwhile I have to
replace the Q-switch on my laser printer. :-)
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 14 May 94 13:04:00 PDT
From: "Goodman, John" <Goodmjo@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: 911 short shift kits; 911 turbo tie rods on turbo-looks



Iikka Paavolainen writes:

>This is my first message to this mailing list. I have an '82 911 SC Taand 
I'd
>like to get the gears changed faster. The distance between 1st and 2nd gear 
is
>quite long (also 3rd and 4th etc.) . Is there a way of shortening the gear
>ratios or somehow get the gears changed faster to improve acceleration ? 
Any
>help
>appreciated!

About a year and a half ago, I put a factory short shift kit on my '85 911. 
 This has been, without a doubt, the best $100 I've spent on the car.  In 
Pano a while back, they compared a few short-shift kits, and the factory 
version pretty much came out on top.  Several of the other versions out 
there greatly exaggerate their reduction in throw.  The factory model is 
cheap (usually around $100, but I saw a dealer in CA selling them for $85 a 
month or two back), definitely not of cheezy construction, and a breeze to 
install.  It shortens the throw a pretty good amount and improves the feel 
of the system.  As with any short shift kit, effort increases as throw 
decreases, but the slight increase in effort with the factory kit was a 
welcome to me.  However, as the 915 gets older, it tends to enjoy 
lightning-quick gear changes less and less.  The SS kit brings this quality 
out in the open a little more.  It will make you double clutch a lot more. 
 YMMV.  If anyone doesn't have this Pano copy, or can't find theirs, and 
would like some specifics, drop me a note and I'll try to dig it up.

Also, a few digests back, someone asked about Turbo tie rods coming standard 
on Turbo-look  911s.  I'm 99.999...% sure they didn't.

John Goodman <goodmjo@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
'85 911
'88 M3

Date: 14 May 94 21:59:30 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Chrome vs Polish wheels

I have an anti-chrome story to tell.  I bought an '86 928 about 1-1/2 years ago.
It's forged wheels were chromed (I believe at the time of purchase when new).
Right before I bought it the previous owner replaced all four tires.  Turns out
the chrome was flaking under the bead, which caused a series of slow leaks that
showed up over the next 1,000 miles or so.  After talking to a few people about
this, it appears this is common behavior for chromed alloy wheels (explanations
vary, but include the different rates of expansion of aluminum alloy vs. the
chrome plating).  In any case, it was a royal pain to have to keep remounting
tires and asking the tire people to carefully scrape the bead each time.  After
one remount each, things have stabilized.  However, I would fully expect to have
to go through this again when I replace the tires, because more corrosion is
probably occuring right now under the beads, but it won't leak until the
tire/bead interface is disturbed again.  I'll probably have the chrome stripped
off at that time.

I really wish my wheels had never been chromed.


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 May 94 08:06:02 -0400
From: tomh@metrics.com (Tom Haapanen)
Subject: Machining 914 heads -- questions, questions ...


I have my spare 914 2.0L engine's heads in the machine shop, ready for the
work.  The shop is quite competent in general machining, and they've done
911 work as well, but they've never done 914 heads, let alone modifying
them.  So I have questions that I hope either Stan or someone else may be
able to answer:

 - Three-cut (venturi) valve job
  Is the term "three-cut" general enough that any machine shop would know
  it, or do I need to give them more specific instructions?  If so, how do
  I describe this valve job to them?

 - Porting and polishing?
  Is there any point to doing this?  Looking at the condition of the
  combustion chambers, I think I should have them polished at least, but is
  there any need for porting as well?

 - Current compression ratio
  I have the 95.5mm NPR pistons and cylinders; I believe that these give me
  the stock 7.6 compression.  Is that right?

 - Calculating the new combustion chamber size
  If I figured things right, compression ratio is 
	(swept volume + unswept volume) / unswept volume
  where the unswept volume is the combustion chamber size.  Or is it really
	swept volume / unswept volume
  Using the first method, I get a current combustion chamber size of 74.7cc,
  and a new one (at 9.5 compression) of 58.0cc.  With the second method, I
  get a current size of 64.8cc, and a new one (at 9.5 compression) of 51.9cc.
  I think these correspond to deck height reductions of 2.4mm and 2.1mm.
  Which one should I use?  And are my calculations correct?

 - Machining the deck
  Never having done this before, I can't tell the machinist where he should
  take off the material to achive the deck height reduction.  Does he 
  machine a deeper groove around the edge of the head where the cylinder
  barrel seats?  Or machine the barrels instead?  I expect that he'd need
  to also machine an equal amount from the bottom (not back) of the
  combustion area (looking at the heads as if they were installed in the
  engine) which is currently flush with with the seat for the barrel.

  Are there other things to worry about?  Valve clearance (I'm using the
  FAT Performance fuel injection cam)?  Pushrod length?  I would really like
  to have this done locally, as shipping parts across the border to the US
  and back can be a real hassle -- and time-consuming as well.

  I am grateful for any and all advice for the seasoned veterans...

- -- 
[ /tom haapanen -- tomh@metrics.com -- software metrics inc -- waterloo, ont ]
[ "castro won't last a year"                      -- fulgencio batista, 1957 ]
