Date: 15 May 1994 15:22:21 -0700 (PDT)
From: Derek van Veen <VANVEEND@CGSVAX.CLAREMONT.EDU>
Subject: Re: Engine running backwards

Yeah, I also cry "bullshit" on the story, since there is no way that the fuel
could get into the combustion chamber to ignite.  Even if it *could* by some
miracle of God (or Ferry Porsche), the spark would occur *before* the fuel/air
mixture was injected.  Also, as mentioned by Kim, if the engine was running 
backwards, the tranny would be "backwards" as well.  Not to mention the problem
with trying to run a distributor backwards...

I think this is just another racing tall-tale--an amusing one, but a tall-tale
nonetheless.

 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 May 1994 16:26:52 -40962758 (CDT)
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Machining 914 heads -- questions, questions ...

> - Three-cut (venturi) valve job

First off, three-cut is not the same as venturi... Venturi is three cut
some extra polishing work, to make the air flow across the valve and seat
maximally smooth. Not quite a mystic art, but close enough -- you gotta
know what you're doing to do it right.

>   Is the term "three-cut" general enough that any machine shop would know
>   it, or do I need to give them more specific instructions?  If so, how do
>   I describe this valve job to them?

In generaly, they should be able to figure this out. *However*, if they've 
not done either VW Type 1 or Type 4 heads, this might be a stretch... I'll
see if I can dig up our numbers (I'm nowhere near my engineering notebook, 
natch) and see if I can get the info for you by tomorrow sometime. Oh yeah --
we run *VERY DIFFERENT* cuts for "stock", "street performance" and "full
race". "Stock" should last a long time. "Street performance" will want a
new valve job in 20-30k miles. "Full race" is measured in hours of 
operation....

> - Porting and polishing?
>   Is there any point to doing this?  Looking at the condition of the
>   combustion chambers, I think I should have them polished at least, but is
>   there any need for porting as well?

Nope. Ignore all that. No porting, no polishing. As I've said about a zillion 
times before, unless you're making *MASSIVE* changes to the rest of the 
engine, the 2.0 heads in their natural state flow more air than you can use.

> - Current compression ratio
>   I have the 95.5mm NPR pistons and cylinders; I believe that these give me
>   the stock 7.6 compression.  Is that right?

Sounds right. Those are flat-top pistons, right? If so, then if you measure
the deck height, you can figure it out. If they're dished, you can still do 
it, but it's a little harder...

In this case "deck height" is the distance between the top of the piston
at TDC and the top of the cylinder under correct torque. 

> - Calculating the new combustion chamber size
>   If I figured things right, compression ratio is 
> 	(swept volume + unswept volume) / unswept volume
>   where the unswept volume is the combustion chamber size.  Or is it really
> 	swept volume / unswept volume
>   Using the first method, I get a current combustion chamber size of 74.7cc,
>   and a new one (at 9.5 compression) of 58.0cc.  With the second method, I
>   get a current size of 64.8cc, and a new one (at 9.5 compression) of 51.9cc.
>   I think these correspond to deck height reductions of 2.4mm and 2.1mm.
>   Which one should I use?  And are my calculations correct?

It's really (swept volume + unswept volume) / (unswept volume). Which is why
you need to measure the deck height -- unswept volume == head volume +
deck height volume!!!!

> - Machining the deck
>   Never having done this before, I can't tell the machinist where he should
>   take off the material to achive the deck height reduction.  Does he 
>   machine a deeper groove around the edge of the head where the cylinder
>   barrel seats?  Or machine the barrels instead?  I expect that he'd need
>   to also machine an equal amount from the bottom (not back) of the
>   combustion area (looking at the heads as if they were installed in the
>   engine) which is currently flush with with the seat for the barrel.

That's where you cut the *CASE* so that the barrels all sit at the same 
height from the case centerline, on nice smooth flat surfaces...

You *CAN* flycut the heads (which is what you seem to be describing in an
odd sort of way), but you absolutely have to be sure on the cut you make
there -- you can't reduce the cylinder head volume too much or the compression
ratio goes up too much, and you can't cut too much or the valves kiss the
piston (also not a good thing).

>   Are there other things to worry about?  Valve clearance (I'm using the
>   FAT Performance fuel injection cam)?  Pushrod length?  I would really like
>   to have this done locally, as shipping parts across the border to the US
>   and back can be a real hassle -- and time-consuming as well.

All I can say is *PLEASE* work with an intelligent guy who's willing to
learn, and have him make as many calls as necessary to shops in the US
who know how to do this stuff.... Done right, it will be very nice; done
wrong, and well, the nice people at the aluminium recycling plant will
still like you....

>   I am grateful for any and all advice for the seasoned veterans...

Please also rememeber that we got seasoned the hard way. The advice you
are given is intended to keep you from the same fate.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 May 1994 11:53:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: jmillick@netcom.com (James Millick)
Subject: Car Covers; Senna

Later this year I'll need to replace my car cover.  I've been using
Beverly Hills Motoring Accessories `Stormguard` for the past three
covers or so.  The OEM on the cover is Covercraft, and the material
Evolution 4 (4 layer quilted polypropylene).

I get about 2 years out of the E4 covers here in the midwest.  At about
18 months, the plasticizer gets baked out, and they started powdering
their way to obscurity.  (I've had cotton and poly cotton before that,
and they don't last, and a heavy dew will soak through them.)  The
E4's start at $144.

There was a Gore-tex cover on the market for awhile, but it was
outrageously expensive, over $300, as I recall.

I now see BHMA is advertising "ultraguard" covers above the E4,
with three layers.  Outside layer is UV resistant knit, middle
layer acrylic foam 1 way moisture barrier, and inner layer
cotton flocking.

They claim the Ultraguard will last longer (3 year warranty instead
of 2 f/E4), better sun protection, and is machine washable (E4 is
washable, in a commercial machine {hassle}, and is NOT machine
dryable).

As you'd expect, it's more money, starting at $224.  Does anybody
have any experience with this new cover, I don't mind spending extra
money so long as it's worth it.  E4 works well, though it would
be nice to be machine washable and last longer.

Jim

Off topic.  Monaco (or F1) just wasn't the same without Senna.  I
really miss that yellow and green helmet flashing around the track
in the red and white car (never did get used to the Williams w/
Rothmans colors).  I've followed Senna for 10 years, this is an
irreplaceable loss for me.

Still no clear answers to why the car left the track, but the
cause of death has been ID'd as a suspension member piercing the visor
of his helmet and hitting him in the head.



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 May 94 18:18 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: '72 911S - Converting MFI to EFI

Ken,

The electronic injectors will definitely not plug in to the screw-in
MFI bosses.  At a minimum, I would check with Kinzler for adapter
bosses.  There are a lot of other possibilities depending on your goals 
for the car and your budget.

Most include replacing the manifold with something set up for electronic
injection.  For example, TWM has a nice butterfly set-up.

If you're going to use a programmable management system such as Motec,
you also have a lot of freedom in the cam you use.  If you plan to
stick to the 2.4 displacement, figure out what the right cam is for
it based, mostly, on what other folks have found to work.

Kevin

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 09:41:42 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Engine running backwards

>On p. 5 of the article on the Cooper-Porsche, we read: 
>"In September 1992, Muller's race team installed the new engine at Watkins
>Glen, but after one lap he headed for the pits. 'It wouldn't go past 2500
>rpm,' he said. 'I was afraid to go past first gear.' A glancing inspection
>by James Cox, the actual engine builder, revealed the fan belt running in
>the wrong direction.
Didn't the 'pooper' have a Carrera engine? (DOHC gear driven?) Or is this a 
much more uptodate equipage?
Anyway it *is* possible to have one cylinderbank running 'backwards' in any 
engine with more than one bank and separate camshafts. Due to 
'massive_misstiming' one can have such an effect. The criterias for what is 
'backwards' could of course be backwards operating; i.e. breathing through 
the exhausts and blowing through the carbs. But if we are talkin backward 
rotation it seem very strange and as someone pointed out; 1st of April-ish!

The only engines I know of, which will run either ways, are the two-cycle 
engines. I had a 50cc Sachs 'moto-bike' some 15 years ago which was fully 
operational both ways. Quite fun running backwards in 35 mph.

cheers,
trond


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 09:52:17 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Solex carburetors and 'Old no 7' ?

Hi,

A hint on how to clean carburetors: (and other parts) use methylated spirit.

It works way better than white spirit and other solvents I've tried.
Be careful though, it is very harmful if swalloved. Always keep one good 
bottle of Whiskey within your reach to ensure you have antidote!!

But don't make it a habit cleaning out carbs........... :) :) :)

cheers,
trond

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 07:39:23 -0500 (CDT)
From: Wayne Brewer <wbrewer@ag.auburn.edu>
Subject: 911 speedometer

During the past year I have had an intermittent problem with the
speedometer in my 87 911 Carrera Coupe.  During the winter months
(Alabama) the car was driven infrequently, perhaps once a week, and often
the speedometer would not function for the first few miles and then kick
in and work fine for the rest of the trip.  The upshift light (or 
whatever it is called) did not function either but would also begin 
working again when the speedometer did.  With the onset of warmer
weather I have used the car on a more regular basis and have had no   
problem until yesterday.  At the beginning of a 20 mile drive the
speedometer worked fine but about 15 miles out it suddenly quit as I was
slowing for a stop sign.  It didn't work again the rest of the day. I
checked the connections on the back of the instrument and took several
short trips to test it but nothing worked.  This morning everything was
fine.  Yesterday was quite warm with temperature in the mid-80's and this
morning, of course, is much cooler.  Is this a temperature related
problem?  Is the speedometer dying?  Any ideas?

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 09:43:24 -0400

Subject: Theft Protection

I had been wondering about how to supplement the built-in Porsche burglar
alarm when I noticed the "Immobilser" ad in the new Pano.  It seems to be an
electronic interlock which kills the ignition, and which operates even if the
bad-guys remove the ignition lock.  We telephoned them today -- it costs $244
+ installation. Sounds like a lot!

a)	Does anyone know about this device. Any good?

b)	What other solutions are there? (I have discussed this with Stan
	and he recommends installation of a fuel pump kill switch. With this
	method the car only goes a few feet, then dies due to fuel
	starvation.)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 08:01:22 -0700
From: Scott.Griffith@Eng.Sun.COM (Scott Griffith, Sun Microsystems Lumpyware)
Subject: Re: Expandable foam as sound deadener?

On May 14, Bill Sulouff wrote:

> Does the aerosol expandable foam found at the loacl hardware store make a 
> good sound deadener if sprayed down into the footwells and inside the 
> door panels?? Are there any adverse effects? Smell?/ Fire?/ Crumbling?

The stuff does work, sort of, as a sound deadener. It has too little
mass to be really effective, especially at the low frequency end of
the scale. But it does help damp out high-frequency resonances, and it
can help add some damping to help prevent outright oilcanning of large
unsupported sheets.

Now, having said that, I would strongly recommend against using the
stuff in a race car, especially sprayed onto large areas. It does burn
very nicely, and as it burns it emits some particularly nasty
combustion products, as well as tending to drip flaming melted
globules as it burns, if it's on an overhead surface. It is also very
unstable when exposed to temperatures well under the flash point, so
if you spray it onto panels that are near exhaust plumbing and run
above 300degF or so, you can expect it to break down.

This is the stuff that everybody uses to make foam-in-place seat
inserts, and nobody ever seems to give the flammability of the stuff,
or its combustion products, a second thought. I wish they would, and
would use the female form they make with it as a mold to lay up a
fiberglass seat, instad of just covering the foam with layers of duct
tape to keep it from crumbling and using it directly... There's not
too much exposed surface area in a seat insert, so it poses less of a
hazard.

I can tell you some really nasty stories from direct personal
experience having to do with burning spray-on isocyanate foams in an
enclosed area, and I can show you the scars if you like. Moral- there
are probably better substances for use in a race car that is likely to
catch fire now and again. Just my opinion.

 -skod

- --
Scott Griffith, Sun Microsystems Lumpyware
expatriate SCCA New England Region Flagging/Communications worker
(and driver, of anything that turns both right and left,
and can pass tech...) Return Path : skod@sun.COM

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 10:03:28 CDT
From: tad@internet.wst.com (Tad Haas)
Subject: 914 Front sway bar mounting tabs - Help

What an awful discovery.  I acquired a stock 914 front sway bar and the 
Weltmiester mounting kit, (hoping to improve my Auto-x performance) only to 
discover that there were no u-tabs to connect the droplinks on my transverse 
/ A - arms.  Currently I can't mount the sway bar!!!

What suggestions can anyone offer?

I called Automobile Atlanta and they said they had a kit that could be 
installed on the original transverse / A - arms by either bolting them on or 
welding them.  I am not a welder, and don't have easy access to anyone that 
is.  So bolting them on sounds like an easier approach.  

Does anyone have experience with these kits or a similar problem?  If so,  I 
am all ears.  

Stan - any advice?  P.S. - I ran into a guy yesterday that knew the old 914, 
you and in particular Elmer Fohey.  His name is Udo Ditges.  He works at a 
Firestone shop on Hwy 6 in Houston.  (They fixed one of the old Pirelli's

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 11:55:20 -0400
From: Dustin Boyette - Logical Design Group <ldg@mercury.interpath.net>
Subject: Wrecked 930

At a body shop down the street from my office there is a red 930 which has
been T-boned on the driver's side. It's obviously an older turbo, perhaps a
77 or so, because it doesn't have a whaletail big enough for an intercooler.

After examining the damage, which is extensive to the driver's side door and
rear quarter panel, I found that red is not the car's original color. Rather,
it was a dark metallic grey. The impact was apparently severe, as it flexed
the frame enough to warp the trunk hood.

Call me crazy, but I'm actually interested in trying to buy the car from the
body shop (I doubt the insurance company owns it anymore - I would say totaled).
I guess I'm hoping I can buy it dirt cheap, put the $10-$15K into it for repairs, and end up with a 911 turbo.

So, what would be a good offer to make on the car? $500? $1000? $3000? I know
the drivetrain itself is worth some money, but the rest of the car has been
ragged pretty bad. I may have LOTS of bargaining power. Also, is it really
worth looking into? I have a friend in body repair who looked at it and said
that it could be fixed up just like new, but that it would take extensive effort
and money.

Thanks for any advice.

Dustin Boyette
ldg@mercury.interpath.net
Signal Green 1969 911S w/ 1980 SC body & engine

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 09:44:11 -0400
From: miketodd@cs.cornell.edu (Michael Todd)
Subject: Re: Engine running backwards

Maybe it was modified to a 2-stroke configuration ....

When I was growing up in England, there were a number of 3 wheelers --
BMW Isetta (also 4, with two very close at the rear), Messerschmitt,
Bond, ... If they had no reverse gear, you could drive them with a 
motorcycle licence, hence at 16 rather than 17. Which led to an amusing
(and no doubt apocryphal) story of an Isetta pulling yp to a brick wall.
The door opened forwards, and the driver was trapped inside, and had to
resort to asking passers by for assistance.

Anyway, back to running backwards. Many of these machines used motorcycle
engines and transmissions, which usually (except BMW R75's and Gold Wings,
and a Brough Superior -- any others?) have no reverse. One enterprising
manufacturer figured out a way to get reverse, by changing the ignition
timing (maybe it had two sets of points) and using a reversible starter/
charging system. So to back up, you stopped the engine and then restarted
it in reverse -- which gave you possibly 4 speeds, and a maximum of 70 mph,
in reverse. These were cars which weren't terribly stable going forwards ...
 
  -- Mike Todd

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 16:53:02 BST
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Theft Protection


Fred Pack asks of the Porsche immobiliser,

| a)	Does anyone know about this device. Any good?

I have the Porsche immobiliser fitted on my 911. It is disabled by
a microchip key, and controls power to a number of different 
electrical systems. The installer chooses exactly which and
keeps a record, most cars have a different permutation plus 
basic fuintionality circuits immobilised. 

The only way to steal a Porsche with one of these is to tow it
away or steal the microchip key. I suppose it might be possible
given about 5 or 6 hours to trace the circuits and disable it
but you would need a workshop. But regular smashed window and 
driven away theft is out of the question.

The UK is the home of car crime, and I have felt a lot more secure
since I had this fitted. Does not stop dorkbrains driving into 
your 911 in the Waitrose carpark though :-(

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 9:39:07 PDT
From: Dick Nyquist <dickn@hpspdbc.vid.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Expandable foam as sound deadener?



| 
| Does the aerosol expandable foam found at the loacl hardware store make a 
| good sound deadener if sprayed down into the footwells and inside the 
| door panels?? Are there any adverse effects? Smell?/ Fire?/ Crumbling?
| 

watch out. A lot of this kind of stuff is NOT fire resistant. 
Another problem to watch out for is that a lot of this kind of
stuff releases poison gasses when heated to a certain point.
Many years ago lot of folks were killed by poison fumes from
burning foame uppolstery in high rise and transportation fires
until underwriters banned certain foames. I know that the rigid foame
you are considering is not the same, but the concerns are.


I don't know how you can find out with respect to a particular material,
but I would try to be sure before I sprayed it into blind section of a 
firewall or sections that have a hot exhaust pipe against the other side.

Maybe calling the manufacturer would get you info.

Let us know if you find out anything specific.

/Dick




------------------------------

Date:          Mon, 16 May 1994 10:24:46 
From: "Roger Garnett" <rwg1@postoffice3.mail.cornell.edu>
Subject:       Re: Expandable foam as sound deadener?


> Does the aerosol expandable foam found at the loacl hardware store make a 
> good sound deadener if sprayed down into the footwells and inside the 
> door panels?? 

It can...

> Are there any adverse effects? Smell?/ Fire?/ Crumbling?

Yes. A friend and I tried this out some, 10+ years back. 

1) If you put it anywhere that it can get wet, it will, and it will hold
water, (especially if it blocks the drain holes) and the constant moisture
will help rust the area. It may not be so bad for filling in fibre glass 
sections, with no steel.

2) If you are going to do it, use good foam (great stuff is ok), or it won't 
set, and will drip out.

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 10:45:55 PDT
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: C4 cylinders

> Subject: C4 cylinders

> Folks,

> I recall there was some posting a while back about bad cylinders in
> Carrera 4's, perhaps C2's as well, and that Porsche was replacing
> same for customers.  I cannot find a tech bulletin as of 12/93 on
> the subject.

> Anyone know anything concrete?  What were the symptoms?

> Kevin

Kevin,
The Tech bullentin is 9202 dated March 13, 1992.  This is a problem for the 
the 1989, 1990 & 1991 C2/4.  You have to have wet oil on the lower part of the 
cylinder heads, otherwise the factory won't authorize the warranty work.  They 
have to replace the pistons, cylinders and replace/install new head gasket.  I 
know there was no recall notice sent out, the dealers are just looking at the 
cars as they come in for service--another way to get you to go to the dealers 
for sevrice.

Quincy Dong (QLD1@pge.com)

Date: 5/14/94 13:45
To: Donn Mukensnable
From: Peter Albrecht
I found the following in the latest issue of Porsche Panorama, which I
submit to the list without comment (yet), for your amusement:
 
On p. 5 of the article on the Cooper-Porsche, we read:
 
"In September 1992, Muller's race team installed the new engine at Watkins
Glen, but after one lap he headed for the pits. 'It wouldn't go past 2500
rpm,' he said. 'I was afraid to go past first gear.' A glancing inspection
by James Cox, the actual engine builder, revealed the fan belt running in
the wrong direction.
 
"Muller explained, 'It was intaking through the exhaust pipe and exhausting
out the carburetors. The car was running backwards!' In haste to make the
race, a starter was installed (not by Cox) which turned in the wrong
direction. The mechanics quickly replaced it with one rotating in the
opposite direction, and Muller was on his way."
 
Comments, gang? I am eagerly awaiting your findings, meanwhile I have to
replace the Q-switch on my laser printer. :-)
 
Pete

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 16:44:03 BST
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Factory Visit Report


Just a quick report on the Stuttgart factory visit I
have recently returned from. 

Arrived in Stuttgart on Thursday lunchtime, met up with
the other people from PCGB (who were the organisers). 
Forty-three people in the group, most people had driven
over, about 20 911 and two each 944 and 928. The cars looked
excellent massed in the hotel carpark. People were stopping
in the street to gape at the site of the massed German metal
all with UK plates.

After lunch we were off the the Mercedes factory to visit the
museum there. This was an excellent visit and we saw some
great Mercedes including plenty of early racers, a fabulous
silver 300SL Gull Wing, and the first Daimler-Benz. This last historic
car was most interesting, and the guide started it up for us to
demonstrate that it still runs!

There was an informal dinner that evening for the masses,
and lots of beer and schnapps drinking. A lot of Porsche
stories etc, etc.

The next day was Der Tag. We were off in the coach for the visit
to the Porsche factory and Museum, both on the same site at Zuffenhausen.
When we arrived there was some hanging around and taking the 
air outside the museum. This is just inside the main gate, 
and the air was thick with the noise of new 911s belting in through the
gates and hitting the gas as they headed up the ramp into the main 
compound area. The drivers were really winding these cars up,
no gently does it, just nailing the throttle!

Then we were into the museum. This was fabulous and had many
historic Porsche motor cars and exhibits. The ones that I really 
remember are Porsche 356 number 1, an amazing 914/8 (yes that's right an
8 cylinder 914), a number of Le Mans winning 917s, some amazing
962s, some historic engines, a brilliant display with
a model of every production and racing Porsche type, a 550 spyder
and a Carrera Arbath.

Next it was the tour round the factory. First off was the interiors
department. We saw leather craftsmen at work on various aspects of
Porsche leather interiors, dashes, door pulls, door linings etc.
I was amazed how much of the leather interior is sewn by hand.

Next we saw the little line making soft tops for the 993 cabriolet.
This is an interesting line, it had about eight or nine stages
involving the assembely of the frame (amazing amount of metal in
that hood!), fitting and stretching the cover etc.

After that we went to the engine assembly area, and saw the line
making the 911 3.6 engine. This is a smallish, 20 odd station line.
Each engine has the flag of the destination nation on it's carrier,
and a special parts set on a kind of upright trolley follows the engine
round the line. Each engine takes about three hours to put together.

Next we went on to the engine test area. Here the engines are unloaded
from their trolleys, and connected up to a test bed in a series of 
little rooms with heavy glazing in the window. The test bed has
all the connections that the 911 engine would require for electrical power, control,
power take off, dme etc. It takes about five minutes for the engineer to winch
the engine into position, make the connections. The the engine is
started up and warmed up. The engineer monitors the operating
parameters, such as oil temp etc. The engine is warmed up more or
less unloaded, and when a certain oil temp is reached, the engineer 
applies a known load on the engine using the water brake (engine drives
water turbine through the clutch). The engine is run up to around 5000
rpm and the dual ignition circuits are tested, the oil temp, oil pressure,
fuel pressure, tourque and power output are all monitored. When the engine 
reaches normal operating temperature, it is run up to maximum power rpm, 
and the final power measurement made. The engine has to be within +/- 2% 
of the stated maximum power. Only 1% fail to pass. Even if the engine
is producing more than the stated power, it goes back to a special
diagnosis area where the problem is corrected.

>From the engine department we moved on to the body shop. Here, we saw the
body preparation and paint facility (from the outside, they are fanatical
about preventing contamination in the multi stage cleaning, dipping, 
priming, painting and finishing cycle.) We then moved downstairs and saw the
911 production line, and the mini lines that mate the rear subframe with the
engine, transmission and suspecnsion and pre-assemble the front running gear, 
and finally mate up the sub-assemblies with the painted bodies, and install 
the electrics etc.  Every car has a different spec, and cars for all markets are 
assembled on the line. A complex tagging system ensures the parts for the appropriate 
spec are arranged together in kits to await the arrival of the body down the line.

Then we saw the body fabrication shop, and saw the 911 line, this has 
fairly extensive automation, and a number of sophisticated robots, plus a 
significant amount of manual work with the more fiddly welding operations.
We also saw a number of bodies designated for the RS 3.8 and the Turbo S 3.6,
these all have special constructions with reinforcing and stiffening elements
built in by hand.

Then it was on to lunch in the huge refectory with all the workers and Ilse and
the other Porsche club liason and factory people.

After lunch it was back on the bus and out to the R&D centre at Weissach.
We arrived at the test track just as the engineers were finishing putting a
Carrera Cup 993 and a RS 3.8 round the track. Sadly we did not get to
go in these, but enthusiasts were pleased to note that the RS was the
infamous blutorange colour! Then we settled into the main business of the day
which involved the engineers giving rides round the test track in a brand
new 928, 993 and 968 Club Sport. Needless to say this was a pretty wild
experience, and we saw some great driving skills and motor cars demonstrated.

In the course of the track afternoon, the 911 used TWO sets of tires, and
928 trashed one set in about 25 laps, the 968 seemed lightest on the tyres and
used a new set of tyres in about 50 laps. The poor 928 was really pushed
beyond the barriers of acceptable use on the test circuit which has lots of very
sharp bends and ups and downs, and basically I think that the engineer trashed
the brakes along with the tyres, the brakes boiled and were smoking when he
called it a day for safety reasons. The 911 took the pounding very well, and
the brakes were unaffected by the remorseless punishment, as was the braking
and cooling system on the 968 CS. This was a really excellent afternoon
which was enjoyed hugely by the assembled faithful.

That evening there was a formal dinner hosted by Porsche, and the guest speaker
was Stephen Murkat (sp?), the guy who leads the design team for the 993 and is
now running the Boxster development. This guy loves Porsche style and
functionality, and was a pretty cool sort of person. He would not give away
any Boxster information, as one would expect, but he did promise the hungry masses
that it would be "pure Porsche" and faithful to the concept car that everyone
went crazy about. He was very pleased with the public reaction to the 993 and
happy it was outselling other rolling objects alleged to be sports cars in the US and UK.
In the question part, I asked him what car he drove, he has the latest 928 GTS.

That more or less sums up the Porsche component of my holiday, except for autobahn
speed trials! I got indicated 6100 rmp in 5th, two up, with luggage and it felt like
there was still a little more to go. One of the other 911 people on the trip
claimed an indicated 170 mph! in his modified Carrera RS 3.6.

Then we wnent down to Interlaken in Switzerland for a few days and then
drove back to the UK in a single hop of 12 hours, with 9 hours actual driving time
over a distance of 786 miles. I only got busted by the police once for exceeding
the speed limit. Yup, France, 60 kilometres outside Calais, 160 kmh, 600 ff fine along
with another 911 driver who originally passed us at 140 mph 100 kilometres 
further back. The thing that got us was that loads of French people were getting 
pulled in, and none of them got a fine just a ticking off, but because
we were Brits driving 911s they felt that were justifiable targets. Still
I don't really mind, in the UK I would have lost my license and had a ban
for driving over 100 mph. In fact Les Flics were very friendly once they got the cash,
and there was a lot of joking about what a good dinner they were going to have that
night etc.

All in all I can recommend this PCGB organised visit, and will probably go again
next year.

Regards,

Ben

1988 911 Carrera 3.2, Gurads Red

Date: Mon, 16 May 94 13:25:02 CDT
From: Brian=Wagner%Radio%WILL@bigbird.will.uiuc.edu
Subject: Engine funning backwards

Engine Basics:
  OK, Here's what I understand would happen--
   (let's just ignore such "subtleties" as valve timing)
INTAKE-- would be the same as a "forwards" running engine, then we would take
   that nice mixture and
EXHAUST it until we hit more or less the top of the stroke. Then at TDC, 
   close that exhaust valve it's time to ignite whatever is left for a huge
POWER pulse. But wait that distributor was running backwards too, I wonder 
   what happens there? Anyhow,
COMPRESS those exhaust gases and blow 'em out the intake when that valve 
   opens again, further diluting the next charge.
 So I guess one basic question is, can you get enough power from a small  
uncompressed mixture to compress its own burned volume?

  On a more serious note, awhile back there was some talk of serious damage
occurring if a 911 engine was run backwards (during a spin, not of its own 
accord). I assumed it had something to do with the cam chain, etc. Anybody
have the lowdown on this?
  Thanks,
    Brian

Date: 16 May 1994 14:31:00 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: 911 VINs - help?

                      Subject:                              Time:  1:49 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         911 VINs - help?                      Date:  5/16/94

I have been trying to keep a good record of VIN definitions
for those interested in buying used but "original" 911's
(1981 and later).  Excellence published a definition a few
years back but it was incomplete and inaccurate in at least
one obvious way.  Someone sent me a definition from The
Performance Handbook (I think) but it conflicted with some
other info I had.  And I have tried to glean some of it from
advertisements (with VINs included).

The one digit I cannot get straight is #13 (figures!).
Here's what I have:

13  = Code for the body type & engine
      81-89 (SC & Carrera)
         2 - coupe (USA/Canada)
         6 - targa (USA/Canada)
         7 - cabriolet (USA/Canada)
      89-94:
         0 = coupe (non-USA)
         (1 = turbo targa (non-USA)
         1 = RS coupe (USA)
         2 = coupe (USA)
         3 = targa (non-USA)
         (4 = targa (non-USA))
         4 = targa (USA)
         (5 = turbo coupe (USA/Canada) or cab (non-USA))
         5 = cabriolet (non-USA)
         (6 = turbo targa (USA/Canada) or targa (USA))
         6 = cabriolet (USA)
         (7 = turbo cab (USA/Canada) and cab and speedster)
         8 = turbo coupe (USA)

I could use some more data to get this right.  If you're feeling
helpful would you look up the 13th VIN digit of your 1981-on
911 and send it to me along with:
Year, USA-Canada/Rest of world, coupe/targa/cab/speedster,
and if it is an 89 or later: Carrera/C2/C4/RS.  If you have a
slant nose (the 911, that is), a  930, turbo-look, or some other
body style that might be relevant tell me that too.  Maybe I can
straighten this out.  Please don't confuse me with VINs for
modified cars.

If someone has THE DEFINITIVE VIN list, or can point me, great.
Thanks.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 18:52:19 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com  ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: F1 Rule Changes

PRODIGY(R) interactive personal service         05/13/94         4:47 PM

12:59 PM (ET) 5/13
Racing Reforms Aimed at Increased Safety
MONTE CARLO--Motor racing chief Max Mosley announced
Friday sweeping safety reforms following recent accidents
that have cost the lives of 2 drivers and left a 3rd
critically injured.

Mosley, president of the International Automobile
Federation (FIA), said the reforms will be introduced almost
immediately, despite opposition from the teams.
He said the measures are aimed to "reduce the performance
of the car and improve the security of the drivers."
Mosley said the changes, regarded by experienced
observers as the most sweeping in Formula One since the
banning of wings in 1981, will come in to force for the
Spanish Grand Prix in Barcelona in 2 weeks.
The new measures have been introduced in the wake of the
accident Thursday in which Austrian Karl Wendlinger suffered
critical head injuries and less than 2 weeks after the
deaths of Brazilian Ayrton Senna and Austrian Roland
Ratzenberger at the San Marino Grand Prix.

The chief changes, Mosley said, "do not have everyone's
agreement, but we will do it despite the Concorde
Agreement." The Concorde Agreement is the legally-binding
document of partnership that had controlled the sport.
"The time has come to push aside such things in the
general interests of the sport," he said. "These things have
to be done."

Mosley said the following measures are to be introduced
by the next Grand Prix in Barcelona:
- -- Reduced size for the diffusor (an aerodynamic section
of the exhaust escape at the rear of the car)
- -- Reduced size for the front wing end plates
- -- Reduced size of the front wing.

He said these measures would reduce downforce by 15 %.
Mosley said that for the following Grand Prix in Canada
June 12, the lateral protection of the drivers' heads will
be increased by increasing the size of the cockpit sides.
This would increase the overall weight, and the minimum
weight for cars would be increased by 25 kilos.
Mosley added that the front wishbones in the suspension
of the cars are to be strengthened to prevent the front
wheels breaking away and cockpits would be lengthened to
help avoid the driver striking his head on the front of the
cockpit.

Rules governing the type of fuel also will be tightened
ahead of the Canadian Grand Prix aimed at eliminating so-
called "jungle juice"--fuel with additives that enhance the
performance of the cars.

Further changes, originally intended for next season,
would come into force by the German Grand Prix at the end of
July including the introduction of a stepped base to the
cars to reduce the aerodynamic affect and slow them down.
The size of the rear wings would also be reduced.
Next year FIA would enforce a further reduction in
aerodynamic downforce of 50 %, Mosley said.

He added that teams would have until Aug 1 to come up
with their own suggestions as to how to do this, but if they
fail to agree on any proposals, he said FIA would push its
own plans through again.
He said also that the power of the engines would have to
be reduced to 600 horsepower from the current maximum of
around 800 for next year.

Mosley added that various other safety issues, such as
the use of airbags and foam and driver restraints were being
studied with various experts and a Safety Advisory Group was
to be formed under the chairmanship of FIA's chief medical
officer Sid Watkins.

There was a mixed reaction from the teams after Mosley's
announcement.

Patrick Head, technical director of the Williams team
said: "I have absolutely no comment to make--on or off the
record."

Benetton managing director Flavio Briatore said: "We need
to see what the technical people make of it, but it's a very
good decision from FIA and Max Mosley. I approve of
everything."

A spokesman for Ferrari said they are pleased with the
regulations proposed for this year, but unsure about the
future rule changes.

Ken Tyrrell commented: "I am sure most teams are going to
be concerned about the dates they have to be introduced by.
It's like asking some of them to have a completely new car
designed in time for the German Grand Prix, something that
would normally take us a year or 9 months."
(From Reuters)

Copyright 1994 Prodigy Services Company. All Rights Reserved.

Subject: BBS RS 3-Piece 8" & 9" X 16 Wheels

Dear Friends,

I purchased a set of BBS RS 3-piece wheels with silver centers for my '87 black 
911 Cabrio. I put new KONI's on all 4 corners, and that kind of lifted the car a 
bit. Unfortunately, I have 9" rims for the rear with 245/45-16 Dunlop DM40's and 
8" with 225/55-16 in the front. Now that I want to lower the car (after only 250 
miles) the front rims are just too wide. I have the following options :
	1. Buy two 7X16 rims and 2 205/55-16 tires. Cost $1420.00
	2. Sell the two 9x16 rims and use the 8x16's in the back
	3. Sell the 8x16's - the 9x16's do well on the rear

Is anyone interested in two 8x16's with or without tires, or wants to consider 
trading 7 for 8's ? The rims are in impeccable state. (the turbos came 
originally with 7's but can use the 8's with 225/50-16 tires).

Any suggestions anyone ???

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 18:39:47 +0800
From: tilden@kea.Data-IO.COM (John Tilden)
Subject: Re: 911 speedometer

Wayne Brewer writes:
 
> During the past year I have had an intermittent problem with the
> speedometer in my 87 911 Carrera Coupe....
> Is this a temperature related problem?  Is the speedometer dying?  
>Any ideas? 

	Wayne, 
		My '87 speedo had a similar problem, then it ceased to 
		work altogether. I replaced the speedo sender in the 
		transmission and it is fixed! I suspect that moisture
		can enter the sensor/sender and foul up it's ability
		to count pulses and fail intermittently, yours will 
		probably eventually fail completely. 

	John Tilden
	Data I/O Corp.

Date: Mon, 16 May 1994 23:28:03 -0700
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>




Re: Backward Running Porsche



 Dear Pete:



  Wow! Another Backward-Running Porsche! Yes, ironically the Maestro had
just such a thing happen to him a few years ago. Actually, it happened to
one of his Customers. And it wasn't an April Fool's joke!

  Oh, Hell, I might as well send you the Story! It's from my Book: "The
Maestro's Newsletter" and entitled: "Why Does my 912 Turn BACKWARDS???", and
is presented here slightly edited to prevent Boredom.

  If you or anyone else wants the Unedited Version, I'll be happy to E-mail
it. (Writing Books on Computers sure does have advantages- all that info
right there at your fingertips, ifin you can remember the subdirectory it's
in!)

  It all started when the Maestro rebuilt an engine for a Customer in That
Great State of Texas.

 One day, when the Maestro was imbibing his Minimum Daily Requirement of
Beer, and reading a story in "Aviation Week" about the first successful
Brilliant Pebble Test, the phone rang.

 It was the Man From Mississippi- finally about to fire up a 912 Engine the
Maestro had built a year before.

 But there was a Problem- the Engine wouldn't run!

 There was no doubt in the Maestro's mind that the 912 WOULD run- and in
fact, HAD run- for the Maestro had run it for an hour on his Test Stand in
California.

 "It's really strange," Maestro- "she's a-popping back through the
carburetors something fierce!"

 "Geez," thought the Maestro, "That's not right. It ran just fine out here!"

 "There's one thing I'd like to ask you," said the Man from Mississippi a
little sheepishly- "Uh, which way is the engine supposed to rotate?"

 "Uh-oh," thought the Maestro - "this sure sounds like one of those Trick
Questions- like on the SAT."

 "Well," said the Maestro, "when viewing the pulley from the Rear of the
Car, all 356/912 Engines Normally rotate CLOCKWISE. Like a Clock."

 "Yeah, that's what I thought too," said the Man from Mississippi. "But MAH
Engine is a-rotating the OTHER WAY!!! It's a-goin' COUNTER-CLOCKWISE!"

 "WHOA!!!" said the Maestro- "that's not right!!!"

 "I didn't think so either," said the Man from Mississippi. "What do y'all
think could be wrong?"

 The Maestro, not having confronted counter-clockwise rotating 912's before,
cogitated on the question before answering. He quarried the Data Base.
"COUNTERCLOCKWISE???" it Cried. "How the Hell can a 912 RUN
Counterclockwise???," it asked incredulously.

 Quick on its feet, the Center of Higher Reasoning jumped in- "If it's
REALLY rotating backwards- it CAN'T Run! Rotating backwards, it'll pump
Exhaust back through the Carbs! Which incidentally, explains the "a-poppin'
back through the Carbs" part."

 The Man from Mississippi interrupted the Maestro's thoughts with- "Uh,
Maestro, I've got my Mechanic with me, maybe you two can figure out what's
wrong with my 912.

 The Man From Mississippi's Mechanic (MFMM) got on the line.

 "Yeah, hey Maestro Man, bo' this is the Damndest thing Ah ever did see! The
damn engine turns over BASS-ACKWARDS!"

 Wanting to be sure that Bass-Ackwards in Mississippi was Counterclockwise
in California, the Maestro asked- You mean when the starter cranks the
engine over, the pulley turns to the Left, Not the Right?

 "Yep, to the Left, not the Right. If the "OT" mark on the Pulley is On Top,
aligned with the Timing Mark in the Case, and the Starter engaged, the
pulley moves to the LEFT!"

 "OK," said the Maestro. "But let's be Sure. I'll show you a little Trick.
Go to the Rear of the 912. Do you see a little Yellow wire over by the
Voltage Regulator that comes out of the Wiring Harness and goes nowhere?
It's got a rubber boot over a Female Spade connector."

 The Man From Mississippi looks around- and sho' 'nough finds a little
Yellow wire with an insulated Female Spade connector.

 "That's the Baby," said the Maestro. "Now, making sure that the car is Out
Of Gear, and that the Brake be on, touch that thar little Yellow wire to the
B+ "Hot Side" of the Voltage Regulator- where the Big Red Wire joins- and
the engine should crank over." Pause.

 Over the Phone the Maestro hears the Unmistakable Sound of a Porsche
Starter Cranking.

 "Dad Burn it," said Mississippi- "You're RIGHT Maestro- it DOES turn over!
Hot Damn, that's a neat idea!"

 "Yes," said the Maestro- "it's a Mechanic's Secret so that ONE Mechanic's
only (not two) can crank the engine over for Compression tests or timing
adjustment. The little Yellow wire runs right to the Solenoid Connection of
the Starter and does Absolutely Nothing unless you touch its other end to
the Hot Side of the Regulator- in which case the Starter Cranks.

 "NOW," said the Maestro- "which way does the engine turn?"

 "Honest to God, Maestro- it STILL Turns COUNTER-Clockwise!," replied the
man from Mississippi.

 The Maestro then flashed through his Data Base and remembered The Strange
Case of Mel, a Gentle Shop Owner who purchased a NEW Battery whose Terminals
had been reversed! "+" was "-" and Vice-versa.

 And BOY did the Gauges acted Strangely Indeed! All of which went away when
the Battery cables were REVERSED, and which went away permanent when the
Battery was replaced with another where "+" was "+" and "-" was "-", and
never the Twain shall meet.

 But I digress. Asked the Maestro- "you said the BATTERY has been changed
too???"

 "Yes," said Mississippi. "I replaced that too!"

 "First let us ascertain that it is NOT a "reversed Battery". Reverse the
Battery connections and try the Starter again." (KIDS! Don't try this at
home on Dad's Carrera GT Speedster!)

 The guy did- "Dad Gum it Maestro, It STILL turns Counterclockwise- and
still pops like hell outa the carburetors!"

 "I'm not surprised," said the Maestro- "even a MaestroMassaged Engine won't
run Backwards. However it WILL suck like hell from the Exhaust and try to
Pump it out the Carburetor! Which is NOT a good thing to do with gas
droplets and high-voltage Sparks all around!"

 "So whaddya think is wrong?" asked the Man From Mississippi expectantly.

 "It is my Professional Opinion," said the Maestro "that what we have have
is The Case of a BAD starter- or more likely- the WRONG starter- maybe it's
for a 914 or a VW Bus or some oddball 911?

 "Y'know said the MFMM, that's what I though too! I just was surprised as
hell to have the engine turn the Wrong Way!"

 "You're not the only one," said the Maestro- relating the Story of the
Gentle Reader back East, near "Joisey", who stuck a Corvair Engine into a VW
bus. Since Corvair Engines rotate backwards relative to Porsche Engines, the
ring gear of the VW Bus's transmission had to swapped to the other side.

 Unfortunately, this Corvair-powered VW Bus got wrecked and the Gentle
Reader made a Deal with the Junk Yard Operator to buy the parts back at a
Good Price once the Insurance Co had paid off on the claim.

 Unfortunately, the Junk Yard owner had other ideas and refused to honor the
deal.

  So, the Gentle Reader merely decided NOT to tell the Junk Yard owner about
the VW transmission mods! Vengeance was to be his.

 So, when the Junk Yard later sold the Transmission to a higher-up in the
Mob's pecking order, the sight of a VW Bus with FOUR SPEEDS in REVERSE but
only one Forward mustave been a sight to behold! As would the Junk yard
owner's kneecaps the next day!

 So, was it really be a Funky Starter?

 Yeah- it turned out that it was the WRONG Starter- a Bosch SR-27X rather
than a Bosch SR-26X for a 912. And WHAT do you think a SR-27X fits???

 Give up?

 Why, a 928!

 So, it was no surprise that a Starter for a Water Cooled, Front Engined,
Rear Wheel Drive Porsche 928 just might turn the Opposite way from an
Air-cooled, Rear Engined, Rear Wheel drive Porsche 912 made 20 years
previously!

 The Maestro was amazed that after all these years and all those differences
that the 928 Starter FIT in the 912!!!

 But all's well that end's well. And with the RIGHT starter, the 912 sprang
unhesitatingly to live. 

 The Man from Mississippi became a Believer. Because he had:



      KEPT THE 356/912 FAITH!!!



 :p


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 May 94 09:17:17 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Engine running backwards

> >On p. 5 of the article on the Cooper-Porsche, we read: 
> The only engines I know of, which will run either ways, are the two-cycle 
> engines. I had a 50cc Sachs 'moto-bike' some 15 years ago which was fully 
> operational both ways. Quite fun running backwards in 35 mph.

It seems to me that if you install the camshaft backwards and use a backwards
starter, you could get an engine to run backwards (badly). The fix would
not be as simple as figuring out that you are in reverse and putting on
the right starter, though. It really doesn't sound like the kind of mistake
that a pro race car builder is going to make.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Tue, 17 May 1994 08:38:42 -0700
From: William Oldham <oldham@EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: SPEEDSTERFEST

WANTED:  SPEEDSTER OWNERS AND ENTHUSIASTS
             (and all 356ers)
The 1994 SPEEDSTERFEST will again take place
at Cal State Hayward on Sunday, June 19, 1994.

(Das 1994 Speedsterfest findet am Sonntag
19 June, bei Cal State Hayward, stat.)

The event is an opportunity for those who own these cars
to gather ans share restoration, concours and SCCA or
vintage racing war stories.  The event is not a judged
concours, but an opportunity to photograph the cars and
enjoy the company of other Porsche owners.

The site will be open at 10:00 AM.  A catered German lunch
will be served at noon and a German band will provide music
until the conclusion around 4PM.  T-shirts will be available
at the event (and for a year or two afterward).   Field
parking for all Porsches.

Directions:  From I880 take Jackson Street east to Mission Blvd.
Go South on Mission Blvd. and take a left on Harder Road.
Go up the hill to the STOP sign, take a left, and you are there.

For Information and Registration Contact:
Hank Tarbell
19 Heather Lane
Orinda CA 94563

Phone/Fax (510) 254-4757

Date: Tue, 17 May 94 10:28:02 -0400
From: "Bart Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: 915 Transmission

Last June, I purchased my '86 911 w/10,700 miles, which came with the factory 
used-car warranty.

I've had a fairly consistent problem with grinding/crunching while engaging 
first or reverse gears while stopped.  I recently took it to the dealer where 
I purchased it and had the service manager drive it with me in the car.  He did 
not have the problem.

I have been driving manual transmissions since '54, don't ride the clutch, do 
engage the clutch fully before engaging first or reverse, and am worried that 
this problem could haunt me in days to come (say, this june 30th, the day after 
the warranty expires...)

Any useful thoughts would be greatly appreciated...  Thanks, Bart

Bart Chambers
bchambers@Atlantic.nos.noaa.gov
'86 911 Cabriolet
'87 Quantum Syncro (Quattro in Disguise)

Date: Tue, 17 May 94 13:13:10 -0400
From: Dustin Boyette - Logical Design Group <ldg@mercury.interpath.net>
Subject: Wrecked 930 part II, Another 930

The car I described in "Wrecked 930" is quite a junkpile. It has been wrecked
more than once, the hood is full of bondo, and, to tell you the type of guy
who owns the car, plastic strips with the words "PUT DOWN HANDBRAKE, YOU DUMMY!"
are stuck to the tach. What sacrilege to treat the near-supercar-status 930
with such disregard. The guy still owns it and it is not for sale by the
insurance company as I thought.

So I found another Turbo...

I talked to the guy that owns the bodyshop (a friend of mine) who has
two turbos: a black gray-market 1984 Turbo, and a white 1978 Turbo which he
has been driving lately. Both cars are gorgeous. While talking to him about
the red 930, he told me that the white 1978 was for sale for $24,000.

It's a one-owner car with 42,204 original miles. It's clean as a whistle. No
rust, the bodywork is in perfect condition, the interior is perfect, and the
engine is spotless. It's not leaking any oil and you could eat off the bottom
of the engine, which is surprising since it doesn't have the late lower rocker
covers. No running problems other than a faulty warm-up regulator which just
slows down cold starting. It doesn't have Carrera tensioners, and since it's
pre-1980 1/2 I think it needs them.

So, is $24,000 really a "steal" for this car? I've seen 1978 Turbos for sale
for $28,00 and up. It is in excellent shape, remember. The car only has 42,204
miles and it hasn't been driven hard (70-year old owned it and treated it
well). Do these engines hold up a long time? Will it need rebuilding before
100,000 miles?

Again, any advice would be much appreciated.

Thanks,
Dustin Boyette
ldg@mercury.interpath.net
Signal Green 1969 911S w/ 1980 SC Body & Engine

Date: Tue, 17 May 1994 04:12:46 -0700
From: Scott Winders <winders@porsche.support.apple.com>
Subject: Re:  BBS RS 3-Piece 8" & 9" X 16 Wheels


Bart,

What you want to do is convert your 8x16 BBS wheels to the 944 Turbo
offset and mount 225/45R16 tires. This will allow you lower your
car about as far as you want and keep 8x16 wheels on the front.

This is basically what I have done on my '78 911SC. I have 8x16 944
Turbo Fuchs on the front with 225/45R16 tires and 9x16 Fuchs on the
rear with 245/45R16 tires. You do not have to roll fender lips.

By using the 944 Turbo offset, most of the increase in width is
toward the inside part of the car thus allowing the 8 inch rims.

Scott
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

Date: 17 May 1994 09:13:27 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Oops..T-Look tie rods

        Reply to:   Oops..T-Look tie rods

>> John Goodman <goodmjo@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
>> Also, a few digests back, someone asked about Turbo tie rods coming
>> standard on Turbo-look  911s.  I'm 99.999...% sure they didn't.

> The _factory_ turbo body option comes with a complete 930 body,
> including tie rods.

My apologies.  John was right.  I should have known better.  I compared
last night and the turbo-look tie rods are identical to the std Carrera.
I learned from Raman (ramans@microsoft.com) that this detail is
significant since SCCA Solo 2 (autocross) racers are allowed to use
any parts that came on any car from the SAME LINE (which is basically
all 911s, 65-89).  Turbo's are a different line.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo body targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date:     Tue, 17 May 1994 12:46 MST

------------------------------

Date: 17 May 94 14:15:31 EDT
From: Hubert Lai <70363.1332@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Bike/ski rack on a 944?

 > $50 Rhode Gear Rhode Rack (mounts on read of car)
 > $90 Rhode Gear deluxe bike rack (mounts on rear of car)
 > $150-$180 Yakima combination of towers, crossbars, etc.
 > (mounts on roof, good for skis too)

Hi Chris.  I have a Rhode Gear Euroshuttle.  It fits my 944 perfectly.  It holds
two bikes facing forward in a classic fork-mount position.  The bikes are very
stable.  I have used it with a variety of bikes and all of them have fit without
any problems.  (My current off-road mount is a 1993 Specialized M2 Team Issue
and my road bike is a 1984 Bianchi Record.)

The rack rests on the car on two cushioned supports which rest on the rear
bumper and on two cushioned supports which rest about two-thirds of the way up
the hatch.  The rack is attached to the car at six points with straps which have
rubber-coated hooks at the ends.  Two hook under the back of the rear bumper.
Two hook over the top edge of the hatch.  Two hook under the sides of the rear
bumper.

The first time I set the rack up and installed it on the car, it took about half
an hour.  However, after the first time, taking it off the car and putting it
back on only takes a few seconds.  It folds up flat and can be stored in a very
small space.

Hope all this is helpful.  If you want to get a permanently fixed roof rack
(which has the advantage of comparatively secure locking mechanisms. I recommend
Yakima, Thule, and Terzo.  The disadvantage with all of these is that the bikes
are mounted much higher, which is less aerodynamic, exposes your bikes to more
bug splatter, and prevents you from driving into garages and underground parking
lots.  It's also harder to lift a bike higher.  With the Euroshuttle, the bike
sits much lower, partially in the slipstream of the car itself, and I have no
trouble driving four levels down in my apartment building's garage.

If you have any further questions, just let me know.

 <=- Hubert
       '83 Gemini Grey Metallic 944


------------------------------

Date: 17 May 94 14:15:21 EDT
From: Hubert Lai <70363.1332@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Chrome vs Polish wheels

 > I'm torn between the maintenance
 > of keeping my wheels polish or
 > just rinsing and wiping down
 > chrome ones.

Why don't you have the wheels polished and then clear-coated?  My cookie cutters
have black centres but the rims have been polished to a very high sheen.  Both
the centres and the rims have been completely clear-coated and they look
fabulous.  I don't think they ever looked this good even when the car was brand
new.  To keep them looking that way, I just wipe them down with a sponge soaked
in soapy water and then rinse.

 <=- Hubert Lai
       '83 Gemini Grey Metalic 944

I had an '83 944 made in early 1982.  It had a 150 (or there abouts)
speedo.  A number of 944's came with 85mph speedos.  There ended up being a
lot of mysterious defects in some of the 85mph speedos.  My understanding
was that was the year that they switched back to the 150 speedos and some
cars got them and some didn't.

Date: Tue, 17 May 94 14:18:21 MST
From: john@sickbay.az05.bull.com (    John Jones [e])
Subject: Re: Theft Protection (Ben Evans)

There is a pyramid selling organisation here in the US selling something
similar. It may even be imaged as a "chip" but it is in fact simply a 
double sided printed circuit board plug mounted in a case each of the
contacts on the plug is attached to a length of wire. The key a piece of
PC board with a plastic encapsulated handle pushes in the plug mounted
on the dash. The PC board key completes eight circuits through the plug
allowing you to disable up to eight vital function of the car. Very low
tech despite the ads but could be very effective. Really depends on the smarts 
the person who installs it. Could be easy to defeat if only static voltages
are used but if some engine management functions were routed through it
it could be difficult to beat. Believe it's patented or applied for in England
(amazing what you can patent these days - I bet Einstein wouldn't have let them
by). But its easy to build your own. Of course the key can make any terminal 
to any terminal of the plug (lots of combinations).

They also make one for commercial vehicles where a barrel lock is used to
make the 60 amp circuits. I believe the car version is rated at 30 amps.

They were looking for garages/shops to install the kits at a terrific mark up.

So D I Y.

Date: Tue, 17 May 1994 12:23:34 -0700 (PDT)
From: LAFORCE@XENON.ARC.NASA.GOV
Subject: re: 1980 911sc speedo

I think it depends on when in the model year.

My '80 'sc has a 150 mph speedo.  I've seen an alledged '80 'sc
with an 85 mph speedo.  My girlfriends '81 'sc has an 85 mph speedo.

On the other hand, my car uses the fuel filter from an '81 but the 
correct ('80) warmup regulator.

I assume that when my car was built, they had run out of '80 fuel filters
and/or fittings but had not run out of '80 speedos.

Date: Tue, 17 May 94 18:18:37 EDT
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: Re: 915 Transmission

> Last June, I purchased my '86 911 w/10,700 miles, which came with the factory 
> used-car warranty.
> 
> I've had a fairly consistent problem with grinding/crunching while engaging 
> first or reverse gears while stopped.  I recently took it to the dealer where 
> I purchased it and had the service manager drive it with me in the car.  He did 
> not have the problem.

>From what I understand, the first gear synchro only works in one direction:
it only winds up the countershaft, it won't slow it down (or maybe the
other way around?). 
In other words: when the car is not moving, clutch
engaged, transmission in neutral, and you press the clutch pedal and
try to put it in first, the countershaft is still spinning (and therefore all 
the forward gears are too); it must come to a stop before engaging the
output shaft, which is stopped. The 1st gear synchro won't do this.
On the other hand, if the output shaft (and therefore the car) is moving
faster than the countershaft, the synchro will speed up the countershaft
to match the output shaft's speed.

Engage first when stopped by pressing gently on the shift lever.

Reverse gear doesn't have any synchros.

Can someone else confirm all this?

- --
``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````
Stefan Reitshamer      sreit@ctp.com       Cambridge Technology Partners, Inc.
"When in doubt, both feet out.             304 Vassar St., Cambridge, MA   USA
In a spin, both feet in."                  (617) 374 8371
``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````

impending family crisis. So the whole fleet is for sale... I'm not really

happen, I figure I'll at least be happier about it if I can sell
to my other "family".  Offers, intersting trades considered.

If you're serious about buying, shoot me a note and I'll fill in
the details. I have very good history on the two street cars,
and built the racer from the ground up so *really* know its story.
But then, you've been reading about them on this list for a while too...

All cars are in Houston. 

Here goes:

1981 Euro 911SC Targa, Grand Prix white with blue Op Art interior.
Super fast, tweaked for *streetable* performance. Lots of goodies.
$13,000.

1963 356SC. Ruby Red with black leatherette interior. Third owner.
*INTERESTING* history on this one. Fresh "Elmerized" engine, new
everything. Nearly rust-free. *GREAT* driver. "Birth certificate", 
all numbers match. Some spares, other 356 parts available.
$16,000.

1974 914 2.0 racer. Orange. Decals, numbers (SOWDIV 13ITA). 
Race car interior.  *COULD* be streetable, but would take work for that.
(It *IS* titled, licensed, and inspected for street use in Texas...)
Instead, it's the fastest 914 I've ever seen in SCCA Improved Touring.
(maybe Production, now that I think about it... For sure if  you ran slicks)
Over 150 HP. Best of everything. New everything (from wheel bearings up!).
I'll even tell you how I did it all.... Current log book. Haven't looked
where it fits in PCA Club Racing yet, but since you can embarrass 911s
in it, you'll probably be happy whereever it goes.... Spares come with it.
$10,000.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 May 1994 22:36:26 -0700 (PDT)
From: ero@netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: re: another 930

I paid $20,000 for my 78 930 with 76,000 mi. Since then I've invested 
about $4500 to repair a few things. I knew of the stuff it needed so 
there weren't too many surprises. $24,000 for a 78 w 42,000 mi. sounds 
good.I suggest you have a very thorough pre car inspection done, it could 
cost a few hundred bucks, but definitely worth it. I hear more horror 
stories about someone buying a low milage car only to find out the speedo 
had been disconnected for a while. A good mechanic should be able to tell 
if it really is a low milage car. A couple of things to check are the 
rear axles, brakes, tranny(i.e. grinding into 3rd.),and the turbo.Stan 
mentioned they need rebuilding every 30,000Mi. Make sure everything 
works, windshield washers, windows, ect., it may sound strange but it all 
adds up pretty quick. Also, the last major service. Despite the repairs 
I've had to do, I totally enjoy the car and would only trade it for a 
newer one, so much fun. Good luck!
ero@netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 10:54:00 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Engine running backwards


>We ought to get him together with a certain brain trust known to
>Porschephiles. Between them they can develop a 356 that pegs the tach and
>speedo, while going backwards, inhaling air, water vapor and carbon dioxide
>and producing high-octane fuel.

Where does the water and carbon dioxide come from when you're running 
backwards,.....other cars?? Or were you thinking of running this setup on a 
boxer engine, with a closed exhaust system, where the left cylinder bank 
would operate normally, spitting out exhaust gases that were inhaled by the 
right cylinder bank which miraculously produces premium grade fuel through 
the right set of carburettors? Recirculating the gasoline!?

Install another fuel pump to handle the produced gas, and off we go............

cheers,
trond

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 07:33:20 -0400
From: Steven John Timmins <timmins@strauss.udel.edu>
Subject: Re: SC vs. Carrera distributor

The gear on 


- ----- End Included Message -----

the CS crank is cut opposite //////   vs  \\\\\\\
that of the carrera and early cars.  


Rather than convert the carrera cranks to the SC gear, or putting in a
carrera distributor (and ascociated electronics) some people (like my
mechanic) put early (like with points ;(  distributors in their 3.4 ltr
conversions which use the 3.2ltr (carrera) cranks.

Apparently this also gets around the problem of using a SC distributor with 
carbs.


Steve
- ----- Begin Included Message -----


    All this talk about backward running engines reminds me of the
    distributor on the 911 SC.  I have been told that the SC
    distributor runs backwards (compared to the pre 78 and post 83
    cars).  Does anyone know why Porsche did this?  Also, how did they
    do it, did they merely put different gears on the crank and
    distributor?

    Thanks

    Steven Stomski




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 08:13:27 +0500
From: len1@sos.wh.att.com
Subject: 915 Transmission

David writes:

> Last June, I purchased my '86 911 w/10,700 miles, which came with the factory 
> used-car warranty.
> 
> I've had a fairly consistent problem with grinding/crunching while engaging 
> first or reverse gears while stopped.  I recently took it to the dealer where 
> I purchased it and had the service manager drive it with me in the car.  He did 
> not have the problem.
> 

From reading an old archive file on the 915 Transmission, I remember that it
said that it lacked a little part inside that actually brakes the spinning
countershaft inside the trans. As a result, if you engage 1st right after you
put the clutch in you will grind gears. You must engage clutch, wait about a
second for the shaft to stop spinning and then go into 1st gear.

Most other trans have this "brake" feature. Reverse gear has no synchro and
like most cars, you will have to wait until things slow down. THis is a common
feature of all cars.

Does anyone know whay Porsche left this out of their trans? Is it only on the
911 family of trans?  Were they trying to eliminate frictional losses and thus
extract the most from their drivetrains?

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len1@sos.wh.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo

------------------------------

Date:  Wed, 18 May 1994 09:19:06 -0400

Subject:  2.4"S" motor

From: STEVE STOMSKI at GSA-KA
Date: 5/17/94 10:40AM
To: /C=US/ADMD=TELEMAIL/PRMD=INTERNET/DT=RFC-822/DV=PORSCHEPHILES@TTA.COM at GSA-X400
To: STEVE STOMSKI
Subject: 2.4"S" motor
- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Thanks to those that responded to my original posting re my
    friend's 2.4 motor that is for sale.  I spoke with him yesterday
    and have some points to clarify: First of all, the injection has
    NOT been rebuilt.  This is a description as I understand it:

    New Mahle 2.4S pistons and cylinders
    New S cams
    New valve guides installed in heads
    Ported/flowed heads (S Specs)
    New valves
    New gasket set
    All new bearings
    New Carrera chain tensioner set
    New Turbo valve cover set (upper and lower)
    Fully counter-weighted/balanced crank
    Re-bushed rods
    Entire engine assembly balanced
    New Weber 40 IDAs (and manifolds)

    T case (no modifications)
    T injection
    Engine oil cooler
    Powder coated (black) sheet metal
    All other parts (shrouding, cam housing, etc.)

    The engine is currently apart and available in the Washington,
    D.C. area (I do travel to Massachusetts on occasion).

    For more information, or for putting in a bid, give me a call or
    post your name and number.

    Steven Stomski
    202.501.3771 (W)
    301.773.2185 (H)

Date: Wed, 18 May 94 14:42:37 CET		Message-Id: <AA20784>
From: tidbits@aviano.af.mil
Subject: Backwards Porsche Challenge

I think we may have something here. After all, technology has 
proceeded to the point where any number of highly qualified
engineers can wicker 356 engines to the point of near-theoretical
output. That's not hard any more. 

BUT getting an engine to run..backwards..successfully could be
more of a challenge!

So how about this: Maestro and Albrecht both tune their 356 
engines to run *backwards* to the best of their talents -- and 
then race to decide who can tune engines better? To give an 
international flair, I donate the use of "Mr. Jones' Driveway," 
a 20-meter mostly downhill mostly paved stretch, one hour from Venice,
Italy. Local cops don't mind if you exceed 15 kmph, just watch 
out for the wall at the end. Winner takes home the loser, or 
an inflatable sex toy -- his choice.

Entries must be postmarked no later than 1 April 1995.

Forza!

Pete Jones
Pordenone, Italy

Date: Wed, 18 May 94 08:43:11 -0400
From: "Bart Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Shop Recommendations 

SCHMIDT@LNS62.LNS.CORNELL.EDU querried about establishing a list of recommended 
shops to use or avoid.  Damn fine idea, IMHO.  Here's my offering:

In Annapolis, MD, there is on place like "Tri-Tech" for Porsche/Audi/BMW
ask for Barry Fisher or Jim Felsky (410) 224-4377.  Honest and competent, 
Reasonable prices.  They are the only folks I allow to touch my '86 911 or
my '87 Syncro.

Before I was directed to them, the local dealer told me I needed cv joints on 
all axles of my Syncro.  As I had not noticed anything unusual, I decided to 
defer the work for a month or so.  Shortly thereafter I was sent to TT and I 
asked them to do the cv joint work.  They told me I was being led down the 
proverbial garden path and my cv joints were fine.  I could go no, but you get 
the point...

Bart Chambers
bchambers@Atlantic.nos.noaa.gov
'86 911 Cabriolet
'87 Quantum Syncro (Quattro in Disguise)

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 06:28:26 -0700 (PDT)

>         Reply to:   85mph speedo's
> 
> > I have a 1980 911SC which I believe to have a stock speedo and it goes 
> > up to only 85.  I've been told that the law required speedometers to 
> > only go up to 85, in the USA that is.  Hope this helps.
> > Wane Joerding, 1980 911SC Weissach
> 
> That's the best argument I've seen for modifying an original Porsche.
> How can anyone live with an 85 mph speedo in a 911?  Are there
> really Porsche drivers out there that have never gone faster than that?
> Or do they just not care to know by how much they've exceeded the speed
> limit?
> 
> Lance. (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
> 
Rumour has it that several years ago, a maverick software co. founder was 
in court for his 2nd speeding ticket over 120mph in a Porsche in Santa Cruz 
county.  The judge asked him what kind of car he had, and he replied "a 
German car" to which the judge (a female) replied, "What kind of German 
car, Mr. Kahn?" to which he replied, "A Porsche." 

The judge then asked "Would you tell the court that you never exceed 
55mph in your Porsche?" He then looks at his lawyer, his lawyer is 
shaking his head, and he says nothing.  Judge suspends his license for 6 
months, he has to have a limo drive him to/from work.

There are some pretty other wild driving stories with this guy...

Ted

Date: Wed, 18 May 94 08:46:55 MST
From: john@sickbay.az05.bull.com (    John Jones [e])
Subject:  Theft Protection (Ben Evans)

The problem with disablers is that if they can't start the car they may trash
it. Not desirable! It also does not cope with the problem of car jacking
since this implies that you are with the car. The ideal solution is somthing
like lojack which activates a transmitter in the car when it is reported
stolen. The car can then be tracked with suitable equipment. The problem I have
with this is that as far as I know its a one off charge of approx $500. I think
this is a problem. Remember a few years ago lifetime membership at the health
clubs. Mad rush - no ongoing income - chapter 11. What gurantees the funding
of the ongoing maintenance. The alternative solution is a silent aarm which
when tripped will allow the car to be driven for a short while before disabling
the car and sounding the alarm. I suppose a manufacturer would have to consider
how to disable the car. They might get sued if they just cut the ignition and
an accident ensued. But with modern engine management system it should be
possible for them to make the car impossible to drive, certainly flee while 
still being safe. No one is going to hang around a crippled car with lights and
siren going.

Anyone know of such a device or adapted one of the currently marketed ones to
behave this way?

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 13:49:15 -0500
From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
Subject: Shocks for 914

Fellow Porschephiles,
I need to put new rear springs and 4 shock absorbers on my 1973 914 2.0
with factory sway bars. I want to preserve the stock ride "quality" (ha!). 
Three questions:
1) What shocks and springs preserve stock handling characteristics and are
good value for money?
2) What other suspension parts are convenient and necessary to replace at
the same time?
3) Do I need to release tension on the front torsion bars, as indicated in
the Haynes manual, to install the front shocks, or is there a simpler way?
4) Does a 914 with a more compliant suspension necessarily handle worse
than one with a stiffer suspension? 
Thanks in advance,  Michael

Date: Wed, 18 May 94 13:13:03 CDT
From: cork@cs.rice.edu (Corky Cartwright)
Subject: Re:  Porschephiles #750 Tue May 17 02:00:02 CDT 1994

Bart,

Have you considered buying lower profile front tires such as 
225/45-16 Dunlop SP8000's for the front?  Would the size reduction
be sufficient to permit lowering?  I recently switched
to Dunlop 225/45-16 SP 8000's on factory 7x16 rims on my '89 951 S.  The 
factory tire size is 225/50-16, but I prefer the stiffer sidewall
of the 45 series tires.  They presumably would work even better on 8x16 rims.

- -- Corky Cartwright


P.S.  As far as I know, D40/M2's are not available in size 225/45-16.  But
I like the SP8000 a bit better than the D40/M2 (my previous tires).

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 14:32:22 -0400 (EDT)
From: David Stroop <darist@freenet.columbus.oh.us>
Subject: Re: 915 Transmission 


914's do the same. Instead of waiting the couple of seconds before engaging
1st or reverse, I hold the shifter against a higher forward gear to stop
the spinning gears and then engage 1st or reverse. Faster and no clashing.


On Wed, 18 May 1994 len1@sos.wh.att.com wrote:

> David writes:
> 
> > Last June, I purchased my '86 911 w/10,700 miles, which came with the factory

> > first or reverse gears while stopped.  I recently took it to the dealer where 
> > I purchased it and had the service manager drive it with me in the car.  He did 
> > not have the problem.
> > 
> 
> >>From reading an old archive file on the 915 Transmission, I remember that it
> said that it lacked a little part inside that actually brakes the spinning
> countershaft inside the trans. As a result, if you engage 1st right after you
> put the clutch in you will grind gears. You must engage clutch, wait about a
> second for the shaft to stop spinning and then go into 1st gear.
> 
> Most other trans have this "brake" feature. Reverse gear has no synchro and
> like most cars, you will have to wait until things slow down. THis is a common
> feature of all cars.
> 
> Does anyone know whay Porsche left this out of their trans? Is it only on the
> 911 family of trans?  Were they trying to eliminate frictional losses and thus
> extract the most from their drivetrains?

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 11:30:18 +0800
From: Pete.Rado@Corp.Sun.COM (Pete Rado)
Subject: Re: Timer (DIY)

I've seen this in use as well.  The part that goes into your car, the IR receiver
and timer and multi-lap memory sells for about $169.  I don't know what the IR transmitter
sells for, but it seems that someone at the track always has a transmitter so that people
with the receivers can use their timer.  You only need one transmitter, since all it does
is transmit an IR beam that the receiver in your car picks up.  All the rest is in your
car.

I don't own one but a number of people in GGR do.

Pete

Date: Wed, 18 May 1994 15:25:22 -0700 (PDT)
From: stevew@tamri.com (Steve Watson)
Subject: No Headlights

Well I'm experiencing my first problem on the '73 S.  Last night when driving 
to my friends house I noticed that my right low beam went out.  Since the left
one was not working (sellers mechanic said that the he put a new left bulb in
and fuse is okay, so left one has a short somewhere) that means I had now 
low beams at all.  Parking lights and tail lights are okay, as well as
brake lights and back-ups.  Anyway, I tried the high beams (pushed turn signal
lever towards dash). No high beams either.  I checked the fuses in FUSE PANEL
#2 in trunk. FUSE 4, I think was open and FUSE 1-3 all looked weak.  So I replaced all 4 and voila, still nothing, now low or high beams.  I had to drive
home with my hand pulling back on the turn signal lever.  This lit the high 
beams so I know the bulbs aren't the culprit.

Any ideas where I should start to diagnose this problem?  Anyone know where 
I can get an electrical schematic for a '73 911S?

Thanks in advance for the help.  I'll be in Jamaica till 6/1.  Leaving tomorrow.

Steve
