Date: Wed, 18 May 94 20:21:00 EDT
From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
Subject: RE: Radar



>> Can anyone advise me on the practicality (and details, if practical)
>> of built-in Radar Detectors for use on my '86 911 Cabrio?  All wisdom
>> appreciated.  Thanks
>>

I have had a Whistler remote in my '88 944 since new. The remote unit is 
mounted near the air intake behind the front spoiler and there is a small 
unit you can put anywhere inside the car. The two are connected by a cable, 
but newer ones are wireless. It works very well and involves no cigarette 
lighter wires and is not visible because it is not in the windshield.

Peter
ptracy@keps.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 May 94 22:08 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Intake manifold-Vacuum Line fitting

If this hose is the soft rubber one I think it is, then the problem
is that it tends to harden with age and heat, and swell from oil
breathed on it from the manifold.  Replace it and you should be all
set.  If you're really fussy, put a baby tie-wrap around it.

You can spend $2-3 a pop for each of the little rubber elbows from
Porsche, or you can buy a foot or two of generic hose from the corner
autoparts store and cut to fit.  I haven't been able to find generic
"Y" fittings, which are about $5.80 from Porsche.

Kevin

Porschephiles #753                         Fri May 20 02:29:44 CDT 1994
Date: Thu, 19 May 1994 00:13:13 -40962758 (CDT)
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Shocks for 914

> I need to put new rear springs and 4 shock absorbers on my 1973 914 2.0
> with factory sway bars. I want to preserve the stock ride "quality" (ha!). 

Good goal.

> 1) What shocks and springs preserve stock handling characteristics and are
> good value for money?

If all you want is stock, then by damn, the *RIGHT* answer is simple:
buy stock parts! However, if you're looking at the plethora of aftermarket
parts, this may be daunting. First things first: call your local dealer,
or Carlsen in Palo Alto (which I think gives PCA and *maybe* porschephiles
discounts -- reality check on that please?) and get prices for stock 
springs. That's an 85 lb spring, btw... Then shop around. If you want a
stock or near stock ride, *DO NOT* get any of the 100-140-180 lbs 
"performance" springs.

There is another very good alternative: Troutman makes a 165 lb progressive
spring. At low excursion, it's about a 90 lb spring. At high excursion, it's
a 165 lb spring. There is of course a linear transition between the two. 
For a street car that gets "spirited" street driving, some autox, etc. it's
just about perfect. 

> 2) What other suspension parts are convenient and necessary to replace at
> the same time?

Consider shocks. If you want a stock ride, there's no substitute for Boge.
If you want improved performance, things start getting better at KYB (which
is usually cheaper than Boge, BTW) and go up through Koni, Bilistein, and
end up at Koni sport yellows... each with progressively "worse" ride.

Also consider new front torsion bars. I highly recommend that for street
cars you stick with the stock diameter. There's just no percentage in 
getting bigger, since any change has a BIG impact -- positive in terms of
handling at the limit, negative in terms of ride quality. (torsion bars
get stiffer as the 4th power of the diameter...)

Finally, consider new tires. Nothing like a fresh set of Yoko 509s or
AVS Intermediate to make your car feel and drive like new... 185/75x15 for
a softer ride, 195/50x15 for the best in performance.

> 3) Do I need to release tension on the front torsion bars, as indicated in
> the Haynes manual, to install the front shocks, or is there a simpler way?

First off, it's not that big of a deal to release the tension. Second, I
usually find that I don't need to do that -- just separate the strut from
the ball joint (NOTE: if you use the little "fork" looking ball joint
seperator, you *WILL* need to replace the ball joint. Take a big screwdriver
and insert it in the "split" at the bottom of the strut, and widen that
until the strut slips off. Don't beat on it, or you may bend the strut 
housing...).

> 4) Does a 914 with a more compliant suspension necessarily handle worse
> than one with a stiffer suspension? 

Yes. Period. But it may not matter if you're not pushing the limits of
the car. Just doing street driving, it's pretty much OK as is. Going to
say KYBs and the Troutman springs will put you in a *VERY* satisfactory
position.

Stan

Date: Thu, 19 May 94 09:02:19 EDT
From: keast@burt.ll.mit.edu (Craig L. Keast)
Subject: Resolution of 944 Right-Rear "Whirring"


Just a short posting to close the loop on and to thank the people who helped 
with this issue.  The "right-rear whirring" was indeed the wheel bearings.  
Once the right tools were collected:
              1) 36mm socket (wheel nut)
	      2) 8mm 12pt. serrated wrench (half-shaft bolts)
              3) Heavy-duty snap-ring pliers (inner bearing retaining clip)

and the parts:
              1) Inner bearing                 $13
              2) Outer bearing and inner race  $30
              3) Inner seal                    $ 2

The job was straight forward.

An interesting side note is that I did not realize that the car had adjustable
Koni shocks...they were on the softest setting.  I set them to their stiffest
setting... makes a VERY noticeable difference.


- ----- Begin Included Message ------
|
| Over the last couple of weeks the right-rear-wheel of my 1983 944 (87k miles)
| has developed a "whirring" sound.  The sound has been getting louder as time
| progresses.  The sound is most evident at highway speeds but it is 
| also present
| at slower speeds.  If I place a lateral load on the right-rear-wheel, by
| turning the car to the left, the sound disappears until the car returns
| to straight line travel at which time the whirring returns.  If I turn to
| the right the sound does not disappear.  In addition, if the suspension
| gets compressed (going over a bump) the whirring also disappears briefly.
|
| This is not the "click-click-click" sound that I have heard when I have
| had CV joints fail on other cars.  It could be a bad wheel bearing, but
| the sound is "smoother" that bad wheel bearing sounds that I have heard
| before.  As a last bit of info, the tires were replaced at 75k miles.

- ----- End Included Message -----

Date: Thu, 19 May 1994 08:54:38 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: Impact Wrench Torque Limiters


Shop Types:

Tire shops are beginning to use a new device for tightening lug nuts with
an impact wrench.  The devices are color coded, about 8 inches long, with
a socket on one end and a square fitting for the impact wrench on the other.
The shaft diameter scales with the torque rating.

I have the following questions for any experts out there:

1.  What is the physical principle governing their operation?
2.  How reliable/accurate are they?
3.  What precautions are needed in their use?

Thanks,
John		'89 944
		Houston, TX

Date: 19 May 94 12:15:37 GMT
From: mvmas@mvusa.att.com
Subject: re: Headlights

Speaking of headlights, this info may save 914 people some time or traffic
citations.  Of the 2 914's I've had (in the salty northeast) the screws
for the headlight retaining ring have rusted and are so small (phillips)
and soft that I've stripped them all trying to get the ring off to change
the headlights.

This weekend, while putting in some halogens I've had lying around, of
course it got really involved.  I suggest, before you need to change a
bulb, to put in some more reasonable hardware to hold the retaining ring.
What I had to do was back out both adjusting screws, and remove the spring,
which allowed the whole assembly to come out (oh yeah, first take off the
plastic surround).  Then with a dremel tool, grind off the heads of the
3 screws holding the retaining ring.  Remove the retaining ring and the
headlight.  Now you can grind the screws a little more, apply some penetrant,
and back them out by grabbing the threads with vice grips.  I found in my
box of old porsche hardware, some screws of the same thread, but with a
larger head for a flat blade screw driver.

Mark A. Skala
mvmas@mvusa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: 19 May 1994 09:10:55 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>

North Hollywood Speedometer, 6111 Lankershim Blvd,
North Hollywood, CA 91606 (818-761-5136).  They are silkscreen,
not decals, and come in different of colors and logos.  I have
had no experience with them or this company but I'm sure you can
get advice from them.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo look targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Subject: HELP!  Removal of 911 Front Fender

Hello!

I have to remove the front left fender on my '75 911 to properly repair some 
minor rust.  The glue holding the rubber seal let go and let some water get down to
where it's not supposed to go!  I think this was the result of using a two-piece
bra so...  if you use one, check the rubber seal!

To the point:

1.  I have everything loose and the fender is moving around nicely.  However, it 
seems to be spot welded up near the top of the door jamb.  Two questions:  a) why?
and b)  how do I properly undo/redo this spot weld?  (note:  I have cut-offs/
grinders/welders/etc.  I'm looking for some advice from someone who's done it.)

2.  I noticed that Wueth has some zinc paint and some primer w/ zinc.  Should I
use both when doing the paint repair?  What's the net's opinion on these products?

3.  What is the caulking-like substance between the fender and body and where can
I get that stuff for the reassembly?

4.  What about the nice, heavy undercoating that's over everything?  What is it, 
where can I find it, and what's a good way to apply small amounts of it?

Thanks for the help!  Oh, just curious...  Are the fenders still bolt-on for the
new 993?  I didn't notice when I went to the dealer last month.  I was more
interested in the test drive of the new Cabriolet they had!  What a car!  Va-room!

Date: Thu, 19 May 94 11:50:00 PDT
From: "Dayton, Mike" <DAYTONM@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: SC Distributor Rotation

>All this talk about backward running engines reminds me of the
    distributor on the 911 SC.  I have been told that the SC
    distributor runs backwards (compared to the pre 78 and post 83
    cars).  Does anyone know why Porsche did this?  Also, how did they
    do it, did they merely put different gears on the crank and
    distributor?

================================================================

The story I heard, and forgive me for the sketchy details, is that the gear 
that drives the distributor on pre-'78 cars was one of the last vestiges of
"VW" parts in a 911.  I think someone at the factory decided that that
just wouldn't do, and so the distributors were changed for the SCs.  If I
remember the *story* correctly, someone at the factory was asked about
the validity of this and they hemmed and hawed and scraped the carpet
with the toe of their shoe, but didn't really deny it.

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911

Date: 19 May 94 12:48:44 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: 85 mph speedos

If I remember correctly, the 85 mph speedometer was mandated by Congress,
yes, to reduce speeding because people wouldn't be encouraged to "see what
she'll do."
 
Also, if I remember, the bill that required this was sponsored by Ted
Kennedy. You know, the Ted Kennedy who can't tell which of the three bridges
he sees before him is the real one, and picks wrong. Ted Kennedy,
the Chappaquiddick Kid, is telling us how to drive.

Pete

Date: Thu, 19 May 94 13:30:25 EDT
From: Doug Boyce <dboyce@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: 944 problem

Howdy!

The car is an '87 944 with 50k miles.  Engine is in excellent
condition.

Here's the problem:
With the engine running at mid to upper rpms, take your foot
of the gas, as the engine returns to idle it will often drop down to a
few hundred rpms before it comes back to normal idle.  This is very
noticable with the a/c compressor running.

Some of you may recognize this as a symptom of running a little too
rich.

Here's what I've done so far:

 -Checked for intake leaks.
 -Unplugged and checked lamda sensor--didn't help the problem but it
runs a little better unplugged.
 -Checked engine temp and intake air sensors.
 -Checked idle speed control.
 -Checked speed and reference mark sensors.

Everything looks ok.  I have no clue how to check the air flow sensor
proper, but I did follow the short test procedure from the shop manual
and it checked out.

Thanks,

Doug b.
- --

Date: Thu, 19 May 94 15:48:40 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: 356 shopping-update

     Well, my colleague did not buy the car ('65 356 SC) so it's
now mine.  I've been driving it for about a week, showing it to
some PCA folks, and gathering opinions on everything from
possible bad carrier bearings to interior color schemes.  It
drives fine - it's a lot of fun.  I guess the rear shock valves
are frozen up as the rear suspension is *VERY* stiff.  While the
paint, interior, rubber, and chrome are all shot, the only
broken/non-functional item I've found is the day/night lever on
the RV mirror.  Interior chrome is OK.  A friend (Wayne Baker)
put it on a lift and all looked solid, but dirty (his cars are
beautiful!)

     I've resolved to collect opinions/prices for at least a
month before starting anything significant.

- --   Bob  --   '83 $C, '65 $C
^Z

Date: Thu, 19 May 1994 11:04:40 +0800
From: Pete.Rado@Corp.Sun.COM (Pete Rado)
Subject: Re: Intake manifold-Vacuum Line fitting


re: vacuum fitting in manifold.


Many years ago I had this problem with a Saab Turbo.  The mechanic,
who had access to a machine shop, knurled the part of the fitting
that fits into the manifold, to increase the radius.  Then he used
loctite and pressed the fitting into the manifold.  I kept the car
for 3 years after that and never had a problem.

Pete

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: 20 May 94 01:28:08 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Helmuth Bott, 1925-1994

The German news wires just carried an item announcing that Helmuth Bott,
former chief of Porsche's Weissach R&D facility, has passed away at the age
of 68 after a short illness.
 
Helmuth Bott was one of the handful of people who made Porsche what it is
today. Most of the things we as Porschephiles enjoy in today's 911, 968
and 928 were developed while he was chief engineer at Weissach. Herr Bott
joined the company in 1952, after brief jobs with Daimler-Benz and Bosch,
and retired just a few years ago. His first major project was development of
the suspension for the 356 A, worked on the team that made the 917 (among
many other projects in a long career), and was chief engineer from 1971 (?)
until his retirement. Any Porsche you can think of, whether road or race car,
was influenced by Helmuth Bott and a very small handful of others.
 
I had the privilege of working at Weissach during a few of the Bott years,
and can honestly say that he was a great engineer and a very
approachable human being. Any employee at Weissach could go into his office
to talk shop. Even in retirement, he continued with the work he
loved most, as a consulting engineer and designer. He'll be missed. When you
drive your Porsche today, remember the man who led the engineering team that
brought you this most excellent of machines.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 May 94 08:02:59 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Engines running backwards

Two strokes (yes), four strokes (no).  Many years ago, I picked up a new
Bultaco (two stroke) motorcycle in Barcelona.  It was sputtering and
popping at idle as two strokes do.  Half an hour later in rush hour
traffic, it eased backwards when I let out the clutch at a stop light.
Light flywheel and a single backfire could reverse its direction.

In a Porsche, you have to alter the differential to reverse its direction.
The VW bus needed this alteration because of the reduction gears at the
wheels.  You also have to make the change for a Corvair Engine (backwards).

Rick  ......  too wet today to drive a fun car :-(

Subject: Police Radar

Hi Group,

An article in my local paper says troopers will replace their HAWK radars with
KA band radars "which don't set off most detectors," and while the HAWK can
detect speed heading away or toward the trooper the new system "can not detect
speed of motorists traveling in the same direction."

Does anyone know what the KA band radar is and why it won't "set off most
detectors." According to the article the new radar costs $2,050 per unit
compared with $2,600 for the HAWK.

Are they talking about the "instant on" or the laser radar? The article isn't
very clear and doesn't give much information.

 -Ed-

Date:  Fri, 20 May 1994 08:56:00 -0400 
From: "eddie (j.e.) hunnell" <hunnell@bnr.ca>
Subject:  re:Impact Wrench Torque Limiters 

In message "Impact Wrench Torque Limiters", you write:

> 
> Shop Types:
> 
> Tire shops are beginning to use a new device for tightening lug nuts with
> an impact wrench.  The devices are color coded, about 8 inches long, with
> a socket on one end and a square fitting for the impact wrench on the other.
> The shaft diameter scales with the torque rating.
> 
> I have the following questions for any experts out there:
> 
> 1.  What is the physical principle governing their operation?
> 2.  How reliable/accurate are they?
> 3.  What precautions are needed in their use?
> 
> Thanks,
> John		'89 944
> 		Houston, TX
>                               

I spoke to the local Snap-on dealer a few weeks ago about these.
He told me that the are calibrated to flex (twist) at the
specific torque that each one is rated at when used with an impact
wrench. He said that they were very accurate, but I don't know
from personal experience. Hope this helps

Eddie Hunnell
hunnell@bnr.ca

Date:         Fri, 20 May 94 11:22:44 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      944S: Tie Rod

Well, I got a second opinion on my tie rod situation.
This second place told me the same thing, the alignment
wouldn't hold because the right (inner) tie rod (the end
under the rubber boot) was worn.  So, off to the dealer
for a new tie rod ($114).  They told me the right side
wears faster because a majority of the potholes, etc. are
on that side.

Darren
'87 944S

Date: Fri, 20 May 94 12:32:48 EDT
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Largest tires for 951 on 7" and 8"

Steve,
  I have run both the stock 205/55ZR16 / 225/50ZR16 as well as the 
225/50, 245/45 combination. While you will notice the extra grip, of course,
you will also find that turn-in is a little slower with wider tires. Also, on
the street, there is much more tendency for the wider rubber to "track"
longitudinal pavement irregularities (here in Vermont there are lots of
"widened" two lane roads where the right wheels run along the seam of the old
and new pavement). Nonetheless, everyone I see at the track seems to run the
wider widths. A friend suggested over the winter trying a bit more toe-in
with the wider rubber, but I haven't tried this yet.

The 225s on the front 7" rims do seem to be the maximum width advisable on
that narrow a wheel (I don't know if a wider wheel will work at the stock
offset). At the rear, I think that wider than 245 will require rolling the
inner fender lip for clearance.

Regards,
  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic

Date: 20 May 1994 10:42:25 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Porsche Insurance

        Reply to:   Porsche Insurance

> From: JonLowe@aol.com
> 2.  Does anyone have experience with Leland West Ins. Brokers who advertise
> in Panorama? They advertise for limited use Porsches which fits us.

I have had experience with Leland West.  Their prices are very good if
you fit their catagories in terms of mileage, home ownership, 2nd
car, etc.  The best thing about Leland West is that you declare the car's
value.  They also speak our language, which is nice.

It turns out I didn't use them because I found another very good policy
with Liberty Mutual, and when I insured all 3 cars and the house I was
better off.  But I was very impressed with Leland West and their rates.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo look, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Fri, 20 May 1994 10:44:22 -700 (MDT)
From: Jim Conforti <jec@us.dynix.com>
Subject: Re: Police Radar


Ok .. for all of us fast drivers ;)

There are three bands (microwave freq. ranges) allowed for by the FCC

	X-Band	10.x Ghz

	K-Band  20 something Ghz

	Ka-Band 30 something Ghz ..

The INTERESTING thing about Ka .. is that the FCC authorized a WIDE
area around 34 Ghz or so for use by police radar .. hence guns came out
that try a new frequency every time the trigger is pulled .. aka 
WIDEBAND Ka .. aka THE STALKER .. 

To detect this, you need a wideband Ka detector .. a simple photo-radar
capable detector will NOT do !!

BELtronics, Escort, and Valentine Research (among others) all make 
good wideband KA detectors .. 

Jim Conforti
<jec@us.dynix.com>


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 May 1994 13:22:31 -0400
From: al774@FreeNet.Carleton.CA (Michael Gaskin)
Subject: Re: List of Shops

>

I hate to be negative but....

I normally do my own work on my 73 2.0L 914 but sometimes you just gotta
take it in.  Late last summer I had finally finished rebuilding the top
end of the engine and was having a cut-out problem that I couldn't solve. 
The engine would run fine sometimes and then run extremely rich or
extremely lean for no apparant reason and then cut out altogether.  I
must have checked grounds, timing, fuel and spark a dozen times.

To make a long story even longer, the last test drive we went out on we
stalled and no amount of jiggling could get her going again.  I lost my
patients at that point and had the car towed to the Porsche dealer.  While
finding an extra car in your service lot with no warning may not be
polite, once the paper work is done all should be cool.

I found the mechanic who worked on my car to be knowlegeable and friendly,
even informative.  The problem turned out to be a $35 cylinder head
temperature sensor (I'm sure some of you have already guessed this).  Turns
out taking the car in was the right decision since I don't have the test
equipment for this kind of trouble shooting or enough know how regarding
the FI system.  The car runs great now with the exception of a little
backfiring/burbling on deceleration.   This little tune up cost me 600
bucks!  Maybe thats' reasonable?

What really bugged me is that it took 3.5 weeks for them to fix the car! 
By the time I got it back it was time to put it away for the winter. 
These guys said they had the car in and out of the garage several time. 
Can't say as I believed them because every time I checked it was in
exactly the same spot.?

Anyhow, if you're ever in Ottawa Canada and you have trouble with your
Porsche or Audi I'd recommend you avoid :

		Mark Motors of Ottawa (1987) Ltd.
		611 Montreal Rd.
 Unfortunately they are the only "authorized" dealer in town.


For what it's worth.

Having much more fun this year.

- --
Mike Gaskin 		        /\              al774@FreeNet.Carleton.CA

An article in my local paper says troopers will replace their HAWK radars with

>ED, The Newer Models, such as the Passport 4500 (Which I have) are very capable
of detecting the newer K and Ka bands(also Laser) now being used. The reason 
your article say's "Don't set of most detectors" is because most are older 
models (It's kind of keeping keeping up with technology thing)also you will note
the "High Tech" models are of course more expensive. Bob in S.J.

 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 May 94 17:50 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 944S: Tie Rod, coolant

1. You need not have replace the whole tie rod.  The end (ball joint)
is separately available, p/n 944.347.333.04.

2. Use a phosphate-free anti-freeze, available from VW/Audi (Autobahn
label), M-B, or at least one of the Swedish car makers.  There's also
this new Sierra stuff, the merits of which I don't know.   Also be
sure to drain from the block as well as the radiator.  You'll need
a new seal ring for the block drain, and you ought to replace the
seal ring at the bleeder as well.

Kevin

> better off.  But I was very impressed with Leland West and their rates.
> 
> Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
> 88 factory turbo look, 89 coupe, 85 535i
> 
I'd be curious if anyone finds a "Big I Independent" broker who knows of 
a company they can use to insure Porsches.  Last time I checked, my big I 
agent said none of their companies handle them, although they usually 
have best prices for non P-cars with Mercury, Safeco, etc. with my 
previous BMW and Hondas.

Ted

cop's Eagle got you at.  It would be nice to see when a cop decided to

On Fri, 20 May 1994, Jim Conforti wrote:

> 
> Ok .. for all of us fast drivers ;)
> 
> There are three bands (microwave freq. ranges) allowed for by the FCC
> 
> 	X-Band	10.x Ghz
> 
> 	K-Band  20 something Ghz
> 
> 	Ka-Band 30 something Ghz ..
> 
> The INTERESTING thing about Ka .. is that the FCC authorized a WIDE
> area around 34 Ghz or so for use by police radar .. hence guns came out
> that try a new frequency every time the trigger is pulled .. aka 
> WIDEBAND Ka .. aka THE STALKER .. 
> 
> To detect this, you need a wideband Ka detector .. a simple photo-radar
> capable detector will NOT do !!
> 
> BELtronics, Escort, and Valentine Research (among others) all make 
> good wideband KA detectors .. 
> 
> Jim Conforti
> <jec@us.dynix.com>
> 
> 

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 21 May 1994 09:05:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Matsumura <tedm@rahul.net>
Subject: Re: shop list

For places to avoid in the bay area for smogging, I'd recommend staying 
away from the Quality Tune Up on El Camino and San Antonio in Mtn. View.  

3 weeks ago, I took my girlfriend's Tercel and my '77 911 there for smog 
checks.  The guy took a look at my engine and said "that ain't gonna pass"

I then slapped the smog belt on, and said "try it now, it's my $20.00", 
and he said "it still ain't gonna pass" so I kept my $20.

A half hour later the guy comes back to where we're sitting and smiles 
"The Toyota failed too"  We left, I cleaned the carb, got a new air 
filter for the '87 Tercel, and took it back the next week, the re-check 
is free.  It failed again.  I then took it last week, a mile down the 
street to AccuTune on Miramonte (Shoreline) and El Camino and left it 
there for a check, tune-up, check, and then air conditioning. 

The first check failed, but with much better numbers than Quality's tune 
up, though a week of time and some driving was in between the tests.  
After their tune up, it passed easily.  Whole price was $180, about $50 
for tune up, $30 for smog, and $100 for 2lb. of freon.  I'll probably 
take my 911 there too.

Bottom line is that this whole Calif. smog check and supposed calibration 
is a lot of horse shit.  I'd love to take some time, and drive down El 
Camino from San Francisco to San Jose and measure the discrepanicies in 
all of these fucked up smog certifer's equipment.  What a crock.

Ted

Date: Sat, 21 May 1994 11:54:16 -0400
From: William Taylor <wet3@pipeline.com>
Subject: Help with C2 alignment 

Does anyone have the factory specs for the 93 C2 alignment 
numbers. I need the camber,caster, and toe. I brought my C2 in 
for alignment and the shop had a brand new Hunter setup. When 
they put my car up they could not get more than -.5 camber on 
the back wheels. The Hunter specs had a range of -.82 to -.5 
for the back. (I was trying for -1.0 for autocross). The Hunter 
specs on the front were -.17 to .17. Also I had a problem with 
the front caster. The Hunter specs called for 4.17 to 4.67 and 
the shop could only get 3.4. I suspect either the Hunter specs 
are wrong for my 93 C2 or the equipment is out of adjustment. 
The spec that is listed on the Hunter equipment lists the 89-92 
C2 & C4 as having the same numbers. Could this be true. Thanks 
for you help.

Porschephiles #756                         Mon May 23 02:35:56 CDT 1994
Date: Sat, 21 May 1994 23:46:55 -700 (MDT)
From: Jim Conforti <jec@us.dynix.com>
Subject: Re: Police Radar


Just an FYI ..

What you describe (EAGLE) is known as instant-on radar ...

First developed as K band .. then backdated to the X band, and now in Ka ..

You detect IT when he pings the guy in front of you a mile or so ..

Jim



------------------------------

Date: 22 May 94 11:23:11 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: What's a Speedster?

Hi, Ted.

>Read about the Eagle in the Automobile magazine with 
>Seinfield.  BTW, it mentions he has late model "Speedsters".  What are 
>these?  I thought Speedsters were another name for 356?
 
There were three different types of Speedsters, not counting plastic fakes.
The first was on the 356 body, a basic no-frills car with minimalist
interior and cut-down windshield. It was built concurrently with the 356
Cabriolet, which has a taller windshield and more substantial interior
equipment. The 356 Speedster evolved into the Convertible D with more
equipment, and then the Roadster. Note that many people call all open 356s
"Speedsters" but that isn't right. Speedsters are special models and are
more desirable. You need to go to Speedsterfest; BIll Oldham wrote

>The 1994 SPEEDSTERFEST will again take place
>at Cal State Hayward on Sunday, June 19, 1994.



Next there was the 1989 Speedster, built with a 911 body. It also had a
cut-down windshield, and used the "wide body" 911 Turbo body pieces.
 
The latest is the 1994 Speedster, with a narrow body. It's the cheapest way
to get an open 911. There are no plans yet to make it in the new 993 body
style.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: 22 May 94 11:23:32 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Smog check scam

Hi, Ted.

>Bottom line is that this whole Calif. smog check and supposed calibration 
>is a lot of horse shit.  I'd love to take some time, and drive down El 
>Camino from San Francisco to San Jose and measure the discrepanicies in 
>all of these fucked up smog certifer's equipment.  What a crock.
 
You don't have to live here long to figure out that the California smog check is 
just a way to forcibly transfer money from your wallet to the station doing the
check. Yes, it's a crock. If you ever saw what car companies have to go
through in terms of high-class measuring equipment to get realistic
emissions numbers, you'll realize that the toys used by gas stations are
nothing more than random number generators.
 
I've had the same idea -- go up and down the coast to have stations check a
car which has previously been proven to pass -- using EPA (not California
CARB) certified laboratory equipment.
 
The entire biennial smog check is a crock. If your car doesn't pass, you can
still drive it by proving that repair will cost more than a certain amount,
I forgot what, let's say $300. Any valve or ring job is going to cost more
than that, even a custom-fit catalyst will be more, so basically all the
gross polluters continue grossly polluting, after paying off the station to
the tune of $300. The system feels this is OK because you've done your
penance, and another 300 of your dollars have gone to feed the economic
recovery or whatever. The gas station stays in business a while longer, 
but the air doesn't get any less browner.
 
A friend had a problem with a Jaguar XJ-6. Too high HC. I told him before he
went in that his catalyst was probably shot, with it the oxygen sensor, and
he might need a valve job. We figured we'd try a "pass or don't pay" Arco
station first. Of course it didn't pass. We managed to keep the
semi-literate former cabbie-type from dicking with the injection system.
(How they read shop manuals is beyond me; far as I know they're only written
in English). After failing, he did offer to "feex" for ninety dallah. Right.
Valve job and cat for ninety dallah. No, thanks.
 
He had a burned valve and it cost nearly $1000 at a Jaguar independent.
 
This whole thing raises an interesting vision of life under the Clinton health
care plan -- will smog station operators be able to upgrade their
certification to do surgery on humans? <g>

Another interesting ripoff -- if you move to California from out of state, 
you have to pay a one-time fee, I think $300 or so, billed as some sort
of "non-California vehicle compliance tax" or something. They bill this
on ALL late model (post-1965 I think) vehicles reregistered in CA, even 
if there were no California-specific versions of that vehicle (i.e. all 
50-state cars were identical). It's a ripoff, just another way to raise 
revenue. California is using for every underhanded trick it can think 
of right now to raise cash. They've lost the military contractors, they're 
chasing other jobs out of state, and the old Proposition 13 (remember 
that?) keeps them from sticking it to us in the form of uncontrolled 
property tax increases. So they have to get it somewhere to pay for 
all those bureaucrats. 

Traffic tickets are just another small way to raise cash. Now you
not only pay the ticket, but there are added "fees" associated with
the thing. And Billary wants to put Xthousand more cops on the
street -- all doing what? Arresting criminals or writing tickets to
pay their salaries? You guess which...

We're not going to see this smog check system go away soon because 
there are too many bureaucratic parasites who survive on our money by
pulling these scams.
 
Pete

Date: 22 May 94 15:03:41 EDT
From: Jeff Karandjeff <70534.2357@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Scotland Yard 968

Thought you guys might get a kick out of this:

=========================================================
U.K. News Clips

RTw  05/22 0926  LONDON POLICE TRY OUT PORSCHE PURSUIT CAR

    LONDON, May 22 (Reuter) - London police, fed up with being
forced to eat the dust of criminals in high-speed cars, said on
Sunday they were trying out a Porsche pursuit car.
     "We are conducting an evaluation of high-performance cars,
including a Porsche, and their role in preventative policing of
motorways," said a Scotland Yard spokesman.
     The Porsche 968 -- top speed 156 miles per hour (250 km/h) --
is to be unveiled at a Scotland Yard-Porsche news conference this
week but the Yard spokesman denied newspaper reports the police had
decided to buy the 30,000 pound ($45,300) cars.
     Despite question marks over the safety of high-speed pursuit,
British police have complained their relatively modest patrol cars
are being outrun by car thieves and so-called "ram raiders" who use
stolen cars to crash through shop windows.


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 May 94 12:21:18 PDT
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: early ignition parts

Mike Dayton writes:

> The story I heard ...  is that the gear that drives the distributor on
> pre-'78 cars was one of the last vestiges of "VW" parts in a 911.  I
> think someone at the factory decided that that just wouldn't do, and so
> the distributors were changed for the SCs.

My 71 911E seems to be able to use the same distributor parts as some 
914s and possible VWs of the same vintage. It is not necessary to buy
the $20+ rev-limiting rotor that is the official part, you can get a
~$6 rotor that is listed for I think 914s. The ignition points are also
the same as those listed for some of the poorer cousins.
If anyone knows of a good book for this type of info, e.g. cross-references
(Bosch parts catalog?) and how to get it, please post & mail me the details.

Also a few parts books list only platinum spark plugs as the replacement
part for this car  (youch - super expensive). Bosch copper W5DCs ($2 apiece)
work ok, although I'm about to try a step hotter - W7DC. The local
mechanic told me to run premium and listen for pinging if I do this.

 -Mitch Craig

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 8:20:12 EDT
From: Brian Abernathy <cba@atl.hp.com>
Subject: 914 steering column question

Thanks to the advice from members of the list, I was able to pull the 
steering wheel off my '74 914 this weekend.  It took a 27mm socket, plus
several blows to the lug wrench with a rubber mallet, but, once loosened,
the wheel came off without any problem.

Next, I wanted to take off the turn signal switch, wiper control, and finally
get down to the "guts" of the ignition switch, but here is the problem:
The wires to the turn signal switch are too short to just remove from the
steering column shank.  They appear to be permanently attached to the
switch, but I may be wrong about that- it was hot in the car, and there were
a couple of wasps buzzing around.

How difficult is it to remove the switches?  Can I repair the turn 
signal cancel without replacing the switch?  (It appears that the small
plastic nub that cancels the signal has the end broken)

- --

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 08:11:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sorin Grama <soring@tigua.natinst.com>
Subject: car won't start


Hello, fellow porschephiles!

Well, I've run into my first problem with my 85.5 944... The beast just
wouldn't start last night.  It's one of those classic "no start" symptoms,
but I wanted to check the net wisdom before I proceeded with a fix. 

Here's what happened.  The engine won't turn at all.  I can hear the relay
clicking and a hissing sound which I suppose comes from the injectors. 
That's it!  But here's another thing that might help you narrow the pool
of possible defects.  While waiting for a AAA towing truck last night (of
course, the car died while away from home just to prove Murphy's law
correct) I was able to start the car by pushing it and popping the clutch
in 2nd gear.  Of course, you might say, it's the battery, you dummy!  No
it's not! The battery it's about a month old and I did try to jump start
it from another battery with no luck.  At this point I think it's the
starter or the ignition switch. 

The car just died all of a sudden without any warnings after I 
attempted to vacuum some leaves underneath the hood (near the fuse box).  
I was pretty careful not to knock any wires, but maybe that's what 
happened.  Do you have any ideas/suggestions as to what to look for?  
My feeling is that I have some loose wiring.  Where/how should I check?  
It was too dark and late last night so I didn't have time to look 
around the engine too much.  I don't even know where the starter 
is located.
Any suggestions are appreciated.  I will keep you posted as to 
what the problem was.

Thanks a bunch,
Sorin

85.5 944



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 08:51:28 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; engine running backwards


      The first time I put my 911 engine back together, it ran backwards.
     Thank god for the pop-valve on the CIS box--before I started the 
     car I did a compression check---and only got 90 psi. "Rings and all
     probably need to seat, don't worry about it" said my mentor. So I 
     primed it, turned the key, and BBBBBBRRRRRRRAAAAAAAAAAPPPPP, a horrible
     sound. Looked everything over, re-primed, tried 
     again....BBBBBRRRRAAAAAPP. Finally I went thru an exercise...turning the
     motor over slowly and watching; piston goes down, exhaust valve opens...
     piston goes up, then down---both closed....piston goes up, intake 
     opens...Yes, Virginia, there is a difference between the left and right
     cam !  
      BTW, the cams timed perfectly swapped backwards. For the race motor 
     running backwards, to the extreme if you can get fuel into a cylinder 
     and a spark somewheres close, I guess it could run. I don't know for sure
     if my 911 was running backwards or just out of cycle...
       My other strange experience was with an RX-7, way back in '80. For 
     some reason, my brother had considered removing the motor, started       
     removing lines, then backtracked. When we went to start the car, it      
     would idle at about 2000 rpm, but couldn't go higher or lower. After     
     probing around, we were further baffled when the carb was completely
     dry--no gas at all. How could it run ? A check of the oil showed it 
     had been thinned...a clue ?
       The crankcase ventilation and fuel supply lines were side-by-side,
     my brother accidentally swapped these. The result was that the fuel 
     pump dumped into the crankcase. The resulting thinned oil was apparently
     creeping past the wankel seals and volatile enough to sustain the car
     at idle....




 
      
       
      


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 11:11:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacd1.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: For sale:  1970 911T Coupe

I got a letter last week from one of the people in my PCA region.
I just got back from vacation so I didn't post it earlier.

Note:  I've never met this person nor have I looked at the car,
so call him if you're interested.  I'll be happy to go look at
it for you if you decide that you're interested or at least 
will recommend a local mechanic to inspect the car.

The entire letter:

- ------------

Dear Fellow Porsche Enthusiast,

I didn't leave my heart in San Francisco I took it with me!

My just painted silver 911T bought originally in San Francisco and
brought out to Iowa to drive on sunny summer weekends and stored
in a heated garage the othe 9 months is now...

FOR SALE

If your looking for a gem, this is it!  This classic 1970 has the smooth
sleek lines that gave Porsche their trademark.  Please pass on the following
stats if you or anyone you know may be interested.

1970 911T Coupe #9110101823.  Perfect original.  silver(gold lettering)/
blck interior, restored inside and out, new OEM paint job with 5yr. warranty,
82k original miles.  Calif. car, no rust, garaged / stored, 5 speed, front
air dam (not shown), Racemark steering wheel, S gauges, webers, new: clutch,
shocks, chain tensioners, dash, door and window seals, headliner, polished
alloys/205s, service records available.  Includes $1500 of spare parts plus
an extra set of steel rims.  Beautiful condition.

Asking $14,000 Tom Scorzelli, 706 South Second Street, Fairfield, Iowa 52556.
(515)472-9250(days) (515)472-4583(eve.)

- -------------

There is a picture of the car in the letter.  It looks good in the picture...

As I said before, if you're interested call him.  I don't know any more
than you do.

Ross Stites

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 10:07:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: SAVE@CPVA.SAIC.COM
Subject: Re: Scotland Yard 968

Ummm.. this brings to memory a recollection of a story out of the UK regarding
a band of hooligans, a Range Rover, and a wild late night chase. Maybe I'm
remembering a tale told in this very forum.  

I recall that the Range Rover was stolen and was consequently chased all over
the country side leaving a few disabled or destroyed police vehicles in its
wake.  The guilty parties, as I heard it, were never caught.

Anyhow, seems to me that providing law enforcement with more performance
oriented vehicles will accomplish nothing if its not supported with the
appropriate forums for developing improved driving skills.  Also, isn't
ramming the car under pursuit a common tactic used by law enforcement to
disable or "trap" the offending vehicle?  I can't say that I'd condone this
in a 968.  Then again, maybe they'll take delivery with those steel and
rubber buggy bumpers so popular with the Highway Patrol here in California
(groan).

Clark

Date: 23 May 1994 09:03:22 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: GGR / RWR AutoX at Candlest

GGR / RWR AutoX at Candlestick
Vroooommm  SKRREEEEEK!
    This past weekend we had two autocrosses at the Stick.  Saturday was
a Golden Gate Region event, and Sunday was Redwood Region event.
    Lotsa fun, lotsa driving!
    Saturday was a very fast course!  The Heathen, Unholy Detroit Iron
(a "well-prepared" Camaro and a recent Vette--possibly a ZR-1) wound up 
blowing everyone away.  Bummer, eh?
    On one run Saturday, I improved my time by 3.7 seconds!  In one run!
Mucho thanks to the guy (I forget his name) who drives another light blue
74 914 2.0L.  He suggested that I try third gear earlier--I stayed in it
through the back sweeper and didn't have to un-settle the car by shifting
in the gates on the way back.  Talk about a difference!  I think that all
the time I made on that run was through those gates.
    Those gates were a bit difficult to find, sometimes.  In fact, we had
one person who made six runs, and had six DNFs!  I think that he just 
plain didn't see the first gate....
    Saturday was very throroughly organized, and well run.  I am learning
that this is typical for GGR events.  We were all in one big run group.  
You signed up to work for an hour in the morning, and an hour in the 
afternoon.  They ran in (mostly) numerical order.  If you missed your spot
while working, when you came off you got into the second driver line, and
got cycled through first.
    The Sunday event seemed to run on Redwood Standard Time--about an hour
later than originally planned.  The orignal course design, a "little Sears
Point," was rejected halfway through construction as being too fast.  
About two revisions later, the course was laid out.
    To be changed after the first run group.  It turned out that there was
a moderate-speed chicane right at a little hill in the parking lot, which
was causing some people to go airborne.  So they made a left-right jog
thing (box chicane?) out of it, and moved it earlier to slow people down
for the hill.  No problem.
    On two separate runs Sunday, I was able to shave two seconds each from
my best time!  Thanks to my instructor, Judy.  Spun out my last run--
bummer!  I had fun, though.
    One word to anyone who signs up as a course worker--always keep your
eyes on the car on track!  Let's just say that the sight of a silver 930
barreling down on you sideways from ten yards off gives a whole new 
meaning to the word, "SHIT!!!"  It was probably further than that, but it
seemed like he was right on top of me....
    Oh, in case anyone's interested, the next Bay Area driving event is an
autocross next weekend at the Oakland Coliseum.  They went through great
pains to tell us that we couldn't use the usual entrance, so you may need
directions if you want to go.  I don't remember what day (sorry) but you
can contact a GGR member to find out.
    Whew!  That's a lot of typing for a Monday!

- --DD

 - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
    "My bug's more mid-engined than your bug!"
     ----          ______                    
    / \/ \        |______| ___ | ___ /____|_
    \\/\//         ______|     |          |

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 11:01:33 PDT
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Re: california smog inspections

the last time i needed a smog check, the guy who ran it was quite
helpful. he first let the car idle for about five minutes before
getting a readout from the tailpipe sniffers. it failed. then
he told me to take a run down to the end of the road, about a mile,
and back, to "blow it out a bit". i went down and back, flat out,
shifting at 7000 rpm. he put the sniffers back in and ran the
test immediately. it passed.

 -mitch


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 14:57:25 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: car won't start

> From: Sorin Grama  <soring@tigua.natinst.com>
> Subject: car won't start
> Date: Monday, May 23, 1994 8:11AM
>
> Well, I've run into my first problem with my 85.5 944... The beast just
> wouldn't start last night.
>
> Here's what happened.  The engine won't turn at all.  I can hear the relay
> clicking and a hissing sound which I suppose comes from the injectors.
> That's it!
[...]

Sounds like the starter or solenoid, or related wiring.  May also be 
the ignition switch itself as you indicated.  Maybe a relay in the 
central electric box - did you have that open when you vacuumed?

The starter is under the center/front of the car, just behind the 
clutch (i.e., under the radio).  It's pretty easy to reach.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 15:15:30 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com  ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re:  engine serial number

Tom asks:
>...Where is this located, on the car or engine itself?  It's a '70
911T...If the answer is on the engine, point me to the right box,...<

Barney says:
The engine serial number is on top of the engine case, adjacent to the oil
pressure sender.  If you have the original case, it should start out with
the numbers 610XXXX where 6 is the cylinder designation, 1 is the engine
type "T", and 0 is the year of manufacture "1970".  The last 4 digits are
the production run (serial) numbers.

Oh, uh...it's the box in the corner. You know, the one the cat tipped its
litter box into last winter.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     autoXer/racer   SLC


------------------------------

Date: 23 May 1994 10:13:11 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: 74-77 911S vs Carrera

        Reply to:   74-77 911S vs Carrera
> Bruce Anderson's book lists the output of a type 911/42 '75 911S 
> engine as 175hp - 10hp more than my type 911/81 '76 engine with
> seemingly similar specs (valve timing, port size, blah, blah, blah).
> Does anyone know what parameter causes this difference?  More
> importantly, does anyone care?

> Mike Dayton
> 76 Euro 911

The 75 is also 100 lbs lighter and faster to 60 and higher top end.
Just a note to add to your curiousity.  Perhaps the extra weight had
to do with the galvanizing that began in 76?

Other questions for the trivia-inclined:
What were the differences between the 74-77 911S vs the Carrera
for those years?  I know that the plain 911 of 74 was dropped for
75, so that your choices became only the above two models, and
that the US Carrera had the same wide rear fenders flares as the
European Carrera but used the same engine as the 911S (due to
EPA reqs.).  Were there other differences in the US?  And what was
different about the European Carreras?   Did all Carreras come
with duck tails and ugly rocker panel/door decals?

It seems like the Carrera models go for a much higher prices than
the 911S's.  Is this just because fewer were made?  Anyone
know how many?  And as Mike says, does anyone care?

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo look targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 13:09:10 -0700
From: rdean@qntm.com (Robert Dean)
Subject: Re: car won't start


Hello, fellow porschephiles!

Well, I've run into my first problem with my 85.5 944... The beast just
wouldn't start last night.  It's one of those classic "no start" symptoms,
but I wanted to check the net wisdom before I proceeded with a fix. 

Here's what happened.  The engine won't turn at all.  I can hear the relay
clicking and a hissing sound which I suppose comes from the injectors. 
That's it!  But here's another thing that might help you narrow the pool
of possible defects.  While waiting for a AAA towing truck last night (of
course, the car died while away from home just to prove Murphy's law
correct) I was able to start the car by pushing it and popping the clutch
in 2nd gear.  Of course, you might say, it's the battery, you dummy!  No
it's not! The battery it's about a month old and I did try to jump start
it from another battery with no luck.  At this point I think it's the
starter or the ignition switch. 

The car just died all of a sudden without any warnings after I 
attempted to vacuum some leaves underneath the hood (near the fuse box).  
I was pretty careful not to knock any wires, but maybe that's what 
happened.  Do you have any ideas/suggestions as to what to look for?  
My feeling is that I have some loose wiring.  Where/how should I check?  
It was too dark and late last night so I didn't have time to look 
around the engine too much.  I don't even know where the starter 
is located.
Any suggestions are appreciated.  I will keep you posted as to 
what the problem was.

Thanks a bunch,
Sorin

85.5 944

> Sorin, sounds like you might check the solenoid or the heavy cable from Bat
to starter, that is if you are convinced the Bat IS ok!! Just follow the Heavy
wire from + lead of Bat and  you will see starter.  Bob, S.J.

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 14:05:04 -0700
From: pjb@cco.caltech.edu (Paul J. Brewer)
Subject: Questions for '80s 928 Owners....


I am looking at old 928/944 with automatic. THe 928 is much roomier, for sure.

Anyway, just looked at one with 62K miles on it. 1st 928 I've driven, but I've
tried the 924 and 944. 

On the auto transmission, does it downshift when you push all the way down?
(floor the gas pedal). How long does it take to downshift, or will it only 
do it in certain rpm ranges? 

This one would not downshift unless you changed the setting (i.e. from D to 3 
or 2 ). 

Cruise control was also broke, tires worn, small oil leak. I dont think I want
one that leaks at all (is that unrealistic at this age? ). 

Handling was awesome, and the engine purred steady. Listen to a 10 yr old Ford
when it idles and you will hear all sorts of interesting stuff. Even with the
worn tires I couldnt get it to slip at 50-60 on corners rated 25. 

Someone offered to email me extensive research which they did on cars this
age. I never got it -- but any and all info from anyone is welcome.

In particular, I am correct in suspecting something wrong on the A/T ? 

Thanks

Paul Brewer
pjb@cco.caltech.edu

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 17:07:07 EST
From: reid_zeigler@merck.com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: 911 rear wheel bearing R&R



Sounds like I have a bad rear wheel bearing on my '73 911.
It makes a roaring sound that gets as loud as engine noise
at 50 mph. The noise gets significantly quieter if I turn
sharply left (that's sharply as in 50 mph off-ramp) I checked
and repacked the CV joints and they seem fine.

Questions: 

Can you replace the bearing without removing the trailing
arm? If so, what kind of bearing puller do you need? 

If I do take the training arms off, can the bushing at the 
other end (Fanblock) be pressed out and replaced with an
arbor press? Are there any precautions or tricks to prevent
ruining the new bushing?

Thanks for the help. I have a lot of P-Car experience, but this
is a new one.

 - Reid
(zeigler@merck.com)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 17:42:56 -0400
From: Dustin Boyette - Logical Design Group <ldg@mercury.interpath.net>
Subject: Re: engine serial number

The engine number is cleverly hiding from you. It's stamped on the right hand
side of the fan support section of the crankcase. It's sometimes difficult to
see because of engine accessories & FI. Bruce Anderson's "911 Performance
Handbook" does a good job of explaining where to find all the numbers you need.
I highly recommend it.

Dustin Boyette
ldg@mercury.interpath.net
1969 911S w/ 1980 SC body & engine

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 14:52:03 PDT
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: I found it!!

P'philes,
        Thanks to all who responded to my engine serial number quest.
I found it where everyone said it would be, in the box where the cat
litter spilled 8^).  No really, it was right below where the blower
is mounted on the right side case half.  I had to scrape some gunk
to actually see it.
Thanks,
        Tom

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 17:35:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: robert merithew <merithew@uxa.cso.uiuc.edu>
Subject: Re: 914 steering column question

Brian Abernathy wrote:

> Next, I wanted to take off the turn signal switch, wiper control, and finally
> get down to the "guts" of the ignition switch, but here is the problem:
> The wires to the turn signal switch are too short to just remove from the
> steering column shank.  They appear to be permanently attached to the
> switch, but I may be wrong about that- it was hot in the car, and there were
> a couple of wasps buzzing around.
> 
> How difficult is it to remove the switches?  Can I repair the turn 
> signal cancel without replacing the switch?  (It appears that the small
> plastic nub that cancels the signal has the end broken)

i just replaced the ignition switch on my '74 2.0 last week.

i removed the under-dash 'knee pad' piece of trim (screws underneath and
at each side, under plastic caps) to get to the back of the ignition
switch and the turn signal switches.  this made it much easier to detach
the switch wires, which were joined by multi-plug connectors.  i also
had to remove the windshield washer lines (water in my face).  then four
long skinny screws held the whole turn signal assembly to the
steering column.

if your only problem is the turn signal cancel tab, then you may be able
to fix it without removing the assembly.  i think i had to remove the
assembly to get out the ignition switch, though.

after i put the knee pad back on, i think i decided it would be possible
to detach the wires without removing it, but that may have been only
because i had seen it with the knee pad off, so i knew exacly where the
plugs came off, etc.  i believe the book i was following said to remove
the knee pad anyway...

- -- 
  Robert Merithew (merithew@uiuc.edu)           _______________    __o
  University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign   ______________     -\<,
  Grad Student, Dept. of Physics                            ......O/ O

Date: Mon, 23 May 1994 16:37:01 -0700
From: rdean@qntm.com (Robert Dean)
Subject: Re[2]: california smog inspections

the last time i needed a smog check, the guy who ran it was quite
helpful. he first let the car idle for about five minutes before
getting a readout from the tailpipe sniffers. it failed. then
he told me to take a run down to the end of the road, about a mile,
and back, to "blow it out a bit". i went down and back, flat out,
shifting at 7000 rpm. he put the sniffers back in and ran the
test immediately. it passed.

 -mitch

> I hate to say it but California Smog Rules (As Crazy as they seemed at first) 
must be having REAL effects, not only on our environment, but on the performance
of our vehicles, IE: My '73 911E (With Mech. Injection)had a very difficult time
passing Smog anywhere, my '82 911SC passes sooo clean they usually don't believe
the readings.... Bob

Date: Mon, 23 May 94 12:56:41 EDT
From: Mike Kohlbrenner <kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>
Subject: Re: What's a Speedster?


> ...  I'm not that much into the 4 cyl. Porsches, they look 
> neat, but I can't see the point of something costing 100s of times more 
> than a Toyota Tercel and not going much faster, and being 100s of times 
> less reliable.  I'm sure I'm missing some religion somewhere here, or 
> have somehow "lost the FAITH" but so be it.  Thanks for the info.
> 
> Ted
> 
> PS: The Spyder 550 Speedsters are nice, at least they look neat in the ads.
> 

Perhaps you should reread your racing history.  356s routinely won their
class at many endurance races, sometimes able to outhandle hulking four-
wheeled V8s.  IF they are properly maintained, they are damned reliable.

What you are missing is the fact that they are a piece of history and
even though you might (although I doubt it!) be able to outdrive one
in a Terdcel (mis-spelling intended!), you'd have a hell of a lot more
fun in the 356.

I track my Civic Si and with suspension tweeks and race rubber can
easily beat many stock Porsches on street tires (this is on "handling"
tracks -- I really need POWER!).  But that doesn't mean I don't like
Porsches for what they are just because I can beat them with a Japanese
car for less than $15000.

I guess you said it yourself: if you don't understand, so be it.  Thanks
for keeping demand and prices a little bit less/lower for us who do!

Mike Kohlbrenner
<kohlbren@hpancma.an.hp.com>

'67 VW Beetle      (Every once in a while it gets closer to running...)
'90 Honda Civic Si (Daily driver/Track Car -- YaHoo!) 
??? Porsche ???    (Someday it will be mine...)

Porschephiles #758                         Wed May 25 02:17:54 CDT 1994
Date: Mon, 23 May 94 20:00:04 PDT
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: Help with C@ alignment

>Does anyone have the factory specs for the 93 C2 alignment
>number.  I need the camber, caster, and toe.  I brought my C2 in
>for alignment and the shop had a brand new Hunter setup.  When
>they put my car up they could not get more that -.5 camber on
>the back wheels.  The Hunter specs had a range of -.82 to -.5
>for the back.  (I was trying for -1.0 for autocross).  The Hunter
>specs on the front were -.17 to .17.  Also I had a problem with
>the front caster.  The Hunter specs called for 4.17 to 4.67 and
>the shop could only get 3.4.  I suspect either the Hunter specs
>are wrong for my 93 C2 or the equipment is out of adjustment.
>The spec that is listed on the Hunter equipment lists the 89-92
>C2 C4 as having the same numbers.  Could this be true.  Thanks
>for you help.     

William,

According to my Service Information Technik for the '90 C4 (aka Technical 
Manual), it list the factory aligment for the front axle as:
Toe (total) as +15' +/-5'.
The camber as 0 degree +/-10' (max. difference left to right 10').
Caster as 4 degree 10' +/-15' (max. diff. le. to ri. 15').
Toe difference angle at 20 degree steering lock: -40' +/-30'.           

For the rear axle:
Toe (each wheel) as +10' +/-5'.
Camber at -20 +/-10'.

I hope this will enlighten you.  Don't ask me how this interpret, I just type 
them up.

Quincy Dong (QLD1@pge.com)

> appropriate forums for developing improved driving skills.  Also, isn't
> ramming the car under pursuit a common tactic used by law enforcement to
> disable or "trap" the offending vehicle?  I can't say that I'd condone this
> in a 968.  Then again, maybe they'll take delivery with those steel and
> rubber buggy bumpers so popular with the Highway Patrol here in California
> (groan).
> 
> Clark
>

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 07:59:07 +0200
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: shipping cars to their home country


>I'm also interested in continental comment on the following issue:  I had the
>impression when I was in Germany that the prices of Porsches were such that
>a profit could be made buying well-kept examples here in the U.S. and shipping
>them back to their birth-country?  From what European readers see in Pphiles,
>does this seem to be true?  If so, is it already happening?

This is changing depending on how strong the currency is in a country.
In the 80's a lot of Porsches were imported to Sweden. Today when the
resession has made the Swedish crown weak, the germans buys a lot of
P cars from Sweden. A couple of years ago it was also beneficial to buy a car
or parts from USA but today the prices are almost in the same region.

The difference is on the other hand MAJOR between two neighbour countries
like Sweden and Norway (right Trond?).

How the relation is between the DM and the USD is not known to me. Is there
anyone from Germany on the net?

Magnus
'82 911 SC (imported from Germany in '84)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 10:38:34 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Re: Scotland Yard 968


> This whole scam of what kinds of cars the cops use is just an advertising
> gimmick.  Look what CHP's did for Mustangs. 

	Possibly ... I can't see what difference a single 968 patrol car
will make to overall law enforcement. Then again, many police forces in
continental Europe have used 911s (and 356s, I think).

> Maybe it will boost Porsche sales to have the incompetent british cops
> using them.  If they were serious about law enforcement they would use
> toyotas, and save the money for drivers ed.

	Hmm. All police car drivers in the UK have to pass extremely stiff
driving tests before they can drive patrol or other fast vehicles. Only
Police Grade One drivers (and probably only the best of those) would get
anywhere near the 968!

	The Institute of Advanced Motorists (who run an Advanced Driving
Test) only use Police Grade One drivers as examiners, and believe me,
these people are *extremely* competant. I have also had tuition from them
on the local police force skid pan and they can do some pretty impressive
things with their cars.

	Compared with stories which I have heard about the driving test in
other countries (especially the US), the bog standard test in the UK is
quite difficult and the Advanced test is much more so. The Police Grade
One is in another league above that!

	We also don't suffer from revenue generation through speeding
fines, and you are unlikely to get done for speeding below 85mph (official
speed limit 70mph) on motorways unless you were driving carelessly or
recklessly.

Philip
~~~~~~

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 12:45:59 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: shipping cars to their home country


>>I'm also interested in continental comment on the following issue:  I had the
>>impression when I was in Germany that the prices of Porsches were such that
>>a profit could be made buying well-kept examples here in the U.S. and shipping
>>them back to their birth-country?  From what European readers see in Pphiles,
>>does this seem to be true?  If so, is it already happening?
>
>This is changing depending on how strong the currency is in a country.
>In the 80's a lot of Porsches were imported to Sweden. Today when the
>resession has made the Swedish crown weak, the germans buys a lot of
>P cars from Sweden. A couple of years ago it was also beneficial to buy a car
>or parts from USA but today the prices are almost in the same region.
>
>The difference is on the other hand MAJOR between two neighbour countries
>like Sweden and Norway (right Trond?).

Even if the import boom seem to have halted, there is a market for some 
cars. New cars are extremely expensive over here(Norway), but import taxes 
are sky-high, and even if you should import used cars, it is very seldom a 
good idea to do this. It gets too expensive.
The only cars that *is* rather 'safe' to import is Classic Cars, we have a 
special tax system for them. Importing a '65 911 would, if i got a nice car 
for $10k, cost me about $ 1000 in shipping, $ 1000 in different costs, $2500 
in import taxes. The car would have costed about $ 14-15k. But such a car 
could fetch $20k in Norway.

Instead I restore cars as a hobby, and would have bought the $5k car, got a 
$2.5k receipt and pay $500 in import taxes,and have the car for about $ 
7.5k. Then I'd put in evenings restoring the car, and maybe sell it for app. 
$15-17k. But again it is a little market, and you have to know the right 
'channels' so that you meet the interested people.

cheers,
trond

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 11:59:36 BST
From: malc@ncc.co.uk (Malcolm Smith)
Subject: Smog Tests....et al.



the last time i needed a smog check, the guy who ran it was quite
helpful. he first let the car idle for about five minutes before
getting a readout from the tailpipe sniffers. it failed. then
he told me to take a run down to the end of the road, about a mile,
and back, to "blow it out a bit". i went down and back, flat out,
shifting at 7000 rpm. he put the sniffers back in and ran the
test immediately. it passed.

 -mitch

> I hate to say it but California Smog Rules (As Crazy as they seemed at first) 
must be having REAL effects, not only on our environment, but on the performance
of our vehicles, IE: My '73 911E (With Mech. Injection)had a very difficult time
passing Smog anywhere, my '82 911SC passes sooo clean they usually don't believe
the readings.... Bob

>>Being from the UK I don't fully understand the rules for California Smog Tests. 
In the UK we have the MOT Test once a year (for cars over 3 years). Although one
car (VW Type 1 '74 Vintage) is exempt the other 2 regullary fail. When "retuned"
to Pass they run badly. So what I do is to "tweak" them 1 block before the station
to be Mega lean which passes CO and HC. Once I've passed then I untweak and carry
on as before with a slightly dirty running but happy engine.

The rest of the MOT (Suspension, Brakes, Steering, Bodywork) is a different matter.
Oh S****t get the MIG out.

Does California have exemptions for different ages.

 -malc-

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 07:11:47 +0000
From: kwb1@cornell.edu (Klaus W. Beyenbach)
Subject: 911 rear wheel bearing R&R

RE: Rear bearing 911

Dear Reid,

I have been through this repair on my 911 (1981SC), and I see no way to
replace the bearing without taking the trailing arm off.  You need a very
heavy-duty press to remove the old  and to install the new bearing. Neither
the car nor the press can be moved into the right position to do the job -
lest there are some heavy-duty protable presses.  

I did well by following the instructions in Haynes manual.  I took both 
trailing arms off, and brought them to the Porsche dealer.  The dealer
ripped me off: $100 ! for just removing the bearings from the trailing
arms.  After that experience I ordered the new bearings from Stoodards and
had a local machine shop press them in for $ 20.

Be sure to follow the sequence for installing bearings.  The removal of the
bearing ruins them.  Better do it right the first time. 

If you need more help, feel free to write.

Best wishes

Klaus W. Beyenbach
1981 911SC Targa    


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 07:27:16 +0000
From: kwb1@cornell.edu (Klaus W. Beyenbach)
Subject: Re: ordering pubs from Germany

>I read German haltingly, but I want to order some VW and Porsche-related
>pubs from VW Scene and other magazines I picked up on a trip a year or so ago.
>The order form has a checkbox for "Bankeinzug: Konto Nummer ___ ..."  Is this
>an indication that they can accept Mastercard, or something else entirely?
>I'm trying to avoid guessing wrong on the amount of a check (if they would
>even take one from overseas) and/o 
>r letting them see my written German in
>an exchange of letters to order.
>
>Can a continental Porschephile help me out?
>
>I'm also interested in continental comment on the following issue:  I had the
>impression when I was in Germany that the prices of Porsches were such that
>a profit could be made buying well-kept examples here in the U.S. and shipping
>them back to their birth-country?  From what European readers see in Pphiles,
>does this seem to be true?  If so, is it already happening?
>
>B.

Dear Bill

"Bankeinzug: Konto Nummer ___ ..." means your bank account number" which
the publisher can bill directly.  Financial services in Germany allow
routine bills such as rent, utilities, insurance, suscriptions, medical
charges etc. to be directly charged to your bank account.  Paying bills in
Germany bypasses your own check-book (and the stupid activity of writing
checks and licking stamps on a regular basis). 

Giving your US bank account number doe not help, because your bank will not
know what to do with bill from the publisher - let alone read German.  

Simply give them your Mastercard number, and specify Mastercard.  You will
find that the exchange rate on Mastercard is much better than what banks
give you.

As to buying Porsches here and taking them back to Germany, there are many
who have figured out that angle - from here to there, and from there to
here.  It depends on the value of the dollar, taxes, and DOT and EPA
regulations (on both sides of the ocean) before the undertaking becomes
profitable.  As can be expected from such volatile business conditions -
the companies engaged in so-called grey market cars (also for Mercedes,
etc) come and go.

Ted,

Yes my 32 year old 356 just squeaked past our smog inspection this
morning, but its engine has never been out and at 79k miles it is
still tight and ready for every day driving.  In spite of some years
sitting, reliability is not a problem.  Have you tried a 32 year old
Tercel?  Yes, you can buy more horsepower and modern stamped metal
for less, but you won't turn heads when you drive by.

Porsches set the standard for reliable sports cars in their day.  I
like sunny days because I don't have to drive my (also 1600 cc) Honda
CRX.

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 08:41:40 CDT
From: Steve=Putnam%Prod=Qual%Mfg=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: 928 A/T questions


From: Paul J. Brewer
re: Questions for '80s 928 Owners....

>On the auto transmission, does it downshift when you push all the way down?
>(floor the gas pedal). How long does it take to downshift, or will it only
>do it in certain rpm ranges?

      Since you stated it as D,3,.. This is the Mercedes-Benz 4 speed auto.  
      It will drop out of 4th without full throttle. 2nd requires the floor.  
  
      1st only if you are below 15mph or so.   NO hesitation, period.  

      Shifting under light load should not even be noticeable, under medium   
      to heavy load will be very tight.   

>tires worn, 

      No doubt from multiple test drives round corners at 2.5x rated speed.

>In particular, I am correct in suspecting something wrong on the A/T ?

      My first guess would be more the linkages & hoses etc. not the A/T      
      itself.


Regards,  Steve

Internet- Steve=Putnam%Prod=Qual%Mfg=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Lone Star Region PCA
1986 928S  Meteor Metallic

r.

>Malc, I am not sure anyone here in Calif. understands the rules either!! 
seriously, there is an age cutoff date where the car is exempt(I believe it's
older than '65) Also if repairs are over $250 to make car meet smog reqs they
are granted an exemption, but must try again in 2 yrs. Cars in the late 80s and
beyond have little or no trouble meeting smog reqs because they were designed 
so, such as Elect. Fuel injection, etc.  Bob 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 7:33:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: LAFORCE@XENON.ARC.NASA.GOV
Subject: re: 911 wheel bearing removal

Reid writes:

>Sounds like I have a bad rear wheel bearing on my '73 911.
>It makes a roaring sound that gets as loud as engine noise
>at 50 mph. The noise gets significantly quieter if I turn
>sharply left (that's sharply as in 50 mph off-ramp) I checked
>and repacked the CV joints and they seem fine.

>Can you replace the bearing without removing the trailing
>arm? If so, what kind of bearing puller do you need? 

The bearings can be replaced w/o removing the trailing arms.

I suspect that any shop will have the tools necessary, one near
me claims to have such.

I did the job myself.  A friend with a lathe built me a set of 
bushings (?correct word?) to press out the old bearings and press
in the new ons.  They operate with a threaded rod down the center.

You also need a slide hammer to remove the stub axle from the 
bearing.  This destroys the bearing.  I do not think (neither 
does the factory) the axle can be removed without damage to the
bearing.

Up until the stub axle is installed, the bearings can be removed
without damage; it's removing the stub axle that destroys the bearing.


- --Soren

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 08:51:12 -0700
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Scotland Yard 968



> Then again, many police forces in
> continental Europe have used 911s (and 356s, I think).

In 1961, while living in France, I dickered for several months with the
Porsche dealer in Orleans before the factory would let me order a
special-color white (not ivory) 356B Coupe because that color was reserved
for the German "highway patrol," who used white 356B Cabriolets in 1960 and
1961 to patrol the autobans. The cars had a blue light fixed to the right
side of the windshield and, except in rain, always ran with their tops
down.

When I took the car to the factory for the 6,000 mile check, I was really
impressed with the autoban courtesy of German drivers who immediately moved
to the right lane to let me through. Then I learned they probably thought
they saw the fuzz in their mirror.
