------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 12:20:42 -0400
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re: 911 rear wheel bearing R&R

I did a couple of these when I first got my car - no, you don't have to take
the trailing arm off to do it...you just need the right tools ;-).

First step is to identify which side has the bad bearing...just because it
gets quieter when you turn left doesn't mean the left bearing is the bad guy.
The 73 bearing is a complete unit with an inner and outer race...the inner
race could go bad and give you misleading sounds.  The way to identify the
correct side is to jack up the suspected side, put the car in neutral (use
blocks on the other wheels!), and spin the wheel.  Hopefully your brakes won't
drag and you can listen to the bearing as it spins.  If it is bad, you will
hear a clickety-clack, like a train.  This translates to a roar while driving.

Next step: removing the hub.  First pull the wheel, disconnect the caliper
(don't let it hang...put it on a can or something), take off the rotor, and
remove the parking brake stuff.  I had a nifty hub puller that had three "feet"
that bolted onto the wheel studs, and had a large screw-type shaft in the
middle that you cranked down on the end of the inner flange to pull the outside
flange out.  Oh, you might want to remove the castellated nut on the end of the
inner flange first ;-).  Use a hammer (on the puller) the help the outer flange
pop out.  Now you've got an outer flange in your hand with the outside race of
the bearing wrapped around it and a bunch of ball bearings on the floor...the
point of no return.  Getting the race off of the flange is a big pain...I
managed to do it somehow without scratching the flange using a vice and a large
screwdriver.  Apparently the trick is to grind a groove somewhere on the
circumference of the race, whack it with a chisel at that point, and it will
break and pop off.  YMMV.

Third step: removing the inner flange, driveshaft, and bearing.  Remove the
driveshaft.  Wear black underwear, 'cause you will get dirty.  Now the inner
flange should fall right out, since it rides inside the outer flange which is
now gone.  Now the fun part: getting bearing out of the trailing arm.  I
happened to have in my socket collection a very large socket (1 1/8"?) that
passed through the inside opening in the trailing arm and butted against the
inner bearing race.  I also had a 6"x4" piece of plate steel, say 1/4" thick,
with a hole drilled in the middle.  Pass a large bolt through the socket hole
and the bearing, place the plate on the outside of the trailing arm with the
bolt running through it, and bolt it all together.  Now you have a homemade
bearing puller.  Crank down on the bolt and the bearing will start to pull out.
A few whacks with the hammer at various points on the circumference of the
socket helps the bearing work itself out.  You may need to shim the plate out
from the control arm to give the bearing room to come out...I don't rememeber
exactly.  Once it gets a little ways out, it comes out easily using a hammer
and alternating blows from side to side of the socket.

Fourth step: installing your new bearing.  You now have a greasy new FAG
bearing in your hand.  I used an additional steel plate to press the
bearing in, with the help of the old bearing casing.  Pass the large bolt
through the two plates with the bearing and trailing arm sandwiched in between.
Crank until you run out of clearance for the plate, making sure the bearing
is going in straight.  Now use the old casing in front of the bearing to get it
to go in the rest of the way.   Do not use the inner race of the bearing to
press it in...you will destroy it.

Fifth step: installing the flanges.  I had just enough bite with the
castellated nut on the inner flange shaft that I could use the nut pull the
flanges together over the bearing.  What could be easier?  You might want to
put the driveshaft back in to keep them from rotating.  Put the parking brake
assembly, the rotor and caliper back on, mount the wheel and you're ready to
go.

PS: at this point I found out that I had replaced the wrong side ;-).

The only really special tool I used was the hub puller - it was a monstrous
thing.  You could probably rent one from your local rental type place.  The
plates and socket worked fine for me.  Been over 4 years on a new set of
rear bearing (did both ;-)) with no problems.  Of course you could spend $250
and get the correct bearing installer, e.g. from Performance Products...
Sorry to those offended by the use of a hammer.

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 10:36:41 PDT
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #757 Tue May 24 02:00:02 CDT 1994

Harry Pellow wrote:

>    Yes, California needs money- the current estimate from Kathleen Brown
> (which should be taken with a grain of Salt as she's trying to follow in her
> brother/father's footsteps) is that we will again be $7 Bil in debt this
> year.
 
And who is responsible for the 7 billion dollar debt? Not the Browns.

Jerry Brown kept the budget balanced and at the same time kept the costs
down for higher education.  When I started college in 1974, when Brown was 
governor, it cost about $120/year (in-state) for tuition at a California 
State University.  During Reagan's governorship it multiplied more than
tenfold, to about $1200/year in-state by 1980.

 -Mitch Craig

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 8:09:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: SAVE@CPVA.SAIC.COM
Subject: V8 912 ?!?!?!?

I've just got to share this one with you all . . .

In the Straight Scoop section of the May edition of Car Craft Magazine (Ok,
cut the snickering!) I found the following:

(reproduced without permission - so cane me why don't you)

STRAIGHT SCOOP GARAGE II

Now under construction in Doug Clark's Lanett, Alabama, garage is this '67 
Porsche 912 powered by a Chevy 350 small-block mounted up front and sending
power back to a Ford 9-inch rearend.  For those of you unfamiliar with
Porsches, this is *NOT* how the factory built the 912 (four-cynlinder version
of the 911).

The car has been equipped with a full frame, and the fuel tank now resides 
where the original engine had been.  The body has been modified with "935"
slope-nose panels from Better Bodies.  Clark promises it will be on the road
by spring.  We just hope the road can stand the strain.

End-of-article

Above the print are two small B&Ws showing the gutted patchwork body (lots of 
plastic, including a whale tail) and the 350 nicely crammed into the front 
trunk.  I'm not sure but it would appear that the rear has drum brakes in the
photo (the wheel is not in place).  Ummm, a small block Chevy can easily 
generate 450HP . . . 

Anyway, thought this might be of general interest, especially in light of the
yearly inquiry regarding V8's and 914s.

Clark

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 10:28:38 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: 356 misc.

OK, you guys talked me into buying it, now it's time to help out
with the reconditioning :-)

     Re: Seat recliner mechanism.  I disassembled one to see why
it sometimes slipped allowing the seat back to go foreward or
back, depending.  There are these two mating devices, I'll call
them bevel gears, which the lever engages/disengages.  It seems
that they hold OK when firmly mated, but frequently fail to do
so.  I cleaned and lubed things, but they still slip.  My next
step will be to un-rivet a couple of pieces to get at these bevel
gears and attempt to sharpen up the teeth via filing or grinding.
Suggestions?

     Re Shocks:     I have fiddled with the blue adjustable Konis
on the car.  It seems a rear one has frozen valves, and a front
is worn out.  So - should I (for mostly street use) replace with
red Konis, or Boges?  The real question here is "Are red Konis
set to soft, about as comfortable as Boges?"  If so, I'll get the
Konis.

     Re distributors:  What's the deal with the "050"
distributor?  I don't know what I have - probably whatever was
stock in a '65 SC.

     What do the "stack of rubber donuts-looking" bumpers do for
the rear suspension?  Mine are pretty well beat, but I don't see
them listed in the catalogues (Tweeks, etc).

     That should do for now, but I'm sure there will be more.
BTW, it's *DEFINATLY* fun to drive:)  If you want to stay happy
with your Tercel, don't try a 356!

     Bob       Learning the 356 faith
^Z

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 15:03:09 -0400
From: "Bart Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Scotland Yard 968

In message <199405241551.IAA13331@mail.netcom.com> Larry Wilson writes:

> In 1961, while living in France, I dickered for several months with the
> Porsche dealer in Orleans before the factory would let me order a
> special-color white (not ivory) 356B Coupe because that color was reserved
> for the German "highway patrol," who used white 356B Cabriolets in 1960 and
> 1961 to patrol the autobans. The cars had a blue light fixed to the right
> side of the windshield and, except in rain, always ran with their tops
> down.

When I was a shavetail in Deutschland (in '62) I recall seeing the 
Bundespoletzi in Porsches, on the autobahn, but I seem to recall that they were 
cream and green (maybe w/green doors).  Also, I can't recall just where I saw 
them, but my recollection is that they were not using Porsches everywhere, just 
in certain "problem" areas.  I also noted that they were always seen (in dry 
weather) with the top down (but then, who in the world would drive a Porsche cab
with the top up in sunshine ... ?)

Bart Chambers

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 16:15:00 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: block drain location

Under the exhaust manifold, on the block.  Check for a little drain 
plug between #3 and #4.  It's close to the ribbing, so may be hard to 
find.  Small hands help.  Expect to scrape your knuckles.

		JBS

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 15:27:48 +0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber Account)
Subject: Re: '55 Carrera

To Trond:
 
Too bad you couldn't get a serial number, but Pops (my dad) gives some of the
following "things" that differentiate (mostly) a Carrera from other models.
 
 
1. rounded edges around the lower bodywork in front(kinda wrapped around a wire)
2. may or may not have louvers on rear deck.
3. came stock with a 547/1 engine (4-cam)
4. 8000 rpm tach
5. 250 kph speedo
6. 2 switches located on the dash that control current to dual coils
7. Gold carrera script on rear deck
8. dual exhaust under the bumper as opposed to through the bumper
9. if it has an anti-roll bar, than it is a Carrera (maybe; depends on year)
10. GS/GT whould have 16 inch wheels (original)
11. Carrera's did not have (normally) have bumper guards.
 
I think the model year of '55 had 5 different engine combo's, too.
 
Still waiting on the amount of '55 Carrera's actually availble.
 
Later,
bill van bibber


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 16:50:43 -0700
From: "Anthony A. Waitz" <waitz2@siarc.com>
Subject: Re: block drain location 

> Does anyone know where the block  coolant drain bolt is on an '87 924S?

Its on the lower right hand  side of the engine at a spot the
is  very difficult to access.  After using both the Haynes and
shop manuals I found the thing but was not able to get a
wrench on it.  So I just flushed it a couple of times with
distilled water to dilute the old coolant then refilled it
with clean coolant.  You have to calculate how much water
stays in the engine to get the concentration right though.  I
think about 1/8 of the total coolant stayes in the system if 
you dont use the side drain plug.

AAW

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 20:03:22 -40962758 (CDT)
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Rather have a Tercel ???

Ted,

I've had about enough of this crap.

If you want to argue that Porsche is not the same as something else,
that's fine. If you want to judge your cars based on a Consumer
Report-ish attitude of  the perfect car has no maintenence costs for
at least the first five years, can be abused systematicly by inept
drivers, and still function more-or-less as intended, that's also fine.
Just realize that Porsches (and for that matter, *ANY* European car)
are designed differently -- to push the envelope, to require maintenence
as a trade off for the performance you get, and to last roughly
forever *ONLY* if you take care of them. And don't try to convince
anyone here that anything different is necessarily better.

Finally, if you want to beat up people that have a preference for Porsches
over something else, go do it on someone else's list.

Stan Hanks,
ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 May 94 19:58:30 -0500
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 misc.

>      Re: Seat recliner mechanism.  

Albrecht the Other wrote a great piece on the care and feeding of seat
adjusters here while back. See if you can get him to shoot you a copy or 
fish it out of the archives.

>      Re Shocks:     ...  The real question here is "Are red Konis
> set to soft, about as comfortable as Boges?"  If so, I'll get the
> Konis.

And the answer: no way in hell are Konis as comfortable as Boges. I have
Konis anyway, being used to things with even stiffer suspensions.

>      Re distributors:  What's the deal with the "050"
> distributor?  I don't know what I have - probably whatever was
> stock in a '65 SC.

If your distributor has a black body with an oval tag rivetted to it, then 
it's the right stock piece. If you don't, you *REALLY* want to get the 
right distributor, or at worst, an 050 (Bob Hoy Imports in El Paso TX
usually as the best prices). *DO* *NOT* get an 009.

>      What do the "stack of rubber donuts-looking" bumpers do for
> the rear suspension?  Mine are pretty well beat, but I don't see
> them listed in the catalogues (Tweeks, etc).

Try Stoddard. They have everything....

>      That should do for now, but I'm sure there will be more.

Couple of other points: 1) join the Registry. See the FAQ or the Monthly
Message for contact info. 2) join the Stoddard 800 Club. You'll eventually
spend enough with them to make you wish you'd just done it up front.
3) keep the faith...

Stan

Date: Tue, 24 May 1994 18:32:29 +0800
From: sfisher@Megatest.COM (Scott Fisher)
Subject: Jumping the Gun...

I've sent in my subscription mail to the -request address, 
but I'm an impatient cuss, so I've decided to jump the gun.
I've read the March 8 FAQ, however, so I'll try to be as
specific as possible.

My first car was a 1958 Karmann-Ghia, the last air-cooled
product I've owned since then (the year in question being
1972).  Every night, when I'd go to bed, I used to hope
that the Porsche Fairy would turn my Ghia into either
a 1958 Speedster or a newish 911S Targa, preferably in
bright orange with black interior, and of course with the
early zip-out rear window.

Well, that never happened.  But now, 20-some years down
the line, I'm in a position to start seriously researching
the purchase of a 911 of roughly that vintage.  I love
the look of the early cars; those slim bumpers with a
little chrome in a few places are what I used to dream 
about, and surely there are enough people on this list who 
understand that the food of dreams is rarely sensible matter.

What I'm interested in is a general history of the early
Porsche 911, roughly up to 1973.  I'm aware, for instance,
that the wheelbase was lengthened during that time, but I
don't know the year.  I know that the original 2-liter six
was enlarged -- I remember seeing the silver 2.4 and 2.7
marks on the engine cover cooling vents, but I don't know
when that happened or whether some motors are better than
others (or what definition of "better" you're using, for 
that matter).  And of course I need to know what to look for 
to indicate bad repairs, botched bodywork, on-the-edge motors 
or gearboxes, or any of the many other reasons to back away 
from a deal regardless of how sweet it appears.  

As for my particular concerns, enthusiasm, or desires: I'm 
more interested in driving than showing or collecting; I don't
want a project car, but I'd rather have a solid, strong
driver than a perfect piece of sculpture that I'd be afraid
to park at work or leave in my driveway if one of the other
cars has to take the garage space for a few days.  Likewise, I'm
more interested in changes that affected the drivability
or "feel" of the car.  And I can guarantee that I'll autocross
the car, and also take it out on marque club open-track events.
I learned about trailing-throttle oversteer before I knew what
it was called, but I'd like my first spin to come in a parking 
lot full of orange cones and not on Calaveras Road...

Of course, I know that Porsche has a general tendency to
keep improving the breed, and that to a very large extent,
each year is better than the preceding.  But I want to 
begin researching the marque so that I can have an idea
of what to look for when I begin shopping in earnest.

Which is...?  Probably in the next two months; I have some
other projects in the pipe first, so if you've got a car
to sell, don't tell me yet, I'll only cringe when it goes
to someone else.  On the other hand, if you've got a good-
condition older 911 in the San Francisco Bay Area and you'd
like to show it off over lunch, drop me a line; I've ridden
in Miq Millman's very sharp black 911S, but not recently.
I live in Sunnyvale, work in San Jose; surely there must be
a few people on this list who are nearby.

Thanks for your attention, and I'm looking forward to being
part of this list.

- --Scott Fisher

------------------------------


Porschephiles #759                         Thu May 26 02:12:07 CDT 1994
Date: Wed, 25 May 1994 09:22:20 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: shipping c


>>This is changing depending on how strong the currency is in a country.
>>In the 80's a lot of Porsches were imported to Sweden. Today when the
>>resession has made the Swedish crown weak, the germans buys a lot of
>>P cars from Sweden. A couple of years ago it was also beneficial to buy a
>>
>Even if the import boom seem to have halted, there is a market for some
>cars. New cars are extremely expensive over here(Norway), but import taxes
>are sky-high, and even if you should import used cars, it is very seldom a
>good idea to do this. It gets too expensive.
>The only cars that *is* rather 'safe' to import is Classic Cars, we have a
>special tax system for them. Importing a '65 911 would, if i got a nice car
>
>E2.5k receipt and pay E500 in import taxes,and have the car for about E
>7.5k. Then I'd put in evenings restoring the car, and maybe sell it for app
>.
>E15-17k. But again it is a little market, and you have to know the right
>'channels' so that you meet the interested people.
>
>Trond, 5-6 years ago there were stories in Porsche Club Sweden
>that the norwegians bought 944's i Germany, put a glass-shield
>behind the seats and registrated the car as delivery truck in
>Norway, saving a lot of \\\ in taxes. Could that be true or
>was it just b-shit ?
>
It was true, they removed the rear seats and registered the cars as 
delivery-trucks, but the rules were changed. One of the good things about 
this was the above resulting in a large import of 944's, 928's and someone 
even got the 911 targa registered in this way. That's why early to mid 80's 
Porsches (944,924 & 928) are almost as 'cheap' as in Sweden. I almost bought 
a 928S some years ago, it was only one year left until I could re-register 
it as a personal car. The rules gave you the possibility to at no extra 
charge register the car as a personal car after 10 years 'duty'. 

cheers,
trond


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 May 1994 10:02:18 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Rather have a Third World War!


>Want to drive around the world?  You in a 356, me in an Infiniti Q45, see 
>who makes it?  Loser pays for trip?

On your 'drive around the world tour' the Infiniti's 45.000 mile service 
occurs in Zenica, Bosnia-Herzrgovina, you just have to park your car and ask 
around for 'the nearest Infiniti dealer with a good reputation'. To your 
great surprise he's no longer in business. 

In the mean time Serbian troops (correctly) mistook your Infiniti for 
hostile armoured vehicle, and decided to take action. KAZOOM,......Mig pilot 
closing in,.....lock on target,.......ait to groound missile 
launched.....SCRATCH,....BOOM,....BANG. No more Q45.

You will have to pay Rick's trip, and your insurance company will not cover 
your losses, since you were using your car in a race. With no competition 
the race get's *very* comfortable, no need to sleep behind the wheel with 
Hilton's Sheraton's etc in every major city. Even if the 356 is no gas 
guzzler, and Rick decides to change oil every 1500 mile the cost grows to 
six-figures.

MORAL: Sometimes (Always..?) it is better to be mistaken from driving around 
in 'an old Beetle', than Asian armoured-vehicle.....!

>> Tercel?  Yes, you can buy more horsepower and modern stamped metal
>> for less, but you won't turn heads when you drive by.
>> 
>
>If turning heads is what turns you on, just take your clothes off and go 
>stand in an intersection.  
It's a matter of turning the *RIGHT* heads, the right way.....   :) 


cheers,
trond

Date: Wed, 25 May 94 09:33:35 BST
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Rather have a Tercel ???


Stan writes:

| Ted,
|
| I've had about enough of this crap.

Yes, my sentiments exactly. I am sure there are many `better'
motor cars than Porsche, depending on the evaluation criteria.
Further, there are many motor cars that are more or less desirable
for various reason. I have no idea what an Tercel is, but I am
sure that Ted must have selected because he felt it was right for
him.

However, I can't really belive that he can possibly think that 
because he prefers a Tercel that he is really going to 
convert the 600+ Porsche owning porschephiles to be infinitiphiles.
I am sure that the Tercel is a very nice motor car, however 
for the purposes of the porschephiles list it is just another
rolling object.

Get a life Ted, or a Porsche.


Regards


Ben

Date: Wed, 25 May 94 10:08:15 EDT
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: 911SC won't start when warm (sometimes)

Hi

I'm generally happy with the '83 911SC I just bought, but
one VERY annoying thing has happened several times:
If I drive the car for at least 1/2 hour, park it for at least 1/2 hour,
then try to start it, sometimes it won't start. Not even one sputter.
It just cranks and cranks without ever firing. If I try it again 
10 min - 1/2 hour later, it starts just fine!!
Why??
I'm told that there was once a problem with the airflow sensor's diaphragm 
falling below the bottom of its housing (crude ASCII diagram):


\       /                  \       /   
 |-----|                    |     |     
 |     |      -->           |     |     /|\ Air
 |     |                    |     |      |
/       \                  / ----- \

The theory is that if the plate falls below the narrow center section of the 
housing, the plate is not pulled up at cranking speeds (600 rpm?) because
the gap around the plate is too big and not enough vacuum is generated;
so the engine doesn't get any fuel. When the engine cools off enough, 
the cold-start injector comes on, the engine starts up, and this engine 
speed (~1000 rpm) generates enough of a vacuum to pull the plate up.

Does anyone else have a problem starting when the engine is warm? Could
it be the above situation? What's the solution?
Help!! It's very frustrating/embarrassing when your car, which has a
reputation for precision and quality, and was running just fine 1/2 hour
ago, won't even START.

Thanks in advance!
- --
``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````
Stefan Reitshamer      sreit@ctp.com       Cambridge Technology Partners, Inc.
                                           304 Vassar St., Cambridge, MA   USA
                                           (617) 374 8371
``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````

Date: 25 May 94 10:41:32 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Scotland Yard 968

Re Scotland Yard evaluating a 968 --
 
Cops all over the world will use any excuse to scam bigger guns and faster
cars from the taxpayers. It's a power thing. Other than going faster than
anybody else on the M1, what earthly use would a 968 be? Do they intend to
shoot it out, wheel to wheel, with the "perps?" Or force them off the road?
A little hard on the 968; you can only do this trick once or twice per car.
 
Even in California, home of the high speed chase (at least according to
Hollywierd) the CHP just follow along, taking turns at keeping the suspect
in sight, until he runs out of gas. The highway patrol will only force a car
off the road if it is clearly an immediate hazard to persons ahead, and that
is very rare even in high speed chases. CHP can also commandeer trucks to
block a road in very serious cases.
 
The worst incidents here happen when amateur police, like the U.S. Border
Patrol, take it upon themselves to chase people. We had a case last year in
which 6 persons were killed while walking along a city sidewalk in Fallbrook
or Temecula, I forget which, a good 60 miles from the border, while the
border patrol was chasing a car full of illegals. And the idiotic thing is,
I can hire 20 illegals to work in my garden, any day, every day, just by
going to a certain corner and offering work. Everybody in town knows which
corner, even the border patrol (question -- who does their gardening?)
 
Pete

Date: 25 May 94 10:41:57 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Rather have a Tercel??

Hi, Ted.
 
I have a better idea. We wait another 32 years and then accept your
challenge. Our 356s will probably still be running. The Q45 will almost
certainly not. Even if parts go out of production on the 356, we can damn
near make anything ourselves. ("Made by blacksmiths, for blacksmiths"?).
There isn't a single item on the car that can't be bought or made by a
reasonably handy person or a conventional machine shop. You cannot say that
of any modern car; they're far too complex.
 
I predict that in ten to fifteeen years, you will have to search the
junkyards for wrecked cars to replace any failed electronic components;
the car will have depreciated so much that it will no longer be cost
effective to pay the dealer price on any electronic parts they may still
care to stock. And God help you if you got the electronic suspension. (How
many Citroens do you still see on the road, here or in France? And that was
only hydraulic everything, not electronic). And I love their ads with the
smug guy with British accent, telling us how wonderful their new multiplex
wiring system is. Think about that: instead of using somthing simple which
even the home mechanic can replace, like some plastic-covered copper going
to a connector on a bulb socket or whatever, they now have to make the bulb
socket recognize that there is a signal coming down the common wire intended
for it and it alone; behold the birth of the microprocessor-controlled light
bulb. Wanna guess on cost or availability when (not if) a socket fails?
 
We can see the same situation today in the 928. Take a 1978 928; worth maybe
8-10K. It doesn't take many 928 parts at Porsche prices to add up to the value
of the car; at that point you build a good relationship with a junkyard, lay
in a supply of parts and parts cars, or off the thing.
 
I'm not saying the Q45 or 928 is a bad car. Of the current Japanese top-end
cars, I like the Infinity most of all, as it comes closest to the BMW
7-series in feel. And I might someday buy a really old, cheap 928, knowing
full well what sort of parts problems await me. But for survivability, you
can't top an old, low-tech car built in reasonable numbers, like a 356. Or
early Mustang. Or Beetle. etc.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 25 May 94 10:41:52 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: 356 Misc.

Hi, Bob.
 
I think the bevel gears are welded to the recliner stampings. I never tried
to unrivet or unweld any.
 
I'm told that when they start slipping like that, it's time to scour the
junkyards for other examples. Take a Friday off and come up north to Bill
Perrone's "The Parts Shop" in Huntington Beach, and Aase Bros. Porsche
dismantling operation in Anaheim. Give a call; I might be free and we can
make it a Porsche parts kind of day.
 
Is everything tight when you reassemble the mechanisms? Did you clean and
grease the thrust washer between the recliner stampings and tighten up the
retaining nut with a drift and hammer (not so cool) or make a special
spanner (about 15 minutes work with hacksaw, file, vise, and 1/2 x 1/8
cold-rolled flat stock)? Was the thrust washer still intact? They used brass
shim stock washers for a long time, finally going to plastic rings at the
very end. Which do you have? The plastic often deteriorates so badly and
falls out that many people never realize there was anything in there.
I have extra plastic rings here, which I
made myself. I loaned my spanner wrench to Thomas Pocius, the
address you have. My seat occasionally slips back one notch, under very hard
cornering. I have learned to live with it. Also in slaloms it seems to rattle
my codriver, John-who-beats-me-by-more-than-a-second, more than it rattles me,
and now I need all the help I can get <g>. Maybe yours is worse. If the seat
recliner halves have too much play (nut not tight) that may be the cause of
the seats slipping back. You want them to have a good amount of friction
when you try to move them by hand (recliners off the seat, helical spring
unhooked); keep tightening nut with spanner until halves move smoothly but
firmly. Remember that even if it feels too stiff, it's probably OK, that's a
very powerful spring that will later overcome the friction. Then rehook
spring. Wear safety glasses. I clamp the
recliner in a vise with wooden blocks, then use needle-nose Vise-Grips to
pull the spring in. The way I clamp it, even if the spring comes out, it
won't fly out of the vise jaws. I have photos showing how this is done;
should I send them down? You can return them when done.
 
Replace with Konis. Red Konis set full soft are probably too soft. Set full
hard I don't like the ride on freeway hop sections. Halfway between is
perfect for me. Occasionally there are deals on Konis, check the ads in Pano.
 
There is nothing special about the 050 distributor except that Pellow
recommends it; it's cheap, readily available and a fair functional
replacement for original. It's close to the advance curve of the 022, which
I think is what you should have. The 009 is too far off. But 050 parts are
hard to find -- points and cap; rotor is OK I think. If you have a stock
distributor, and it isn't worn, keep it. If you need it checked, let me
know, I can have a company with test equipment give it a diagnostic. Minor
problems may be repairable. Does your distributor appear to have a black
cast iron housing or a bright aluminum one? There should be an oval tag
on the visible part of the housing, with a Bosch number on it
(9 xxx xxx xxx). The last three digits are the number used to refer to it.
 
The stack of donuts are bump stops. Autocrossers frequently cut off the top
donut. These are still available new or repro, I forget which. Try Bill
Perrone again. Also Brad Ripley at NLA Ltd. has them, part 695 333 311 00,
also special bolt 695 333 513 00. Cost $68.10 and $12.65 respectively. Brad
is at 1-800-438-8119. You need his catalog. Tell him I said Hi.
 
By this time you probably also need to replace the rubber donuts inside the
rear trailing arms. Don't get the hard plastic stuff that Twinks sells. The
correct rubber parts are available. There are two different moldings, late
cars and all the rest. I think there are VW parts that fit our C models. Do
you need to set the ride height of the rear trailing arms? There is a very
easy way to do this, but the trick is that you have to pull the arms out far
enough to clear the bottom rear of the 4 threaded bosses for holding the
cover, otherwise the arm will rest on this and give a false reading.
With the rear on jackstands, pull out just far enough so the arm swings
down, past the boss for the bolt. Use a bubble protractor to find the angle
of droop. This is arbitrary, since you haven't set the car level, but it's
all you need for a baseline measurement. Write it down. Now you can play
with the splines on the torsion bars to fiddle with the angle, in 50
minute increments, to raise or lower the car. This is sometimes called
"decambering" (assuming of course you don't set the rear so high that you
get positive camber). Set both sides to the same angle, or if you want to
get fancy, you can even do some "weight jacking" by setting the left side
with a bit more droop so the car will ride level with only you in it.
 
There is a Porsche junkyard in National City, just up the street and
visible from Lemon Grove Plating. I have never dealt with them. Might be
worth a visit though. It's small. Let me know what you think of the
operation, is it good, honest, etc.
 
There is probably a good VW parts place near you, but if not I've had very
good experiences with a place near my house, Kymco. They're knowledgable and
honest and have never steered me or my VW-owning friends wrong. Kymco is at
2121 Harbor Blvd., Costa Mesa, CA   tel. 714-642-1835
 
I found my old posting on recliner assembly and sent it to your private E-mail.
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 25 May 1994 08:59:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: ero@netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: re:subwoofer box

I just caught the tale end of the sub woofer box request.If your 
referring to the ad for the sub woofer that sits on the floor behind the 
front seats for a 911, After I saw the ad I built one myself, the problem 
I ran into was it restricted the distance I could move the seats back. It 
wasn't too much of a problem for the drivers seat because I don't move it 
back all the way, the problem was the passenger seat. I was really cramp, 
I'm 5'8'' and couldn't stretch my legs out. I built the box as narrow as 
possible.I opted to remove the back seats and build an enclosure there. 
the top of the enclosure is the same height as the seats were and the 
woofers face the back of the front seats, allowing me to still put things 
in the back. It also looks pretty stock since you can't see the speakers.
ero@netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 May 94 8:55:19 PDT
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: early ignition parts

Well, I really wanted to add to the Toyota discussion (Ted, you asked
for it, you got it!), but if you can't say anything nice......

But the more pertinant comment is about rotors.  I consider using
parts other than factory when I beleive the quality is comparable
and the price is better, and in fact have a one of the less expensive
non rev limiting rotors in my '70T.  I won't do that again.  I always
figured that I'm smart enough to watch the tach and not over rev the
engine, but at the two days I spent at the driving school last month
I was so focused on driving that I couldn't watch any of the gauges.
I was trying to figure out which way was straight ahead!  The exercises
and the courses were set up in a way which didn't require much if any
shifting to minimize the stuff us rookies had to learn at one time, but
I know that if I were to auto-x the car that over reving could be a real
possibility and some type of rev limiter would be one less thing for
me to worry about.  I'll be buying a different rotor before I go back.

It was at the driving school that I really began to appreciate the design
of the Porsche.  My car is in pretty decent shape with a recent motor
rebuild, but it's still 24 years old.  I drove the car 45 miles each way
for two days, to go to the school, drove the car harder than I ever thought
I would (or could), and then drove it to work the next day.  We have 5 cars
and the Porsche is probably only car I would consider "treating" to this
kind of use/abuse with minimal fear of breaking. 

Mark

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 May 1994 10:35:02 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Matsumura <tedm@rahul.net>
Subject: Re: Jumping the Gun...

Scott,
  I'd recommend looking at '78 on 911 SC's, they have rust proof bodies 
(as do '76 and later 911s), and have the reliable 3.0 litre engine and 
wider wheel flares than pre '88 911s.

The older 911's can be made reliable, but only with an upgrade to the 
3.0l engine.  There are some good books on 911 out there, 911 Performance 
book by Bruce Anderson, and Used 911 buyer's guide by Peter Zimmereman, 
both available at Automotion, a great place for books, but questionable 
place for authentic replacement parts...

Good luck,

Ted

From: Drew A. Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Spring replacement on an RS America



Since it looks like we need a break from the Tercel and police car
threads, I'll offer up a question...

on my RS America and have some time to burn this weekend...

My question is:

   Other than marking and measuring to get the alignment "close
   enough" to get it to the alignment shop, are there any other issues
   I should be concerned about?

I was hoping to be able to perform the spring replacement without 

having to remove the entire strut, but my mechanic advises that this
is probably the easiest route to take. I have a spring compressor
available to avoid eating the spring as the upper perch is removed.

Any opinions/ideas would be greatly appreciated...

Date: 25 May 94 19:26:28 GMT
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 951 on Steroids

>From: dougie@physics.att.com (Douglas Dykaar)
>Subject: 951 at Sears pt(?)

>I forgot who mentioned the non S 951 with 255/40 and 275/40-17s, but:

>I would like to find out who they were. what school? what region? HELP!

>Doug Dykaar

Doug:

I wrote last week about this 951.  The car was very mean-looking wearing these 
tires.  The fronts might have been 255/35.  I'll check.  It was race-prepped 
with Cool Carbons/Rollcage/harnesses.  It had very nice seats (not Sport 
seats; black with suede-like finish) with huge side and thigh bolsters which I 
believe were an option on the '89 Speedsters.  I didn't get a chance to speak 
with the owner but I overheard it was putting out 350 horsies. 
I'll see how it does this weekend at NNJR's driver's ed event at Pocono 
Raceway.

A few months ago, European Car had an article on a similarly shod 951 with NOS. 
I'll dig it up and post details if you like.  On a related topic, isn't there 
an optimum tire size for given output/suspension/layout etc?  I would think 
above that optimal point, rolling resistance would negate the extra grip and 
actually slow you down.  Anyone care to elaborate?

____________________________________________________________________________ 
Steve Jagernauth	     '87 951 Black (Sunny days, Track, AutoX) 
AT&T Global Network Design   '87 Audi 5000CST 
Bridgewater, NJ 



					    
                                   

------------------------------

Date: 25 May 94 19:34:36 GMT
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 924S vs 944S

>From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU> 

>I can tell you where it is on a '87 944S.  What I dont know is how 
>similar the engines are.  Can someone clarify the difference 
>between 924S and 944S?  Did all 924's (including the S) have that 
>'VW' engine? 

>Darren 

Your 944S is the 16-valve 2.7L version of the base 2.5L 944 engine found in 
'87 & '88 924S (not to be confused with Audi-derived 924 of 70's-'82).  The 
924S has all 944 drivetrain components, is lighter and faster than base 944 
and is supposedly the most aerodynamic road-going Porsche produced to date.

____________________________________________________________________________ 
Steve Jagernauth	     '87 951 Black (Sunny days, Track, AutoX) 
AT&T Global Network Design   '87 Audi 5000CST 
Bridgewater, NJ

------------------------------

Date: 	Wed, 25 May 1994 14:34:26 PDT
From: "William M. York" <york@parc.xerox.com>
Subject: Re: 911SC won't start when warm (sometimes)

   Date:	Wed, 25 May 1994 07:08:15 -0700
   From:	Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>

   If I drive the car for at least 1/2 hour, park it for at least 1/2 hour,
   then try to start it, sometimes it won't start. Not even one sputter.
   It just cranks and cranks without ever firing. If I try it again 
   10 min - 1/2 hour later, it starts just fine!!
   Why??

This same kind of problem was discussed a while back so you might want
to check the archives.

On my '76 911, a similar set of symptoms was cured by replacing the
fuel pump check valve, basically a device that keeps pressure in the
fuel system after the pump is turned off.

If you don't get a definite diagnosis, definitely try replacing this
before other, more expensive repairs (such as the new warm-up
regulator that my mechanic sold me).

------------------------------

To any 928 owners && / || mechanics :

I would like to replace the front brake pads on my '86 928.

Is changing the pads on the 928 a more complicated procedure ?

Is there anything signifcant about the prodedure that I should know ?

Do I need any special tools ?

Should I fork out big $ and have it done at the dealership ?

{possibly from a service manual} ?

As an aside :

I had a vacuum leak in the vacuum control bladder on the control near the
upper ventalation port above the colsole.
I simply removed the vacuum line and pluged it.
The leak was causing a very high pitched whine at various temperature
combinations, i.e. cold outside <-> warm inside, hot outside <-> any
temperature inside.

have ?

Is this a really neccessary control ?

Will I die if it is not connected ?

Porschephiles #760                         Fri May 27 02:10:39 CDT 1994
Date: 25 May 1994 21:46:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Derek van Veen <VANVEEND@CGSVAX.CLAREMONT.EDU>
Subject: Re: V8-engined 912

I dunno...does anyone else kinda view this as some sort of blasphemy?  I feel
the same way about this as I do about the joker who put a SAAB 16V engine in
his Volkswagen Type III Squareback.  Maybe I'm old fashioned, but I think that
an aircooled car should have an aircooled engine--regardless!

On the other hand, dropping a 3.0 litre or bigger 911 engine in the sucker
would turn a lot of heads--and snap a few transaxles as well.

 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: 25 May 1994 21:52:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Derek van Veen <VANVEEND@CGSVAX.CLAREMONT.EDU>
Subject: Scotland Yard 968

I remember hearing about what the German police used to do back when there
were problems with terrorism (post-1973).  If you were speeding and didn't
pull over, they wouldn't try to run you off the road, they would simply
set up a roadblock with a couple of machine guns and wait for you...I guess
people only made that mistake once.

Mind you, this is a second-hand story, so the original teller might have been
exaggerating, but seeing as how the guards in the airports are all young kids
with submachine guns, it wouldn't suprise me.

Actually, when you think about it, its a safer way of doing things, since it
doesn't involve innocent people.

 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 04:40:00 UTC
From: w.oconnell4@genie.geis.com
Subject: 993 stuff

We were given a 993 model introduction tonight at Holbert's Porsche for our
monthly meeting.  The local zone sales and tech reps were there to chat.
 Some interesting facts (at least to me):
  This cosidered the perfect 911.
  The car will probably be made till at least the end of the century.
  The under 60k price is not an intro low ball which will shoot up soon.
  The US gets about 300 a month and sells about 500 - something they have
     not seen for a few years.
  The 'average' out the door sticker will be in the low 60s.
  In most markets, there will be some discount but they don't expect anyone
     to 'whore' them out, nor do they expect any outlandish over sticker $.
 Along with the 993's, Holberts put out a display of cars from 356 to now.
One that seemed to catch everyone's eye was a '93 911 Turbo S - fly yellow
(no flames, I don't know the "correct" Porsche color name).  The very last
of the '93 911 run was the Turbo S and 50 came here.  They carried a sticker
of about 127k and while some were slant nose models, most were the 'pure'
style.  Amoung some of the differences were 959 ducts in the rear fenders,
special tail, 18" 3 piece wheels and '25' additional hp.  Why '25'?  Well,
any more and the motor had to be re-certified.  The very unofficial response
to hp was - "Is it more like 400 hp?" "Ja, you could say that very easily"
this, btw, from the factory, not the PCNA people.
 
Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA
 81 SC Pacific Blue - Die Luft-Keule fur Manner

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 09:42:03 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: 928 Clutch Job

Avery,

>I want to thank all of you for your experience and wisdom which helped me
>on making a wise decision.
>
>Next question is does $1,600 sound too much for a clutch job for a '79
>928?  I've seen kits in magazines advertising clutch kits for 928s for
>about $400.  How hard is it to do yourself?  Even if it would take a full
>weekend to do the job saving $1,200 sound pretty good to me.
>
If you get the kit for $400, and has the possibility to save $1200 by doing 
it yourself, go ahead and do it!! I'm not even sure how the 928 clutch job 
is, but with the right tools this could be a nice weekend.
The 928 has the gearbox in the rear and therefore only the tunnel with the 
intermediate shaft should be removed.(right???)

Be sure to get hold of the clutch alignment tool. It'll save you a lot of 
swearing!! i'm myself using the 'pinion-shaft' (transformed from 
Norwegian...sp=??) from an old Transporter(VW van) for this task.Much 
cheaper, and also more precise than the tool! 

I can't give you more advices as I haven't done this myself on a Porsche, 
but I've changed the clutch on a handful of Alfa GTV's with the same 
engine-gearbox layout. you can do it!

cheers,
trond


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 10:10:43 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Rebuillt wheelcylinders

Hi,

Just a short note on rebuilding front wheelcylinders for the 356's.

Yesterday I was finished rebuilding, my front brake assemblies. What I did 
was: stripping all parts, washing with methanol, honing (?) the wheel 
cylinders and installing new rubber. Painting the backing plates, inatalling 
new 'connector line' between upper and lower cylinder. The assemblies look 
good, and I'm really eager to put them on the car. 

ATE has rebuild sets for the wheel cylinders, I have the part # somewhere if 
interested. After honing the clearance between the piston and wall was .15 
to .20mm and the specification allowed for maximum 0.26.(ATE spec.) 

I rebuillt 8 wheel cylinders for the cost of $50. I took the '60 T-5's too, 
these were stuck, but with the grease gun connected to the brake line's 
inlet, the pistons came out nice.

Does anyone know the limit for rebuilding the brake shoes?

Is the rear wheel cylinders exchangeable with VW ones? Which?

cheers,
trond

Rain pours down, so my '58 will be happy tonight.... :)
  


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 10:38:36 +0200
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: ride height for a 911

I've been told that one can adjust the ride height of the car
by measuring the distance from the wheel arches to the ground.
The distance should be 25.5" front and 25" rear.

The question I have is whether I should take into account the weight
of the driver. In autocrossing and track events there is never anyone
in the passenger seat...


P.S. Even Sweden has a history of Porsche police cars. In late 60's
(and early 70's?) the police drove some 912's and 911's. 

Today, they drive nothing more exotic that Volvo's and Saab's...

Magnus
'82 911 SC

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 10:07:49 BST
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: P-prices


| Another question: All the types listed above,
| do they all come with steering on the right
| side when sold in England

All new Porsche models are shipped in the UK with the steering
on the right. even exotica such as the 911 Turbo S and 911 Carrera
RS 3.8 are RHD I think.

I don't know what proportion of all Porsche are RHD, but
I don't suppose that it is huge.


Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 07:20:30 -0500
From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
Subject: 914 battery tray replacement

Pete,
With a screwdriver, poke the sheetmetal underneath and a little forward of
the battery tray. On my car, this had assumed the consistency of peanut
brittle. 
I  removed the old tray with a chisel (careful, don't make a hole in the
wheel-well) and cleaning up the remains with a grinder.
This may be unacceptably low-tech, but you might consider pop-riveting the
battery tray into place (no one will notice). If you rivet, you can just
unbolt the brain from the battery tray, and set it aside, but leave its
electrical connections intact.  Eastwood (see FAQ?) sells some rubbery
battery-tray coating that worked well for me. Also, always have a cover
over your battery to shed rain. 
Michael

------------------------------

Date: 26 May 1994 09:53:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Andrew J. Toth" <TOTHAND@hsdwl.utc.com>
Subject: Re: 914 battery tray replacement


Pete,

| 
| I need to replace the battery tray on my 75 914 and would be interested in 
| hearing the
| experiences of anyone who has done this (or had it done for them).
| How complicated a task is this?

It ranges from not very complicated through "part it out".

| To remove the old tray, are the welds drilled out?

The welds can be drilled out, but only if the mounting points still
exist.  I've seen some pretty rusted battery trays.

| What specific areas should I inspect when looking for rust/acid damage in 
| the body
| below the battery?

Thoroughly inspect (visually) the area around the battery.  Sometimes,
the sheetmetal which makes up the inside of the right rear wheel well
is damaged, which will have to be repaired before the new tray is installed.
Also, check the area under the tray:  the right engine shelf.  Usually, this
area is damaged (remember, water flows downhill).  From there, the acidic
water settles into either the right console or the longitudinal.  The console
is the inner tab used to mount the trailing arm.  Check the console and the
longitudinal both visually, and with a hammer.  Light to moderate taps with
a hammer will help disclose any damage in this area.  The hammer blow will
either make a dull "thud" or penetrate the metal if there is damage in this 
area.  

| If I remember right, the ECM mounts to the battery tray support bracket.  Do 
| I need to
| disconnect/remove the ECM before welding in the new tray to prevent $$$ up 
| in smoke?

YES!  YES!  YES!  Remove the ECM before you start any work in this area.

| Any information appreciated.
| 

Not to scare you Pete, but you may want to be prepared for what may lie
ahead.  In the best case, you may just have to replace the tray.  In
the worst case...well...I'll tell you about a car I parted out.  It was
driven into a garage where it sat for eight years before it was given to
me to dispose of.  I removed the passenger seat, then stepped on the floor
to get over to the driver's seat.  The floor panel collapsed.  "Okay", I
thought, "I'll just step on the door sill to step over."  So I did, and
the car floded neatly in half.  Ooops.  Good thing I had the cutting torch.
I don't believe your car will be that bad, but it's best to inspect it
and take care of any problems now, before they grow.

Good luck, Pete!  Let me know if you need any more info.


						    ajt

- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Andrew J. Toth                             Katana Pilot
    tothand@hsdwl.utc.com                                  ===o&o>

    Speed costs money...how fast do you want to go?
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 08:13:24 TZ
From: Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 928 Clutch Job

avery,

	there are two things to consider when evaluating this price: what
and whose parts are included, and how much labor are they charging you
for?

	first off, you do know this is a two-plate, racing-style clutch, right? ok.

	the parts prices from Porsche for a 928 clutch are about $700 for
the two disks, the pressure plate and t/o bearing. this doesn't include the
intermediate plate, which may or may not need to be replaced, i've been
told. that plate is another $350 from Porsche. so if they are including the
i-plate, and charging you full retail, that leaves about  10-13 hours labor,
depending on labor charge. so i'd say its high, but in the ballpark.

	the $400 clutch kits you see are generally sachs components,
which, rumor has it, is what the EuroSelect parts are, in this application.
you still might have to fork over $300 bucks for an i--plate, if yours 
is scored.
so you should be able to save somewhere between $1100 and 800
by doing it yourself, and from my reading of the manual, it will take a
whole weekend!

	as you might have guessed, my '79 928 has started asking
for a new clutch, so i've been researching this while i save up the
required number of dimes.

						jim

------------------------------

Date: 26 May 1994 08:49:04 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: Swedish cars

        Reply to:   Swedish cars

>>Today, they drive nothing more exotic that Volvo's and Saab's...

> Not to us, but I'll bet our American friends find these cars 'exotic' and 
> qualified as status symbols, or what?

Well, sort of.  Drivers of Volvos are thought to be (overly) concerned
about safety, not particularly automotive-minded, certainly not
enthusiasts.  But careful, conscientious people.

Saab owners are thought to be a little quirky, like the cars (but not as
quirky as say, Morgan owners).  Individualists.  Independent-minded.
Somewhat enthusiastic about cars and very loyal to Saabs (as we are
about Porsches).

Swedish cars are expensive so owners are thought to be reasonably
well-off.  But status-symbol types tend to go for M-B's,  BMW's, and
high-end Japanese cars.

I've probably offended someone here.  Sorry.  Just my opinions, of
course, based on what I see in CA & NY.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 10:47:21 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; V8 Porsches, 928 clutch job

 
     1. Chevy V8 in 912; putting the motor in front is new to me, the
        first I heard of anybody mixing Detroit and Zuffenhausen was 
        in the late 70's, in a hot-rod mag where a guy stuck a Chevy
        302 (from a Z-28) in an early 911S. The article showed the beast
        at speed at Riverside. Both car and speedway and apparently driver
        r.i.p., I heard a few years later from a  907-team mechanic
        (Ken Rosegay) that the driver killed himself in that car. 'Course
        maybe I'm  confusing that with the guy who put wings on his Gremlin 
        and killed himself flying it.
         Since then I guess everyone has seen the twin-turbo Chevy/914,
        928 powered 914, etc. etc. Seems like a terrible waste of the 912 and
        the Chevy motor to me, abandoned V8 Vegas or hot-rod bugs are a lot
        more common and probably better engineered...
                      
          Oh, don't forget that Detroit and Porsche did collaborate on 
        a production car---the 4 cylinder AMC Gremlin. Motor is the same
        as the 924 motor, except the Gremlin was carb'd instead of FI'd.
        If you have a 924, you can get the same hard parts cheaper for your
        Gremlin. Just don't race that Levis Gremlin for pink slips, though--
        he probably has a 6-cylinder motor and could blow your doors off.
        I suppose that bell-housings and etc might somehow link up, if you
        wanted to put the 6-cylinder AMC motor in your 924. But putting 
        Nitrous in a Chevette may mean more...

     2. Clutch job in 928; You are in luck, this isn't so bad. Unlike the
        924/944, you don't need to retract the torque tube, etc. Drop the 
        exhaust, remove the shield pans, the torque tube has a collar shaft
        that slips back away from the clutch (allen-headed bolts hold it
        at either end). The clutch drops out of the bottom of the bell        
        housing, you can get to everything pretty well. Definitely the 
        easiest Porsche to replace a clutch in, in fact easier than 
        probably about any car.

        Good luck ! Lee   '79 928 and other twisted wreckage

Date: 26 May 1994 09:46:06 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Bay Area Porsche Monstrosit

Bay Area Porsche Monstrosities
To give us some relief from 356 vs. Tercel:
    I recently spotted a pair of local (SF Bay Area) commercials that
had Porsches in them.  Good, you say, more P-cars on TV!  Not so.  The
Porsches in question had been un-mercifully butchered by some body
shop.  Sigh.
    One was an ad for a limousine company.  They had a Turbo-body 911
STRETCH limo in white!  Ouch.  I think it was even a cabrio.
    The other was for one of the "motorcycle lawyers" we have around
here.  To prove that he was a real biker, too, they had a few shots of
him riding on the highway with some other bikes.  Except his "bike" was
a three-wheeler.  In fact, it was the rear end of a 914, with the pas-
senger compartment cut down into a triangle with a single seat, and a
handlebar/shock/wheel arrangement up at the front!  Made me wince, see-
ing what they'd done to the poor little red beastie!  Sniff.
    So, you locals, if'n you see these guys out on the road, thumb your
nose at 'em for me, will ya?

- --Dave D.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 11:24:37 +0500
From: Barry Chapin 617-258-2809 <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: RE: 911SC won't start when warm (sometimes)

>>Date: Wed, 25 May 94 10:08:15 EDT
>From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
>Subject: 911SC won't start when warm (sometimes)

>If I drive the car for at least 1/2 hour, park it for at least 1/2 hour,
>then try to start it, sometimes it won't start. Not even one sputter.
>It just cranks and cranks without ever firing. If I try it again 
>10 min - 1/2 hour later, it starts just fine!!
>Why??

Hey Scott,

I have a 1981 911SC Targa with the same problem.  I have been told that it
may be a few things.  First, I was told it might be the warm-up regulator.
I ordered one and installed it, drove for 20-20 minutes, shut off the engine
waited 15-20 minutes, but the problem persisted.
 
When the engine starts fine when cold, but not when warm, that it may be the 
fuel pump.  There is a check valve in the fuel pump which prevents the fuel 
from flowing backwards into the tank when you shut off the engine.  If this
valve is bad, when the engine is hot, the fuel system runs leaner and the fuel
will flow back into the tank, thus there is no fuel in the lines, and the
engine will not start (right away).  There are two ways to test if this is
the problem.

#1:  The harder way: start the car when cold, drive 20 minutes, and right
when you shut off the engine, have a friend clamp the rubber fuel line
just on the engine side of the fule line, right at the point where the fuel
exits the pump.  By clamping the line, this traps the fuel in the line to
the injectors (what the check valve should do).  Wait 20 minutes, then have
your friend remove the clamp just as you try to start the car.  If it starts,
you need to replace the fuel pump (about $200 for my '81 911).  

#2:  The other way to see if you fuel pump check valve is not stopping the
backwards flow of fuel after stopping the engine is to run the car 20
minutes.  Shut it off, and wait 20 minutes.  Then try to start the car.
But wait, it should not start right?  Well, not right away - This is the
problem that you are having correct?  Yes, but let the starter crank for
30 seconds or so.  Yes - this does beat on the starter, and the battery.
But is you keep trying the starter, letting it crank for 10 seconds, then
off for a half second, and try asgain, and keep doing this, if it starts
in about 30 seconds (or one long 30-40 second crank), then you prpobably
need a new fuel pump.  Pumping the gas pedal usually helps to start it quicker.
What is taking place is that the pump is sucking air out of the lines.  Once
the fuel (which ran back to the tank when you shut off the engine hot for 20
minutes) goes all the way back up to the fuel pump, and into the injectors,
the engine starts.  Pumping the gas peddle opens up the injectors to let 
out the trapped air.  Thus, until you get you fuel pump and put it in, 
this method should always work when you are in the no start situation.

I just put a new pump in mine, I have not tried to start it yet, as the car
is in the shop for other things.  I hope this solves the problem.  I could
always start mine with my method #2.  I hope the pump is the problem for
me, but it seems to make sense.  

>I'm told that there was once a problem with the airflow sensor's diaphragm 
>falling below the bottom of its housing (crude ASCII diagram):
>

Yes, this too could be the problem.  I would try method #1 to see if it is
the pump for sure, if method #2 does start the car.
The sensor plate height measures the air entering the engine.  The upper
edge of the plate must be even with the narrowest part of the air cone.
I have not checked this, nor have I tried to adjust it on mine, since my
fuel line tests have seemed to isolate the problem.  I believe you need 
a special tool to adjust this plate height.

>Does anyone else have a problem starting when the engine is warm? Could
>it be the above situation? What's the solution?
>Help!! It's very frustrating/embarrassing when your car, which has a
>reputation for precision and quality, and was running just fine 1/2 hour
>ago, won't even START.

Yes it can be embarrasing.  Especially when you are on a date.
Hope this helps.

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
Engineer	Draper Laboratory, Cambridge, MA
1981 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 94 10:33:18 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  914 battery tray replacement

Pete,

While you are at it, crawl under the car and check out the mounts for the
rear trailing arm.  The one under the battery (especially the inboard 'tab')
get a good deal of the acid and often rust/weaken.  A sizable fix to do, 
but the other option is the trailing arm being set free.

Pat Norris

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 12:11:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Matsumura <tedm@rahul.net>
Subject: Re: Rather have a Third World War!

Date: 26 May 1994 17:52:42 -0500
From: "Sarah Sprafka" <sallys@kccgw.com.msu.edu>
Subject: 911's and SO's

                       Subject:                               Time:5:41 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          911's and SO's                         Date:5/26/94
John Butler quotes:  "A wise man once said:

"Under no circumstances should a person with a Porsche marry a person who
doesn't like Porsches without 1st executing a pre-nuptial agreement that
contains very specific language concerning the disposition of said Porsche in
the event of divorce."
That reminds me of an apparently true story told me by an investment broker
(and P-car enthusiast) of my acquaintance.  Apparently a friend of his bought a
911 (1980's vintage, but don't know exactly what year) for $500.00...that's
right five hundred dollars!  You guessed it.  It was a situation where the wife
(or ex-wife) "got the Porsche" with instructions to "sell it for whatever you
can get for it" and the arrangement was to split the proceeds.  And she did. 
Here's your $250.00, honey,  and good riddance.  OUCH.  BTW, the prenuptial
agreement idea would probably apply equally well to women P-philes who might
mixed up with a man who doesn't like Porsches.  It may be hard to imagine, but
there are men who don't like Porsches.

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 16:24:12 -0700
From: leedsg@halcyon.com (Leeds Gulick)
Subject: Re: 911SC won't start when warm (sometimes)

>   Date:        Wed, 25 May 1994 07:08:15 -0700
>   From:        Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
>
>   If I drive the car for at least 1/2 hour, park it for at least 1/2 hour,
>   then try to start it, sometimes it won't start. Not even one sputter.
>   It just cranks and cranks without ever firing. If I try it again 
>   10 min - 1/2 hour later, it starts just fine!!
>   Why??
>
>This same kind of problem was discussed a while back so you might want
>to check the archives.
>
>On my '76 911, a similar set of symptoms was cured by replacing the
>fuel pump check valve, basically a device that keeps pressure in the
>fuel system after the pump is turned off.
>
>If you don't get a definite diagnosis, definitely try replacing this
>before other, more expensive repairs (such as the new warm-up
>regulator that my mechanic sold me).

I have had the same problem on a 1980 911SC that was also cured with a fuel
pump check valve.  Some models had the valve included with the pump while
others had the valve separately attached to the end of the pump.  Even if
yours is integrated into the fuel pump you can buy the separate unit and
add it on.  You will then have one functional valve and one non-functional
valve and you don't have to purchase an expensive fuel pump.

Leeds Gulick

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 16:52:24 -0700
From: leedsg@halcyon.com (Leeds Gulick)
Subject: Re: Spring replacement on an RS America

>Since it looks like we need a break from the Tercel and police car
>threads, I'll offer up a question...
>
>I've recently purchased a set of springs to replace the stock set
>on my RS America and have some time to burn this weekend...
>
>My question is:
>
>   Other than marking and measuring to get the alignment "close
>   enough" to get it to the alignment shop, are there any other issues
>   I should be concerned about?
>
>I was hoping to be able to perform the spring replacement without 
>
>having to remove the entire strut, but my mechanic advises that this
>is probably the easiest route to take. I have a spring compressor
>available to avoid eating the spring as the upper perch is removed.
>
>Any opinions/ideas would be greatly appreciated...

The rear struts definitely have to be removed to replace the springs (not
too tough except for reaching back to those upper strut nuts behind the
engine), but you can do the fronts without totally removing the strut from
the car.  The problem with removing the front struts (besides requiring a
realignment) is that the brake lines go through a plate on the strut and
have to be disconnected (entailing a brake bleed) or you can cut a notch
through the side of the plate so that the brake line can be slid out after
removing the retaining spring that holds the brake line coupling to the
plate.

What I have done with my RS America and now my 993 is to detach the strut
top from the car body, pivot the strut out of the fender well, remove the
strut top bearing from the strut, and replace the spring.  But first you
must disconnect the front sway bar (easiest while the car is level so there
is no preload) to allow the suspension to pivot downward.  The only thing
that restricts the strut from pivoting outward easily is the length of the
brake line.  To allow a little more slack in the brake line, it helps to
remove the brake line retaining clip from the brake line holding plate on
the strut, play with the steering wheel to rotate the strut into a more
favorable position, and to tilt the strut slightly toward the front of the
car.  Be careful not to damage the outer edge of the fender.  


Leeds Gulick

Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 17:17:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: Clark Wallace <SAVE@CPVA.SAIC.COM>
Subject: Re: 944 Fuel Gauge

Darin queries:

>How do I set my tire pressures to minimize understeer in my '86 MkI MR2?

I've read somewhere that one procedure involves chalking the tire (sidewall
down onto the tread) at 90 degrees interval around the circumference and
then take the car out for some "spirited" driving.  The ideal tire pressure is
determined when the chalk marks are rubbed off only to the edge of the tread
pattern (ie, sidewall marks still inplace).  

Clark

------------------------------

Date: 26 May 94 17:44:00 -0500
From: ANTHONY.KELLEY%MSFC2PO@x400gw.msfc.nasa.gov
Subject: Motronic Warning

forwarded message from ken house:

This note is a caution to those people who are retrofitting a 3.2l  Carrera 
engine into an earlier model 911.  i just finished repairing two more DME 
(Motronic) control units that were damaged by incorrect wiring.  The cause 
of this particular failure mode has occurred so frequently that a word of 
warning is warranted.

Scenario: An early model 911 owner/racer buys a 3.2 motor with wiring 
harness and DME control unit, but usually does not buy the tachometer.  
Installation is straight-forward until the wires to the tachometer are 
encountered.  The Motronic tachs are microprocessor-based electronic units 
with two wires coming from the DME unit.  For some reason the wire to pin 
11 of the DME gets connected to a +12 volt line under the dash.  The 
installation gets completed, and the key is turned to start the car --zap-- 
it won't start.  After much time and trouble someone narrows the problem 
down to the DME unit, after a few phone calls they find out that i fix 
DME's and send it to me.

Cause/effect:  Incorrectly putting B+ voltage on pin 11 will BLOW the
proprietary Bosch injection controller chip on the analog board inside the 
DME and render it useless.  The car will turn over with the starter, the 
plugs will spark, the fuel pump will pressurize, but there will be no fuel 
injection.

Reason:   Pin 11 of the DME is an output not an input, it outputs  the fuel
injection pulse width as a 12 volt signal  TO the tach.  The special Bosch 
chip is an analog driver for both the injector stages and the tach.

Repairs:  The repair is easy--replace the chip.  The hard part is to obtain 
replacement chips.  If anyone has a connection to BOSCH to get chips i 
would be interested, or if you have DME problems give me a call.  
- ---------------------------
- --ken house--(800)-752-9574--plans to get an internet line and join pfiles
- ---------------------------

I don't believe the assertion that european cars are designed to require
maintenance and that there's some related, mythical euro-mindset not
understood by americans.

BMW prides itself on self-maintaining and low-maintaining cars.

If a euro car can't run on sludge like an american car, then it is of 
course lower quality engineering.

Let the discussion begin! :)

be because it 'looks' better or because of an actual superiority. Why not 
decide which one you like better against your own standards (subjective: 
looks, objective: engine, drivetrain etc) and then worry about the price.

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 12:45:23 +0200
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@lammio.hut.fi>
Subject: Re: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence

>Date: Thu, 26 May 1994 23:40:46 -0700 (PDT)
>From: Bill Ataras <jetfax@crl.com>

stuff deleted

>If a euro car can't run on sludge like an american car, then it is  
>of course lower quality engineering.

You can't be serious with this. A big Detroit V8 runs on sludge for a  
considerable time but a high revving engine built anywhere won't.  
Smaller and more sophisticated engines just simply require proper  
maintenance. And there is a mindset that goes with it - you take care  
of it and get to know your machine and the driving is more rewarding  
after that. I think most americans think cars as consumer goods to be  
fixed at mechanics and discarded when used up.

But let's not generalize too much. I think Stan exaggerated in his  
original comment saying that any european car lasts forever with  
proper maintenance. What about the many pathetic Fiats and others  
whose reliability even the enthusiasts refer to as "character"?

On a more technical side question for the experts. If the 944 sunroof  
goes up and down but refuses to to be disengaged (i.e. cannot be  
removed) is there an obvious reason? A faulty gauge that tells the  
roof is released but where is it? 


Cheers,

Kari Eloranta

84 944 Guards Red

effeciently and enjoyably accomplish the task for which the tool is

is true, and there are even some that are American made (Gasp!...).

don't lose sight of that fact, or insult others for their (different, 
subjective) preferances...  ;>)

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 09:02:09 -0400 (EDT)
From: Douglas Kush <dk4s+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Source for floor mats

Tracy,

I recommend that you buy quality floormats, even if it costs a little
more. I bought some after market mats about a year and a half ago which
are already wearing through by the accelerator pedal. My original
Porsche mats had the heavy duty carpet by the driver's feet and were
still in pretty decent shape after five and a half years. Definitely
wasn't worth the small amount of money I saved.

Doug

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 09:01:34 EDT
From: edd@suneast.East.Sun.COM (Ed DeBarros - Chelmsford Site Human Resources)
Subject: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence




Bill writes:

>I don't believe the assertion that european cars are designed to require
>maintenance and that there's some related, mythical euro-mindset not
>understood by americans.
>BMW prides itself on self-maintaining and low-maintaining cars.


I had a BMW 320i a while back that was everything but self/low
maintaining. My first experience was at the end of a workday when
I went to the BMW dealer service dept. to pick up my car and saw 
the frowns on the faces of a long line of Bimmer owners, checkbooks 
and service contracts in hand, lined up at the cashier window.  

Luckily I found an independent, BMW trained mechanic who was competent,
honest and reputable.  Though the car was generally reliable, frequent
minor problems that occured made the car more demanding than average,
service-wise compared to other cars I have owned.  On the other hand, 
the car was 6 years old when I sold it and felt more solid than any 
6 year old Toyota, Nissan, Chevy, whatever.

The trade-off question, I guess, is, what do you want after 6 years ?
A solid-feeling, well maintained used car or a less solid-feeling 
car that cost less to maintain ?
   

 -ed

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 15:54:18 +0100 (BST)

Here in Britain the Maestro was a horrible (now defunct) car. It's sort of a
British version of a Skoda. 

It is the size of a VW Golf (Rabbit ?) with *none* of the build quality. It
was made by British Layland who became Austin Rover (then Rover and now BMW)
around the early 80s'. If the puny 1.3 liter standard engine did not blow and
the terrible build quality and rattling dash did not force you to sell, then
the poor quality steel would rust instead.

Maybe a Maestro Porsche a fabled Lemon Porsche ?

Who knows

picked up the repainted roof they had neglected to replace all the screws which 
hold the clips in place, which kind of makes me wonder if they have forgotten to
replace any screws while working under the hood!  They claimed, "100% sure" to 
have fixed my 3100rpm noise by replacing the right front motor mount (~$200 
total) and the noise was/is still there.  Now I'm thinking it's an exhaust pipe 
rattling..  Blah, blah, blah.

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 10:19 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: 924 vs. 944

Tracy Meyer (tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov) writes:
> I am contemplating the purchase of an '87 or '88 944 or 924s.  The 924s is 
> about one-half the cost of the 944 in the Washington D.C. area.  My question is:
> What am I getting in the 944 (or giving up in the 924s) that justifies the 
> higher price?  I understand the drivetrain is the same.  There has to be 
> something I am missing.  Any insight would be appreciated.  Thanks in advance.

If you're contemplating the purchase of a water-cooled Porsche, you should
definately get a copy of the Feb '94 issue of _Excellence_ magazine.  It has
a very good article on the purchase of used 924/944/928s.

The 944 does have more horsepower (150 vs. 115), and is (I think) slightly 
bigger.  A list of the good and bad points about each model (from "So You
Want To Buy A Water-Cooled Porsche?" by Jim Pasha, copyright (C) 1993 by
Ross Publications):

924 -- Good points:
"When lowered and aligned properly, they handle as well or beter than their 
contemporaries.  The engines, when maintained and repaired correctly, will
easily give over 150,000 miles of service. The last ones produced had 115 hp.
The bodies were the first designed for electro-plated steel in fabrication and
these bodies have the highest torsional strength of all production Porsches.
The transaxles on the 76-78 cars were somewhat noisy, yet gave excellent
service.  The seat position is excellent and visibility is good.  It has good
fuel economy and service parts for almost all mechanical pieces are
inexpensive."
924 -- Bad points:
"Not as much horsepower as an enthusiast wants, though faster than a 914, 912, 
or 356.  The seats, although among the best on the markey, have durability
problems in the foam inserts, the dashboards crack and the carpet seems to fade
quickly in the sun.  Some maintenance items, like the clutch, are expensive in
labor because of the car design.  The turbo versions aren't highly regarded,
and require more than a little thought before purchase.  Sometimes the
electricals can drive you nuts, but not as badly as a 928.  Brakes work well,
but not up the later Porsche standards."
===
944 -- Good points:
"Much more power than a 924, easier to drive in traffic, still more than a match
for newer, more powerful cars.  When aligned and lowered, it has the potential
to win at the track if equipped with sport suspension.  The 944S2 is still
winning at the track.  Most of the early defects were corrected by the mid-1983
model run, so your major risk is in the quality of maintenance and repair.  An
excellent dollar value, the range is $5,700 to $14,000 for a 944, $12,000 to
$22,000 for a 944S2, and $12,000 to $25,000 for a 944 Turbo" [Note: all prices
are in US$.]
944 -- Bad points:
"The novice cannot perform many of the necessary repairs without a few
expensive or special tools.  These cost a lot of money, so you'd better line up
a mechanic or be ready to buy the tools.  Early cars have the motor mount 
disintegration problem and premature water pump failure syndrome.  The former
can be handled by the knowledgable home mechanic, the latter requires a
flywheel-lock-and-belt-tensioning tool available from most Porsche suppliers
for [US]$450.  As many of the cars have already been through a replacement
cycle, most of these problems should hvae been picked up and fixed."

Sorry this got so long, drop me a line if you'd like a copy of the checklist
I used when I shopped for my 944.

Tracy Nelson
