Date: Fri, 27 May 94 08:45:57 PDT

Subject: Swedish Cars and Engine Swaps


Hi guys,

Swedish cars.......Hmmmm......The only place that safe sex can be 
practiced is in the back seat of a Volvo parked in the garage with 
the seat belts on (for those with REAL excitement on their minds).

Okay, groan a little.

Engine swaps........Let's see..... Mr. Lister used a Jag engine....
Pete Lovely used a Porsche in his Pooper.....Some Texas chicken 
farmer took a long-in-tooth Brit roadster and stuck a Ford in it...
...A couple of guys took a 4-cam Porsche and put it in an Elva....
....Porsche made a deal with a slick Austrian to make an Abarth-
Carrera which was slower than the car the boys at the factory body
shop built.......some guys in So. Cal. have been stuffing Chevys 
into Porsches for 25 years.....A guy named Newman (of spaghetti 
sauce fame) used to run around in a chevy-powered something that had
a VW body grafted over it. 
Engine swaps? No biggie, it's as natural as the Jeep getting new drive
trains each time the company gets sold.

------------------------------

Date: 27 May 94 11:55:32 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: V8-engined 912

Hi, Ted.
 
Ted Matsumura wrote
 
>Is it true that the 912 has weaker transaxles and other parts than a 911?
 
Depends. When it was new, the 911 and first generation 912 had the same
transmission (second generation = 912 E of mid 1970s, built for only 1 year
to bridge gap before 924 came out).  The '65-67 912 used the 902/0 or 902/1;
the 911 used the same transaxle, except the 66 911 S which used
the 901/02. There were other variations, but that's basically it. The 911
eventually went through other, much stronger transmission designs, which
were never installed in the 912 because it was gone by then.
 
The later 911 E used the 923/02 5-speed based on the 915/44 of the 911.
 
Pete

Date: 27 May 94 11:55:52 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: 944 vs. 924S

Tracy Meyer writes
 
>I understand that the drivetrain [of the 924 and 944] is the same.
 
Lots of parts are shared. The 924 S has the same engine as the
944. But the 944 S has more power again. So for 1988 the progression is
924 S -- 944 -- 944 S -- 944 Turbo.
 
The engine used in the 924 S is a Porsche-built engine, also used in the
944; the engine used in the older non-S 924 is a non-Porsche, Audi-built
engine.
 
The 944 is a better car than the 924 S, but I don't think it's twice as
expensive better. I think the 944 had better suspension and a much nicer
interior. More performance options were available on the 944, such as ABS
brakes and wheels & tires and the Turbo's anti-roll bars. It could be that
924 S prices are dragged down by the reputation of the older non-S 924.
How much are we talking about here? I didn't like any of the non-Turbo
4-cylinder Porsches of that time, but felt that the 944 Turbo was a much
better car. (I wrote the cover story comparing all four Porsches in the
November 87 Road & Track). If it's not too much more money, a same-
vintage 944 Turbo might be a more enjoyable car. If it's a loaded 944 with
lots of good options, it may be worth it.
 
Weigh this free advice against the fact that I don't own a 924/944; maybe
some members of the net will offer their experiences.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 10:50:59 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: 944 sunroof (was: Re: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence)

| From: Kari Eloranta  <eloranta@lammio.hut.fi>
stuff deleted
| On a more technical side question for the experts. If the 944 sunroof
| goes up and down but refuses to to be disengaged (i.e. cannot be
| removed) is there an obvious reason? A faulty gauge that tells the
| roof is released but where is it?

It took me some rereading of the owner's manual to figure out how to
remove the sunroof.  If you don't have the owner's manual, then it would
be very difficult to figure out this procedure.

To disengage the lifting "forks" to remove the sunroof, the ignition switch
must be *off*!  With the ignition off, press the sunroof switch towards its
open position.  You should hear the sunroof motor run for a moment
whilst it is retracting the lifting forks.  After pulling the front 
hinge levers
open, you can remove the sunroof (with the door open, you press under
the sunroof with one hand and grab it on top with the other).

Now, if the motor doesn't run when pressing the sunroof switch with the
ignition off, then you probably have a bad sunroof relay.  I don't have the
service manual with me, and I forget exactly where the relay is.  It is either
on the relay/fuse board under the dash, or back by the sunroof motor.  If
you would like, I could check my service manual.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 10:32:38 +0800
From: sfisher@Megatest.COM (Scott Fisher)
Subject: Re: 944 vs. 924s

~ > Hello Porschephiles;
~ > 
~ > I am contemplating the purchase of an '87 or '88 944 or 924s.  The 924s is 
~ > about one-half the cost of the 944 in the Washington D.C. area.

~ > My question is:
~ > What am I getting in the 944 (or giving up in the 924s) that justifies the 
~ > higher price?  I understand the drivetrain is the same.  There has to be 
~ > something I am missing.  Any insight would be appreciated. 
~ 
~ Not knowing about the internal physical differences between the cars, 
~ here's my stab at it:

Knowing at least some of the mechanical differences between the cars,
here's some actual hard data:

The 924S was the factory's last (so far :-) effort to build an 
"affordable" Porsche that wouldn't be an embarrassment to the
name.  It used the narrow-fendered 924 body and the less-
expensive 924 interior, but got the 944's half-a-928 engine
in place of the old Audi 100 block that had gone in the original
924.

There were several other differences.  The 944 has forged lower
control arms in the front that wouldn't fit in the narrower 924
body, so the 924S retains the 924 front suspension bits.  In
addition, the 924 body is lighter and more aerodynamic (due to
its smaller frontal area if nothing else), so early tests with 
the 944 motor in the 924S made it both quicker and also blessed
with a higher top speed than its contemporary 944.  I faintly
remember some very un-Porsche-like fumfuhing with excuses for
detuning the engine in the 924S on ludicrous grounds like "um,
the engine bay isn't big enough for the right exhaust manifold
so we had to, uh, fit a different one and, er, that's why the
much more expensive 944 is still quicker than the cheap 924S."

Much depends on what you want to do with the car.  The 924S is
very competitive in SCCA autocrossing's C Stock category, with
San Francisco-based Franklin Wong a recent National champion.  
Autocrossing of course rewards cars that are slightly narrower,
as long as it's not so much that handling is adversely affected,
as it gives a little more clearance to miss cones.  The first
time Franklin beat me, I was driving a friend's Miata in my
first autocross after a year spent road-racing an EP MGB.  "Gee,
this Mazda feels almost exactly like my MGB," I said, the first
time I ever drove the car (which was on the course).  There was
a THUMP as I knocked down a cone with the right-front corner.
"Only it's about ten inches wider than the B."  I hit a pile of
cones on that run, got it down to only two cones by the last
run, and that's part of the reason that the car's owner, as well 
as Franklin, finished ahead of me that day.  (I figured it out by 
the next event, at which Wong didn't show up; I finished first, 
and then you went and moved to Oregon, Miq, ya big lunk. :-)

~ IT costs more because people are willing to pay more. 

And that's the truth; any object, from a Coney Island hot dog to a
959, is worth what people are willing to pay for it.  

~ Why not decide which one you like better against your own 
~ standards (subjective: looks, objective: engine, drivetrain 
~ etc) and then worry about the price.

Again, sound advice for buying any car that exceeds the basic
necessities of transportation in some substantive way.

If what you want is the sensation of speed, precision handling,
and the sound of the 944's engine, either car will do it and with
the money you save on the 924S you can outfit the car with a
second set of rims and tires for competition.  (I looked into 
doing exactly this last year.)  If what you want is recognition
on the street, you'll have to pony up for the 944.  Plus of course
the later 944 variants had more performance than the 924S due to
larger engines, more valves, and in the top-end versions, turbocharging.
I don't have the yearly breakdown committed to memory, but I think it's
actually in the FAQ, or at least some of the details are.

Me?  I've always admired the integrity that Porsche showed with the
924S, and I think it demonstrates the difference between Porsche
and the domestic auto industry to compare the 924S to the Camaro RS.
Both cars were marketed as less-expensive versions of their respective
line -- the 924S an introduction to the 944, the Camaro RS a cheaper
Z-28.  (Admittedly, one of the reasons for the RS was to counteract
rising insurance claims on V8-powered Camaros, but for this list we
can stretch a point, I think. :-)

Chevrolet put the graphics, spoilers, and wheel package from the Z-28
on a V6-powered Camaro so that people on the sidewalk wouldn't know 
which car you had.

Porsche put the drivetrain from the 944 in the less-expensive body of
the 924 so that the *driver* would know.

As a driver, rather than a spectator, I know which choice *I'd* prefer...

- --Scott

------------------------------

Date: 27 May 94 11:56:01 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: 356 dash covering

Hi, Larry.
 
>My 15-year restoration project (1955 Speedster) will resume as soon as
>the temperature in my garage reaches optimum range (72 degrees thru 85
>degrees) and I need to obtain original-like material (black) to cover
>the dash. The original stuff on the car is like oil-cloth, not vinyl.
 
I don't know the Speedster that well, but are you absolutely sure this
material is different from other 356s? My daily driver 356 has original
vinyl on the dash, it's been out in the sun so long it's kind of crispy and
maybe feels like oilcloth. As far as I know, they only used one kind of
vinyl for the cars. It wouldn't make sense to have a different type for the
Speedsters. Could your dash have been recovered at some point?
 
Fairly good matches, color as well as texture, are available for the vinyl.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 14:02:13 EDT
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence

Here's a nasty thought I had the other day which, perhaps, some of our
European friends can confirm or refute:

It has always seemed to me that European cars have delivered very well in the
handling (fun factor) department and (especially Porsche) in the quality of
fit and finish. But it has also always seemed to me that there was a
disproportionate premium in $$ charged for horsepower. 

Could it be that we are (willing) victims of a fluke in European tax laws
which causes manufacturers like Porsche to prefer small-displacement, highly
stressed designs over (American practice) larger displacement, less highly
stressed designs which provide more low-end torque? I have heard that there
is a tax based in part on the displacement of the cars engine, and also the
number of seats (which is why p-cars have the useless rear 'seats').

Paying more because of limited production makes sense to me; paying more
because of tax laws in countries I don't live in does not.

Does any of this ring true?

Regards,
  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic

brake lights), but they did it on a rush for me at a decent price.  
Autothority was recommended to me and did some pre-purchases for me and 
replaced a steering box.  Kinda expensive, but you get what you pay for!  
That was a few years ago though.

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 13:27:59 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 924 vs. 944

| From: Tracy M Nelson  <tnelson@telesciences.com>
|
| Tracy Meyer (tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov) writes:
| > I am contemplating the purchase of an '87 or '88 944 or 924s.  The 924s is
| > about one-half the cost of the 944 in the Washington D.C. area.  My 
question is:
| > What am I getting in the 944 (or giving up in the 924s) that justifies the
| > higher price?  I understand the drivetrain is the same.  There has to be
| > something I am missing.  Any insight would be appreciated.  Thanks 
in advance.
|
| If you're contemplating the purchase of a water-cooled Porsche, you should
| definately get a copy of the Feb '94 issue of _Excellence_ magazine.  It has
| a very good article on the purchase of used 924/944/928s.
|
| The 944 does have more horsepower (150 vs. 115), and is (I think) slightly
| bigger.  A list of the good and bad points about each model (from "So You
| Want To Buy A Water-Cooled Porsche?" by Jim Pasha, copyright (C) 1993 by
| Ross Publications):

The horsepower difference is only with regards to early 924 years.  The '87-'88
924S had the exact same drivetrain as the same years' 944 with 150 HP.  
The biggest
difference in these cars is the track:

	924S		944
	-------		-------
wheels	6J		7J
front	1419mm		1477mm
	55.86"		58.14"

rear	1393mm		1451mm
	54.84"		57.13"

Note that the 944 also comes with one inch wider wheels and can accommodate 8
inch wheels in the rear.

I think the biggest explanation for the cost difference is guilt by 
association.
The 924S looks nearly identical to the Audi drive-trained earlier model 924.
The 944 looks more sexy/agressive with its flared fenders and hatch spoiler.
Consequently, the 924S is quite a bargain.

    Eric

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 16:25:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacd1.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: 924S vs. 944

>Tracy Meyer (tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov) writes:
>> I am contemplating the purchase of an '87 or '88 944 or 924s.  The 924s is 
>> about one-half the cost of the 944 in the Washington D.C. area.  My question is:
>> What am I getting in the 944 (or giving up in the 924s) that justifies the 
>> higher price?  I understand the drivetrain is the same.  There has to be 
>> something I am missing.  Any insight would be appreciated.  Thanks in advance.
>
>If you're contemplating the purchase of a water-cooled Porsche, you should
>definately get a copy of the Feb '94 issue of _Excellence_ magazine.  It has
>a very good article on the purchase of used 924/944/928s.

Agreed.

>The 944 does have more horsepower (150 vs. 115), and is (I think) slightly 
>bigger.  A list of the good and bad points about each model (from "So You
>Want To Buy A Water-Cooled Porsche?" by Jim Pasha, copyright (C) 1993 by
>Ross Publications):

Actually I think he was trying to compare the 924S to a 944.  The 924S
has the same drive train as the 944.  Since the 924S is better 
aerodynamically, it is actually a bit faster.  These both have 150 hp
in US trim.  

These are the advantages I can think of.

924S advantages:

Price, aerodynamics.

944 advantages:

Dash - The 924S doesn't have the newer 4 gauges layout of the 85.5+ 944s. 
Wheel sizes - Because of the bigger wheel arches, 944s will take bigger
              wheels.  Anyone know the "maximum" size that the 924S will
              take.
Sport suspension available.  I don't believe the 924S had this option.

Anything I missed or messed up? :)

Ross Stites

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 14:22:46 +0800
From: sfisher@Megatest.COM (Scott Fisher)
Subject: Re: 924 vs. 944

~ Tracy Meyer (tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov) writes:
~ > I am contemplating the purchase of an '87 or '88 944 or 924s.  

That "S" after 924 needs to be capitalized; it's significant.
I covered the major differences in a posting from earlier
today.  There is a vast difference between a 924 and a 924S.

~ The 944 does have more horsepower (150 vs. 115), and is (I think) slightly 
~ bigger.  

The fender flares make it wider and permit the use of different lower
control arms (at least in front; don't remember about the rear).  Other
than that, the power difference between the 924S and the 944 ended up
being minimal, if any, as they used the same motor, not the Audi 100
block used in the original 924.

I looked it up, BTW, and the 924S was introduced in mid-1986 according
to the FAQ.  That august document has no information on how long the 
924S production was maintained; as with other Porsche products, I'd
guess that if there is a 1988 924S, it's probably marginally better
than a 1987.  It's highly competent autocross car, as well as an effective 
and inexpensive introduction to Porsches, at least for people to whom the 
word "coolant leak" doesn't elicit a blank, uncomprehending stare. :-)

- --Scott "Hey, 911s use *their* coolant in the tires" Fisher

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 16:25:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sorin Grama <soring@tigua.natinst.com>
Subject: Summary "car won't start" & other q's


Thanks to all of you who replied to my question earlier this week.
The symptoms were the following (for a 85.5 944):
	- car wouldn't start
	- you could hear the relays clicking and the hissing sound
	(which probably came from the injectors)
	- I was able to start the car by rolling it.
	- looked like a typical battery problem, but the battery
	is fairly new.

The culprit was the starter, as many of you guessed.  It cost me 
$280 for the rebuilt starter plus shipping costs and one hour labor.

I am told that my car needs an oil cooler or an oil cooler housing
pretty soon (or maybe just the sealants).  There's a small oil leak there 
and in the worst case the coolant can mix with the oil and cause some 
major problems.  Is this a typical 944 failure?  In worst case scenario,
how much would it cost?

Thanks in advance,
Sorin Grama
85.5 944

Date: Fri, 27 May 94 16:09:42 -0700
From: Patty Winter <winter@apple.com>
Subject: Re: 911's and SOs

	Bill Ataras writes:
	> > It may be hard to imagine, but
	> > there are men who don't like Porsches.
	> 
	> And we pass them every day in their sputtering rice rockets
	 
	Bart Chambers writes:	
	>Whoa, Hoss...
	
	>Preference is a subjective, not an objective, judgment.  Wise
	>folks don't lose sight of that fact, or insult others for their
	>(different, subjective) preferences...  ;>)


Thanks to Bart for injecting some sanity into a discussion that's 
been getting increasingly arrogant.

Different people have different needs/desires for a car. For
that matter, *one* person may have different needs and desires.
 
I now have the exact combination of cars I've been wanting for 
years: a wonderful sports car ('85 951) and a very useful 4WD
auto-transmission station wagon ('93 Subaru). The Subaru is just 
as excellent in its own way as the Porsche is in its. When I'm
driving around town or in snow, I'm really glad I have the Subaru.
When I go to the mountains in good weather, the Porsche is a dream.
(Although you might get a slightly different opinion from the
friend I took for a ride on California Highway 49 recently... :-) )

Oddly enough, my ex-boyfriend couldn't understand why anyone would
buy a car based on any criteria other than low cost and inexpensive
maintenance. He's as arrogant in his viewpoint as some of the Porsche
owners on this mailing list are in theirs. 

Let's drop the snide remarks about people who don't buy Porsches as
well as the stupid arguments about Toyotas, Infinitis, etc. etc., okay?
Then we can get back to important discussions, like how I can get to
that seemingly inaccessible front side light whose bulb has burned out. :-)


Patty

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 18:37:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Matsumura <tedm@rahul.net>
Subject: wheel straightening, new tire

Today after crashing my right wheels into a sidewalk, popping the front 
right, I jacked the car up, removed the front right and replaced the 
popped Nitto with a Bridgestone 195/60 * 15" tire at Firestone for $82.13 
balanced.

I installed it, and the pull had gone, so I'm hoping my suspension is 
still straight.  I will be keeping my 16" BBS rear, and 15" BBS fronts 
for daily driving, but bought a set of Cookie Cutter 15"x6" wheels to use 
for "touring".  After burning up the rubber on them, I hope to use them 
with some 185x70x15" tires to take on long distances like 4 hours from 
the bay area to Tahoe.  

I also found an inexpensive strap to hold down my air box cover, it s a 
15" rubber tie-down with S hooks on the end for $1.49 at Target.  Now 
when I get a big backfire, the pop off valve will release into the air 
filter holder and have to go out the big air end.  I'm hoping that this 
will be sufficient release.

I"ve also read up on some back issues of Excellence and found that the 
'78 and maybe '79 had oil problems where sometimes there is trouble 
keeping oil in the right places, and that there was even a Porsche tech. 
note on this?  Sometimes revving high, I do have my oil level go down 
into the red, even though at idle or when very warm it's over the halfway 
mark in the white.  I rarely get the temp over 210, but would a terbatrol 
or other oil cooler make my engine last longer?

Ted

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 21:27:40 -0500
From: schless@iastate.edu
Subject: 944 sunroof


Howdy

You don't have the procedure correct (that is why the roof wont come loose)

You said::
To disengage the lifting "forks" to remove the sunroof, the ignition switch
must be *off*!  With the ignition off, press the sunroof switch towards its
open position.  You should hear the sunroof motor run for a moment
whilst it is retracting the lifting forks.  After pulling the front 
hinge levers

That is WRONG!

You have to move the key to the 1st postition away from off.
(that is when radio, ect will work)
Than you push the sunroof button and hear the motor run for 1/2 sec.
and the REAR of sunroof will be free.

Reverse process when installing (it should automatically lock 
if you forget though)  

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 19:16:47 -0700
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Dash Covering



Hi Pete; Hi Greg

Thanks for answering my post re: Looking for 1955 Speedster dash covering.

At your suggestion, Greg, I talked to Cecil Beach today, but he has his
upholstery work done by Los Gatos Upholstery. I got their phone number but
wasn't able to make contact today. Will try again Tuesday. First time I've
talked with Cecil. It was kinda fun - he goes way back - regrets having sold
his 1954 sunroof coupe, not many made.

Pete, re: "I don't know the Speedster that well, but are you absolutely sure
this
material is different from other 356s?" I think it is different. The dash
and door sills are original and the car has never been in the sun, hardly
(you've heard the stories about the car never having been in the rain?). It
was sold here in Sacramento by Sammy Weiss (owned Oxford Motors, sold
English cars and Porsches, then got killed at Laguna) to the first owner, a
reporter for the Sacramento Bee. He kept it for a year, then sold it to the
first of three who used it exclusively as an E-Production race car. I was
the last of the three. The only time the car saw the sun was during
practice/qualifying and the race. Otherwise, under cover or in the garage. I
also have a '61 coupe, bought new. Big difference in dash covering. Cecil
Beach refers to the '55 material as vinyl canvas.

I may call Tim Goodrich and leave a message on his machine.

Thanks for your help.

Date: 27 May 94 23:46:53 EDT
From: Triet Le <73370.50@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Summer is here!

1) Went to NJ PCA Concours/Swap Meet at the Parsippany Hilton last Sunday. 
There was a nice showing of cars, mostly Porsches. The following were 
present, had license plates and were probably driven there:

Carrera Cup Car
'94 Carrera RSR Turbo (looked very trick, but what is it?)
Mercedes 300SL Gullwing (looked like a daily driver)
Ferrari's (don't know much about them - maybe a Daytona and a Super 
America)

The concours winner had done so the last 13 times.

2) At the swap meet, I purchased a Stable Energies harness support bar. It 
mounts on the B or C pillars and can support a racing harness and video 
camera. I did not buy the Camber Truss, because it required some minor 
modifications for clearance in my car. Any experience with Cambermeister or 
Racing Dynamics strut braces? Can anyone recommend easily installed (to 
stock mounting points) racing harnesses. I will probably go with the street 
legal 3" Schroth Rallye belts.

3) There was a recent ad in Autoweek for '94 Speedster Recaro seat 
take-offs@ $850 for the pair (they are already gone) from Sportique Motors. 
While at Paul Miller Porsche recently, I overheard an earnest customer 
negotiating the purchase of a Speedster, and demanding that they put in 
real seats. It seems like these Recaros may be finding their way to some 
swap meets. I am interested in them in burgandy. If they come up for sale 
in any club newsletters could whoever sees them please post to 
Porschephiles or E-mail me?

4) There was an article in the NY Post today about the new State Trooper 
Camaros. There is only one on Long Island and it goes 152mph. There is only 
one officer on Long Island approved to drive it and it's a she. It is 
marked and has a light bar. I saw one two weeks ago on Rt 195 near Cape 
Cod. It was teal, unmarked and had a Corvette (Tupperware?) pulled over.

5) The RX-7 list has had a discussion about using DOT-approved roadrace 
tires for the street. It seems that RE71R are well-thought of and last for 
up the 15K miles. They are being closed out by Project Racing @ $75/95 and 
Blackburn Racing @ $60, in both cases same price for all sizes, but not all 
sizes available. I find it difficult to believe that anything with a 30 
treadwear rating would last 15K, but I did get 10K on my Goodyear ZRS' (50 
treadwear) on an RX-7. If there is any interest, I will dig up addresses 
and phone numbers.

6) Summer is here! Turns out that I am the 4th person (out of 11) in my 
summer share with a Porsche. Also a couple Miatas, 3000's, etc.

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 22:19:50 -0700
From: pjb@cco.caltech.edu (Paul J. Brewer)
Subject: [Q?] '82 928 Diagnostic lights ALL turn on


	I am considering the purchase of a '82 928. The air conditioner
is shot. Engine is ok and owner has records showing 3000 mi oil changes
and changed water pump and timing belt at 109K (110K now). 

	The owner told me about a problem with the diagnostics unit.
Apparently, a few times a month when he turns on the headlights, all the
warning lights illuminate as well. Then after 10 min or so they turn off.
Then it wont happen again for a few weeks. 

	Intermittent electrical problems are a pain in the ass, I know. 
The question is whether some board or chip simply needs to be swapped out.

	In what order should stuff be looked at? Anyone know a good LA 
area mechanic who could do it? Is there a way to figure out if this is
a minor or major headache before purchase?

	In some cars, failure of certain electrical portions can make
the car undrivable. How much compujunk is in a '82 928 anyway?

	Incidentally, I think I can find someone to check out the rest of
the car. My question primarily involves the status of the electrical/diagnostic
systems.

Thanks

Paul Brewer
pjb@cco.caltech.edu

Date: Fri, 27 May 1994 22:51:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: ero@netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: porsches/girlfriend

I've been pretty lucky, my girlfriend and my porsche (930) get along 
really well. She(my girlfriend), now, naturally grabs the door handle and 
seat cushion when I speed up on the off ramps, and doesn't really 
complain until I exceed 115(not on the off ramps). I also talked my Porsche 
mechanic into 
converting my girlfriends manual steering 280 sl mercedes into power 
steering, I'm not sure if he's ever going to let me live that one down. 
While her car has been in the shop i've offered her my turbo many times, 
she now takes it reluctantly, and has actually started to enjoy it, ie 
telling me she now goes into the corners alittle faster and saw the turbo 
gauge hit .04 bar. I've been using the 930 as a daily driver for the past 
3 months while my v.w. crewcab(1/2 van&1/2pickup) has been in the paint 
shop undergoing a total restoration. I've just started putting it back 
together. By the time it's finished my mechanic will have forgiven me 
about the mercedes fiasco, and I can start working on him to install a 
911 3.2l motor and trans in the bus.
ero@net.com

Date: 28 May 1994 11:00:34 -0400 (EDT)
From: CCONRAD@HBS.HBS.HARVARD.EDU
Subject: Re: Girlfriends/Porsches

The prenuptual agreement idea is probably a good one.  In the early 80's,
my husband and I spotted a Toyota 2000GT (the coupe version of the car in
"You Only Live Twice") sitting in a driveway in Oakland CA looking very
neglected.  We sighed enviously, and went on our way.  We saw it there many
times after that.  It obviously was not in the hands of anyone who
appreciated it.  So one day, we knocked on the door to talk to the owner 
about buying it.  The owner wasn't home, but we talked to her housemate.
It turns out that the owner got the car in a divorce settlement.  Seems
her ex loved that car more than anything else, I believe he was the 
original US owner of the car.  Since hubby loved the car, that was the
ONLY thing she insisted on getting in the divorce settlement.  She claimed
she would NEVER sell it, because if she did, her ex might be able to get
the car back somehow.  So it stayed in her driveway.  Now THAT'S
vindictive.

We heard a few years ago that she eventually sold the car when prices
skyrocketed in the late 80s.  Rumor has it that her vindictiveness stopped
at the $100,000+ mark.  I just hope the car is in the hands now of someone
who will appreciate it.  

Claudia

PS: My husband and I are both Porsche nuts, auto racing nuts, and general
car nuts.  It's a match made in heaven!  We always say that we knew it was
true love right from the start.  The first time he gave me a ride in his
914 (badly in need of a tune-up), I told him it sounded like a VW.  But he
still asked me out again.  And he got a tune-up.

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: 28 May 94 11:17:16 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence

Hi, Bill.
 
>If a euro car can't run on sludge like an American car, then it is of
>course lower quality engineering.
>Let the discussion begin! :)
 
Take the other extreme. GM now claims its engines will go 100,000 miles
without major maintenance. At least that's what it claims in ads. But it
won't back that claim with a warranty, as far as I know. And I would really
like to see any engine go that far without something breaking -- water pump,
alternator, and we're not even getting into the black magic like brain
boxes. When those go, and they're out of warranty, think of that great ad
campaign while you peel the bills out of your wallet. I think 100,000 is
approaching the useful life of these things, not the time to first
maintenance.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 28 May 94 11:17:40 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@CompuServe.COM>
Subject: Oil temp and level

Hi, Ted.
 
What your oil level gauge does when you rev it doesn't mean anything. RTFM.
That gauge is only to be read with the engine warm, at idle and while
standing on a level surface.
 
210 is a good operating temperature. You don't want it any cooler than that.
Think of it this way -- if it's too cool, the oil is more viscous and you
lose horsepower. Also if you have condensate (water) in the oil it won't
evaporate. Get the temp too high, and the oil viscosity is too thin. 210
sounds good. While we were testing engines on the dyno at Porsche, we used
to run lots hotter than that -- and for 600 hours, too.
 
I'd save the money for those aftermarket coolers. Maybe use it to buy extra
wheels and tires, mount them on the roof (London-Sydney Rally style).
Again, let us have fiancee's address...) Maybe find a late model
factory cooler to fit in the front fender. I don't know prices; are wrecking
yard prices for factory coolers higher than the aftermarket stuff? Try
Parts Heaven up in your area, I've had good experiences with them.
1-415-782-0354
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 May 94 11:56:26 -0400
From: "Bart Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence

In message <9405280942.AA01871@larbd1.sbil.co.uk> Ben Evans writes:

> by a certain Bavarian Motor Works, prior to that it was a 
> company owned in part by Honda, and from the technology point of
> veiw was driven by Honda. Triumph and MG have not existed except
> as badges for aeons. I have a feeling that the only real English
> motor car manufacturers are Rolls-Royce, and TVR. 
> 
> While I'm on the subject, do the USans amongust the list get the
> chance to purchase the TVR Griffith? Now there is a real
> sports car, 

Ben, ben, ben... 

Where have you been, and why are you missing the point? :)

  The ownership of the various marques you cite has no bearing on the point.  
The point is that euro-cars, over a span of many, many years were designed with 
small engines because of factors like fuel cost (nearly universally at least 3 
times us fuel cost) and taxation based on displacement.  And oh, BTW, unless I 
am mistaken, the TVR uses a Ford V8...

  Oh, yeah, one small piece of advice, don't bet the farm on the outcome of 
*any* performance contest between a TVR and a 3.6L 930, or a 512 TR, or 348tb...

Bart Chambers
bchambers@Atlantic.nos.noaa.gov
'86 Guards Red 911 Cabriolet
'87 Quantum Syncro (Quattro in disguise)
David E. Davis is right, "Cogito, ergo Zoom"

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 May 94 11:49 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Summary "car won't start" & other q's

Sorin,

Sounds like you're talking about the seals on the oil/water heat
exchanger.  It's not that uncommon for them to leak, esp. on a car
which is nine years old.

It's not a lot of work to re-seal the manifold.  Make sure you use
the latest version of the rubber seals, which I believe are green.
Also make sure that the heat shield between the exhaust manifold and
oil/water heat exchanger is in place.  Speaking of heat shields, for
that matter you might also want to add the neighboring oil pan heat
shield which was added for MY86.  It protects the oil pan seal from
excessive heat coming from the exhaust.

Kevin

Date: 28 May 1994 11:09:48 -0400 (EDT)
From: CCONRAD@HBS.HBS.HARVARD.EDU
Subject: Re:  Carrera RS book

The Carrera RS book is worth every penny.  These cars have been so
neglected in other P-books, it's about time someone did a complete history
of them.  

Besides having great pictures, stories, and detailed technical info, there
is a list of every 1973 RS ever built, and how each was originally equiped.
This is a must have book if you own, want to buy, or just lust after the
'73 RSs.  If you're more interested in the 1993 RS, it may not be worth
the price.

We got the book from Automobilia in SF (mail order).  I don't have their
phone number at the moment, but I could find it if you don't want to call
information.  Automobilia was selling the book at a discount, which was
a nice surprise.  For us, the book is worth the full price.

Enjoy!
	Claudia

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 May 94 12:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: ride height for a 911

Magnus,

You should set the ride height by measuring from the ground to an
appropriate suspension member, as described in the factory manuals or
spec booklette.  Measuring ride height to body panels is probably
ideal for concours, but really isn't the thing to do for best
handling.

For that matter, if you want to tune the height and suspension for
best handling in autocrossing and the like, an important first step
is to corner weight the car.  I've seen some pretty wild imbalances
in cars coming into the shop, all of which to my memory have been
easily corrected.

You should align the car with the weight in it which you expect to
carry when driving.  So perhaps a half tank of gas, unless you like
to autocross with as little fuel as possible in the tank.

The shop has two plastic milk crates we put onto the driver's seat.  We
fill them with weights to match the driver's weight.  The weights
themselves are of the body-building kind.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 May 94 14:52:03 EDT
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 sunroof

>>Now, if the motor doesn't run when pressing the sunroof switch with the
>>ignition off, then you probably have a bad sunroof relay.  I don't have the
>>service manual with me, and I forget exactly where the relay is.  It is
either
>>on the relay/fuse board under the dash, or back by the sunroof motor.  If
>>you would like, I could check my service manual.

>>    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red


On my '87 944 Turbo, to retract the forks, the ignition switch must be in the
"No. 1" position (one click clockwise from off). If the ignition switch is in
the "No. 2" position (normal running on) then the switch acts as usual
raising and lowering the sunroof.

Hope this helps rather than confuses the issue!

Regards,

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic

told Aldo to do it. He did.

Date: Sat, 28 May 1994 21:19:13 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Girlfriends(Make that WIVES)/Porsches

We got a '76 911S after my daughter was born (had an RX7) to be our 
"sensible family car" (the Mazda only had two seats; 911 has four 
(sorta)).  We got rid of it when the shop time started being greater than 
drive time.  Now we have two kids, and I started looking at "sports" cars 
(read Corvettes, MGs, Austin Healys etc.) rather half-heartedly.  Note 
all those mentioned have TWO seats.  My wife INSISTS that we get another 
911 because otherwise we can't fit the family.  Besides, she LOVED the 
old 911.  My then 18 month old son climbed into a 911 I looked at last 
fall, sat in the front passenger seat and would NOT get out.  He still 
talks about the "Porch car."  So, I'm convinced.  It's fate. It's 
genetics.  It's just one of those things I'll have to learn to live with.

Moral of the story:  To all those folks dealing with 
girlfriends/fiances who don't seem to "get it,"  tell 'em its a "sensible 
family car" because someday you want to have kids and room for them and 
the wife as well!

Good luck!

 - Jerry "911 Hunting" Mac

Date: Sun, 29 May 94 02:25:56 EDT
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: What is a MAESTRO?

Dear Sir:

     Re: Maestro. As describe in The Books,  there are (at least) two
meanings  to the term "Maestro".  The first  Maestro being that little Voice
 you (hopefully) have deep down inside you saying- "DON'T reuse the  old Rod
Nuts, damn it. REPLACE them!"
   The Maestro is  also the  Learned Conductor of a Special Symphony who is
 always trying to get a whole bevy of Prima Donnas to play the right note
(machne the part, plate the part, powder paint the part, etc), at the right
time. The Prima Donnas KNOW they are Prima Donnas and they  EXPECT you to
kiss certain of their body parts-. They also  expect you to know which part
to kiss and how.
    When the Maestro succeeds, Beautiful Porsche Music is heard out the
Tailpipes., for a  surprisingly long time. When he fails, well Hell, at least
he tried to do it right. And besides, Great Failures make Great Stories. 

  KEEP THE 356 FAITH!!!
   The Maestro

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 29 May 94 19:06:01 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: British Cars

The British cars developed under some very interesting rules.  There was
a large tax on new automobiles, but not on cycles.  This led to a whole
family of interesting (and unstable) 3-wheel cars.  Engines tended to
be taxed on piston area and not on horsepower.  Did you ever notive how
tall a Jaguar engine is with its long stroke.  It has very high piston speeds
because of its long stroke and small piston diameter.

The British tradition was that cars needed fine finish and that there
were plenty of mechanics to fiddle with the machinery.  Reliability
developed elsewhere.  Unfortunately, we didn't have the mechanics here.

An interesting contrast to the British car reliability in the 50's and
60's was the VW Beetle, which often went well past 100,000 miles before
significant engine maintenance (other than tuning and valve adjustment).
Were similar engines used elsewhere?

Rick  :-)

Now for some opinions.  Does anyone have an idea of what this car
should be worth?  The dealer wants 28K with the 1-year Porsche
warranty.  Would you expect it to hold its' value well over the
next two to three years?

We're searching for a new car to upgrade our 87 944S that we use
for autox and track events as well as a daily driver.  My wife
and I share the car at the track.  This is pretty hard on the
brakes since they sometimes don't get a chance to cool down
between run groups.  Our 87 also has the 16" C2 wheels.  How much
better would the S2 be at the track than our S?  Would we be
better off waiting a while and then picking up a 92 968?

- --
Jim Foster - madif@rohmhaas.com          (215) 592-2446 (voice) 592-2369 (FAX)
"Being on a Beemer and not having a wave returned by a
Sportster is like having a clipper ship's hailing not                  DoD 142
returned by an orphaned New Jersey solid waste barge." -OTL      '91 K100RS16V
The opinions expressed are those of the writer and not of the Rohm and Haas Co

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 09:37:05 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: 911's and SOs

> From: Patty Winter  <winter@apple.com>
> Subject: Re: 911's and SOs
> Date: Friday, May 27, 1994 4:09PM
[...]
>
> Thanks to Bart for injecting some sanity into a discussion that's
> been getting increasingly arrogant.
>
> Different people have different needs/desires for a car. For
> that matter, *one* person may have different needs and desires.
[...]
Agreed strongly from this Porschephile!  I love Porsches, but geez, I 
have other vehicles too.  Thank goodness not everyone else has the same 
interests as me - society's varieties make for an interesting day.

> Then we can get back to important discussions, like how I can get to
> that seemingly inaccessible front side light whose bulb has burned out. :-)
There's an access flap in the fenderwell liner.  Turn the wheel to the 
side (or remove it) and you'll see a little trap door.  Pull or push 
it, then reach around and unscrew the 2 white plastic knobs on the 
light's backside.  It's just like the rear lights, which you can 
examine in your trunk cubbies.

You'll get scraped knuckles from the hard plastic door trying to shut 
on your hand...

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 10:17:06 -0400
From: "Bart Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Advice wanted on 91 944S2

In message <9405292301.AA28797@tta.com> Jim Foster writes:
> 
> I'd like to get the advice of the net on a 1991 944S2 that we looked at
> yesterday.  The car is in *mint* condition with 5,500 miles on the
> odometer.  Is this mileage so low that I should be worried?  
Can't help on ID of the option, but since this comes with the warranty, you can 
be confident that the milage is correct.

 
> Does anyone have an idea of what this car
> should be worth?  

Go the the news stand (or the public library) and pick up one of the
many guides to used car prices (Edmonds, others)

> Would you expect it to hold its' value well over the
> next two to three years?

All cars depreciate.  Look at the pattern over the last few years.  
Copy the numbers and do some spreadsheet analysis.  

Remember that the dealer is asking a premium price for a premium car
determined by the low miles.  If you put a bunch of miles, and you autox
the living hell out of it, you will no longer have a *premium* car, and
your depreciation will be greater.  If that's your plan, IMHO, you could 
be better off to buy something less *premium* 

Decide how much you can afford to pay, and how much depreciation you 
can live with.  No one can answer these questions for you.  

> We're searching for a new car to upgrade our 87 944S that we use
> for autox and track events as well as a daily driver.  My wife
> and I share the car at the track.  This is pretty hard on the
> brakes since they sometimes don't get a chance to cool down
> between run groups.  

Do you use Cool Carbon pads?  If not, get them ASAP.

> better would the S2 be at the track than our S?  

Would this make you change classes?  would that matter to you?

> Would we be better off waiting a while and then picking up 
> a 92 968?

See discussion above, same applies.  OTHO, the S2 is 2.7L vs 2.5L 
for your S.  Hot rodders are right, IMHO, *ain't no substitute for
cubic inches* - *all other things being equal*.  and...as with all
Porsches, newer is usually better due to the factory's running 
up-grade policy.

good luck,



Bart Chambers
bchambers@Atlantic.nos.noaa.gov
'86 Guards Red 911 Cabriolet
'87 Quantum Syncro (Quattro in disguise)
David E. Davis is right, "Cogito, ergo Zoom"

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 14:02:21 EDT
From: tmmew@eos.ncsu.edu
Subject: Three 944 questions...


  Last week my father & I bought a 1987 944 here in Raleigh, NC.  It is
stock but does have the optional touring package.  Since I do tech
inspections for Car Guys I have driven quite a few cars, including
several 944's and 951's so I was puzzled when I drove this one and found
that it was Impossible to heel-and-toe b/c the gas pedal was a good
three inches below the brake peddle.  Is this normal???  Unless I hear
otherwise, I will bend the metal bar supporting the pedal so that it is
more even with the brake pedal.

The other 2 questions are...

  1.  At the end of the throttle cable, there are two places to attach
the cable.  Will the other one (the one closer to the driver's left of
the car) give better throttle response?  It almost looks like a racing
part.

  2.  Where is the cheapest place to get a K&N filter for the car? 
Racer Wholesale want $55; this is the lowest I have found so far.  Also,
does anyone run their 944 with the air intake tube off?  (The tube
leading from the airbox to the front fender.)  It looks like removing
this would free up the intake a bit.

If anyone has ANY other suggestions for the car, they would be most
appreciated.

TIA,
Ty

deal to me, as I don't own one.  He does seem to know about mechanical 
basics, and if he likes to make movies and claims about his engines that 
are logistically difficult to prove, or if he is just chicken to race, 
there's nothing wrong with that.  

My boss, a professional manager, wants to race me in his Mustang 5.0 
litre, but I won't (at least not yet...)  If I'm going to race someone 
with a lot of visibility, I need to have a high assurance I'm going to 
win.  The Maestro is possibly in the same position, building a race 356, 
or so I think I've heard... ;)

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 19:46:00 EDT
From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
Subject: Carb Adjustment?


This is not a Porsche question, but a motor question, nonetheless. 
Hopefully, someone can help.

I put a new 2 bbl carb in my boat. The boat seems to work well with one 
exception. The motor bogs down when accelerated from about 2000 rpm (maybe 
the transition from primary to seconary?) It idles ok and accelerates well 
at higher rpm. The dwell and timing are OK. Any insight into the problem

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 21:07:11 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Three 944 questions...

> From:  <tmmew@eos.ncsu.edu>
> Subject: Three 944 questions...
> Impossible to heel-and-toe b/c the gas pedal was a good
> three inches below the brake peddle.  Is this normal???  Unless I hear
> otherwise, I will bend the metal bar supporting the pedal so that it is
> more even with the brake pedal.
No, this isn't normal.  All 944 pedal cluster should be identical.  
Sounds like yours has been changed or damaged.  I wouldn't recommend 
just _bending_ the metal back, as the arm may be severely weakened.  
Get a new/used replacement if you determine that to be the problem.  
Also check the cable and throttle housing, etc.

[...]

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 20:27 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Three 944 questions...

Ty,

The 944 pedals are set up, out of the box, for best heel/toe under
heavy braking, eg, at the track or autocross.  Deep into the brakes,
you find the throttle pedal right about where it belongs.  You can, I
believe, adjust pedal heights to suit if you'd like them a little
different.

Bending one of the pedal arms would be a really bad thing to do.  If
it didn't break right away, it will probably do so eventually.

I don't know about the throttle cable pick-up.  I think the factory
linkage is just fine.  What problem are you trying to solve?

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 May 94 20:27 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Advice wanted on 91 944S2

Jim,

The options are cruise control, A/C, and sunroof, in that order.  BTW,
for whoever asked some time ago what option C02 is, it specifies a
catalytic converter.

If your problem sharing the car with your wife is due to brake
overuse/overheating, your best bet is additional cooling and/or a
higher temp fluid.  For cooling 944 brakes, the only show in town is
the Holbert Cool Brake kit, now sold by Bob Russo.

To contradict what someone else said, Cool Carbons are likely only to
exacerbate a cooling problem.  They are wonderful, and I do recommend
them.

Great that your wife tracks the car with you!

Kevin

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 10:02:19 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Old car mags.

hi,

Sunday I visited the largest multi-make car meeting in Norway. There was a 
little swap meet in one of the corners. I found a guy selling old 40-50-60's 
car magazines, I took his adress and boght one magazine from him. I wasn't 
too sure whether his prices were high or low, so I will have to ask you guys 
for advice.

I bought the October '61 issue of Road&Track, he charged $6 for it, rating 
the state of the magazine from 1 to 5, this magazine was a 2-3. But the 
contents were 1. It had a test report on the '61 1600N, and a special 
version s-90GT. Among other funny historia, there were ads for 166vignale 
spyder(Ferrari) for about $3000, and a RSK spyder for $7500.

What is a 'decent' price for fifties car magazines over in the US? Any 
special issues I should ask for when i contact this fellow again?(Porsche 
stuff.)

He seemed to have C&D, R&T, and many more,....almost complete collection.

cheers,
trond

Subject: Who's Who on Porschephiles

To post to Porschephiles, send mail to:
	porschephiles@tta.com

Your list administrator is:
	Stan Hanks <porschephiles-request@tta.com

To be added to this list, send a note to "porschephiles-request@tta.com".
YOU WILL NOT BE AUTOMATICALLY ADDED FROM YOUR SURVEY INFO!

This list is also available in a digest format. Mail to porschephiles-request 
for more info.  Archives are kept on-line and are available for anonymous
FTP from tta.com between the hours of 19:00 and 07:30 daily.

Also available on the Web at URL "http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html"

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 03:06:52 -0501
From: pfile (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Message

June 1994

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

This list has a growth rate like a Certain Pink Bunny -- it just keeps 
going and going and going.... We are over 700 members now, and if we'd
kept all the people that joined and dropped off within a week, we'd be
closer to 850... Something to think about as you start recommending this
to your friends!

Otherwise, list operation is running smoothly. There are some changes
in the offing, Real Soon. You'll hear it here first...

COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 7 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.


CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at n_weissenberger@harvard.edu.   You can ask her for info or 
get her to send you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds published the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 or (908) 287-8070..

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
President,                                                    NetSmiths, Ltd.
2025 Lincoln Highway     Edison     NJ     08817
Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com       voice: (713) 661-2084 fax: (713) 661-0633
Edison:  e-mail: stan@netsmiths.com voice: (908) 287-8070 fax: (908) 287-3883
I live in Houston TX and work in Edison NJ. Don't bitch about *YOUR* commute.

'81 Euro 911SC Targa	(daily driver when I'm where it is...)
'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
'64 356 SC  		(OK, so I fell in love again...)

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 02:00:13 -0700
From: richlu@uclink.berkeley.edu (Richard Hsiang Lu)
Subject: Stuck odometer


Hiya!
  Can anyone please advise me on how to fix an odometer that fails to roll?

The problem:  Both the upper and trip odometers remain stationary while the 
	      car ('83 944) is being driven.  All other instruments & gauges
	      (esp. the speedometer) appear unaffected.

I have a pretty good idea of the cause, but of course, I can't be sure:
While on the I-880, something (a hubcap?) flew off a car that was ahead
of me in an adjacent lane.  It hit me.  My friend, who was following behind
me at the time, said he saw the object come up from under my car and was then 
subsequently hit by it too.  After a quick inspection, I saw no visible 
damage to the body, let out a "whew!" and thought the matter was closed.
The next day, however, I noticed my odometer(s) wouldn't budge.

I've thumbed through my Haynes manual, but the book doesn't touch the
subject of odometer repairs, instead referring the reader to an authorized 
dealer.  Is such a job really that sensitive or difficult?  If so, can
anyone estimate the cost (both time and parts) involved in such a repair?

Despite not knowing what to look for, I propped up the car anyways and took a 
look underneath.  I looked all over for any signs of damage.  I found a dent in
the undercover, but otherwise, no loose or severed cables/lines.  Where 
*should* I have been looking anyhoo?     ?:\

Thanks a bunch!
 -rich

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 12:10:09 BST
From: malc@ncc.co.uk (Malcolm Smith)
Subject: Euro cars designed for Maintenance.


>>>From: LouKrieg@aol.com
>>>Subject: Re: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence
>>>
>>>Here's a nasty thought I had the other day which, perhaps, some of our
>>>European friends can confirm or refute:
>>>

>>>Could it be that we are (willing) victims of a fluke in European tax laws
>>>which causes manufacturers like Porsche to prefer small-displacement, highly
>>>stressed designs over (American practice) larger displacement, less highly
>>>stressed designs which provide more low-end torque? I have heard that there
>>>is a tax based in part on the displacement of the cars engine, and also the
>>>number of seats (which is why p-cars have the useless rear 'seats').
>>>
>>>Paying more because of limited production makes sense to me; paying more
>>>because of tax laws in countries I don't live in does not.
>>>
>>>Does any of this ring true?


You have to understand life here is very different. I have driven large
parts of both Europe and the States. Distances for european
journeys are on the whole shorter ("The English think 100miles is a long
way, the Americans think 100years is a long time!"). Journeys are conducted
along much windier (read more driver involvement!) roads. Generally to
travel for more than 3-4 hours is condidered a "Big" journey. Add to this fuel
costs. Fuel is approx 3-4 TIMES  the cost. (I remember someone on the list
worked out you'd need to drive a small Honda in Europe to pay the same in
fuel as a 930 in the States).

Over here an Chevy or such like is  a. A rarity and
				    b. Expensive in fuel terms.


The fuel tax is a distinct encouragement to buy a smaller engine. It has
also been argued that is also a more effective way of reducing emmisisions.
If you burn less fuel in a slightly dirtier manner then the emmisions will
be the same (and you don't have carry all of the extra emmissions C**P).

To show what is meant by distances, most Dealers in the UK refer to
the ~12K mile serivce as an "annual" service and indeed your average
family man doesn't even get that many miles.

The final point is the our cars are smaller because out cities are small.
Most European cars come into the American "compact" classification and
are therefore lighter etc and so don't big engines. The cars fit our
countries like Chevy Caprices and Ford Taruses etc are the right size
the American market. So basically yes they are more stressed engines
but for many different reasons than you suggest.


Incidently the 924 is a classic case in point about emmisions. The "world"
variant produces 125bhp in all variants met all of the emission regualtions
except Federal ones. The US variants changed virtually every model year and
produced as much as 115bhp (some produced 96bhp). My european GM carbed 1.6L
boring family sedan produces that much (96) with better encomony and has lasted
180K miles (so far!).

 -malc-

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 08:17:03 -0500
From: stan (Stan Hanks)
Subject: OK -- *LISTEN UP*!!!!

Dear Subscribers,

Over the weekend, I have received enough mail from irrate subscribers
who are pissed off at the mini-flame war that has been running asking that
the participants be dropped from the list that I'm *SERIOUSLY* considering
it. I'll give you all until close of business Wednesday to be in compliance
with this, then *THAT'S IT*.  That should be sufficient to cover anything
that's "in the mail" and not posted yet. Do not use this grace period as
an excuse to get in one last shot -- I'll be looking at posting times
relative to the delivery timestamp for the last copy of this message
leaving tta.com.

Here's the deal: you're supposed to be a bunch of professionals, and this
is supposed to be the premier automotive related list (as befits something
dealing with Porsche) in terms of signal to noise content. So discussion
of personal characteristics of individual subscribers will not be
tolerated, nor will extended discussions "off the topic" such as relative
merits of other cars, girlfriends, or whatever.

In particular, personal attacks will not be tolerated. If someone is 
wrong, you are certainly encouraged to say so. But calling them a fool
in public -- or worse -- will NOT be tolerated.

If you don't like this, too damn bad. Either voluntarily drop off the
list or mouth off again and I'll just take care of that for you...

Stan Hanks
Porschephiles ListMeister

Date:     Tue, 31 May 1994 09:29 MST
From: JBUTLER@PARK.ADMIN.UTAH.EDU
Subject:  Re: Pro Life/People/Civilization....!

The fact of the matter is, the Maestro is the only source of good info on the
356 engine for people like me (uh oh...let the *people like me* flames begin)
whose pre-Maestro rebuilds were accompanied by caveats like:

*if Germans made TVs, they'd leave an oil spot on your carpet*

I am forever in debt to the man who taught me how to how to bolt a case
together so that it doesn't leak. Thank you, Maestro...no more strategically
placed cardboard on the garage floor. My motor is intact because I didn't go
with the 10.4 to 1 on one side, 10.1 to 1 on the other side compression
ratios I would have ended up with if I'd followed the local expert's advice
and used only one stock base gasket all the way around. My marriage is intact
because I got the cheap NPRs instead of the budget blowing Mahle pistons and
liners.

I know there are others out there whose tried and true practices would be of
great value to lame brained backyard mechanics like myself (wow...all this
flaming has got me *auto-flaming*). However, your secrets will likely die
with you if you don't pass them on in written form. Like they say at the
university, *publish or perish.* I just wish he or someone like him would
write a book on rust repair/bodywork to keep me from costly foul-ups
as I enter that arena.

John, U of Utah

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 08:18:41 -0700
From: Robert_Dean_at_LETHAL@qntm.com
Subject: Re[2]: 911's and SOs

	Bill Ataras writes:
	> > It may be hard to imagine, but
	> > there are men who don't like Porsches.

	> And we pass them every day in their sputtering rice rockets
	 
	Bart Chambers writes:	
	>Whoa, Hoss...
	
	>Preference is a subjective, not an objective, judgment.  Wise
	>folks don't lose sight of that fact, or insult others for their
	>(different, subjective) preferences...  ;>)


Thanks to Bart for injecting some sanity into a discussion that's 
been getting increasingly arrogant.

Different people have different needs/desires for a car. For
that matter, *one* person may have different needs and desires.
 
I now have the exact combination of cars I've been wanting for 
years: a wonderful sports car ('85 951) and a very useful 4WD
auto-transmission station wagon ('93 Subaru). The Subaru is just 
as excellent in its own way as the Porsche is in its. When I'm
driving around town or in snow, I'm really glad I have the Subaru.
When I go to the mountains in good weather, the Porsche is a dream.
(Although you might get a slightly different opinion from the
friend I took for a ride on California Highway 49 recently... :-) )

Oddly enough, my ex-boyfriend couldn't understand why anyone would
buy a car based on any criteria other than low cost and inexpensive
maintenance. He's as arrogant in his viewpoint as some of the Porsche
owners on this mailing list are in theirs. 

Let's drop the snide remarks about people who don't buy Porsches as
well as the stupid arguments about Toyotas, Infinitis, etc. etc., okay?
Then we can get back to important discussions, like how I can get to
that seemingly inaccessible front side light whose bulb has burned out. :-)


Patty

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 11:49:24 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Euro-cars 'designed' to req maintainence

> Take the other extreme. GM now claims its engines will go 100,000 miles
> without major maintenance. At least that's what it claims in ads. But it
> won't back that claim with a warranty, as far as I know. And I would really
> like to see any engine go that far without something breaking -- water pump,
> alternator, and we're not even getting into the black magic like brain
> boxes.

That's a big problem with newer engines. The electronics are the single
thing most likely to require major service. Especially when a battery goes
low or something. As a counter-example to Pete's "would really like to see",
my '81 Toyota Corolla engine has now gone 207,000 miles with no such breakage.
The car is on its third transmission, but the engine goes up to 4000 miles
between oil changes and never needs to have any oil added. Runs like a top...
maybe I'm just lucky. Alternator? I'd hardly count that as part of the engine.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 12:22:00 EDT
From: "Evans, Randy: GTIS" <REvans@ott1.gta.doc.ca>
Subject: 944 Tire Pressures


The owners manual for my 1985/2 944 specifies tire pressures at 29 psi for 
the front and 36 psi for the rear. My wheels are the stock 15 x 7 cookie 
cutters with tires sized 215/60VR15 as recommended in the owners manual.

I find it unusual that there is such a great difference between the front 
and rear tire pressures - especially in a car with a near 50/50 weight 
distribution.

I have a few guesses at the reason for this:

1. To encourage understeer.

2. To minimize the front camber change which was a problem in the early 944.

3. To soften the ride at the front end.

4. To minimize wheel hop at the read end under accelleration.

The tire chalking that I did at one autocross last year seemed to indicate 
that the front tire pressure should be higher than 29 psi. Setting the 
pressures to 32 psi all around seemed to improve the handling by reducing 
the understeer.

Why should the front tire pressure be 7 pounds lower than the rear tire 
pressure?

Randy Evans
1985/2 944
Ottawa, Canada

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 08:56 PST 
From: stephenk@lauto.lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Stuck odometer

Rich

My 914 has the same kind of problem: speedometer works, but the
odometer & trip odometer don't turn.  I can manually roll the odometer
by cycling the trip odometer, but other than that nothing.  I've been
assuming that the problem is internal to the speedometer unit and not
the result of a damaged cable or drive gear.  I suspect this could be
coincidence.  If you hear about an external cause of odometer failure,
would you pass it along please?

In VDO speedos from Audis, a broken odometer drive gear is pretty
common.  The drive gear in these units is a dime-sized nylon affair
that tends to crack.  The odometer apparently will operate for a long
time with a crack drive gear but eventually it gives up and stops
working.  Does anyone know if Porsche VDO speedos use a similar nylon
gear?

I've often wondered if a machinist (maybe a model maker) could
fabricate an aluminum replacement gear, but never pursued it.  With
the Audi, we always opted to scrounge up a used speedo with the good
odometer; broken Audis are plentiful (thus not too dear) around the
salvage yards here.  Precision machine work on the other hand is
expensive.

Any thoughts, experience?

stph
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------
Stephen Keller            (503) 531-2246             stephenk@lmc.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 11:08:30 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; cracked 928 dash

>Like many others, I have cracks in my 928 dash.  Are these worth it?
>Are they as easy to install as claimed?  How do they look?  How
>detectable are they once they're on?  

     I tried installing the hard-plastic dash cover on a 924 years ago,
   and did not like the way it fit at all. I've talked to someone else who 
   used one on a non-P car and liked it. I've been happiest with the
   fabric-type of dash cover--the fit is flexible, and IMHO I think the 
   non-OEM look is fine. Its also possible to fit it over a warped leather
   dash.
    The vinyl dashes on Porsches wear poorly, the leather ones just horrible.
   I realize that temps on the dash are probably over 130'f in the summers
   but it seems the Germans can't equal US cars when it comes to rubbers.

     Has anybody had experience with these guys (like "Just Dashes") who 
   rebuild dashes ? For a Porsche dash, I mean... 


------------------------------

Date: 31 May 1994 09:35:41 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@engtwomac.SynOptics.COM>
Subject: 911 Oil level gauge

        Reply to:   911 Oil level gauge
> Sometimes revving high, I do have my oil level go down into the
> red, even though at idle or when very warm it's over the halfway 
> mark in the white.
> Ted

In a last year Panorama one factory rep was quoted as saying the
oil level gauge was to be used strictly "as a source of amusement"
(ie, pay no attention to it).  Here's better practical advice: Ignore
it almost all the time, except when the engine is fully warmed up
and the car is idling on level ground.  And even then only use it as
a rough approximation, once you've gotten used to how it matches
up with a real dip stick reading.  The accuracy of this gauge has
varied wildly among the Carreras I've owned.

Lance Keigwin (lkeigwin@synoptics.com)
88 factory turbo-look targa, 89 coupe, 85 535i

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 08:59:17 -31702 (PDT)
From: Wayne Joerding - Economics <joerd@wsuaix.csc.wsu.edu>
Subject: Thanks Stan

Thanks Stan for rescuing the list from the flame wars.

However, I'll miss the discussion of girlfriends/wives/partners and other 
tidbits from the gossip side of life.  I enjoyed hearing about the 
vindictive wife and the 2000GT, etc.

Now I suppose I won't get to tell about letting my daughter drive the 911 
for the first time without DAD!! Of course, I followed behind in the 
family truckster as we transported about 2 million teenagers from the river 
for Memorial day.  As long as I was in the rear view mirror everything 
was fine, but I had forgotten about the twisty road coming up from the 
Snake river breaks.  As soon as the curves intervened, BOOM my 911 SC was 
a memory, last seen moving fast and getting smaller.

Well, the family truckster finally found the 911 at home, safe and sound. 
And my daugher even had an explanation.  I had told her that her friends 
better not even sneze in my car, so naturally, when one wanted to sneeze 
she had to hurry home and drop him off, so she wouldn't get into 
trouble.  

That could happen, right.  ;)

So, for all of you worrying about girl/boy friends, wives/husbands, let 
me warn you that the next step in this dance is worry about daughters/sons.

Merry driving

Wayne Joerding
911 SC (unsneezed in)

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 13:04:25 +0600
From: Eisuke.Muroga@att.com
Subject: Re:924S vs 944


I remember reading in a Road and Track article that the 924S is actually
faster than the 944, having the same engine but in a lighter chassis with
a smaller frontal area. But it doesn't match up in handling, which the
wider track 944 excels at. I've never driven a 924S so I can't add anything
from experience.


Eisuke Muroga

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 19:56:57 CET		Message-Id: <AA01681>
From: tidbits@aviano.af.mil
Subject: Re:  Stuck odometer

Rich, this may be a dumb question... but every odometer I've ever
seen (and I've not seen _yours_) is driven off the same cable which 
drives the speedometer. Since you say the speedometer runs OK, I'd
not suspect the cable or driver. You may have just had a fortuitious
breakdown which happened at the same time as your "incident" on I-880.
Another possibility: the thing which hit your undercarriage may have 
whacked the cable, and the shock traveled up the cable and dislodged a
gear or follower inside the speedometer housing; then the cable returned
to its' original postion and speedo works fine. Long shot, but there have
been longer ones.

I honestly have no idea how to repair an odometer. If this happened to
my '83 944 (currently in storage), I'd find a replacement speedo/odometer
from a used parts supplier.


Best

Pete Jones
tidbits@aviano.af.mil
'86 928S
'83 944

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 11:47:40 -0600
From: Drew A. Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: C2 ride height 



Begin forwarded message:

> [snip]
> if I could without doing a spring replacement. Can this be done 

> ? Thanks.
> bill
> 


My RS America with the M030 package has struts with threaded
perches to allow some adjustment of ride height.  For my 

purposes, this has turned out to be insuffucient, so I bought
some shorter springs.  By running the adjustment nuts on the
perches to their lowest stop all around, the front is higher
than the rear with the factory springs :-(.

Since I'm still awaiting shipment of the factory manual set I 

unfortunately don't have the information handy, but will post 

the info when I get them.

Drew

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 14:46:23 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: Late 2.7 Engine for sale

        I  recently replaced the 2.7 in my 1977 911S with a 3.2.  I now
need to get rid of the 2.7 as it is taking up a lot of space.  
        The engine was built at the end of the production cycle and has all
the factory mods made to the 2.7 engine (e.g., it came with divlar studs
and improved air baffles).  It has 150K miles but was not giving me any
problems.  The temps were always good (it came with a trombone cooler) and
even with the a/c on during FL summers, I never saw the oil temp above
220F.  The last time I checked, the compression was at the low end of
acceptable and the between cylinder values were good.  The engine has the
fuel injection, complete exhaust system, a/c compressor, sheet metal, and
everything else that had to be taken out to put the new engine in.  
        I can put in touch with the person who takes care of the high-end
maintenance for me and who could answer any other questions you may had. 
Please contact me directly (wise@db.erau.edu) for more info or to make an
offer.  

Thanks!

Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University            E-mail: wise@db.erau.edu

>Then I started using Foriegn Service in Tyson's.  They seem to be OK, and just

>cassette-holder cover during the last service.  They did repaint the roof and

to
>replace any screws while working under the hood!  They claimed, "100% sure" to

Call Intersport in Vienna, VA, (703) 242-8680.  A lot of the PCA Potomac Region

his customer left with him and followed him to Intersport.  Give Ivan a call.
