Date: Tue, 31 May 94 12:56:14 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Stuck odometer

| From: Richard Hsiang Lu  <richlu@uclink.berkeley.edu>
|
| Hiya!
|   Can anyone please advise me on how to fix an odometer that fails to roll?
|
| The problem:  Both the upper and trip odometers remain stationary while the
| 	      car ('83 944) is being driven.  All other instruments & gauges
| 	      (esp. the speedometer) appear unaffected.

[story about meeting with hubcap deleted]

The odometers are driven by the same cable as the speedometer.  If the
speedometer is working, then their is nothing wrong outside of the speedometer
case.  I would not recommend opening the speedometer case unless you
have watchmaking experience.  It is full of tiny springs and gears.  (Later
speedometers are full of microchips; they have evolved in the same way
as watches!)  I am not sure if I would trust the local speedometer shop
with my Porsche, but the dealer would probably want to just replace it
rather than repair it ($$$).  I'd make some phone calls to speedometer
shops and Porsche mechanics to see what information I could gather.

    Eric, '84 - 944 Ruby Red

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 12:46:15 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: 944 sunroof

| From:  <LouKrieg@aol.com>
|
| On my '87 944 Turbo, to retract the forks, the ignition switch must be in the
| "No. 1" position (one click clockwise from off). If the ignition switch is in
| the "No. 2" position (normal running on) then the switch acts as usual
| raising and lowering the sunroof.

Lou, and schless and the original poster, whose name I have misplaced,

The sunroof opening procedure obviouly varies by model year.  I suspect
it is directly related to the interior upgrade that occurred at the 
85-1/2 model
year change.

On my '84, the manual explicitly states that the ignition must be off.  
The ignition
switch has only three positions: (going clockwise) off, on, and start; 
there is no
"auxilary" position.

At any rate, I hope that the original poster has had some luck in removing his
sunroof!

    Eric

Date: Tue, 31 May 94 13:10:01 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Dash caps

> 
> The May issue of Excellence has an ad from Tweeks for Dash Caps at 20%
> off ($103 for 928).
> 
> Like many others, I have cracks in my 928 dash.  Are these worth it?
> Are they as easy to install as claimed?  How do they look?  How
> detectable are they once they're on?  
> 
> I'd like something to look seamless and original, and if these look like
> someone just slapped a cap on a ratty dash then I'll pass.  
> 

My 1969 911T has a dash cap on it, but this is for a normal errand running car.

I'll never be entering it in a car show.

The dash cap doesn't look original, but it isn't bad from a distance (>4 feet).

Advantages are
   1. Low price
   2. Easy installation, since the 911 requires removal of the windshield
      to install a new dash.
   3. Probably more resistant to cracking than the OEM dash
   4. Better visually than a typical cracked 911 dash.
   5. Better visually than the cloth type dash protectors

Disadvantages are
   1. Not a perfect fit, it bulges somewhat in spots
   2. Not perfect match for texture, sheen.

BTW, after a repaint, I bought a new OEM dash for the 1972 911T.

Incidentally, J.C. Whitney also sells the Dash Caps or similar.
Probably lower price than Tweeks.

John Wright

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 14:53:01 -0700 (PDT)
From: LAFORCE@XENON.ARC.NASA.GOV
Subject: SC wheel bearing R&R

From:	SMTP%"porschephiles-request@tta.com" 31-MAY-1994 14:24:17.57
To:	LAFORCE
CC:	
Subj:	911 Front wheel bearings.

Date: Tue, 31 May 1994 11:48:26 +0500
From: Barry Chapin 617-258-2809 <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Message-Id: <9405311548.AA00610@support7.draper.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: 911 Front wheel bearings.
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Content-Length: 507

Barry writes:

I need to replace the front wheel bearings in my 1981 911SC.  Is this
difficult to do by myself?  I am reasonably mecahnically adept, and
have a decent set of tools, but have never done a wheel bearing (front
only) replacement.

******************************************************


I did two sets recently (puh-leeese, two different cars...) on 'SC's

Jack and correctly support the front wheel(s).

Remove the front hub.  Note: other stuff may have to be removed too.

The outer bearing just falls off.

The inner bearing is pressed into the hub.

I removed it by pounding it (carefully - BLAM - BLAM - BLAM!!!  ;-) 
out with a punch.  If you have a press and the correct sized cylindrical
tool, that would work better.

As they like to say, installation is the reverse of removal (tap, tap, 
tap, BLAM!!!, tap, tap, tap...  ;-)

Be careful putting the new bearings in.  Often a large socket will do 
as a "press."  I would not pound on the inner race, only the outer one.

When I pound on something like a socket, I use a copper mallet, not 
a hammer.

I used moly wheel bearing grease.

If you waste the hub, Parts Heaven in Hayward, CA has used hubs for 
$25 (don't ask; it wasn't from the wheel bearing R&R).

I think it took about 1-1.5 hours for the first wheel and about half
that for the rest.

Don't let the caliper dangle from its hose.  (I think that is relevent
advise, but can't remember for sure)


- --Soren


------------------------------
